column2: ST. LOUIS, March 11.--St. Clair Division No. 49 of the Brotherhood of Engineers, who represent all the railroads centring in East St. Louis, held an important meeting to-day. There were 200 members present, and it was decided that after 6 o'clock this evening no member should haul a Chicago, Burlington and Quincy car, or any consignment of "Q" freight on any of the connecting roads.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 11.--The westbound Erie train No. 5, which usually passes Elmira at 1:01 A.M., and Wellsville at 3:31, was a little late this morning. It does not stop at Scio, and was running by there very rapidly on a down grade.

Two of the Queen's large carriages (a landau and a wagonette) were dispatched from Windsor last week, by Folkestone and Boulogne, on their way to Florence. They were directed: "Sa Majeste la Reine de la Grande Bretagne, Villa Palmieri, Florence, Italia." A bedstead for her Majesty's use, with its furniture, and a quantity of plate, linen, and china, are to be sent off to Florence next week.

Shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning Policeman Perkins of the Nineteenth Precinot went into the New Argyle, a drinking saloon at 600 Sixth-avenue, and arrested Raphael Verona, the bartender, for violation of the excise law.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--The historic precincts of Independence-square were yesterday morning the scene of a fistic combat. The principals in the engagement are both lawyers of wide local reputation. F.F. Brightly is a son of the late F.S. Brightly, the famous legal author, and a son-in-law of ex-District Attorney William B. Mann, one of the most distinguished lawyers at the Philadelphia Bar and a war horse ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 11.--The police of this city yesterday arrested a woman named Nina Mertain, an inmate of a disorderly house, on information received from Gloversville stating that she was wanted in that place for abducting a 15-year-old girl named Maggie Simmons.

The various projects for a service pension which have been discussed during the last dozen years seem now to have been eclipsed by the bill before the Senate giving such a pension "at the rate per month of 1 cent per day for each day's service."

Thomas Mccartney, a contractor, living at 194 Wyckoff-street, Brooklyn, was arrested on Saturday on a charge of perjury, and was held yesterday by Justice O'Reilly.
The twenty-second annual Commencement of the New-York College of Dentistry was held Saturday evening at Chickering Hall. Seventytwo young men from this city, neighboring States, ...
Joseph Nimmo, Jr., spoke last night in the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby's church, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street, on the subject, "Shall We Admit a Mormon State?"

John Riley, a drunken laborer living at 456 West Fifty-sixth-street, stood at Fifty-sixthstreet and Tenth-avenue last evening and amused himself by insulting the passers-by. Patrolman Charles Paulding of the Twenty-second Precinct remonstrated, and for his interference ...
At the regular morning service of Plymouth Church the Rev. Dr. Abbott spoke a few words in reference to the memorial anniversary, and referred to Mr. Beecher, his life, and his love for his church.

The Rev. Wilbur F. Crafts of the Eightysixth-Street Presbyterian Church at Lexingtonavenue preached a vigorous sermon last evening on the subject, "Shall Trusts and Labor Troubles be Settled by Lawlessness or by Law and Gospel?" In the course of his remarks he said:

The Jewish Theological Seminary Association, which was organized two years ago, held its first biennial convention in the Cooper Union, yesterday afternoon. The association is composed of representatives from congregations in various cities of America and was formed to establish a seminary for the training of ministers to teach according to the ancient forms and traditions of Judaism.

CHICAGO, March 11.--If the managers of the Western railroads adopt the agreement recommended to them by the conference committee they will take pretty effectual means to provide for the payment of fines and penalties.
In All Souls' Church, Forty-eighth-street, near Sixth-avenue, yesterday, Pundita Ramabai addressed a large audience concerning her work on behalf of the child widows of India.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 11.--The following private letter from a prominent citizen of Indiana, who is known all over the country as a true-blue Republican and honorable gentleman, was received here to-day:

"The Age of Swindle" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Talmage's sermon in the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday morning. His text was Job viii., 14, "Whose trust shall be a spider's web."

BOSTON, Mass., March 11.--The Boston Stock Exchange voted yesterday to accept the recommendation of the Governing Committee imposing a fine of $1,000 for the first offense on any member operating in bucket shops. The second offense will be punished by expulsion.

Representatives of the two discordant Irish sociaties of Kings County were in convention yesterday at Myrtle Hall, 181 Myrtle-avenue, and at Hibernian Hall, 328 Gold-street, ...

CHICAGO, March 11.--The Rev. A.J. Bartels has been Pastor of the New Jerusalem Swedenborgian Church for two years, but today he saw in the morning papers a notice that the church committee had suspended him.
The highest point of land in Connecticut is in its extreme northwest corner, in Salisbury, and that is 2,200 feet above sea level, or 400 feet less than half a mile.
The will of William Bittinger, who died last Saturday at Abbottstown, was probated in Gettysburg yesterday. It disposes of $225,000.

A lecture upon "The Poetry of George Eliot" was delivered by Archie Emerson Palmer in the Second Unitarian Church, Clinton and Congress streets, Brooklyn, last night before the Association for Moral and Spiritual Education.
Local mariners are interested in the announcement that came to the Merchants' Exchange a few days ago that William E. Church of Taunton, Mass., has ordered the construction at Rogers's ship yard.

ST. LOUIS, March 11.--The 10 Douglass County (Mo.) Bald Knobbers, who were convicted last September in the United States Circuit Court at Jefferson City of whipping and driving two homesteaders from Government land have been sentenced by Judge Krekel to from two to six months in the penitentiary with costs. Three others who attempted to intimidate Government witnesses were each given 60 days in jail.

ALBANY, March 11.--The proposed asylum buildings for insane criminals, for which the Legislature appropriated $185,000 last week, are to be located about one and one-quarter miles east of the villages of Matteawan and Fishkill, Dutchess County.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 11.--The conventions now being held in Ohio for the election of delegates to the Chicago Convention are attracting no little attention, and in some instances a vigorous fight has been made to elect anti-Sherman men.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 11.--There is a serious breach here among the colored Knights of Pythias. Recently the Grand Lodge, which has its headquarters in Boston, ordered that the members of Palm Leaf Lodge in this city pay an additional per capita tax of 75 cents for every death.
Said Mr. Tom Ambrose, an old sleeping car conductor: "There is no reason why women should not be employed as conductors on sleeping cars.

Manager Frohman of the Lyceum Theatre, with a desire to accommodate Manager Hill in his forthcoming production of "A Possible Case," has loaned him Henry Miller for a few weeks to create the leading character in that comedy. Mr. Miller's part in "The Wife" will be played by Mr. Frohman's other juvenile man, Mr. Faversham, an able and promising young actor, who will now be enabled to make ...

The Rev. Dr. R.R. Meredith of the Tompkins-Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, preached to a large congregation yesterday with especial reference to the building of a new house of worship, which the growth of the church seemed to demand. In the course of his sermon he said:
The Vatican has received an addition to its objects of art in the shape of a huge basrelief, representing Prince Bismarck receiving, ...

BERLIN, March 11.--Further particulars of the last hours of Kaiser Wilhelm's life have come to light. At 5 P.M., Thursday, Court Chaplain Koegel was summoned to his bedside, and as at short intervals throughout the evening he addressed the Emperor with verses from the Psalms and other parts of the Bible, the Kaiser several ...
SALT LAKE, Utah, March 11.--The Utah Legislature adjourned at 12:30 this morning. Appropriations were made by it largely in excess of any former session.
EAST LIVERPOOL, March 11.--A farmer coming to town to-day reports a terrible case of sickness, destitution, and death near Calcutta Township, a hamlet three miles from this place.

CHICAGO, March 11.--A week without important lawsuits, a week without publiclyaired private grievances, a week without a startling feature, such is the Chicago theatrical record for the last seven days. It is like Spring weather on the heels of a blizzard, all the more remarkable for being unexpected. Mrs. Langtry, who occupied so much space in the newspapers because of her varied tribulations, hied ...

Monmouth Park's progressive, even though at the same time conservative managers never did a more sensible thing than when they decided to abandon their project, already given in THE TIMES, of building the proposed three-quarter-mile straightaway track for 2-year-olds.

LONDON, March 11.--The Stock Exchange and monetary circles generally approve Mr. Goschen's financial proposals. Large revenue payments restrict the available supply of money. The Bank of England's return, showing 12,500,000 public deposits, has caused short loans to rise nearly to the level of the bank minimum.
WASHINGTON, March 11.--Mr. Randall has completed his tariff bill, and will introduce it in the House to-morrow. In explanation of its terms and scope he makes the following statement:
ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, March 11.--A number of officers and Directors of the Diamond Match Company passed through this city yesterday en route to California.

At the regular-meeting of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club Saturday evening three new members were elected--J.J. Phelps, Thomas Barrow, and Alfred Hoyt. The classification adopted by the New-York Yacht Club in the previous meeting was discussed informally, and the date for the annual race fixed for June 23.

The old question of how the history of the Reformation shall be taught in public schools has been raised again in Brooklyn through a complaint of Father Kelly of St. Thomas Aquinas Church to the Board of Education.
The Church of the Holy Spirit had an anniversary celebration yesterday. At the morning service Bishop Potter confirmed a class of 25 and preached a sermon.
CHICAGO, March 11.--Railroad lawmaking is popular nowadays, and it seems to be a part of the duties of the Chairman of the Central Traffic Association to invoke legislation on various subjects.

CARLOTTENBURG, March 11--Midnight.-- The imperial train on its arrival here was threequarters of an hour late, having been delayed by a snowstorm. It arrived at this place at 11:15. The Crown Prince William and his wife and Prince Henry of Saxe-Meinengen entered the saloon, and each kissed the hand of the Emperor and embraced Empress Victoria.

The fair at Webster Hall in aid of the building fund of the Congregation Moses Monteflore and its religious school, which began last Monday and which will end with a ball this evening, has already netted a large sum of money to its projectors.
Dr. Willis W. French, a popular young physician, died at his residence, 173 West Eighty-third-street, yesterday of plero-pneumonia, after an illness of one week.

French's Hotel has been purchased by Joseph Pulitzer for $630,000. The site occupies the entire block in Park-row between Frankfortstreet and the bridge entrance with the exception of Mr. Kosmak's small building.

There is a conflict of authority between Coroner Eidman and Police Justice Wolde as to their jurisdiction in the homicide case of Arno Oebel, who shot and killed Rosa Schneider at her mother's home, 1,122 First-avenue, Saturday night, because she would not marry him. Several such disputes between Coroners and Police Justices have arisen within a year, but ...

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 11.--For some weeks rather sensational and alarming reports have been received here from the West to the effect that the Indians were very restless, owing to the neglect of the Government in furnishing supplies, and that there was serious danger of an uprising unless food was at once forwarded to the half-starved Indians.
The moving of theatrical scenery and appurtenances has come to be about as fine an art as the work of the actors themselves.
Sixty-one arrests for violation of the excise law were made by the police in this city yesterday.
Lewis Jones, colored, was committed for court yesterday, charged with stealing a silver watch, gold chain, and coat from Capt. William McDaniels of the schooner J.T. White, on Feb. 15.

To the general American public, special students of pure military art excepted, Mr. Kinglake's fifth book is a wonderfully tiresome one, and there is still a sixth volume. After the long European peace, a period extending over 39 years, the Antwerp business being excluded, as there had been no war of great consequence, the Crimean conflict was a rude awakening.
There was a smash-up on the New-Jersey Central Railroad about 9:30 yesterday morning at Bergen Point, near the Newark Bay shore.

Jasper C. Coombs, the janitor of the five-story flat at 257 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventhstreet, went on the roof yesterday afternoon. He stepped upon a board, his foot slipped and he was precipitated headlong to the yard below and instantly killed. He leaves a wife and five children.
Superintendent George E. Babcock had his men out early yesterday morning, and Seventh-avenue was sprinkled from the Park to Barry's in anticipation of a big rush of vehicles in the afternoon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 11.--Anna Katharine Green, the author of "The Leavenworth Case," has been a resident of Buffalo for several months. Like all American writers, she wants to see enacted an international copyright law. She wants it as a matter of right and justice, aswell as for self protection.
The rainstorm which made the streets of New-York flowing rivers yesterday was a much worse and more complicated disturbance of nature further west and south.
DES MOINES, Iowa., March 11.--The Republican State Committee have agreed upon J. S. Dolliver of Fort Dodge as temporary Chairman of the convention which will meet here March 21.
There was a fire yesterday afternoon in the one-story frame stable 216 and 218 West Forty-ninth-street, occupied by Richard Yarwood as a sales stable.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11.--Never before in the history of the Republican Party has so little interest been shown in the election of delegates to the National Convention as now. The primaries to choose the delegates to the State Convention, who will meet by Congressional districts and choose the delegates each to Chicago, will be held on Tuesday evening, and promises to be utterly tame.

In the issue of THE TIMES of Tuesday last expression was given to the deductions from the investigation of the Senate Committee on General Laws, from what has otherwise become established in relation to the Sugar Trust, and from careful examination of the sugar schedule embodied in the Mills tariff bill now pending before Congress.
The New-York papers urge the authorities to "dump the garbage into the sea." In Chicago they simply consign it to the crematory, and it does not return again to worry the guests at Summer resorts.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 10.--The Printing Cloth market was quiet and firm at 3 5/8c. for 64 squares, and 3 5.16c. @ 3 c. bid and asked for spots and near deliveries of each. Production for the week, 170,000 pieces; sales, 68,000 pieces; deliveries, 170,000 pieces, and stock, 1,000 pieces.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 11.--A few days ago a State paper brought out the name of Gen. W.D. Washburn for the Presidency.
COFFEEVILLE, Miss., March 11.--A row occurred the other night on an Illinois Central train because the conductor refused to pass Roderick Lowry, a nephew of Gov. Lowry, on the Governor's family pass.

The congregation of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Jersey City, which had worshipped in Excelsior Hall, 630 Communipaw-avenue, was forced to seek other quarters yesterday.
The funeral services of William F. Lee, who died of pneumonia at his home, 679 Madison-avenue, Saturday, were performed yesterday ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 11.--The steamboat Phil E. Chappel, belonging to the Red River and Coast Line, left here with a full cargo of general merchandise last evening for Garland City.

The Central Labor Union yesterday elected the following officers: Recording Secretary--Isaac Wood; Corresponding Secretary-- Ernest Boehm; Financial Secretary--George McVey; Treasurer--William A. Hotchkiss; ...
United Council, No. 1,035, American Legion of Honor, gave its third anniversary supper and sociable in Nilsson Hall on Saturday evening.

Prof. Felix Adler, before the members of the Society for Ethical Culture, in Chickering Hall yesterday, spoke on inter-marriage between persons of different religious beliefs. "The question touches on two sentiments most powerful in the human heart," he began, "love and faith.
LONDON, March 11.--A fierce southwest gale is blowing, and numerous casualties are feared in the St. George's and English Channels.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March. 11.--The proposed action of the Clerks' Association in bringing action against retail merchants who keep open on Sunday has caused considerable ex citement and uneasiness among the merchants who have kept their places of business open for a portion of the first day of the week.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 11.--Dr. Walter E. Judson, a prominent physician of this city, and Emerson F. Judson and Frank L. Judson, together with other relatives, have brought suit against their father, Russell Judson of Plainville, who is 80 years of age.

Wall-street commented a good deal on the story told in THE TIMES Saturday of the mismanagement of the Columbus, Hooking Valley and Toledo Railroad Company's finances. President John Shaw is a man in whom Wallstreet has confidence. His word goes. And his arraignment of the Burke combine elicits earnest words of approval.

The sugar rates of the Mills tariff bill may be described briefly as follows: On all sugars not above No. 13 of the Dutch color standard the duties are about 20 per cent. lower than those of the present law. ALBANY, March 11.--No bill introduced in either house after next Thursday can have its final reading, except by unanimous consent, until after every measure introduced prior to the 15th of March has been disposed of. This rule of Senate and Assembly will doubtless hasten the introduction of all sorts of bills, good, bad, and indifferent, during the coming week.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 11.--The first case on record in this State where it has been found necessary to enforce the compulsory education law is reported from Stearns County, where John Langner, a farmer living in School District No. 116, ...

Judge Foster of this State has ruled that an alien who has never read nor heard read the Constitution of the United States is not eligible to naturalization. We are glad Judge Foster has established this precedent. For a man to take oath to support the Constitution, not knowing what the Constitution is, would be a burlesque.

While in her apartments at 103 South Second-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last night, Mrs. Richard A. Simpson was burned to death by a kerosene lamp falling from the mantelpiece and setting her clothing on fire. The oil from the lamp spread all over her dress, and before she could obtain assistance she was fatally-burned.
The report that was published last week that the dye works of Barrett Nephews Co., at West New-Brighton, Staten Island, had been closed, was unfounded. The works are in full operation.

An important joint meeting of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen was held yester day in Tammany Hall. The session lasted from 10 A.M. until 5:30 P.M., and was secret. The Press Committee subsequently told the reporters that between 1,800 and 2,000 members attended during the day, representing at least 20,000 engineers and firemen, in sympathy with ...

After prolonged labor the revenue bill prepared for Mr. RANDALL has at last been brought to light. It is, of course, only such a bill as any individual member of the House might present "by request," and in the ordinary course of procedure it is entitled to and would receive no different treatment from that accorded to any other of the thousands of bills introduced in the ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 11.--A woman who gave no name published in to-day's Courier-Journal an offer of $5,000 reward to a Catholic priest of Louisville with whom a package was left in 1868, and whose name had been forgotten. She paid for six insertions, and left the city last night. The address given with the offer is "E.L., care Mercantile National Bank, New-York." All priests ac cessible say they know nothing of such a package.

Lincoln, inquiring whether or not he would be a candidate for the Presidency and assuring him of the hearty support of the colored people of North Missouri:

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 12.--A collision between the second section of passenger train No. 9, west-bound, and an east-bound freight train occurred near Huntingdon, Penn., on the Pennsylvania Railroad, about 3 o'clock this morning.

In April, 1881, Miss Luse, an American girl, the daughter of one of the present American Consuls in Italy, married Capt. Alexander McMahon of ...

A man was found lying on the tracks of the New-York Central Railroad at Fourth-avenue and Fifty-first-street yesterday morning at 2 o'clock, and Ambulance Surgeon C.A. Smith of Bellevue Hospital discovered that his right hand was crushed and that he was in liquor.

Two alarms were struck at 11:30 o' clock last night for a fire which broke out in the cellar of 428 Sixth-avenue, occupied with the store by Young Brothers, tailors. Several apparatus due at the fire were delayed or stopped by the snow ...

PARIS, March 12.--The second ballot in the Department of Bouches du Rhone to fill a vacancy in the Chamber of Deputies resulted in the election of M. Felix Pyat, Socialist. In the Departments of Cote d'Or and Haute Marne Radical candidates were elected.
Several additional contributions to the fund now being raised for the benefit of Annie Knieriem, the Dakota blizzard heroine, were received yesterday by Gen C.T. Christensen, as follows:

Surrogate Ransom will begin the trial of the Stewart will case this morning. When the case was called yesterday morning the Surrogate was present, and so were ex-AttorneyGeneral Leslie W. Russell and Treadwell Cleveland of Evarts, Choate Beaman. Mr. Russell proposed postponemont, but ...

LONDON, March 12.--The navy estimates were discussed in Committee of the Whole in the House of Commons today. Lord Charles Beresford, lately a Junior Lord of the Admiralty, submitted a motion declaring that an entire reform was needed in the management of the naval service. He said that when he joined the Board of Admiralty he told his colleagues that he intended to say his say to them as well as anybody else.

The storm yesterday set Brooklyn back 50 years. Its great surface railroad system became useless, and its telephone service practically valueless. Its telegraph wires were torn down, and its main thoroughfares, where only electric lights are used, were left in darkness. It will cost the business firms, including the street car companies, about $1,000,000.

A report reached Brooklyn Police Headquarters at a late hour last night to the effect that the Brighton Beach Hotel had been blown down and entirely destroyed, and that the ruins had been carried out to sea.

Under the gaslight in New-York last night was cheerful indoors only. Those who were abroad, beating against the biting wind, slipping about on icy places, or floundering in snow drifts, must have been impressed by the fact that the systems of electric lights operated in the metropolis are not storm-proof.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, March 12. --A duel, ending in the death of the combatants, occurred at Springerville, Arizona, last evening. William Pitman and a man named Blaine had agreed to fight out a quarrel over cards, and going outside Sperling Brothers Taylor's store they fired at the same instant. Pitman fell dead and Blaine died in two hours.
The Senate Tax Committee engaged in investigating the charges against the Society of the New-York Hospital succumed to the storm.

The Bellevue Hospital Medical College has its twenty-seventh annual Commencement yesterday in spite of the storm. The exercises took place at 6 0'clock in the afternoon at the Carnegie Laboratory, East Twenty-sixth-street, ...

The handy way in which women managed their clothes and fought their way through snow banks was remarked often by male pedestrians. Thousands of shop girls went to their work as usual, and many walked immense distances. Tied up in veils and mufflers, they .....

GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 12.--The sohooner Brunhilda, which arrived here yesterday from Grand Banks, reports the loss of Daniel McKinnon and Alonzo McMasters, two of the crew, by the capsizing of a dory while attending trawis. McMasters belonged in Guysborough, N.Y., and McKinnon in Prince Edward's Island. Both were unmarried.

The United States Signal Service officer in the Equitable Building observatory was almost forced to vacate his desk in consequence of a leaky roof. Water dripped from the ceiling into receptacles and trickled down the walls, forming pools on the floor. The weather man, when not making observations or talking to visitors, occupied the time sopping up the water ...

Most of the theatre managers succumbed to the storm. Only three of the theatres on Broadway were open last night. Those enterprising and irresistible showmen, Barnum Bailey, had advertised that they would begin their Madison-Square Garden season with two performances regardless of conditions. In the very teeth of the gale the matinee was given, and last evening the second performance ...

BERLIN, March 12.--There is a gloomy kind of fitness in the idea that the dead Hohenzollern should be carried to the church for the last rites and that the living Hohenzollern should arrive in his ancestral capital to assume royal control both in the midst of a blinding, whirling tempest.

The wheel of justice was stopped. Recorder Smyth found his way to the General Sessions building at 11 o' clock and waited patiently until noon, but at that hour only four of the Longobardi jury had been able to get to their chairs. The Recorder reluctantly adjourned court.
We had long known that alcoholic beverages were "liquid fire," but this is a decidedly new version of their origin: Teacher--What is a volcano? Boy--A mountain that throws out lager.

EL PASO, Texas, March 12.--Senor Lauro Carrillo, Acting Governor of the State of Chihuahua, Mexico, is here. Janos, the town where United States Marshal Meade of Arizona was arrested by Mexican authorities, is in the State of Chihuahua, and therefore within Gov. Carrillo's jurisdiction. Gov. Carrillo is fully informed ...

While enveloped in almost impenetrable clouds of snow and sleet, a heavily-loaded train on the Third-avenue elevated railroad crashed into another train equally crowded near the Seventy-sixth-street station, at 7:20 o'clock yesterday morning, killing one person, seriously wounding seven, and slightly injuring over a hundred others.

BANGOR, Me., March 12.--It is not probable that the Grand Jury will be recalled to find an indictment against Dr. Weed, who is charged with complicity in the theft of Peter Bennett's thousands, as the County Attorney prefers ...

Postmaster Pearson was at his desk on time yesterday morning and staid until the regular hour for closing. He made a vigorous effort to have the usual accumulation of mail left over from Sunday and the few mails that arrived yesterday delivered promptly.

RIO JANEIRO, March 12.--The new Brazilian Ministry is composed as follows: Premier and Minister of Finance--Senor Alfredo; Foreign Affairs--Senor Prado; Marine-- Senor Vierra; War--Senor Coelho--Almeida; Justice--Senor Vianna; Agriculture--Senor Silva; Interior--Senor Costa Pereira.

Capt. William W. McLaughlin of the First Precinet was proud yesterday. The howling of the storm did not affect him in the least, and could in no way detract from his feeling of gratification at having accomplished the capture of a professional burglar, well versed in the tactics of his profession.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 12.--Sheriff Sawyer found Josie Blann, the long-lost heiress to-day. Judge Hamilton pointed her out to him in court, where she had gone quietly under escort of one of Mrs. Ammon's friends.

The ferryboat Oswego of the West Shore Railroad broke one of her rudder chains last night and became unmanageable. She drifted into the dock at West Forty-sixth-street and came in collision with a canalboat and the pier. No serious injury was caused to her, and she was finally got into a slip and tied up.

A Sixty-second-street young man went home Sunday night late in a drenching storm of rain and snow. ATLANTA, Ga., March 13.--Yesterday a premature blast of dynamite, three miles from Bremen, buried four convicts beneath a huge pile of dirt, and when exhumed three were found to be dead. The fourth is not expected to recover. The dead men were Bob Alley, Jesse Brooks, and Ed Harmett.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., March 14.--This is the worst snowstorm ever known in this section. It began on Sunday. The wind began blowing hard Monday afternoon, drifting all country roads and making travel impossible. The streets in North Adams are filled with snow about four feet deep, while in the gutters it is piled up fully 12 feet.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 14.--The Cleveland Gesangverein has unanimously refused to sing at the meeting to be held Sunday in memory of the dead German Emperor. The feeling appears to be widespread among Germans here that it is un-American to do homage to royalty. The majority of them are Freethinkers and the meeting was proposed by German ministers, which intensifies the opposition.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15.--A meeting of the Reading Railroad strikers was held at Keystone Hall last night. The strike was declared off, and the men are now at liberty to seek positions on the railroad as individuals. The company has reiterated the statement that they will not take back any of the strikers.

The Sound boats which reached here yesterday morning brought numbers of passengers who had been snow-bound in New-England and unable to get anywhere by land. They reported the railroads generally throughout New-England as either wholly blackaded or running trains very irregularly, and business of all kinds nearly at a standstill.
Frederick Schilling, a butcher, 30 years old, was remanded, in the Yorkville Court today, on suspicion of having murdered his wife, Mary.

CHICAGO, March 15.--The Burlington had a surprise to-day in store for the Western railway managers, and an agreeable one it proved to be. General Manager Stone early in the morning notified Chairman J.W. Midgley of the Southwestern Statistical Bureau, that it would consent to and co-operate in the proposed restoration of rates on March 26.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 15.--The bay mare Julia, full sister to Maxey Cobb, stallion, record 2:13 , by Happy Medium, dam Lady Jenkins, has been purchased by A.J. Alexander of Woodburn Stock Farm for $5,000 of Edward Pyle, Humboldt, Neb.
John Galbraith, a bed-ridden and helpless Odd Fellow, known throughout the fraternity as "Uncle John," was fatally burned yesterday. He is 83 years old and has been paralyzed for the past five years.

The inspectors attached to the Bureau of Contagious Diseases had a rather unique experience during the storm. Yesterday was "ladies' day" at the Manhattan Athletic Club, and fully 500 guests graced the clubrooms at 524 Fifth-avenue.

ST. LOUIS, March 15.--The engineers on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad went out on a strike at 5 o'clock this evening. Dispatches from along the line show that the strike was simultaneous at all points. Nothing is yet known of the grievance, but it is believed to have been precipitated by the Burlington traffic controversy.

EASTON, Penn, March 15.--A horrible accident, in which three men lost their lives, occurred yesterday afternoon on the New-Jersey Division of the Lehigh Valley Railroad at Three Bridges, N.J. Four engines, drawing two wrecking cars containing 100 men, left here yesterday morning to open the road.

WASHINGTON, March 15.--Washington has had a remarkable storm experience. It was cut off up to Monday afternoon for nearly 24 hours from nearly every part of the country, so far as telegraphic communication is concerned, and it has had only limited connection by rail with neighboring cities.

The shopping district has recovered from the blizzard and is again well patronized. Yesterday the ladies turned out in force, as if to make up for lost time, and the great thoroughfares up town were thronged from early in the afternoon until the sun sank low.

The snow embargo was nearly raised yesterday as far as Jersey City and Hoboken were concerned. In Jersey City all the street car lines were open for traffic; trucks loaded with groceries and meats wended their ways to the sold-out stores, and cartmen were busy in removing the snow from the streets.

LONDON, March 15.--The steamship Rebilant (Ital.) for New-York, arr. at Messina yesterday. The ship Andromeda, (Gen.) Capt. Bernger, from Bremen for New-York, has been wrecked off Yarmouth. The crew were saved.

Sleighing parties to the circus are something of a novelty in this city, but they were indulged in last night and formed a pleasurable beginning to the entertainment Phineas T. Barnum has provided for this Spring. The phenix Phineas cannot be put down.

FORT ASSINIBOINE, Montana, March 15.--A general thaw and flooding is in progress here. The ice in the Missouri River has broken up. The bridges on the Manitoba Railroad along Milk River are expected to be swept away at any moment. The bridge at Teton is gone. The rivers are rising rapidly and great damage is expected.

ALBANY, March 15.--The Assembly listened with amazed interest to-day to an astonishing story told by Mr. Hadley of Franklin County. Mr. Hadley is not a sensationalist. He has been a member of the Legislature for two years, and in that time he has acquired a reputation for conservatism, strict integrity, and veracity that has never been questioned.

The backbone of the surface car blockade was fractured yesterday by a combination of sunshine and human energy and perseverance. C.P. Huntington stated yesterday that the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad's annual meeting appointed for yesterday in Richmond had to be postponed on account of the blizzard.

DIXON, Ill., March 15.--Samuel Whitmeyer killed George Albright, fatally shot Borbara Albright, and blew his own brains out here yesterday morning. Whitmeyer was a laborer on Albright's farm and fell in love with Barbara. He was ordered off the place some time ago and left, but returned for his clothes and without warning began shooting, with the result stated.

The Submarine Monitor Company of 10 West Twenty-third-street is in the hands of the Sheriff. C.D. Shepard, who advanced considerable money to the company, obtained a judgment against it for $9,127.

Samuel Decker, a sturdily-built young man of Newark, left Newark on Saturday with his brother in a buggy drawn by two horses, and drove to Midvale, five miles from Pompton Junction, to visit an uncle.

For the past seven months the officers of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company have been aware that the company was being swindled daily by bogus tickets. A meeting of the members of the Manhattan Club was held last evening, at which the subject of changing the quarters of the club from Fifth-avenue and Fifteenth-street to the Stewart mansion, at Fifth-avenue and Thirtyfourth-street, or some other suitable place, was considered.

Madison-Square Garden was yesterday engaged for another six-day go-as-you-please race. It will be under the management of "Billy" O'Brien, the well-known sporting man, who has decided to give the race at the solicitation of a number of well-known pedestrians.

Ludwig Barnay began his engagement at the Academy of Music last evening with a prospect of certain success to encourage him. There was a large audience, including many distinguished German citizens, and many more German citizens who, if not distinguished, were at least vociferous.

CHICAGO, March 15.--The members of the Board of Trade voted, by a majority of 61, an amendment to the commission rule allowing members to charge one-eighth of a cent and onesixteenth of a cent per bushel for grain in "special cases." The total vote was 897.

PARIS, March 15.--The Journal Officiel says that Gen. Boulanger came to Paris on Feb. 24, again on March 2, and again on March 10 without permission from the War Office. The last two times, it says, he was in disguise, wearing dark spectacles and affecting lameness.

LONDON, March 15.--In spite of all the expressed sympathy for Germany at the present time there is undeniable evidence that Russia intends to take pronounced action of some kind, and probably soon if the weather permits.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., March 15.--One of the most thrilling incidents of the blizzard is the experiences of the snow-bound passengers and trainmen at Lofty. Their sufferings were intense, and, driven by cold, hunger, and thirst, three of them made their escape Tuesday evening, and, after a long and perilous walk down the mountains reached a train and arrived at Pottsville.

Great disappointment was expressed at the inability of Dr. McCosh to leave home.

Yesterday was a busy day with the people of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Early in the day calls began to come in from all parts of the city for the removal of disabled horses.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 15.--From a private letter just received it is learned that Judge O. N. Denny, who received the appointment of Inspector-General of Customs for the Corean Government nearly three years ago, tendered his resignation, to take effect March 31.

Ferdinand Carolin and his wife, Bridget, both about 30 years old, have lived for the past four months in a back room at 47 Stanton-street, which they rented for $3 a week from Mrs. Louisa Kleiner. Carolin is a carpenter, but has been out of work for the last three months or so.

RATON, New-Mexico, March 15.--Deputy Sheriff G.W. Cook shot and killed Deputy United States Marshal Frank Catlin yesterday. The murder was the outgrowth of hard feeling that originated in a dispute over the election for Sheriff last Fall.

The steamship Ailsa, Capt. Evans, from Port Limon, where she left March 4, arrived at the Bar yesterday at 3:20 P.M. She reported exceedingly heavy weather, which began at about 8 o'clock on the afternoon of March 11.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 15.--A reduction of from 12 to 15 per cent. among some of its employes was made to-day by the New-Brunswick Hosiery Company.
HAVANA, March, 15.--A dispatch from Sagua states that the cane crop and several houses of the Santa Rita estate have been destroyed by fire.

The blizzard that raged throughout the United States on Monday struck this city yesterday. The air was intensely cold in the morning, and at 8 o'clock the thermometer stood at 1 below zero, a difference of 35 from the highest last Saturday.

DENVER, Col., March 15.--The Cattle Trust of this city has closed a contract with the French Government to supply the French Army with 150,000 head of beef cattle annually. The cattle will be all range stock. The price to be paid has not been made public. The shipments will be made to Chicago, where the cattle will be slaughtered.

BERLIN, March 15.--The official programme of Friday's funeral, published last night, would fill two columns of THE TIMES solid. LONDON, March 15.--There was a very large number of guests at the wedding of Prince Oscar of Sweden and Miss Munck at Bournemouth to-day. The weather was brilliant.

WASHINGTON, March 16.--The Ways and Means Committee held meetings yesterday and to-day to consider the Tariff bill. These meetings will be continued next week until Friday probably, when they will be brought to a close so far as the Tariff bill is concerned by a vote upon reporting it to the House.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., March 21.--The court here to-day refused every application that had bden made for liquor licenses in Huntingdon, and after May 1 this county will be completely dry. The decision is that of the two associate Justices, President Judge Furst having been in favor of granting three hotel licenses.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21.--The first conviction of a Board of Excise in the State of New-York on an indictment for granting a hotel license where there were no proper accommodations was secured to-day before Judge Barnard.

Judge Brown of the United States District Court yesterday rendered a decision in the cross libel suits brought by George Clough against the steamer Britannia for $45,000 by the Compagnie Francaise de la Navigation a Vapeur against the steamer Beaconsfield for $25,000, and by John L. Cotton against both vessels for $45,000.

Somebody committed wholesale forgery in order to establish a liquor saloon at 106 Second-place, Brooklyn. The building is owned by Mrs. Lucy McGuire. She rented it to James H. Reynolds last December, and in a month he had converted it into a liquor store.

Capt. E. Martinez, the Spanish aeronaut, is at the Hotel America, in Irving-place. He is 28 years old and stands 5 feet 4 inches. His chest development is remarkable and he looks like a typical athlete.

CHICAGO, March 21.--Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association some time ago notified his managers that he was about to resign and remove to New-York. In order to retain his services his salary, it is announced today, has been increased from $12,000 to $25,000 a year, and he has consented to remain.

The number of children that attend the afternoon performances of Barnum's Circus must be a delightful sight to the great purveyor of instructive and startling amusement as he walks around the ellipse before the kaleidoscope of wonderful acts begins to revolve.

ALBANY, March 21.--The Republican Senators all save three or four who would not climb the Hill on account of the prevailing snowstorm held a conference in the Senate library this evening, which continued for nearly two hours. The Platt and the anti-Platt men exchanged the most cordial views regarding ...
NYACK, March 21.--A fashionable Jewish wedding took place in the Nyack Opera House last evening and was witnessed by a large company of invited guests.

The funeral of Daniel Sweeny took place yesterday at St. Peter's Church, Barclay and Church streets. Mr. Sweeny had been connected with the church for over half a century and was known to almost every member of the congregation.

The suit of Frank Engeman, a Swedish sailor, to recover $10,000 damages from Dr. David S. Skinner, a Brooklyn dentist, for injuries received in pulling the plaintiff's tooth, was placed on trial in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, before Judge Cullen.

ST. JOHNS, Newfoundland, March 21.-- Fifteen thousand seals are reported taken on Partridge Island. Men and women are taking them. Father Sheehan has captured 40. It is estimated that Green Bay is good for 60,000. Nothing has been heard from the sealing steamers. An Anti-Confederate League is forming.

WASHINGTON, March 21.--The majority of the Ways and Means Committee are now devoting their attention to the report with which they will accompany the submission of the Tariff bill to the House. The bill will be very carefully gone over before it is reported and examined for any errors that may have been overlooked, but ...
ALBANY, N.Y., Marah 21.--The following is the day calendar of the Court of Appeals for Thursday, March 22: Nos. 736, 731, 683, 775, 663, 664, 770, 728.

As the Bremen steamer Aller sailed up the Bay Sunday morning United States Deputy Marshal Bernnard boarded her with the customs officer. He manifested particular interest in pretty Rosalia Toms, but his interest in her was purely professional.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21.--George Dunham of Gloucester County, N.J., murderer of his mother-in-law, Barbara Kandle, to-day admitted his guilt and has in preparation a long statement of the circumstances that led up to the crime.

The sale of trotting stock by Peter C. Kellogg Co. was continued yesterday at the American Institute Building. The attendance was very much larger than on the day before, and the interest in sales seemed to be much keener, due to the fact that the lots on sale contained very few animals below standard grade.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 21.--Late last evening Mr. John W. McKinney, manager of Clara Morris, entered suit against Dr. Harriott and Miss Morris for $500 and an accounting of 5 per cent. on the receipts for the season.
CHICAGO, March 21.--Miss Thompson, daughter of Col. W.H. Thompson, a wealthy westside resident, made an innovation to-day in the general Chicago practice of changing names by decree of court.

Steamship Alvo (Br.,) Williams, Savanilla 16 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Pim, Forwood Co. Steamship State of Nevada, (Br.,) Stewart, Glasgow 12 ds., via Larne, with mdse. and passengers to Austin Baldwin Co.
OPORTO, March 21.--While a performance was in progress at the Banquet Theatre last night an explosion of gas occurred, and the theatre took fire and was destroyed.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 21.--The local committee of railroad agents have come to an agreement with the owners of railroad elevators regarding receipts of car grain.

CALHOUN, Ga., March 21.--There was a terrible windstorm here last night. The town is 90 miles from Chattanooga on the Atlantic and Western Road.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 21.--The train which left this city at 10:30 this morning for Rochester had on board the body of Amariah H. Bradner, the Dansville (N.Y.) banker, who died in the prison hospital here at 2 o'clock this morning.

Peter Mitchell and Charles W. Brooke, for the appellant, O'Neil, held that the court ...

It would be difficult to conceive a more solemn and impressive tribute to the memory of a dead monarch than that paid last night by nearly 4,000 German-American citizen in honor of their former King and Emperor William I. on Germany.
CHICAGO, March 21.--The Classification Conference Committee continued its work today and made fair progress.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 21.--A terrible electric storm enveloped the State last night, beginning about 10 o'clock and lasting until midnight. In Fairburn both the colored churches were demolished. Court House chimney torn off, shade trees uprooted, and other damage done.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 21.--Edward Hugh McKenzie turns out to be a fraud, but, neverthless, his sweetheart will marry him.

WINNIPEG, March 22.--The Battleford District Indians have become much more communicative.

ALBANY, March 22.--Unless a change is made in the programme arranged for Saturday's meeting of the Republican State Committee in New-York the convention for the selection of delecates to Chicago will be called to meet in Syracuse on May 16.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The President sent a brief message to the Senate today in reply to a resolution introduced by Senator Frye on the 16th inst. requesting the President to transmit to the Senate copies of the minutes and daily protocols of the meetings of the Commissioners who negotiated ...

The Senior Class of the Law School, Columbia College, yesterday elected a commtttee to make the necessary arrangements for Commencement, consisting of H.A. Tenney, Chairman; J.D. Baucus, J. V. Bouvier, Jr., A.L. Clark. W.A. Douglass, T.G. Frost, H.B. Gayley, F.R. Kellogg, and P.P. Sandford.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 22.--A disastrous flood visited this portion of the Mohawk Valley last night, caused by the breaking up of the ice in the Schoharie Creek and other tributaries of the Mohawk River. At fort Hunter, where the Schoharie Creek empties into the Mohawk, the high waters have caused widespread devastation.

The body of the Venezuelan patriot, Gen. Jose Antonio Paez, is now lying in state in the Governor's Room at the City Hall. On Saturday it will be placed on board the United States ship Pensacola, and will be taken to Venezuela.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 22.--To have mentioned the tariff disrespectfully five years ago in any part of Pennsylvania would have been considered little less than profanity by Republicans or Democrats; now there are Democrats, even in the Lackawanna Valley, who say it ought to be "revised," and say it boldly.
A reception was given last evening at the Park-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church in honor of the retiring Pastor, the Rev. Dr. James M. King, who thus closed his fifth Pastorate in this city.
The expected storm passed this city yesterday morning with a rush. Between midnight of Tuesday and 10 o'clock A.M. Wednesday, the barometer fell about an inch.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 22.--Chairman B. F. Jones of the Republican National Committee was at the Union Station this morning en route to Washington. His visit to the national capital, he said, had no political significance whatever.

Nearly all the sailing vessels which reached this port yesterday had suffered damage during the storm of March 12, and some were in a very battered condition. The bark G. De Zaldo, Capt. Miller, from St. Jago Feb. 8, was swept by the heavy seas.

OTTAWA, March 22.--In the Senate to-day the leader of the Government announced that all the correspondence relating to the seizure of Canadian vessels in Behring's Sea by American revenue cutters would be brought down shortly.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate: Dwight N. Miller, to be Postmaster at Homer, N. Y.; John Dennis, to be Melter and Refiner of the Mint at Carson, Nev.

BERLIN, March 22.--To-day was the anniversary of the late Emperor William's birth, and to memorial service was held in the castle chapel at Charlottenburg. The Empress Victoria and members of the royal family and many people of prominence attended a service in the Berlin Cathedral.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., March 22.--The funeral of ex-Gov. Horace Fairbanks took place to-day and was attended by a large concourse of people. Gov. Ormsby and staff, ex-Gov. Farnham, and friends from New-York, Boston, and Montreal were among the mourners.
PITTSBURG, March 22.--The furnaces of the Girard Iron Company of Girard, Ohio, will be banked on account of a lack of orders to keep them running.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--There is to be an International Council of Women in this city. Francis E. Trowbridge, a broker, having an office in the Drexel Building, was arrested and taken to Police Headquarters by one of In spector Byrnes's men last evening on a warrant sworn out before Justice Power by Abraham Kling, a lawyer, of 261 Broadway.

Four hundred thousand shares of stock were dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday-- activity greater than has been known in a long while. Still, the chief and almost only interest was in the Gould stocks. All day long a fierce battle raged over Missouri Pacific, Western ...

HUNTINGDON, Penn., March 22.--Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon an east-boundfreight train on the Pennsylvania Road was badly wrecked at Barre, caused by the breaking of an axle on a freight train.

OPORTO, March 22.--The bodies of 66 victims of the theatre fire were exposed for identification to-day. Many heartrending scenes were witnessed. Besides the bodies there are 53 heaps of unrecognizable remains. Several projects have been organized for the relief of the families of the poorer victims.

Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes has presented to the Medical Libarary, Boylston-place, his very valuable, and extensive collection of medical books. The library is already so filled with books that in order to accommodate this donation, which will cover 30 lineal feet of shelf room, the librarian found it necessary to have built several additional shelves.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., March 22.--A German tramp who has made this place his headquarters for the past two years has just received a windfall in the shape of a forty-thousand-dollar fortune from the death of relatives in Germany.
Hamilton Cole has filed in the Supreme Court his report as Referee in the suit of Stephen M. Chester against Francois Henry Jumel and other heirs of the Jumel estate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 22.--The Senate to-day passed the Poorman bill increasing the liquor tax to $250. Heretofore the tax has been $100 for wine and beer and $200 for wine, beer, and liquor. The State will receive onefifth of this sum, or nearly $500,000, thus placing the financial condition of the State upon a better footing.
DETROIT, March 22.--G.O. Cowles of Utica, N.Y., was found dead in his room at the Bancroft House, in East Saginaw, this afternoon.

DANVILLE, Va., March 22.--The little village of Stokesland in Pittsylvania Counts, Va., was considerably aroused last evening over a tragedy enacted in its midst. J.H. Blackburn, a farmer, aged 50 years, was shot down by a man named J.J. Henderson, who kept a groggery in the place.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 22.--Effie Ellis, the young variety actress who was disfigured by Dr. Cox arrived in the city this morning with Fenton Cox.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 21.--The Republican State Convention meets in Raleigh on Wednesday, May 23. The call includes the nomination of candidates for Governor and State officers, three Judges of the Supreme Court, and the selection of four delegates and four alternates to the National Republican Convention.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 22.--Early this morning as the west-bound passenger train on the Ohio, Illinois and Western Railroad was passing Troy siding, an out-of-the-way side track just East of Covington, Ind., a fire was discovered ...

The losses paid by the Travelers' Insurance Company of Hartford, 140 Broadway, NewYork, during the month of January, 1888, on life and accident policy holders together amounted to $33,654.46, or a fraction under $18 a minute for every banking hour of the month.-- World.
SOFIA, March 22.--M. Natchevitz, Minister of Finance, in an interview said the Government had no intention to proclaim the independence of Bulgaria. The country would remain local to Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--Chief-Justice Morrison R. Waite of the United States Supreme Court is confined to his house by sickness, which is giving his family and friends some anxiety, but which his physician does not regard as necessarily dangerous. The Chief-Justice dined out on Saturday evening, and on his return home ...
A suit over the custody of trunks arising out of a family tiff came up in the City Court yesterday before Judge McAdam.

LONDON, March 22.--The Liverpool Spring meeting opened to-day. The race for the Molyneaux Stakes of 5 sovereigns each, with 800 sovoreigns added, for 2-year-olds, distance five furlongs, was won by a neck by J.H. Houldsworth's b.f. Gazelle, by Springfield, out of Rozelle.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 22.--The Rev. Dr. W.J. McKnight to-night united in marriage Hugh Edward Mackenzie, who is alleged to be a tramp and a Scotch heir, and Miss Emma Johnson, who cared for him and fell in love with him when he appeared at her father's farm in October last.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 22, via Galveston.--A banquet in honor of Gen. Bragg, the new United States Minister, was given yesterday by American residents. Leading officials of the Mexican Government and a number of members of the press were present. Consul-General More presided.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 22.--The Junior exhibition prize speaking contest of Yale University took place in Batten Chapel this afternoon. All of the members of the literary magazine board were among the speakers.

ALBANY, March 22.--Gov. Hill signed the Fassett Quarantine Fee bill to-day, not forgetting to file with the Secretary of State a little memorandum in which he claimed for the Democracy no modest share of any credit which may be bestowed upon the Legislature for the passage of the measure.

BOSTON, March 22.--The Carrie E. Phillips, the fishing vessel designed by Edward Burgess, has made an unofficial record of a run from the Georges to Boston which proves her to be the fastest vessel in the feet.
Travel by road and rail is still greatly retarded on Long-Island, the snow blockades having been closely followed by floods which have washed out the roadways and tracks at many different points.

The large judgment obtained by Richard A. Tilghman of Philadelphia through the United States Supreme Court a few days since is against the estate of Procter and the old firm and does not affect the present firm of Procter Gamble. The estate is amply able to meet the claim and has made arrangements to do so.--Philadelphia Inquirer.

Some of the relatives of the late Barbara Fritchie in Frederick, Md., recently send to Mr. John G. Whittier, who immortalized the venerable lady in verse, a number a table articles which formerly belonged to Mrs. Fritchie.

ALBANY, March 22.--The Delta Chi Chapter of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity was incorporated to-day. Its headquarters are to be in New-York City, and its objects are to maintain a clubhouse and promote the welfare of Delta Chi Chapter of Cornell University.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, March 22.--A highly-important decision has just been rendered by United States Commissioner Smith of Seattle in the case of the United States against six sailors of the ship Fannie Tucker, charged with disobedience and desertion.
Charles Behrens, a paper box manufacturer in Chambers-street, was burned out last Summer. He held policies for $10,000 in several insurance companies, one for $3,000 being in the Williamsburg City.
WASHINGTON, March 22.--The resignation of Second Lieut. Pierrepont Isham, Third Cavalry, has been accepted, to take effect on June 1, and he has been granted leave of absence until that date.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22.--The Reading Terminal Company has now practically secured the right of way for an elevated road from Twelfth and Market to Ninth and Green streets for the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company. ST. LOUIS, March 22.--Rumors about Receivershihs for the Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain ago still flying aronnd, but the stockholders have so far done nothing but "squeal." Large lines of Missouri Pacific and Iron Mountain are held in St. Louis, and the first intimation that the holders received that decay or something worse had fastened on the system was the telegrams from New-York Tuesday.

Judge Wallace of the United States Circuit Court yesterday rendered decisions in the two equity suits of the Banque Franco Egyptienne of Paris against John Crosby Brown, Jesse Seligman, and Duncan Sherman, and of Henry L. Bischoffsheim of London against the same defendants. Both bills were dismissed.

SING SING, N.Y., March 22.--Warden Brush of Sing Sing Prison this afternoon at closing-up time issued orders to stop work altogether in the shoe shops, owing to the failure of the Legislature to appropriate money to carry on the prison industries.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22.--The sawmakers of the United States met in convention at 806 Girard-avenue this afternoon. Many of the delegates from distant cities did not arrive until late in the afternoon, and this delayed the business of the meeting considerably.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 22.--R.H. Morehead, Chairman of the State Executive Committee of the Union Labor Party of Arkansas, has called a convention of that party to meet in Little Rock, April 30, for the purpose of nominating a roll State ticket and selecting delegates to attend the National Convention.

A patent has been granted for methods and apparatus to increase the tractive power of locomotives and other self-propelled rail vehicles by increasing electrically the frictional adhesion between the driving wheels and the rails.

A.G. Mandel, a dealer in oils, railroad grease. c., at 251 Front-street, because of failing health went recently to the Pacific coast in order to regain strength, and at the same time push his business interests in that part of the country.
ST. LOUIS, March 22.--Eight hundred members of the Wagonmakers' Union threaten to go on strike within three days.

The police central detectives were hard at work all day yesterday trying to get a clue to Miss Beatrice Allison, who disappeared from her home, at 81 East Tenth-street, on Tuesday forenoon. Her mother, Mrs. Allison, is the widow of Jonathan Crag Allison, who was a wealthy merchant of Halifax and one of its most prominent citizens.

LONDON, March 22.--The Local Government bill, as it is legally entitled, continues to be the chief subject of discussion in the press of the entire kingdom. It begins to be seen that there is a big home-rule plan behind it; in fact, it is frankly stated by the advocates of the bill that the extension of the system to Scotland and Ireland is merely a matter of time.
"G.P.A." has sent 10 and "R.R.B." $2 to this office for the Annie Knieriem fund. A certificate of membership in the Produce Exchange was sold yesterday for $1,550.

Holders of the securities of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad held a conference yesterday at the office of the Stock Exchange firm of Edward Sweet Co. to consider means for defense of their rights.

Eugene Lynn Spotts was until very recently a clerk in the dry goods house of James McCreery Co., Broadway and Eleventh-street. Becoming tired of life behind the counter he determined to win fame and fortune in other walks.

John T. Howard, one of the founders of Plymouth Church, died yesterday morning at his home, 174 Hicks-street, Brooklyn, from the effects of a stroke of apoplexy. Although in his eightieth year, Mr. Howard was in good health, and on Wednesday was in this city at the office of one of his sons.

Detective Heidelberg yesterday arrested William H. Ayres at the Grand-Street Ferry on a charge of robbing his employer, Robert Bicket, a diamond dealer at 202 Broadway.
Those who have recently been honored with "commands" to dine and sleep at Windsor have noticed the beneficial effects of the recent spell of cold weather on her Majesty's health and spirits.

CHICAGO, March 22.--There does not seem to be any question that by April 1 the rates in the West to all points will be restored to the tariffs agreed upon in September last, and that, for a time at least, the earning power of traffic will be brought back to something like its old standard.

BOSTON, March 22.--Two cranks visited the State House to-day. The first one was an Irish woman with a rich brogue who coolly informed the people on the Hill that she owned the State House, and intended to make it her home.

Capt. R.W. Meade, United States Navy, is at the New-York Hotel. Clayton McMichael of Philadelphia is at the Victoria Hotel.

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., March 22.--The British steamer Aguan, Capt. Adair, from Honduras and Jamaica, with fruit, is off here in distress. She has signaled for a tug.

OSWEGO, N.Y., March 22.--A cyclone passed over a small section of country about a mile south of Fulton, this county, yesterday afternoon, doing considerable damage. The farmhouse occupied by Mr. E. Hubbard was badly wrecked, every pane of glass being broken, the roof lifted off, and Mrs. Hubbard badly injured by being cut with flying glass and splinters.

DETROIT, March 22.--Four ordinary-looking trunks, which had been checked at British Columbia, reached Windsor, opposite this city, last Friday evening over the Canada Southern, from the East.
The Sands-Street Church, the big, oldfashioned building which stands opposite the Brooklyn entrance to the East River Bridge, was sold yesterday for $107,000 to Charles E. Bill, Jr.

DANSVILLE, N.Y., March 22.--Col. L.B. Faulkner and Leonard Kuhn, Director and Cashier respectively of the First National Bank of this place, were arrested last night by Sheriff McNeil upon a requisition of the United States court and taken to Buffalo. It is reported they are held on an indictment of the Grand Jury on criminal charges connected with the affairs of the bank.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22.--This has been a dull day after yesterday's exciting contest over the Morris Canal abandonment. The members are now looking forward anxiously toward final adjournment, which it is believed can be reached next Friday.
A large number of members and their friends attended the annual exhibition of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen at its building, 18 West Sixteenth-street, last evening.
CALCUTTA, March 22.--The Sikkim expedition has captured the Thibetan works. The defenders fled to the jungle.

SARNIA, March 23.--Mr. Samuel Edison, the father of Mr. T.A. Edison, the inventor, is lying very ill at his home in Fort Gratiot, opposite Point Edward, with very little hopes of recovery. The old gentleman is in his eighty-fifth year, and has always been hale and hearty.

CHICAGO, March 25.--The past week at the Chicago playhouses has been marked by no startling feature. Business has been fair, and while the seven days will not make the season's record on receipts the results have averaged very satisfactorily.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 25.--The employes of the Dayton, Fort Wayne and Chicago Road were paid their first installment of back pay by Receiver Marshall yesterday, $37,000 being distributed.

CHICAGO, March 25.--A curious feature of the completion of the Denver, Fort Worth and Texas Road is that it gives Denver the benefit of seaboard competition. The first-class rate, as established between Galveston and Denver, is $1.44 a hundred.

ST. LOUIS, March 25.--Measles have broken out in a virulent form among United States recruits at Jefferson Barracks, 12 miles below this city. Seven deaths have already occurred, and the hospital is crowded with sufferers from the disease. All newly-arrived recruits are quarantined. It is said the contagion was brought here by recruits from New-York.

WASHINGTON, March 25.--The International Council of Women opened this afternoon with religious services at Albaugh's Grand Opera House. The attendance was large. The Rev. Ada C. Bowles, the Rev. Antoinette Brown Blackwell, the Rev. Anna H. Shaw, and the Rev. Amanda Deyo officiated. The subject of the sermon by the Rev. Anna Shaw was "The Heavenly Vision."

PHELPS, N.Y., March 25.--Prof. Brooks of Red House Observatory obtained a fine view this morning of the new South African comet, in right ascension 21 hours 40 minutes; declination south 5 degrees 15 minutes. The comet is now in the constellation Aquarius. It is just visible to the naked eye before dawn, and in the telescope presents a fine appearance, with a bright, elongated nucleus and a short, spreading tail.

ST. LOUIS, March 25.--A new and very fatal disease has broken out among cattle in the vicinity of Gainesville, Texas. It is entirely new in that section of country, and kills in a few hours. The most thrifty animals succumb to it. It somewhat resembles the milk sickness of the North, but is much more suddenly fatal.

UTICA, March 26.--In the United States District Court to-day the jury in the "Blind" Patterson case gave a verdict acquitting the three defendants --Patterson, Laidlaw, and Mills. MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 26.--News received here to-day from the Sledge and Mason plantations, a few miles below Australia landing, tells of a killing and lynching which occurred there on Saturday last. Robert Taylor, a white man, shot and killed a negro who attempted to strike him.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., March 26.--A freight train on the Erie Railway broke in two early this morning near Mast Hope. The broken parts came together on the bridge over the Delaware River near that place, wrecking several cars and damaging the bridge. Through trains from the West will be obliged to reach NewYork ovor the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road from Binghamton. The bridge will be repaired to-day.

C., March 26.--The Prohibitien people of this State have decided to assert themselves during the campaign of this year and have issued a call for a State Convention to be held in Greensborough on May 16 next. Nicholas Goldenkirch, a young man whose residence is unknown, lies in a room in the Eastern District Hospital, Brooklyn, with a bullet in his brain, planted there by the brother of his sweetheart.

Gilson Rhinehart, the old pilot, of 205 South Third-street, Brooklyn. Eastern District, who was summoned to appear before Justice Bartlett on an application to have him committed to an insane asylum, has been discovered to be perfectly sane.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., March 26.--A sad case of poverty and destitution came to light in a most respectable quarter of Mount Holly last night.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--At 2 o'clock this morning a fire occurred in a frame building at the corner of Ninth and K streets, Northwest, the upper part of which was occupied bY W. H. Duffy, his wife, and five children. Two of the children were rescued with much difficulty. They were unconscious and badly burned, and one of them died later in the day.

ALBANY, March 26.--Senator Vedder's bill taxing trusts $l 25 on every $I,000 of their capital was the theme upon which the Senate was called to display its oratorical powers to the galleries to-night. Mr. Vedder denied with marked vehemence the published reports that this is a bill to legalize trusts.

The Inman Steamship Company yesterday filed in the United States District Court a libel for $2,000 against the Western Union Telegraph Company. The Western Union runs a cable from Cortlandt-street over to Jersey City, which goes under the Red Star pier at the Jersey side.

ALBANY, N. Y., March 26.--Charles and William Winn, United States prisoners confined in the Maiden-Lane Jail for robbing small Post Offices in this county, escaped from the jail.

BOSTON, March 26.--News was received here to-day of the death at Toronto, Ontario, yesterday of Abner Ingalls Benyon, late President of the Pacific National Bank of this city, the failure of which in May, 1882, and the history of its management and the disappearance of its President are well-known matters. Mr. Benyon had lived in Mexico and Canada for the past two years. He leaves a widow and nine children.

Mr. Gould's attention is not monopolized by either his Missouri Pacific and its wavering dividend schemes nor by the prospect looming up of Grand Jury indictments. The failure of the steamship Trinidad to bring news of the yawl Cythera on Sunday has occasioned a great deal of anxiety among the friends of the Cythera's owner, William A. W. Stewart, and of C. S. Lee, the owner of the Oriva, who accompanied him.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 26. In the First District Court at Provo Saturday 16 Mormons were sentenced for living with more than one wife, contrary to the provisions of the Edmunds law. Most of them received six months in the penitentiary and were fined $300.

While crossing Broadway yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock John Barnes was knocked down by the horses of a Broadway street car, yet escaped being run over. He was bruised about the shoulders to such an extent that it was deemed advisable to take him to Chambers-Street Hospital. It was found that his injuries were not serious and he was permitted to go home. The driver of the horses was Gus Schultz.

A capital entertainment of its kind is that offered at the Star Theatre this week by the company of singers, dancers, jugglers, and comedians from the Howard Athenaeum, in Boston.

The case of Ellen Foy, a servant, against Robert Sowell, a lawyer, was on trial before Justice Bookstaver, in Supreme Court, Part II., yesterday. Miss Foy sues to recover $25,000 for damages received in an assault alleged to have been committed upon her in October,1884, by the defendant, who was her employer.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--Senator Sherman has given his personal assurance to Senator Riddleberger that the pending fisheries treaty with Great Britain shall not be taken up in executive session until the Virginia Senator has had a chance to vote in open session upon the question of public consideration of the treaty.

Something legitimate in the dramatic line is to be seen at Niblo's this week. Margaret Mather began a week's engagement last evening in a round of famous characters. She has not appeared in this city since her season at the Union-Square Theatre last year.

A postal card that is traveling around the world was received yesterday by C. B. Richard Co., bankers at 61 Broadway, and will be sent to George Geymann Co. of Nurnberg, Germany, who first started it on its journey.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--The International Council of Women formally opened to-day in Albaugh's Grand Opera House. It was assembled by the National Woman Suffrage Association of the United States to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the first Woman's Rights Convention.

WASHINGTON, March 26.--Information has been received at the State Department of the assassination of J. A. Clark, a United States citizen, near Huanuco, Peru. At the instance of the American Minister at Lima the Peruvian Government will investigate the facts.
There is no more important question before the Legislature of this State than that of providing for the printing and distribution of ballots at elections at public expense.

Manager Hill's lease of the Standard Theatre is for four weeks, beginning next Monday, when Margaret Mather will appear in the house for one week. On April 9 "A Possible Case" will have its first representation in NewYork at the Standard.

LONDON, March 26.--Mr. Goschen, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, introduced the budget in the House of Commons this evening. The House was crowded. Mr. Goschen said that the Local Government bill gave a special interest to the present budget. Hitherto the Chancellor of the Exchequer had had to consider chiefly the claims of taxpayers.

Henry S. Lowenthal, manufacturer of rufflings at 12 White-street, is in the hands of the Sheriff on confessed judgments in favor of two creditors for $5,743. Last June he claimed assets of $30,000 and liabilities of $14,000. He was formerly of the firms of H. L. Lowenthal Co. and Lowenthal, Mass Co., and has been alone for about three years. His liabilities are reported to be about $22,000.
BOSTON, March 26.--Mrs. Robert Hawkes, who now lives at Somerville, was married about 25 years ago to a man in the town in Nova Scotia in which she then lived.

BERLIN, March 26.--The Emperor has issued an order directing that the usual Spring review of the Guards be omitted this year. The order gives great satisfaction to the military authorities.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 27.--The total rainfall since Sunday night has been 7 77-100 inches, the largest on record for the same length of time. A flood higher than that of 1886 is anticipated.

Among the passengers on a Pennsylvania Railroad train which left this city, bound for Florida, on March 15, were ex-Lieut-Gov. William Dorsheimer and Mrs. Dorsheimer. Both were in comparatively good health and excellent spirits. Gov. Dorsheimer simply needed a rest.
Josef Hofmann, with his parents, sails for Bremen today by the Saale of the North German Lloyds. He passed a happy day yesterday in anticipation of his journey toward the Fatherland.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 27.--The little town of Reville, in Grant County, Dakota, is completely blocked in. NASHUA, N.H., March 27.--There were two distinct earthquake shocks felt in this city early this morning. The first stock was at 1:30 A.M., and was sufficiently violent to jar residences and awaken people. It was accompanied by a rumbling noise, which lasted a few soconds. The socond shock occurred at 2 o'clock.

CHICAGO, March 27.--It is understood that the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy will not restore the rates on April 1 as it had announced, but will postpone the advance for a period not decided upon.

ALBANY, March 29.--The Crosby High License bill passed the Assembly to-day with 66 votes, one more than was actually necessary. Mr. Crosby had to permit its amendment in two particulars to procure the sixty-fifth vote, that of John H. Bagley, Democrat, of Catskill, Greene County.
A well-pleased audience of goodly proportions left Stein way Hall yesterday afternoon at the conclusion of Theodore Thomas's eleventh public symphony rehearsal.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 29.--The ice on the Hudson River were away very rapidly under the effects of the fog in the morning and the sunshine this afternoon, and to-night the indications point to a general break-up if the mild weather continues.

Advance copies of the full report of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company for 1887 were issued Wednesday. It covers over 50 pages. It shows that during the year the road added 371 miles to its lines, having at the end of 1887 5,355 miles in operation.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--Ed Andrews, the famous outfielder of the Philadelphia Club about whose probable retirement from the ball field much has been written during the Winter, has signed a contract with President Reach to play with the Philadelphias the coming season.

Effie Ellsler writes to a friend in this city that she has arranged with Manager Palmer to appear at the Madison-Square Theatre April 30 in a new play which Mr. Palmer proposes to produce on that date, and that she is to be supported by a first-class company.

At the engineer office, in the Army Building, at Houston and Greene streets, bids were opened until 12 o'clock yesterday for the improvement of Sheepshead Bay. WASHINGTON, March 29.--It has been discovered that a conspiracy had been formed by 18 or 20 of the more desparate of the prisoners in the District jail, who are under sentence to the Albany Penitentiary, to murder the guards if necessary, release their fellow-prisoners, and make their escape.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 29.--At the Republican State Central Committee meeting here this afternoon the city of New-Haven was selected as the place for holding the State Convention for the nomination of delegates to the National Convention at Chicago in June.
