Delmonico's great hall, which has glistened this Winter with the blue of Yale and the crimson of Harvard, was last evening aglow with the rich carnelian of Cornell and resounded with her complicated cheer. It was the eighth annual dinner of the New-York Association of the university and the most successful of the series.

"Col." C. Calvert Egerton, a patent agent of Baltimore, was arrested yesterday on complaint of Proctor A. Roberts, proprietor of the Broadway Hotel, 834 Broadway, for passing a worthless check, and committed in default ...

The Brooklyn Excise Commissioners have become involved in a fierce fight over the disclosure of the fact that their ex-Secretary, Frank McCutcheon, had been allowed to run a saloon for over 200 days without a license, and an investigation by the Mayor is among the possibilities.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--Officials Of the Adams Express Company in this city received a dispatch to-day from the main office in New-York confirming the rumor which was current on the street that the United States Express Company had secured express privileges of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey.
VIENNA, March 29.--Serious fires are reported in Hungary. Nineteen houses have been burned at Csaba and 20 at Kitinda. At the latter place the fire is still raging.
NANTUCKET, Mass., March 29.--The British steamer Canonbury, previously reported ashore, has sunk two miles southeast from the Surf Side Life-Saving Station, where she had been abandoned.

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner Messemer in the case of Mrs. Francis Westlake and Frederic, her son, who were killed at the fire in the Elberon Flats, 1,131 Madison-avenue, on March 19. The evidence was a repetition of the story told in THE TIMES at the time.

The one hundred and fiftieth performance of "Pete" was given by Mr. Hurrigan and his entertaining associates at the Park Theatre last evening in the presence of a large audience. There were no souvenirs, but Mr. Hanley had made the auditorium fragrant and bright with flowers. "Pete" is as prosperous as ever, and the season at Mr. Harrigan's theatre will close long before the public has tired of the play.
Fire was discovered about 9 o'clock last evening on the third floor of the four-story building 228 Mercer-street, occupied by Adam Schwaab, manufacturer of cabinet furniture.

Assistant District Attorney Dos Passos, for the prosecution, in an hour's speech yesterday morning, told the story of the murder of Rachel Pittman by her father, Francis W. Pittman.

While on her way to the wharf of the French line of steamships on March 10, about to start for Europe, a woman, whose name is withheld, lost her recticule, which contained diamonds worth $1,000, 430f. in French gold, and some small articles.

WASHINGTON, March 29.--First Lieut. Henry Merriam, Fourth Infantry, has been granted three months' leave of absence on surgeon's certificate, and Capt. John P. Rodman, Twentieth Infantry, granted 14 days' leave of absence. Cadet John B. Rushing, Third Class, Military Academy, has been granted leave of absence until July 1 on account of sickness.

BERLIN, March 29.--The engagement of the Russian doctor, Zabludovsky, to apply the massage treatment to Emperor Frederick was by the advice of Prof. Bergmann. His employment is leading to similar remarks among the people to those applied to Dr. Mackenzie.

ALBANY, March 29.--The man of woes aired his grievances again in the Senate to-day. Some mild reflections that appeared in these columns this morning suggested to Senator John Raines of Canandaigua the thought that their author was a purveyor of falsehood, and ...

WASHINGTON, March 29.--The majority report of the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate, submitted by Mr. Wilson of Iowa on Feb. 28, while recommending the confirmation of Mr. Lacombe as an additional Circuit Justice of the United States for the Second Circuit, coupled with the recommendation a statement that the President had no right to appoint Mr. Lacombe temporarily during the recess of the Senate, and in doing so he had acted illegally ...
DETROIT, Mich., March 29.--In the United States Circuit Court in this city Judge Brown has ordered the sale of the Chicago and Canada Southern Railroad under foreclosure ...
The twenty-seventh anniversary of the Forty-Seventh Regiment, N.G.S.N.Y., was celebrated last evening at the armory of the regiment, Marcy-avenue, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, March 29.--Mayor Hewitt must have been surprised when he appeared in the Senate Chamber this afternoon, fresh from a call on Gov. Hill, to argue before the joint railroad committee in favor of his scheme for a rapid transit in New-York, to see how few of the Senators knew him and how many wanted to.

PITTSBURG, March 29.--The works of the Leechburg Machine and Foundry Company at Leechburg, Penn., caught fire from escaping natural gas to-day, and were totally destroyed. The flames spread so rapidly that the employes barely escaped with their lives, and several were slightly injured. The loss will probably reach $50,000, on which there is $17,000 insurance.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 29.--There seems to be a great deal of uncertainty among the farmers as to where the agricultural element of Minnesota is to be found politically this year. The farmers of the State have drifted apart during the past two years as regards their political views.

Gen. Charles A. Stetson died Wednesday at Reading, Penn. He was for nearly half a century one of the best known men in this country. As proprietor of the Astor House from 1832 to 1875 he won the esteem of many of the most distinguished men of America, among whom were Webster, Choate, Clay, Grant. Seward, and Thurlow Weed.

One hundred and sixty paintings, water colors, and drawings line various smaller galleries of the American Art Association on Madison-square. Many belong to the epoch of 1855-- 1870, and a few are even earlier. But the greater part seems to bear witness to the statement of the auctioneers that they belong to the estate of the late Christian H. Wolff of Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, March 29.--Chicago seems in a fair way to repeat the worst disturbances of the late troubles on the Missouri Pacific. What was very much like a riot marked the progress of the Burlington strike late this afternoon, and resulted in the ditching of several cars, the rout of a squad of Pinkerton guards, and acts of violence toward the new men.

A father in his efforts to obtain possession of his daughter was compelled to invoke the aid of the courts yesterday and petition for a writ of habeas corpus to bring the little one down to the Court House.

MONTREAL, March 29.--Detective Fahey was to-day sentenced to 14 years in the penitantiary for robbing the Grand Trunk Railway offices.

That unfortunate steamship, the Britannia, which so often meets with detention at this port, remained at anchor all day yesterday off Ellis Island. A large crowd of Italians gathered at the Battery and looked with longing eyes at the vessel containing their compatriots.

J.J. Adams, ex-member of Congress, has sued Henry S. Ives for $20,000, which, he says, Ives owes him for his services in "pulling the young Napoleon of Finance" through his troubles last Summer and Fall. ATLANTA, Ga., March 29.--It is not generally known, but it is nevertheless true, that Georgia furnished one regiment of infantry to the Federal service during the civil war. It was not a full regiment, and somehow the officers and men were never paid for their services, although they did hard fighting and a number of them were killed and wounded.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that the Military Order of the Loyal Legion has decided to buy a property and form a museum, which is to be known as the "War Library and Museum of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States."

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 29.--At 10 o'clock the special train bearing the remains of Chief-Justice Waite rolled into the Pennsylvania Station, with the committees of the Senate and House, Justices of the Supreme Court Miller, Harlan, Blatchford, Gray, and Lamar, and others.
PORTLAND, Oregon, March 29.--The Democratic Convention of Multnomah County last night chose 17 delegates to the State Convention, which meets at Pendleton next Tuesday.

BINGHAMTON, March 29.--Charles Pierce, a well-known cigarette manufacturer of Chenango Forks, a village about nine miles north of this city, committed suicide this evening by shooting himself through the head. He died almost instantly. No cause for the act is known. He came from New-York City a few years ago, and was supposed to be doing a successful business. He leaves a widow and several children.

The Commissioners of Emigration, at their regular meeting yesterday, passed a resolution requesting Superintendent Jackson to post the news of the Garden on bulletins for the use of the reporters, who have hitherto skirmished for themselves.

Upon the strength of a favorable statement from the President, Secretary, and Superintendent of the "Cleveland Tin Mining Company" regarding the prospects of its mine on Nigger Hill, in the northwest portion of the Black Hills, Dakota, the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange yesterday placed the stock of the company on the permanent list of the Exchange.

PITTSBURG, March 30.--A movement is on foot among the puddlers in several of the mills in this city to withdraw from the ranks of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers and form a separate organization.

NYACK, N.Y., March 30.--An interesting lawsuit, the first of its kind, it is believed, in Rockland County, was tried at Spring Valley on Thursday. During the late blizzard the high snowbanks made many of the roads throughout the county impassable and it was necessary for farmers and others to turn out and break them before travel over them could be resumed.
BALTIMORE, March 30.--Claus Speckels played his little sugar comedy in Baltimore to a good audience and a satisfactory amount of applause.

The Board of Directors of the Teachers' Association of the New-York has decided to present Thomas F. Harrison with an engrossed set of resolutions on the occasion of his retirement from the position of Senior Assistant Superintendent of the Public Schools.

RICHMOND, March 30.--The way in which Mahone took the party bit in his mouth at the meeting of the Republican Committee at Petersburg last night and defied all party law is the talk among politicians to-day. He fixed upon May 17 as the date for holding the State Convention and Petersburg as the place and ...

Five years ago Christopher Riordan was married to Nellie Downing. They did not dwell together peaceably, and on Jan. 28 Riordan made an assault upon his wife with a knife. She escaped to her father's house, 1,555 Avenue A Riordan went there the next day and threatened her.
Mr. Harrison Branthwaite, who keeps a home for inebriates at Twickenham, sends me some statistics about his patients which are rather interesting reading.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 30.--A convention of the Democrats of the First Congressional District has been called to meet at Helena June 28 to nominate a candidate for Congress. The Hon. Poindexter Dunn, the present incumbent, will not be a candidate for re-election.
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 30.--The St. Paul officials who attended the managers' meeting at Chicago have returned home.

Yesterday another egg of the extinct great auk (Alca inpennis) turned up at a sale at Stevens's rooms in the collection of a Mrs. Wise, whose husband bought it in 1851 of Mr. Williams, a dealer in Oxford-street, for 18, it having been imported from Paris.

Ought not the value of house property to rise if 2 3/4 per cent. is to become the standard rate of interest on safe investments? Estate agents and builders assert that it ought to rise, and will rise; that capital will be drawn off the Stock Exchange for investment in bricks and mortar.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, whose lectures at the Museum of Natural History were interrupted by his sickness, has recovered, and will resume the course on the first Saturday in April, when "Dogs and Seals" will be the subject.

The Citizens' Committee on High License, through its Finance Committee, Henry A. Oakley, Henry F. Howland, and Charles H. Marshall, has issued an appeal for funds to carry on the high license campaign.
ALBANY, March 30.--The Platt Senators began their tinkering with the Quarantine Commission again to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--The International Council of Women held a session this morning for women only. Mrs. Elizabeth Boynton Herbert made an impassioned address for the establishment of school houses all over the land in close proximity to each other, and the banishment of drinking saloons and houses of ill fame. Mrs. Herbert spoke against the employment, of young children in stores and factories, advocating the employment of older persons for these tasks.

The quarterly report prepared by Bradstreet's of the mercantile failures throughout the United States for the last three months places the total number at 3,053, or 75 fewer than in the first quarter of 1887.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 30.--A southbound freight train on the Delaware Road left the main track at Woodside, 52 miles below here, at 1:30 this morning, and crashed into a car loaded with pig iron which stood on a siding.

When Judge Shields came down to the County Court yesterday morning he drew from his pocket a marriage license and deposited it in the pigeon hole set apart for the reception of these precious documents.
The scheme to induce sanguine people with more money than they know what to do with to invest in the stock of the Cleveland Tin Mining Company is being pressed for all it is worth.

NYACK, N.Y., March 30.--Rockland County can boast of as well preserved a family as there is in the State. There are living in this family three sisters and a brother, each of whom is over fourscore years old and in apparently perfect health.

The City Reform Club held a protracted meeting last night and discussed the various phases pertaining to its fight for the exposure and punishment of the election frauds in the Eighth Assembly District last Fall.

Paraphrasing the words of Napoleon, the odds seem to be on the side of the heaviest bills in the storage warehouse business, for if the sale of the property of derelict customers which took place at the Lincoln Safe Deposit Company yesterday was a fair thing to judge by persons who failed to pay their bills made more money than the storage company.

JACKSON, Miss., March 30.--W.G. Colmery Cashier of the Crystal Springs Bank, committed suicide in that place to-day by shooting. A social disagreement of a trifling nature is said to have been the cause.
Mrs. Julia Malone, the wife of James Malone, living on the fourth floor of a double tenement house at 200 East One Hundred and Ninth-street, has had an unpleasant experience.

PARIS, March 30.--The Chamber of Deputies to-day, by a vote of 268 to 237, despite the opposition of the Government, voted for urgency for the Extreme Left bill providing for the revision of the Constitution. The Government thereupon resigned.
TRANTON, Mo., March 30.--J.W. Hill, a wealthy contractor of this place, shot, and killed by accident Miss Sarah Brown, daughter of A.T. Brown.

The loss of a valuable watch by Frank Borroto, a boy of 18, who works in his father's tobacco store at 57 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, and his utter inability to account for its disappearance led to an investigation yesterday.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., March 30.--The water in the streams in this county are higher now than have been known for many years past. At Sheldon yesterday the new iron bridge just built by the Berlin Bridge Company at a large expense was swept away.

Prof. C.A. Johnson, who modestly styles himself the well-known professional astronomical lecturer, philanthropist, literary, and educational writer, editor, publisher, and proprietor of the British Lion and American Eagle, , made his annual visit to the city last night and to a mixed audience delivered a lecture upon evolution.

MOBILE, Ala., March 30.--Passenger train No. 1 of the Louisville and Nashville, which left Montgomery Tuesday, arrived here this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The train was detained three days at Evergreen by wash-outs above and below that place. The drummers on board formed a baseball nine and had several lively games with the men of Evergreen.

From one or two leaflets which have been forwarded to me. I gather that the Liverpool people are much exercised about the growth of their municipal expenditure, and that they have the best reason to be so.

Justice Duffy, erstwhile the antagonist of the baby bang, has of late given over his active crusade in this direction and taken up his position with the army of short-necked people who object to having the field of their vision trespassed upon by lofty headgear.

Some days ago the articles of incorporation of the Garfield Safe Deposit Company were filed, and it will soon begin operations in the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third-street and Sixth-avenue, adjoining and connecting with the Garfield National Bank.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30.--A sense of modesty that is truly shocking has developed itself among the students here since it was announced that Anthony Comstock was coming to give a lecture before the Young Men's Christian Association.
RICH HILL, Mo., March 30.--The appalling disaster that occurred in Keith Perry's mine yesterday is horrible enough, but it is not as bad as the first news indicated.
The dead body of Michael Dillon of Newark was found in a barn near Elizabeth, N. J., on Monday night. He had died of exposure probably during the recent blizzard.

WASHINTGTON, March 30.--The Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee have had an unhappy time of it today endeavoring to explain how the report on the Tariff bill came to be given to a small number of papers instead of being assured general publicity.
After next Sunday Savannah will run by standard time. The City Council voted last night to adopt a uniform time system, and next Sunday at noon the city clocks will be set back 36 minutes.
Secretary Jackson issued his first Castle Garden bulletin yesterday. For a maiden effort it was very good, and the Secretary was justified in the pride which he felt at its successful completion.

Good Friday was observed yesterday far more generally as a religious anniversary than in the past. The services in the Episcopal and Catholic churches were held with the usual formalities, but other denominations shared yesterday in the observance, even one of the Unitarian Pastors leading his congregation in a distinctively Good Friday service.

ST. LOUIS, March 30.--John F. O'Rourke, who five years ago was a prominent figure in St. Louis social circles, and furnished a sensation subsequently by eloping with a schoolgirl, deserting his wife, has turned up in Detroit, ...
CHICAGO, March 30.--The fire which started early this morning in the five-story block, corner of Lake and Peoria streets gave the firemen great trouble before it was finally subdued.

The Republican Executive Committee met last evening at the Lincoln Club Rooms, 56 Clinton-place, and fixed upon May 8 as the date for the primaries at which delegates will be elected to the Republican State Convention on May 16, which will elect four delegates at large to the Republican National Convention.
The steamships Britannia is still kept lying off Bedlow's island, but she has only 688 of her steerage passengers left on board.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 30.--The most singular case of "big head" on record is reported from Chatham County, the possessor being a negro, Abner Dorsett. He is of a bright yellow color, has clear cut features, and an intelligent countenance.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Capt. S. Livingston Breese was placed on the retired list to-day upon his own application under the provision of law allowing the retirement of officers who have been in the service over 40 years.

A lot of fish called trout were received here yesterday from the Rogue River. They looked like trout, but were two feet and some of them 28 inches long.

MADISON, Ind., March 30.--The boilers in the large flouring mills of Paine, Johnson Co., Franklin, Ind., exploded this morning, wrecking the mill, instantly killing two men, and fatally injuring another.

Controller Myers yesterday re-leased the ferry from the foot of East Thirty-fourth-street to Hunter's Point, Long Island, to the company now operating it, for 10 years, at $10,000 a year. The city reserves the right to claim 5 per cent. of the gross receipts of the ferry during the last five years of the lease.

NANTUCKET, Mass., March 30.--The crew of the wrecked steamer Canonbury are all right, there being no sickness among them, and they will leave in to-morrow's boat for Boston. The report that cholera has existed among them is erroneous.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 30.--As was expected, the examination into the affairs of the State National Bank developed wholesale forgeries.

The growth of street railroads in the United States and Canada recently has been very large. According to returns received by the Street Railroad Journal, which will be published in full in the April number, 1,198 miles of new track were added in 1887.
In the rear of 70 Grove-street yesterday morning Colden Robinson, a negro porter employed at the office of the Chicago and Grand Trunk Railroad, 271 Broadway, killed his wife with a razor.

At the last meeting of the Anthropological Institute, Prof. Flower, C.B., Director of the Natural History Museum, gave a description of the two skeletons of Akkas, lately obtained in the Monbuttu country, Central Africa, by Emin Pasha.

CHICAGO, March 30.--It is agreed that all of the east-bound lines from Chicago are maintaining rates, although there is considerable grumbling over the heavy percentage of the business taken by the Chicago and Grand Trunk.

ROME, March 30.--King John of Abyssinia has proposed terms of peace to Gen. San Marzano, Commander-in-Chief of the Italian forces in Abyssinia. Gen. San Marzano communicated the proposal to the Government.

The family of Stephen A. Marshall of Rye were yesterday very much alarmed over Mr. Marshall's unexplained absence. They reported the case to the police of this city. They say that for some days he has been acting strangely, and they fear that he is wandering about somewhere in an unsound state of mind. For many years he was a Deputy Sheriff of Westchester County.
The death of three of A. Augustus Healy's children from diphtheria during the past week has alarmed the residents of Brooklyn Heights and stirred up the local health authorities.

Cornelius Foley, an old man who died Tuesday at 84 James-street, hsa been the occasion of much difficulty between the family undertakers, Broderick Lenahan of 149 Madisonstreet, and Cornelins's son.
TRENTON, N.J., March 30.--This has been a busy day in the Legislature, as since yesterday the members have seen an excellent prospect of getting through the session to-day.

Luther R. Marsh, whose devotion to the heroes of ancient history is exemplified by Mme. Editha Lola Dis Debars in more or less spiritual portraits, put aside the evanescent side of his character yesterday and became dignifled and as matter-of-fact as a city official.

ALBANY, March 30.--Upon a request by the Superintendent of the Banking Department, Attorney-General Tabor has written an opinion in which he holds that before a bank can move its place of business it must comply with the provisions of chapter 517, Laws of 1887, and apply to the Supreme Court for leave, even though such contemplated removal is from one place to another in the same city or county.
SOFIA, March 30.--Bulgaria has asked the Porte to explain the presence of Turkish troops at the town of Mustapha Pacha on the frontier.

CHICAGO, March 30.--This morning found the prospects for more trouble in the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy strike as promising as the worst enemies of the road and of the men could wish. The assault of the evening before and the arrest of two of the mob had resulted in giving the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul a strike of its own yardmen to attend to.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 30.--"No, Sir; the Knights of Labor in Minnesota as an organization will not join with the Farmers' Alliance in supporting Albert Scheffer for Governor of this State," said one of the chief officers of the Minnesota District Assembly to-day.
PHILADELPHIA, March 30.--The University Baseball team opened its season on the University Athletic Grounds this afternoon by playing a good game against the champion Yale nine.

Lord Lytton has decided to let Knebworth, furnished, for a term of years. It is one of the finest old manor houses in England, and the interior is splendidly decorated. The gardens and grounds are very beautiful, and there is a finely wooded park.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 30.--Mrs. Copley, a widow living in Richfield, had a terrible experience last night. Her house is in rather a lonely spot.
SULPHUR SPRINGS, Texas, March 30.-- News has reached here from Sulphur Bluff that John Ingle, a white man, was fatally wounded by a negro near Sulphur Bluff, in this county, yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 30.--Of late many thefts of overcoats have been reported at headquarters from hotels and from the courts. Detective Murray was put on the case, and he last night arrested a man who gave his name as George Hopkins.

Mr. HORNBLOWER has taken the trouble to examine the law reports of California, Kansas, and New-Jersey with the view of discovering the comparative merits of code and common law as administered in those States. He finds a larger number of appeals in California, and therefore we are told the law is more uncertain there. Hence the Civil Code now before the Legislature should not be passed.

BERLIN, March 30.--Emperor Frederick and Empress Victoria drove in a half-open carriage from Charlottenburg to Berlin to-day and paid a visit to the Dowager Empress Augusta. They received enthusiastic greetings along the road.

SUMMERVILLE, Ga., March 30.--The life of Henry Pope, who is to be hanged in this place on May 8, would furnish material for the dime novelist.

KEYPORT, N.J., March 30.--M.B. Bannister was this morning found dead in his bedroom. He had a large oyster business here and a big fruit grove in Florida, whence he arrived last night. He was about 70 years old.

PARIS, April 1.--M. Floquet, M. de Freycinet, and M. Goblet conferred together this afternoon and met again at a late hour to-night. M. de Freycinet, it is stated, declined to assume the office of Minister of War, but agreed to take the Foreign portfolio.

LITCHFIELD, ILL., April 1.--Five years ago, Thomas Davis, a well-dressed stranger, came to Litchfield and a few days after his arrival a wealthy citizen was robbed at the muzzle of a pistol. Samuel Waldrop was constable at the time, and he arrested Davis for the offense.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 1.--A call has been issued for a convention to be held at Topeka, May l, for the purpose of organizing the Farmers' Trust. Circulars have been sent to the Governors of all the States west of the Mississippi and to Illinois and Wisconsin to send delegates to the convention.

Benjamin F. Brady, who died at Bellevue Hospital Friday, was one of the most expert penmen in the world. He styled himself an artist penman. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 2.--At the town and city election to-day the Democrats made a clean sweep. Gen. John Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, was formally elected President of the Panama Railroad Company yesterday.

PENDLETON, Oregon, April 4.--In the Democratic State Convention to-day the Committee on Resolutions reported a platform which was adopted unanimausly. The first resolution heartily indorses President Cleveland, the second indorses the present State administration.

George Green, the partner of George T. Putney of the Rossmore Hotel, returned home yesterday with his newly-made wife, and held a reception in the parlors of the Rossmore last night.

JACKSON, Miss., April 4.--The Republican State Convention, for the purpose of sending delegates to the Republican National Convention, assembled in the City Hall to-day, about 250 colored and 25 white delegates being present.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4.--The Senatorial investigating committee to inquire into the charges of violation of the civil service law in the administration of the Federal offices in this city resumed its sessions here this morning, Senator Hale presiding.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4.--The arrest of a gang of negroes for chicken stealing near Kingston is likely to result in unearthing the mystery surrounding the murder of Theodore Cruse eight years ago.

BERLIN, April 4.--The Reichsanzeiger publishes a letter from Emperor Frederick expressing his thanks for the universal sympathy shown him and for the congratulations offered to him upon his accession to the throne.
Mrs. Margaret H. Rodrigue, a sister of Archbishop Hughes, died at the Home of the sisters of Charity, in Madison-avenue, yesterday morning.
TORONTO, Ontario, April 4.--This charges of forgery to be brought against President O. Ross and Cashier White of the State National Bank of Raleigh, N.C., are peculiar.
The parlors of the New-York Hospital, 8 West Sixteenth-street, were well filled last evening with friends of the New-York Hospital Training School for Nurses.

PHOENIX, Arizona, April 5.--Charles Bassett, a stockman, was fatally injured last night by the collapse of an old adobe house on his ranch. Bassett was a prominent member of the Wyoming Legislature a few years ago, and his wealth is estimated at $750,000. He has no relatives.
ALBANY, April 5.--The Knickerbocker Telephone company of New-York, with a capital of $125,000, was incorporated to-day with Henry E. Townsend, Charles L. Cammann, and Gustave Frank.

Activity continued in the stock market yesterday, and though early in the day there were sharp recessions from Wednesday's booming quotations, the closing prices left the market practically unchanged from the close of the day before.

Jacob Sharp died at 9:20 o'clock last evening. His death was sudden, his enfeebled heart ceasing to act after a violent and exhaust ing fit of coughing. He expired in the front alcove bedroom on the second floor of his residence at 354 West Twenty-third-street.

OSKALOOSA, Kan., April 5.--The ladies whose election to the offices of Mayor and Council has brought on a deluge of telegrams and special reporters took the oath of office to-day and will at once assume their official duties. They declare for law and order and public improvements.

A number of young women in the bookkeeping department of the Western Union Telegraph Company who were prevented by the blizzard from attending at the office March 12 and 13 found at the end of the month that their salaries had been docked.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--John T. Stone, charged with forgery and embezzlement of $37,000, the property of the Pennsylvania School Supply company, pleaded guilty before Judge Hare on sereral bills of indictment to-day, and received a sentence of two years from commitment.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--Major-Gen. Alfred H. Terry was placed on the retired list of the army today. This is in accordance with the report of the Army Retiring Board of which Major-Gen. Schofield is President. The report was submitted by the Secretary of War to the President to-day, and was immeately approved.

ELLSWORTH, Me., April 5.--News is received here that N.K. Sawyer, formerly editor of the Elisworth American and recently American Consul at Turkistan, died at Jacksonville, Fla., on March 30, aged 71.

CHICAGO, April 5.--Whatever may be the result of the deal between the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen and General Master Workman Powderly of the Knights of Labor, the fact remains that there is such a deal, and it is in writing and signed by the parties to the agreement.
The private collection of paintings owned by Edward F. Rook was sold at auction last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries, 366 Fifth-avenue.

BEDFORD, Ind., April 5.--This entire community was thrown into great excitement this morning by the announcement that Newton Gainey had shot and killed himself. There was a temporary suspension of business and hundreds rushed to the family residence.

The National Opera Company presented Gounod's "Faust" at the Academy of Music last night before an audience which applauded with all the energy of despair.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 5.--A curious complication under the prohibitory law has arisen here. Some weeks ago the stock of liquor belonging to F.L. Stubbs, a wholesale dealer, was seized under a charge that he was selling in violation of the law. The liquors were put under charge of a watcher, pending a decision in court.

Bianca, according to the lines of "Katherine," a travesty on "The Taming of the Shrew," by John Frederick Bangs, should have said, "Don't arouse her ire;" but the departure from the text was of no consequence to Bianca, who appeared to great advantage in a low-necked pink and gray velvet gown and a black mustache.

CHICAGO, April 5.--Although the new cable-car system of the Yerkes-Philadelphia syndicate on the north side has been in operation two weeks, the syndicate, according to a local paper, is having much trouble, and, so far as rapid transit is concerned, the project is a failure.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 5.--E.A. Caldwell, who was the stroke car of the winning Yale crews of 1886 and 1887, stated to-day that he would never row in another college race. At Capt. "Bob" Cook's request he took a seat in the boat the other day, and was urged to occupy his old position.

The trial of the Ward's Island keepers, Cleary and McHugh, was continued yesterday in Part I., General Sessions. Dr. David G. Hathaway of the asylum testified that he examined George Farrish before his death and found two ribs broken. He did not think that death was caused by the broken ribs.
JACKSON, Miss., April 5.--Of the 18 delegates from Mississippi to the National Republic an Convention 15 are for Sherman and 3 are for Gresham. Ex-Congressman Lynch heads the latter party.

The Senate finally passed the Bond-Purchase bill yesterday by a vivd voce vote, Mr. STEWART'S request for the yeas and nays being met with a murmur of protest from all sides.

The many friends of the Rev. C.L. Wells, Pastor of the Reformed Church of Flatbush, braved last night's storm to visit the cozy church and congratulate him upon the completion of the twenty-fifth year of his Pastorate.

The annual dinner of the New-York Alumni of Hobart College, at Geneva, took place at Clark's restaurant, on Twenty-thirdstreet, last evening. Mr. Clarence A. Seward presided, and the occasion was one of much enjoyment.

BERLIN, April 5.--Emperor Frederick slept fairly well last night and his condition is satisfactory. His indisposition of the past few days was due to slight symptoms of inflammation of the larynx, which are now subsiding. To-day, after a short walk, the Emperor received verbal reports from Gens. von Schellendorff and von Albedyll.

CLARION, Penn., April 5.--In March, 1886, John S. Everhart, a well-to-do farmer, lived with his wife, her mother, and George Fleming, an adopted child 7 years of age, half a mile from the village of Lickingville, Clarion County. Everhart was Overseer of the Poor of Washington Township.

DETROIT, April 5.--James Dougall, one of the pioneers and ex-Mayor of Windsor, opposite this city, died this morning after a lingering illness in the seventy-ninth year of his age. Boston capital entered the real estate market yesterday to competition with native gold and secured two buildings on Broadway which Richard V. Harnett offered at auction.

A certificate was received at Sanitary Headquarters yesterday of a death from the rare spinal disease, amyotrophic lateral scelerosis. The records do not show that such a disease has ever before occurred in this city. The name of the person who died was not told.

ALBANY, April 5.--The trouble in the breweries here, prophesied in THE TIMES Tuesday, has begun. There was a meeting last evening between a committee representing the Brewers and Malsters' Association of this city and the Arbitration Committee of District Assembly No. 147, Knights of Labor.
Julia Busch, manufacturer of lace caps, , at 12 Wooster-street, made an assignment yesterday to Theodore Kuck. She started the business 25 years ago and built up a good trade.

AMESBURY, Mass., April 5.--Midnight.-- The largest fire ever known in this town is now raging. The Babcock Carriage Company is burned out; also J.H. Clark Co., Walker, Shiels Co., A.N. Parry Co., and Lambert Hollander and the Hume Carriage Company, while nearly a dozen dwellings have been burned.

Delmonico's was last night invaded by the Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island and their guests, altogether about 50 in number. Although professedly friendly to water, last night's provision was declared too copious and promiscuous to allow a larger attendance at the banquet of even these, its champions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--The trial of the Rev. Howard T. Widdemer, Rector of the Church of the Beloved Disciple, which was set for today to take place before the ecclesiastical court of the Diocese of Pennsylvania, in the Church of the Epiphany, Fifteenth and Chestnut streets, was postponed for an unlocked-for cause.
A new treasure was recently added to the Lenox Library in the shape of a sixteenth century vellum manuscript valued at $12,000.

In the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, J.C. Samuels, a tailor at 246 Bowery, was complainant against Moses Strauss, a dealer in trimmings at 508 Broadway, whom he charged with conspiracy to burn his (Samuels's) store.
The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of the Actors' Fund of America took place yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the fund, 145 Fifth-avenue.

ALBANY, April 5.--The Canal Improvement bill occupied the greater portion of the session of the Senate again to-day. Senators McNaughton, Linson, and Laughlin all spoke in favor of its passage, while Senator Fassett argued in favor of a reduction of the milliondollar appropriation.
MILWAUKEE, April 5.--The Layton Art Gallery, presented to the city of Milwaukee by Frederick Layton, an old and wealthy resident, was thrown open to the public to-day.

DETROIT, April 5.--The call issued last week by Chairman Moses W. Field for a State Convention of the Greenback Party at Grand Rapids, May 10, over which there has been considerable squabbling among the leading members of that party, was considered at a meeting of the State Central Committee, held yesterday.

FARIBAULT, Minn., April 5.--At 3:30 yesterday afternoon this city was visited by the severest wind and hail storm it has ever known. Roofs were torn from stone buildings, signs were blown about like straws, and dry goods boxes and empty barrels were sent flying up Main-street like paper balls.

One of the most interesting-features of yesterday's meeting of the Democratic State Committee in the Hoffman House was a smallsized row which occurred between Hugh McLaughlin, the leader of the Democrats of Kings County, and Edward Murphy, Jr., ex-Mayor of Troy and Chairman of the State Committee.

MACON, Ga., April 5.--A negro named Jack Wilson attended Joe Jefferson's play of "Rip Van Winkle" a few weeks ago. From that time he has developed a longing to imitate Rip in his long sleep, and has almost lost his mind on the subject.
The New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne City has absorbed the Argonanta Rowing Association.

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 5.--In the Second District Republican Convention held here today Lieut.-Gov. Fuller presided. Daniel D. Hobson of Brighton and Henry C. Ide of St. Johnsbury were elected delegates to the National Republican Convention at Chicago. The platform adopted by the State Convention at Burlington yesterday was heartily indorsed.

Surrogate Ransom had before him yesterday the matter of the estate of Adrien and Lucie Crucy, the brother and sister who in 1886 were found dead in bed in their house at Twenty-seventh-street and Lexington-avenue.

The Democratic State Committee met yesterday in the Hoffman House and unanimously agreed upon May 15, at noon, as the time and the city of New-York as the place for holding the Democratic State Convention which is to choose delegates from this State to the Democratic National Convention, to be held in St. Louis on June 5.

In consequence of the recent decision of the Court of Appeals in The People against Dumas, reported in the one hundred and sixth New-York Reports, Maurice Meyer, counsel for John Bough, is trying to get him out of Sing Sing.

BOSTON, April 5.--Designer Edward Burgess didn't throw his customary flip-flap to-day at the conclusion of the fishermen's race. He wanted to, but the decks of the saucy little craft, the Carrie E. Phillips, were too wet. He broke his record, but his boat won the race handsomely.

LONDON, April 5.--Mr. Phelps, the American Minister, left London to-day for Southampton, en route to New-York. BERLIN, April 5.--Reports were current throughout this city today that Prince Bismarck had asked the Emperor to relieve him of his post on account of the state of his health. These reports were officially declared to be untrue.

Richard Schenck began suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday to have set aside the will of his father, Charles Schenck, who died Sept. 20, 1886, leaving all his estate, valued at $20,000, to his widow, the stepmother of the present contestant.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 5.--The celebrated brood mare, Nora Crenia, 29 years old, by Mahomet dam by American Eclipse, died at Mrs. McFadden's farm, in this county, yesterday.

Mrs. Ashton W. Dilke, who is a sister-inlaw of Sir Charles Dilke, a sister of Mrs. Crawford, and a noted advocate of woman's rights in England, gave the only lecture that she will deliver in this country at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon.

OIL CITY, Penn., April 5.--The failure of the Eagle Oil Refinery at Lima, Ohio, is regarded in oil circles here as a very significant event. It is believed that this will remove Ohio oil entirely from the field as a competitor of the Pennsylvania product.
ROME, April 5.--Gen. Marzano, the commander of the Abyssinian expedition, telegraphs that Ghinda and the whole adjacent plateau have been evacuated by the Abyssinians.

"Hamlet" was, acted at the Thalia Theatre in the Bowery last night in the presence of 3,000 persons, and not one in the multitude treated the play and the actors with the disrespect that always characterizes a large assemblage of English-speaking playgoers.

The action of the managers of "Captain Kidd; or, a Peerless Peeress and a Haughty Pirate," in regard to the sale of tickets for the performances this evening and to-morrow afternoon and evening for the benefit of the 'varsity boat club of Columbia College, has been severely criticised during the last two days.

A portrait of Judge Henry E. Davies was presented by his family to the University of the City of New-York yesterday afternoon in the council room of the University Building. Judge Davies, after his term in the Court of Appeals, accepted the position of Professor in the University Law School, and continued to impart his legal learning to the young men from 1871 to 1881, resigning a short time before his death.

Madison-Square Presbyterian Church was crowded to the doors last evening by a distinguished company who had braved the weather to witness the marriage of Miss Ruby S. Tilden, daughter of Henry A. Tilden, and niece of Gov. Samuel J. Tilden, to Willis S. Paine, Superintendent of the State Banking Department.

WASHINGTON, April 5.--The weary House took another recess this afternoon, after an allday fight on the Direct Tax Refunding bill, and will resume the contest to-morrow morning, constructively prolonging the legislative Wednesday assigned to the Judiciary Committee into Friday.

Coffee men had a lively time yesterday and sold to each other 131,000 bags at from to 3-5 cent a pound, or from 25 to 60 points, below Wednesday's quotations. Bearish advices from Havre started the tumble.

PARIS, April 5.--M. de Freycinet, Minister of War in the new Cabinet, will allow the War Department to retain an exclusively military character and will refer to a special secretaryship all civil and parliamentary questions.

ABERDEEN, Miss., April 5.--Last evening about dusk a negro, George Washington, beat two young white men with a heavy stick and an earthen jug, it is thought, fatally. A colored boy and girl witnessed the deed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5.--The funeral services of the late Benjamin Harris Brewster will be held on Saturday afternoon at 2 o'clock at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church on second-street. The interment at Woodlands Cemetery will be private.

RONDOUT, N.Y., April 5.--A severe electric storm prevailed along portions of the Hudson Valley to-night. In the Catskill Mountains the display of lightning was terrific. It is reported that several buildings have been struck.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5.--The shanghaeing evil has received a decided set-back in the conviction of Capt. William T. Phillips of the oyster sloop Annie M. Haywood.

NEW-HAMPTON, Iowa, April 5.--A terrible accident occurred about four miles west of this town on the Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, by which at least nine persons lost their lives and from 15 to 20 were injured.
Oscar M. Conkling, an officer in Justice Schillein's court, Brooklyn, was tried in the Brooklyn Sessions yesterday for extortion, the plaintiff being Lorenzo Cimbrola.

A goodly assemblage of ladies and gentlemen, despite the heavy dampness, graced the first annual reception of the United States Custom House Inspectors' Association last night.

When Louis James presents "Virginius" at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre Monday, April 16, he will have as part of his support a number of actors and actresses who have shone, or have aspired to shine, as amateur stars.

Patrick H. Tiney, formerly an inmate of the Kings County Ponitentiary, appealed to the Charities Commissioners yesterday for money to pay his fare to some Southern city.
CHARLESTON, S.C., April 6.--The ghosts of the great Bond-Dudley "corpse trust" will not down. A half-dozen of the grave robbers are in jail awaiting trial.
The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund announce that the drawings for the new municipal buildings will not be exhibited to the public.
William A. Kinnilly died in this city nearly 25 years ago, leaving a will in which he bequeathed $500,000 to an orphan asylum and $20,000 to his brother Edward.

CENTREVILLE, Mich., April 6.--A remarkably severe thunderstorm passed over this place yesterday afternoon, doing much damage to property and causing the loss of three lives. James Parsous's barn in Sherman Township was struck by lightning and totally destroyed. Mr. Parsons and his little child and a Mrs. Yakee being instantly killed at the same time.

Bernard Neis, more familiarly known as "Barney" Neis, an lod Eighth Ward barber, died Thursday night at his home, 173 Varick-street, of pneumonia. Neis had carried on his barber business in the vicinity for a quarter of a contury, and his shop was frequented by all schools of local politicians for years.
Sultan MULEY HASSAN has contrived to occupy, in one way or another, his full share of the world's attention during the last six or eight months.
BERLIN, April 6.--It is affirmed to-night that Emperor Frederick insists upon the marriage of his daughter to Prince Alexander.

Francis W. Pittman, who was convicted on Thursday night of murder in the second degree for stabbing his 19-year-old daughter, Rachel, to death with the leg of a carpenter's dividers on Aug. 4, 1887, was before Recorder Smyth yesterday morning for sentence.

Graduates of Oberlin College met at the Hotel Brunswick last evening, formed an Alumni association, and dined. A.L. Barber was chosen President, J.J. McKelvey Secretary, and J.J. Wilson Treasurer of the new association.

The cornerstone of the Montefiore Home for Chronic Invalids was laid yesterday. The recent Montefiore fair that was held to raise funds for the purpose netted about $158,000, and the society has $100,000 more.

The seventh season of the New-York Trade Schools, at First-avenue and Sixty-eighthstreet, was brought to a close last night by the presentation of diplomas to 364 young men who have completed their course of study in the various trades taught in the schools. ALBANY, April 6.--The second day's developments in the browers' troubles was not so successful for the Knights as was the first day. This morning the Arbitration Committee of District Assembly No. 147 went to the Albany Brewing Company's office.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 6.--The NewEngland Southern Conference this morning elected as delegates to the General Convention the Rev. C.W. Gallagher and the Rev. D.A. Jordan.

More activity, more buoyancy, improved feeling all around--these were the marks of yesterday's stock market. Nearly every stock on the list made a handsome advance. Reading was particularly active. It led in the advances, and kept there.

PARIS, April 6.--The taxation returns for March show an increase 6,100,000f. over the Ministerial estimate. M. Peytral, Minister of Finance, will present to the Chamber of Deputies a bill making the financial year begin on July 1. It will also extend the term of the present budget until the end of June.

LONDON, April 6.--A Cabinet council was hastily summoned to-day by telegraph. Many of the ministers came a long distance to take part in the conference. It is supposed that the subjects discussed were the German crisis and the proclaiming of National League meetings in Ireland. Lord Salisbury conferred for an hour to-day with Baron de Staal, the Russian Ambassador.

Dr. Henry Y. Satterlee, officiating, assisted by the Rev. William Benjamin, a warm and life long friend of the dead man. The burial was in Greenwood Cemetery.

SALT LAKE, Utah, April 6.--To-day was the second day of the Mormon conference. In the afternoon Rudger Clawson, who was convicted of polygamy and afterward pardoned by President Cleveland after three years' imprisonment, said he was convicted for obeying the law of God, and saw 300 of his brethren come there for the same offense and 200 go from the prison.

ALBANY, April 6.--The Quarantine pool was agitated by the Governor again to-day. He nominated two Democrats and one Republican this time for Quarantine Commissioners.

Fred E. Benuett of Boston made on Wedneday evening last what is probably the best score yet made with a revolver. He used a 44-calibre Smith Wesson army revolver, firing with arm extended, a distance of 30 yards, at a standard American target with a 4-inch bull'seye.

GREYTOWN, March 23.--The arrival of a portion of Admiral Luce's squadron--the Richmond, and Ossipee--off this town was a very cheering sight, especially as they brought us later papers than we had seen for some time, and afforded an opportunity for earlier communication with home than if we had been forced to wait for the irregular mail steamer.

The steamship Chateau Margaux, which sailed from this port for Bordeaux last Friday, returned yesterday, having in tow the steamship California. The California sailed from Hamburg for New-York on March 22. Her high-pressure piston gave out on April 5. During the next day she encountered a heavy gale and could make little head way. On Saturday she was picked up by the Chateau Margaux 275 miles east of Sandy Hook.

The distribution of free soup to the deserving poor closed yesterday for the season. A neat little model locomotive was made to travel back and forth on a miniature railway at 29 Broadway yesterday to show the working of the Parsons patent switch and block system, . which, it is said, will prevent accidents. It has already been highly spoken of by railway men.

Manager Palmer has just closed an engagement with Miss May Walcott, the ingenue of Josph Jefferson's company, and she will join the Madison-Square stock company next season. Miss Walcott has been playing with Jefferson for the last three years, and was before that time connected with Gillette's "Professor" company.

The American Jockey Club announce another new stake to be run at the Spring meeting this year over the Titan course of 1,400 yards. It is called the Arrow Stakes, is for 3-year-olds, and is a sweepstakes of $75 each, $25 forfeit for horses entered by May 1, or of $150, play or pay, for those entered by the usual hour on the day preceding the race.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 10.--The Leader and Sunday Dispatch offices in this city were destroyed by fire to-night. The fire started in the Leader's composing room. C.C. Wentzler, city editor of the Dispatch, and John G. Doyle, a reporter, ...

Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN in a communication elsewhere printed calls attention to the danger of a serious disappointment of the expectations of the people of this city when the new aqueduct is completed a year or so from this time.

WASHINGTON, April 10.--While there appears to be a good deal of public dissatisfaction at the obstructionist course adopted by the Democrats in Congress toward the bill to refund the direct tax of 1861, the most thoroughly indignant people about the Capitol are the lobby representatives of the State agents who are to benefit by the bill if it becomes a law.

The census of 1890 will probably show that the population of California has doubled within a decade. The census of 1880 gave the State 864,694 inhabitants. The great tide of Eastern immigration had hardly commenced then.

In the suit of Mrs. Julia A. Hershey of Philadelphia against Hugh O'Neill, the Sixthavenue dry goods merchant, to recover $20,000 damages for false imprisonment and malicious prosecution, a jury in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Coxe yesterday, returned a verdict for the defendant.

The College of the New-York Ophthalmic Hospital held its thirty-sixth annual Commencement exercises last evening in the clinic hall of the hospital building at Twenty-third-street and Third-avenue. After the entrance of the Faculty and graduates, who walked to their seats as the music played a grand march, the opening prayer was made by the Rev. H.M. McCracken.

CHICAGO, April 10.--Dr. C.W. Chase, aged 30 years, hanged himself by means of a long scarf handkerchief in a cell below the detective headquarters in the City Hall this afternoon.

Maidens armed with tambourines so lavishly decorated with gorgeous-hued silken ribbons as to be almost unrecognizable and youths armed with mandolins that were bare of all embellishment wandered about the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last evening as if it was their duty so to do.

ALBANY, April 10.--The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the judgement of the court below in the case of the People, respondent, against ex-Alderman John O'Neil, appellant. This sustains his conviction of bribery, and confirms his sentence to four and a half years in State prison and to pay a fine of $2,000.
COLUMBUS, S.C., April 10.--Moses Murphy, 13 years old, and Moses Brown, aged 16, of Orangeburg County, quarreled Sunday about "egg picnicking."

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, April 10.-- Congress last evening granted President Diaz and his Cabinet a vote of confidence. One of the features of last Sunday's bull fight was a struggle between a Comanche Indian and a bull. The Indian was "knocked out" in the first round, and is now in the hospital seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, April 10.--Capt. Lewis Smith, third Artillery, has been ordered to inspect certain garrison equipage at Washington, for which Capt. D.M. Scott, First Infantry, is responsible.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 10.--The following appointments were made to-day by Bishop Foss in the New-York East Methodist Episcopal Conference:
BERLIN, April 10.--It is stated that the late Emperor left the sum of 30 marks to every invalid soldier of the war of 1870.
D. Eckstein, United States Consul at Amsterdam, wrote Collector Magone that 40 Russians, Austrians, and Hungarians had sailed from Amsterdam March 24 on the steamship Schiedam.

The Stock Exchange district worried a good deal yesterday over the health of Jay Gould. A story was abroad representing him to be dangerously sick. Neuralgia and nervousness were reported to have him in hand again. It was not, however, till late in the day that these rumors got widely spread. Then the stock market tumbled, Missouri Pacific leading in a quick sensational slump.

Roscoe Conkling's condition at midnight last night was somewhat easier, as he had slept at intervals during the evening, after a day of great suffering, unconsciousness, and delirium. His physicians are now trying to husband his strength, hoping that, if he can be kept alive for three days, the original disease will have spent itself and exhaustion will be the main thing to be feared.

A course of lectures on "The History and Teachings of the Early Church as a Basis for the Reunion of Christendom," will be delivered at Christ Church, Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, under the auspices of the Bishop of New-York and the Church Club, beginning to-morrow evening.

The British-American Association, an organization for the promotion of naturalization among English, Scotch, and Welsh residents of the United States, held its first regular meeting at Cooper Union yesterday.

Wrapped in an American flag and draped with black crape, the casket containing the body of Gen. Quincy Adams Gillmore was carried yesterday from the dead soldier's house in Remsen-street, Brooklyn, to the Second Presbyterian Church across the way.

The orchestra lately employed at the Metropolitan Opera House is now at work rehearsing Verdi's "Otello" at the Academy. Members of the band speak highly of the music. The sale of seats for Signor Campanini's production of this opera will begin to-morrow.

ALBANY, April 10.--In all probability an investigation of the New-York Aqueduct Commission will be ordered by the Senate. A resolution calling for one was introduced by Senator Fassett this morning. It delegated the inquiry to a special committee to be appointed by President pro tem. Low.

The bill to provide for the ampler education of Indian children is likely, if it becomes a law, to give a great impetus to the school system on the reservations. Care, of course, should be exercised to see that the proposed compulsory feature works no injustice.
Drivers of Roome Co. of the Manhattan coke office, 462 West Eighteenth-street, a few days ago rebelled because J.J. Duffy, a member of the firm, hired an Italian.

The employes in the cigar factory of Straiton Storm, who have had difficulty with the Cigarmakers International Union, of which they are members, but have been suspended on charges of refusing to pay the strike assessment, say that they have been misrepresented by certain leaders of the union.

A suit in which race horse men take much interest will be tried this week in the Circuit Court in Brooklyn, and in which "Snapper" Garrison, McLaughlin, and other famous jockeys are expected to be witnesses.

ALBANY, April 10.--The friends of the Crosby High License bill managed to-day to get a postponement of its consideration until Thursday. This will give them more time in which to persuade the beery brethren among the Republicans that they are making a mistake in either amending the bill or opposing its passage as it stands.

A queer ending came to the trial of the suit of Mrs. Matilda Kirkland against the NewYork Central and Hudson River Railroad Company in Judge Van Hoesen's part of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday afternoon.

At no time since constant change in designs became a feature of the trade have the creative artists who evolve new ideas in furniture been kept more busy than in the last six months. Fashion called for more severely plain designs than had been in vogue, and the designers had to give her a blind obedience.

The boss brewers who signed the circular refusing to deal with the journeymen brewers' unions met yesterday at 2 Irving-place and discussed the boycott imposed on them by the Central Labor Unions of Brooklyn and Jersey City and the threatened boycott by the Central Labor Union of New-York.

Kerr, taken in connection with Inspector Byrnes's trip to Montreal, gave added impetus to the rumor that Keenan will return to NewYork and testify against Kerr and Richmond.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 10.--The Republicans carried the city at the municipal election to-day on the Mayoralty by over 600 majority. The day was wet and disagreeable, but a good vote was polled.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10.--The statement is published here to-day that the Oceanic Steamship Company (Spreckels's line) has signed a contract, by the terms of which it becomes the representative of the Canadian Pacific Railroad in San Francisco.

LONDON, April 10.--Lord Salisbury delivered a speech at Carnarvon, Wales, to-day. He said he was convinced that all the rulers of Europe were struggling to prevent the calamity that might result from race conflicts, in which circumstances might arise that would involve their peoples.

CHICAGO, April 10.--The prospect of a big rate war in the Southwest is growing with each day's developments. It is said that the Texas Traffic Association has concluded to wait a while and give the Fort Worth and Denver management time to show its hand before taking steps to bring about a general war upon the new road.

The members of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club will have a pleasant time at their clubhouse, 7 East Thirty-second-street, next Tuesday evening, when the graduating exercises of the Navigation Class of 1888 will take place.

Deputy Collector Wight had a long talk with Collector Magone yesterday, and was persuaded that it would be useless to resist the orders from Washington which called for his retirement from the service.

The Eighteenth-Street Methodist Episcopal Church has not been pursuing its course evenly for a year. It intimated to last year's Conference, of which Bishop Fowler was the head, that it would like a certain minister to fill its pulpit. The Conference disregarded its wish and sent another man.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10.--Sydney H. Phipps, an Englishman, 20 years of age, employed as footman by Lawyer G.L. Bispham, at 1,805 Delancey-place, has received word that he has fallen heir to a fortune of $30,000.

Very pleasant indeed was the musicale yesterday afternoon in the Stanton-Street Mission Chapel given by the friends of the Helping Hand Association. It was under the immediate management of Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt, assisted by Superintendent E.J. Herrick of the mission, who acted as director.

PITTSBURG, April 10.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Allegheny Valley Railroad Company was held at the office of the company in this city to-day.
Henry F. Gillig turned $181 more into the Custom House yesterday on account of the diamond necklace which he quietly landed at this port in January.

The New-Yorks will play the Jersey City Club to the Central League on the Polo Grounds to-day. The Chicago nine, with Van Haltren pitching, defeated the St. Louis for whom King pitched, yesterday, by a score of 7 to 2.

The fierce litigation which has been pending for the last six months between Emma Louise Davies, the widow of John M. Davies, and her brotherin-law, Robert K. Davies, was settled yesterday in the Supreme Court.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 11.--Brig. Gen. Heyerman, Adjt,-Gen. Dillingham, with Quartermaster Mentz, Commissary, early this morning reviewed the pioneers and the marine battalion, the last under command of Fleet Marine Officer Russell, with Lieuts. Spicer and Ellsworth, and Sergts Carey and Woodson, as Captains of the four companies.

HAVANA, April 11.--Seffor Galidez, the wealthy merchant who was recently kidnapped at his estate in Santa Rita by bandits, has been released on the payment of $17,000 in gold. By the bursting of a boiler on the San Lorenzo estate, province of Havana, the engineer and fireman were killed and 16 other persons were injured.

The faces of the members of the Central Methodist and Jane Street Churches were expressive of the joy they felt as they gathered in the Central Church on Seventh-avenue near Fourteenth-street yesterday to join in songs of praise and a real old-fashioned Methodist jubilee, because of the 1,000 souls converted is the recent revival services.

The Hahnemannian Society of the Homeopathic Medical College and Hospital held their sixteenth annual exercises at Association Hall last night. There was an interesting literary and musical programme, the singing of the glee club, and solos by J.H. Bryan.

PORTLAND, Oregon, April 11.--The Republican Convention, which met here to-day, contained 209 delegates, and less than 30-- these from distant counties--were represented by proxy. For the first time in many years there seems to be a spirit of harmony throughout the party ranks.

As the Fulton Ferry ferrsboat Fulton was on her way from Brooklyn to this city about 3 o'clock last evening she came into collision with the tugboat Willie opposite pier 22 East River. William Burns a deckhand on the tug, fell overboard, but was promptly fished out. The damage to the tug was $200. No one was injured. Capt. John Baulser was in charge of the ferryboat and Capt. Delevreda commanded the tug.

NYACK, April 11.--The village of Spring Valley, Rockland County, which for several years past has been in an inactive state so far as the business interests of the place are concerned, is to receive a boom that causes general rejoicing among the people there.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 11.--State Treasurer Bamberg has issued a call for purchasers for $311,577 of new South Carolina 4 per cent, bonds and stock certificates which will be issued to refund deficiency bonds and stocks maturing July 1 next.
Forty-six wharf-property leases for one year were put up at auction yesterday at Pier A North River, by order of the Dock Commissioners. All but 10 of the leases were sold and prices ran well.

The reasons given by Recorder SMYTH for refusing to authorize a resubmission of the charges against JAY GOULD and RUSSELL SAGE to the Grand Jury are not such as will satisfy the minds of those who had previously any doubt on the subject.
GAFFNEY CITY, April 11.--The truth concerning the recent double marriage of Miss Florence Little of this place to Mr. Augustus Mintz and then to Dr. D.C.Atkinson of Chester, S.C., is out at last.

Mr.Jay Gould was at his business office yesterday, though he did not remain a long time. His friends all insist that he is not seriously sick. They add what he himself has been saying for a half-dozen years or more--that he is out of the stock market.

Mme. Dis Debars, so long the priestess of the Temple, 166 Madison-avenue, once the home of Luther R. Marsh, is now is the meshes of the law. She and her confederates--her husband and the Lawrences, father and son--were arrested yesterday, and they spent the night behind prison bars at Police Headquarters.

Henry A.Cram asked the Park Commissioners yesterday to open One Hundred and Eleventh-street through the Polo Grounds. When asked why he didn't appeal to the Board of Aldermen, he said; "I'm ashamed that there is such a body. The board is a disgrace to this city. MONTREAL, April 11.--A ripple of excitement pervaded French-Canadian society to-day, when it became known that senator Thibaudeau's daughter had eloped to New-York with an ex-policeman, a married man named Racicot.

CLEVELAND, April 11.--On accepting the office of President of the Fifth Congressional District Republican Convention at Fostoria today ex-Gov. Foster made hold to say that he was sure Blaine was elected President in 1884, but that the Democrats cheated him out of the office.

BOSTON, April 11.--By virtue of the provisions of the imported contract labor law, the Customs authorities to-day prevented the landing of 16 sailors, who came to this port on the packet On Time, from Liverpool, Nova Scotia.

The first of the series of Wednesday matinees of "The Wife" was given at the Lyuemm Theatre yesterday afternoon, and the result fully vindicated Manager Frohman's judgment in arranging for them. The house was packed to overflowing by an audience composed largely of women and children, and standing room was at a premium. "The Wife" can he seen every Wednesday afternoon of the present month.

OMAHA, Neb., April 11.--Mrs. Albert Dumkee, who resided near Columbus, this State, was murdered by her husband Monday night last. Dumkee left the house after dinner and went to Columbus, where he remained all the afternoon.

BERLIN, April 11.--The Post says that all fear of Prince Bismarck resigning has disappeared and that the idea of the betrothal of Princess Victoria to Prince Alexander of Battenberg has been abandoned.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday heard arguments on the proposition to equip the Police Department with a patent signaling system by which every officer when on duty will be enabled to communicate with the station house or with Headquarters.
PARIS, April 11.--Noisy political meetings were held at Roubaix and Avesnes, Department of the Nord, last night. The orators had much difficulty in speaking so great was the confusion.

A marvelous butterfly exhibition, consisting of the collection of Berthold Neumoegen, was opened yesterday at the Eden Musee. The collection comprises about 100,000 specimens of the most curious and beautiful butterflies from all parts of the world.

Roscoe Conkling has a fighting chance for life. That was the substance of what the doctors said at midnight as to the condition of their patient. He had been sleeping quietly since 9 o'clock, and, compared with his state just 24 hours earlier, he was better.

The election in Jersey City was conducted entirely on the basis of the High License Local Option bill. The saloon keepers made a desperate effort to punish the Republican Party, which had made itself responsible for the law, and the result was that in every part of the city the most phenomenal majorities ever known in the political history of the city were rolled up.
The New-York Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday, on motion of Henry James, indorsed the bill pending in Congress to improve the condition of commercial travelers in several States.

MARION, Ohio, Apri1 11.--The members of the Marion and Huber Gun Clubs of this place fell into line at an early hour this morning, and began the destruction of sparrows with shotguns and Floberts at a premium of 10 cents per dozen.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 11.--An old colored woman, familiarly known in the neighborhood as "Granny Rose," died at Davidson College yesterday morning at the age of 131 years. Her mind gave way several years age, and last year she became totally blind.
Two new cases of smallpox were reported yesterday, one from One Hundred and Ninthstreet and Park-avenue and the other from the New-York Dispensary.

Dr.Cornelius R.Agnew is seriously ill at his residence, 266 Madison-avenue, and yesterday, during the day, his condition was regarded as critical. He was taken ill on Monday and was provented from taking part in the consultation over Mr. Conkling. His trouble later, developed into peritonitis. Late last night, however he felt better and was resting quietly.

Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court decided yesterday that the Third-Avenue Railroad Company is entitled to a peremptory mandamus requiring the Commissioner of Public Works to permit the company to make the necessary excavations for the laying of cables along the line of its road.

The Democratic Couuty, City, and Assembly District Committees in joint session last night adopted without a dissenting vote a resolution in favor of the renomination of Grover Cleveland. INDINAPOLIS, Ind., April 14.--The College Avenue Armory was fired by an incendiary this morning and destroyed. It was occupied by the Richardson Zouaves and Indianapolis Light Artillery. There were a four-gun battery and a Gating gun belonging to the Government in the building, also damaged.

The statistics of deposits in Irish savings banks, given in the Registrar-General's recent report, prove the truth of my statement that, speaking generally, Irish poverty is a myth. The precise figures are, on Dec, 31, 1881, 3,765,000, end on Dec. 31, 1887, 4,975,000.

CHICAGO, April 17.--An explosion in McAvoy's brewery this afternoon caused a loss of $5,000 to the proprietors, injured two workmen, smashed glass, and shook up the neighborhood. The cause of the explosion was the ignition from some unknown cause of dust in the milling room, on tho second floor of the main building.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--The great tariff reform contest which has been awaited with so much interest, and which will engage the attention of Congress and the country for several weeks, is at last formally under way. It began at 1 o'clock to-day, and the opening skirmish lasted exactly four hours.

There was a reception and review last evening at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, in Brooklyn. On the grand stand erected on the armory floor sat Brig.-Gen. McLeer and staff. BRUSSELS, April 17.--The Independence Belge reports that the establishment of a Regency for Belgium is imminent.

DUBLIN, April 17.--Joph Dillon was arrested in this city this afternoon and conveyed to Collon, County Louth. Mr. Dillon was taken before a magistrate, and after a preliminary hearing was liberated on bail. His trial was then to take place at Mell on May 9.

The American Association championship season opens to-day, the Brooklyns playing the Clevelands in Washington Park.

Half a carload of furniture, directed to Robert E. DeLacy, 103 Mackay-street, Montreal, was shipped on the Hudson River Railroad yesterday. It comprised all of the household goods of the ex-Alderman, which had been stored for some time, and included an upright plane, a case of large mirrors and other valuable articles.

Rose Coghlan, the actrees, is confined to her home in, West Thirty-first-street by a sprained ankle. The injury was sustained by slipping, last evening, on the side walk at Broadway and Thirty-first-street. In consequence she could not fill her regular engagement at Wal lack's Theatre. She will probably be unable to go out for some time.

BUTTE, Montana, April 17.--A lady about 45 years of age arrived in this city last week and stopped at the Centennial Hotel. She was taken down with pneumonia, from which she died Thursday morning. The death of the woman deserves more than passing notice.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 17.-Reports from the Milk River district on the Manitoba Road state that there has been considerable damage done and freight traffic on the Manitoba Road from Forts Benton and Buford to Helena has been practically at a standstill since Wednesday last.

The name of Roscoe Conkling is one that will live in this State. No more striking personality ever appeared in the arena of New-York politics. From his youth until death claimed him he stood in the glare of publicity. In all that time no breath touched his integrity. Retirement from official station hardly lessened public interest in the man.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 17.--People hereabouts are being treated to a novel spectacle, nothing lees than gold digging in the heart of the city. On the wastes known as the Cove lands, north of the Union Station, rich placer digging is going on that will probably yield big for two or three months to come.

The hearing before Referee Burrill in the petition suit for a dissolution of the Third Order of St. Francis was continued yesterday. Mgr. Preston was asked if an interdict had been put by the church upon St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He replied that he had put a prohibition on the society.
SAN FRANCISO, April 17.--Drafts--Sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

MEXICO, Mo., April 17.--Samuel Apgar, an old and wealthy citizen of this city, was killed by a burglar in his house at 3 o'clock this morning. The assassination has caused great excitement, and parties are now out searching the country for the murderer.

It is difficult to understand the course of Mayor HEWITT with reference to certain very important public improvements. The plan for widening and extending Elmstreet has been before the public for a long time, and it seems to have the universal approval of the people.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 17.--"Jack" Hazzard, Teller of the Fort Pitt Bank, is missing. One of his last official acts on Saturday was to have a check cashed at the Allegheny National Bank for $5,000. This is nothing unusual, since it is a common occurrence for Cashiers and Tellers to pass checks current at neighboring banks ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17.--The Supreme Court to-day handed down an important decision. It was in the case of Robert Patterson, a Miami County prisoner in the penitentiary, sent up on a five years' sentence for burglary, which sentence will expire in 1890.

George A. Stainway, eldest son of William Steinway, was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Ottilie Roesler, daughter of August Roesler, of the firm of William Wicks Co. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's father, 17 East Seventy-third-street, the parlors being decorated by Klunder.
OTTAWA, April 17.--After four hours' discussion in Committee of the Whole the Fisheries Treaty bill was this evening read a third time and passed the Commons, thus adopting the treaty.

CHICAGO, April 17.--Four members of the Board of Trade were suspended by the Directors at the meeting this afternoon for trading out of hours. They were E.M. Switzer, 5 days: A.P. Hart, 10 days; Thomas O'Brien of Reynolds, Lindblom Co., 5 days, and Edward Partridge, 5 days. John Moore was reprimanded by the board.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 17.--John S. Simon, the defaulting Treasurer of Darke County, was received at the penitentiary to-day on a six-year sentence, the charge being embezzlement. He was also fined $47,970 and costs of prosecution amounting to $239.

Ephraim George Squier, the well-known archaeologist, died at 6:30 o'clock yesterday morning at the residence of his brother. Frank Squier, 310 Lafayette-avenue. Brooklyn. His death was not unexpeced, but was the result of a sickness of many years' standing, which brourght his scientific labors practically to an end 17 years ago.

Roscoe Conkling died at 1:50 o'clock this morning at his apartments in the Hoffman House. In the circle gathered around his deathbed were his wife, his daughter, Mrs. Oakman, and his nephews, Aldermen Alfred R. Conkling and Judge Alfred C. Coxe. His last moments were passed in unconsciousness.

DANBURY, Conn., April 17.--W.H. Hawley, one of the leading druggists of this place, this morning shot and fatally wounded his brother-in-law, Virgil Barnum, in Hawley's residence. He fired five shots at Barnum, two of which took effect. The shooting was the outcome of a family quarrel.

ALBANY, April 17.--The High License bill passed another danger spot to-day, and is now ready for final passage. It was discussed by the Senate in Committee of the Whole for nearly four hours, and amendment after amendment was offered by the Democrats, only to be rejected by the 16 Republicans who took firm ground against any changes whatever being permitted.
