NEW-HAVEN, Conn. April 17.--Two sons of Sidney Wilson of Naugatuck, both of whom are under 12 years of age, left their home some time Friday last. Their absence at first occasioned no anxiety. They had not, however been heard of up to this evening. Their father is at a loss to know what has happened to them and is almost, distracted with grief and anxiety.

The Riverside Day Nursery, at 303 West Sixty-seventh-street, is in need of money. The nursery is an excellent institution and a great benefit to many poor women of its neighborhood who are compelled to work for the support of their families.

WINONA, Minn., April 18.--During the recent floods, while the river did not rise so high as it has as times before, nevertheless, much damage was caused, and occasioned great loss to the lumber merchants of the city.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 18.--At 5 o'clock this afternoon a very quiet wedding was solemnized at 192 Farmington-avenue. The bride was Miss Lucy Jones, daugter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jones, and the groom was Mr. Edward Franklin Meeker, Postmaster at Bridgeport, Conn.

CINCINNATI, April 18.--Benjamin E. Hopkins, the convicted ex-Assistant Cashier of the Fidelity National Bank, was to-day sent to the Penitentiary at Columbus to serve out his term of 7 years and 8 months. He said he was a very sick man, and that he expected to be brought back from Columbus a corpse.

BALTIMORE, April 18.--The Baltimore and Ohio Directors held their monthly meeting today. The net earnings for the month of March were $366,729, against $544,837 for 1887, a decrease of $178,108. Of this decrease, $162,814 was on the lines east of the Ohio River.

Inspector Edward Morgan of Surveyor Beattie's staff has reported at the Custom House that he discovered Charles J. De'Vertu, a passenger on the steamer Lord of the Isles, attempting to smuggle a case of decorated china. The matter is being investigated.

READING, Penn., April 18.--The Brooke Iron Company, at Birdsborough, this county, today notified its puddlers of a reduction in their wages on May 1 from $3.52 to $3.25 per ton. The reason given for the reduction is that the price of puddled iron is very low.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 18.--The town of Hazelton, near here, was the scene of a fearful explosion yesterday, which seriously injured four persons, and will probably result in their death.

This is a good time and a bad time to buy. It is a lucky season for the buyer and a rather discouraging one for the seller. One of those depressing spells in trade that bother the commercial men occasionally without any apparent reason is on now, and they are trying to stimulate business by making a general reduction in prices.

John R.G. Hassard, for many years the musical critic and subsequently the literary editor of the New-York Tribune, died yesterday morning, of consumption, actor an illness which extended over a number of years, at his house, 218 East Eighteenth-street, in this city.

Springfield, Mass., has been agitating itself over the question whether Beethoven or Haydn was the greater symphonic composer. The editor of the Homestead of that city submitted the question to musicians and crities in Boston, Chicago, New-York, and other places.

BEREA, Ohio, April 18.--Henry Basch, a Pole employed in the stone quarries, went on a spree last night with some companions. At 7:30 o'clock this morning, when the wholo party was in his humble home, he ordered his wife to go and get some beer.

PARIS, April 18.--The Figaro says that Gen. Boulanger will issue a significant political manifesto, in which he will propose the revision of the Constitution.

Two young men who make a precarious living as bunko steerers made a most unfortunate mistake yesterday. They were in Broadway, near Vesey-street, when they saw an Englishman who looked as if he had just landed approaching.

TROY, N.Y., April 18.--The town meetings in Clinton County yesterday resulted in the election of eight Republican and six Democratic Supervisors. In Plattsburg Edward C.O'Brien, the high license candidate, was elected Excise Commissioner by a majority of 238 over Richard Stone, the no-license candidate.

TROY, N.Y., April 18.--Two jewelers of this city have been swindled by a very clever trick. A stranger in the garb of a clergyman called at the jewelry store of Samuel C. Tappin about 1 o'clock and asked to be shown diamonds.
Mr.Gilbert's performance of Sir Peter Teazle gave great enjoyment to a large audience at Wallack's Theatre last evening.
Charles A. Fleron, a young locksmith at Paterson, N.J., was recently forbidden the house of George B. Carleagh, to whose daughter, Ida, he had been paying has devotions.

LONDON, April 18.--In the House of Commons this afternoon the Right Hon. Edward Heneage moved the passage of the bill to legalize marriage with a deceased wife's sister. The motion occasioned a sharp debate, but was finally carried by a vote of 239 to 182.
Katie McGuire, 19 years old, was taken to Bellevue Hospital suffering from a mild type of insanity, said to have been produced by an immoderate use of quinine.
ST.LOUIS, Mo., April 18.--The failure of Moses Fraley, the biggest bear in the St. Louis market, was announced on 'Change at 11 o'clock this morning, and created great excitement.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 18.--Some years ago Peter Smith removed with his family from the adjoining town of Mamakating to a farm on the southern shore of Cayuga Lake.

CHICAGO, April 18.--The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy has announced a reduced scale of rates to Colorado points to meet the competition of the new Denver and Fort Worth Road, the cut to go into effect to-morrow.

Dr.Cornelius Rea Agnew, the distinguished eye and ear specialist, died yesterday at 2:45 o'clock at his home, Madison-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street.
Mr.JOHN SHERMAN was again indorsed so far as life service goes, by the Republican Convention of Ohio yesterday as a candidate for the Presidential nomination.
Edwin B.Haskell of Boston is at the Brevoort House. Ex--Gov. John L. Routt of Colorado is at the Victoria Hotel.

Miss Frances Livingston, daughter of William S.Livingston, was married to James A.Glover of Mount Vernon yesterday at noon by Mgr. Preston at the residence of the bride's father, 113 East Seventeenth-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 18.--Further returns from the interior of the State show unexpected heavy Democratic gains. Nicholl's majority will probably reach 75,000 or 80,000. Parishes that never failed to go Republican heretofore are Democratic for the first time.

The bill proposed in the Senate to repeal the section of the law of July 28, 1866, which makes certain persons ineligible to appointment to places in the army, does not seem to involve immediate considerations of practical utility.

At Memphis yesterday the opening handicap race at three-quarters of a mile was won by Sam Harper, Jr., 109 pounds, by a half length from Huntress, Bonnie King third, the time being 1:16. Sally O., 112 pounds, won the 2-year-old five-furlong dash in 1:04 , with Irish Dan second, and Entry third.

CHICAGO, April 18.--The switchmen and some of the enginemen who left the Burlington Road and went on strike two months ago have been circulating petitions among business men in this city addressed to the Inter-State Commerce Commission asking them to investigate the trouble.
There was but one new case of smallpox reported yesterday, a man who had applied for admission to Bellevue Hospital.
MENLO PARK, Cal., April 18.--One of the stables on Senator Stanford's stock farm at Palo Alto was destroyed by fire last night, and seven of the valuable horses perished in the flames.
SHAMOKIN, Penn., April 18.--The Philadelpliia and Reading Coal and Iron Company are reducing the wages of their minors. Many miners have been suspended indefinitely.

ST. LOUIS, April 18.--Vice-President H. H. Clark of the Missouri Pacific was seen at his home to-night and asked if it was true that a Receiver for the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway had been applied for.
The opposition to the lock-out ordered by the employing brewers has collapsed without a cuntest. The men have seen that they were beaten, and as many of them as could have returned to work.

DETROIT, Mich., April 18.--The wholesale jewelry firm of Burt Huriburt is in an embarrassed condition, but the senior member this morning expressed confidence that matters could be arranged without an assignment being necessary.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 18.--At the Democratic caucuses in Buffalo to-night Cleveland delegates were elected in all the wards with no opposition whatever.

The inquest into the death of Pittman, the murderer and suicide, was concluded yesterday. In their verdict the jury stated that they were unable to discover who supplied Pittman with the poison. They criticised the management of the Tombs, and said it was a disgrace to the city. It was their opinion that the method now employed in conveying prisoners to and from the Tombs is unsatisfactory.
ALBANY, April 18.--Representatives of a syndicate of New-York capitalists have purchased the Olcott Iron Works in this city, paying in the neighborhood of $125,000 for the plant.

Everything boomed on the Stock Exchange yesterday. New-York and New-England leaped up two or three more points--a feat that has become quite a part of its regular daily performance lately. Oregon Transcontinental awakened out of its long sleep and did some jumping, too, its advance being almost as great as New-England's. The Northern Pacifics also were in booming mood, and the coalers--Roading, Lackawanna, and Jersey Central--all sailed upward.

LONDON, April 19.--I get a dispatch at midnight from Berlin saying that there is deep excitement throughout the capital over the gradual sinking of the Kaiser. It is a most significant and unexpected fact that the anxiety and display of personal interest on the part of the population is much greater than it was in the case of the old Emperor.

At last terms have been agreed upon between Short Stop Ward of the New-York Club and President Day and that player lies agreed to cover the short field for a salary of $4,000. The Second Battery celebrated last evening the opening of its new armory, in Broadway, between Fifty-second and Fifty-third streets. The armory floor was crowded with guests, the military portion of whom were in full-dress uniform.

LONDON, April 19.--The Cunard Line steamship Gallia, Capt. Murphy, from New-York April 11 for Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 9:30 o'clock to-night.

CHICAGO, April 19.--The strike of the switchmen at the Chicago and Northwestern yards last night was adjusted this morning and the men are now working contentedly. This morning the affair was settled by the appointment of Thomas Nash, the oldest switchman in the yard, to the position of yardmaster, after which the strike ended.

The first Board of Directors of the new Players' Club held a meeting yesterday afternoon at the residence of Lawrence Hutton, and organized to begin active work. BOSTON, April 19.--By a vote of 109 to 41 the House to-day defeated a bill to exempt laborers in cities from the Civil Service act.

The annual election of the Electrical Club, in East Twenty-second-street, was held last evening. Members who went around to vote, eat an electrical dinner, and listen to a sparkling address by the President, found that the front door opened by an invisible agency.
RIVIERE DU LOUP, Quebec, April 19.--At 12:40 this morning a slight shock of earthquake was felt here. It passed from north to south, and lasted only three or four seconds.

BALTIMORE, April 19.--Mr. A. S. Abell, founder of the Baltimore Sun, died shortly after 3 o'clock this morning at his residence. Charles and Madison streets, in this city, in the eightysecond year of his age. He had suffered from no organic or special complaint, but died of general failure of the vital powers.

LONDON, April 19.--Our Paris correspondent sends an account of what seems to have been a momentous day in Paris. In the midst of bright sunshine coming between two heavy April showers; Boulanger made his triumphal tour through the streets to the Chamber of Deputies. Since the fall of the empire no similar ovation has been given any public man.

BERLIN, April 26.--Mr. Pendleton, the American Minister, while traveling to Frankfort, was stricken with apoplexy. He was taken to the hospital at Wiesbaden, where he now lies.

LOUISVILLE, April 20.--A.G. Owings, shot by Richard Hunt at Owingsville Saturday, April 7, died yesterday. The ball from a 48-calibre pistol struck Owings in the forehead, between the eyes, and penetrated five inches.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 20.--A uniformed club of 1,000 Blaine Republicans, under the leadership of Mr. T.M. Curtin of this city, will go to the Chicago Convention in June, Mr. Curtin has for nearly two years been organizing clubs of Blaine admirers in Missouri, and he claims that he has 200,000 sympathizers in the State, one-sixth of whom are Democrats.

The profits on the national investment in newspaper business, while still considerable, show a slight diminution. BERLIN, April 22.--The following bulletin was issued at 9 o'clock this morning: "The Emperor passed a more quiet night. His fever has moderated and his general condition is better."
DUBLIN, April 22.--Mr. O'Brien spoke at Fermoy to-day. He was not molested. He declared that the meeting would have been held if it had been proclaimed.

The Anti-Poverty Society celebrated yesterday the anniversary of its first public meeting. The large hall in Cooper Union, in which the meeting began at 3 o'clock, was filled with an audience made up principally of women. Henry Smith, Congressman for the Fourth District of Wisconsin, made a long address.

Four hundred men, rough and hardy, but neatly dressed, sat on the benches of the Avenue A Mission last evening and munched sandwiches and drank coffee. After their hunger had been thoroughly appeased a short service was conducted by Col. H.H. Hadley, the Superintendent ...

CHICAGO, April 22.--There is trouble in the Republican camp over holding the National Convention in the Auditorium Building. The Laborites have given it out that they will fight the men nominated under the Auditorium roof, for the reason that nonunion labor was employed in putting up the building.

Standing room was not to be had at the Fifth-Avenue Riding Academy last night. The trotting evolutions by female riders were well performed, Miss F. Ehret, who commanded, and Miss G. Roesler doing remarkably well.
Judge Patterson fulfilled the expectation of Thomas B. Kerr's lawyers, as well as of the public generally, yesterday morning by denying their motion for a change of venue.
ALBANY, April 23.--Adjutant-General Porter, before leaving for Europe, arranged for the State Encampment at Peekskille. It will cover six weeks, and includes these New-York and Brooklyn regiments:
The annual charter elections in the villages of Sing Sing and Port Chester take place to-day for the election of Presidents, Trustees, Collectors, and Treasurers.
MILFORD, Penn., April 23.--Frank Detrick, who lives two miles below this place, discovered a hawk pursuing a smaller bird high in the air near the Detrick farm.

HARRISBURG, April 23.--John Hester was an employe of the National Rolling Mill at Duncannon, Perry County. He weighed over 200 pounds. A few days ago he was oiling the neck of the iron rolls between which the bars of iron are passed in the process of rolling.

For the last two years Gov. HILL has taken every opportunity to pose as the champion of home rule for the city of NewYork, but the most outrageous interference with the administration of its affairs that has been known in recent times has come mainly from him.
LEOMINSTER, Mass., April 23.--The will of Capt. Leonard Burrage of North Leominster gives for benevolent objects and to special friends over $80,000.
A large part of Brooklyn went out doors yesterday to witness the great Barnum parade, and they were well repaid by a sight of neat horses, ponderous elephants, shambling bears, and gilt carriages.
LONDON, April 23.--The steamship Jersey City, (Br.,) Capt. Govier, from New-York April 7, arr. at Bristol to-day.

MARQUETTE, Mich., April 23.--Yesterday afternoon a party of log drivers, on a log drive in Baraga County, attempted to thaw some dynamitc over a cook stove in their shanty. The result was a terrible explosion which killed Patrick Ratigan, William Morrison, and Peter Somerville and severely injured Malcolm McEachlin and Edward McGill.
Seventeen years ago a railroad was projected up in the Northwest to be known as the Michigan, Canada and Chicago.

Hofrath Chronegk, the general intendant of the Ducal Saxe-Meiningen company, has cabled to C. De Grimm, the artist, that he will visit this city about the middle of June to make preliminary arrangements for the appearance of the celebrated dramatic company of Duke George II. in this country.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 23.--The Record will announce to-morrow that Editor B.F. Dilley of Kingston, who mysteriously disappeared nearly a month ago and who was supposed to have been murdered is alive and well. He is in Denver, Col., and will leave there to-morrow for home. Though not known positively, it is believed that he was temporarily insane.

At the meeting of the Board of Managers or the Brooklyn Sunday School Union, hold in the building of the Young Men's Christian Association last evening, the resolutions were introduced to secure the admission of the Unitarian and Universalists to the annual parade, but they were defeated by a vote of 20 to 6.

In response to the letter sent by the Central Labor Union to Collector Magone relative to the admission of the 16 marble cutters who arrived from Italy some days ago a reply has been sent which states the condition of affairs.

Examples multiply of the folly and futility of legislation in the interest of "the laboring class." It is not more foolish than legislation in behalf of any other class, as, for instance, the class of hereditary landowners, but it is more futile.
MOUNT UNION, Penn., April 23.--A pair of barn martins spent two days last week in constructing one of their mud nests under the caves of a barn in Warriorsmark Township.
Funeral services over the remains of William B. Dinsmore took piace yesterday morning at Calvary Church, Fourth-avenue and Twentyfirst-street, a large number of business men being present.

I learn that the Empress Victoria, whose nervous system has been almost shattered by the worries and anxieties of the last year, has been suffering severely from neuralgia since she left San Remo. The Empress has been advised to visit Schwalbach early in the Summer, in order that she may take a course of the baths there.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 23.--The family of J. C. Waltmyer, repairman on the Marietta Branch of the Reading and Columbia Railroad, residing in West Hempfield township, has been terribly affilicted. About 10 days ago his son William was taken within a few days,. Then three other children, aged 5,8, and 11 years, were taken ill and died within a day of each other.
CHICAGO, April 23.--Miss Emma F. Price, the pretty daughter of the rich baking-powder manufacturer and President of the Lincoln National Bank, eloped last week and now Dr. Price has a son-in-law.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 23.--The firm of Schleiter Hess, dry goods dealers on Marketstreet, was closed to-day while the assignee, J. McDowell, was having the stock appraised. The cause of the assignment could not be learned, except that it was at the instance of some Eastern creditors of the firm.

The second week of the Italian opera season under Signor Campanini's management at the Academy of Music began last evening, when Verdi's "Otello" was once more performed before a highly-delighted audience.
HARRISBURG, April 23.--Jason Harkness of Pine Creek recently went to New-York City to pay a visit to his friend John Garrison, an employe of the Standard Oil Company.
A neat little plot to release from the Bangor Jail the robbers who raided the property of the miser, Peter Bennett, at Newport, on Dec. 4, has been nipped in the bud.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 23.--To-day Richard Bale, a colored man, was convicted of setting fire to the barns of George Stout, near Monmonth Junction. There have been half a dozen incendiary fires in a few months, and Bale is the first man to be caught. He was sentenced to seven years in the State prison.

The Episcopal cathedral project, that seems to be making little progress toward the hoped-for consummation, is really making haste with as great speed toward completion as is consistent with the vastness of the proposed building.

On July 30 Patrick Neville was crossing the Bloomfield Branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, near Newark, when the rig was struck by a train, the horses killed, and the wagon smashed. Neville had one leg broke. He sued the road for a large sum, and last night the jury awarded him $4,200.
There was an amused smile on many faces in the throng that sat and stood in Part II. of the Superior Court yesterday morning when Senator Pierce had shot his bolt.

An old-fashioned boom stalked into Wallstreet yesterday and the Stock Exchange had a merrier time than it has known in months. Everything was inclined to go up. Everybody was happy. There wasn't a bear to be seen anywhere. The bulls had the market all to themselves.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 23.--There is a right royal row in the Corean Legation. The members of the legation are homesick, and say that they will return to Corea.

The Republicans and Democrats of New Jersey are both making active preparations for the holding of the State Conventions at which delegates to the National Conventions are to be chosen.

The Sixty-ninth Regiment Veterans, at the armory last evening, celebrated the twentyseventh anniversary of the departure of the Sixty-ninth for the seat of war. The platform of the drill hall was decorated with the battle flags of the Veteran Corps.

It would not be remarkable if there should be many converts to the Darwinian theory as to the origin of man in this city during this week at least among those who will attend the performances at the Star Theatre.

Last Wednesday, at a parish church in Devonshire, a spinster of 75 led to the altar a bachelor of 66. Both have been for some time in receipt of parish relief, and as they left the church together after the ceremony they were well pelted with rise by a crowd of their neighbord.

CHICAGO, April 23.--The fourth and last week of the McCaull opera season was brilliantly inaugurated to-night by the production of "Falka" at the Chicago Opera House before even a larger audience than usually greets this favorite organization.

The approaches to the General Term room of the Supreme Court presented an unusual scene at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning. A procession of lawyers had been filing up stairs for some time before. Never were lawyers more decorous.
Ex-Senator John Birdsall visited Long Island City yesterday, and while in Miller's Hotel, near the ferry, met Mayor Patrick Gleason.
DETROIT, Mich., April 23.--There has been current a report for several days that the well known and extensive dry goods house of Metcalf Brothers Co. of this city was financially embarrassed.
COOPER, Texas, April 23.--Three miles east of here yesterday B.F. Boydston shot Miss Luin Frasier, and then blew out his brains.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 23.--The effort now being made in Washington to secure recognition for the only Georgia regiment which fought on the Union side during the late war is not meeting with success.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 23.--The Republican city primaries to-day elected delegates to the Congressional Convention, who are unanimously in favor of sending James B. Fisher of this city to the Chicago Convention. Fisher is for Blaine first, if he is a candidate. His second choice is Depew.

The Young Men's Democratic Club last evening heartily indorsed the Administration of President Cleveland, and recommended that the Democratic State Convention, to be held in this city May 15, should be instructed to vote for the President's renomination.

John, alias "Red," Leary, who was struck on the head with a brick thrown by one of a party with whom he had been quarreling in the Knickerbocker Cottage, on Sixth-avenue, Saturday, died at the New-York Hospital last evening.

On supplemental affidavits by John Hemmens and Charles Shirley, Judge Barrett yesterday reconsidered his former decision and granted an order of arrest in the conspiracy action brought by them against Anthony Comstock, John Noble Stearns, and James S. Stearns.

A commission of four members, one of them being the Mayor, ex-officio, was constituted a long while ago, with full authority over all the electrical conductors in the city, and with the special ministerial duty of changing the overhead systems to underground systems by the means of subways suitable for the wires of companies using pole conductors.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 23.--Mayor Francis and the Chairmen of the various local committees inspected to-day the hall to be used by the Democratic National Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23.--A dispatch from South Vineland, N.J., says the barn of Mrs. Ellen Buckmister was destroyed by fire yesterday afternoon, together with two horses and a cow. Mrs. Chase, the aged mother of Mrs. Buckmister, and the latter's 10-year-old son went into the barn to rescue the stock and were burned to death, the roof having fallen in, imprisoning them. The property was not insured.
The auction sale of furniture at the Pottier Stymus warerooms in Fifth-avenue was continued yesterday. It lasted from 11 A. M. to 6 P.M. without interruption.

PITTSBURG, April 23.--Pinkerton men are still on duty at the Edgar Thomson Steel Works. There were no strikers about the place to-day, and it is evident that they intend to hold strictly aloof from the company's property as long as the strike lasts.
The ticketing of the immigrants who landed at Castle Garden yesterday took longer than usual, and there was a good deal of confusion, but they were pretty well cleared out by night.

As Mary Murphy, aged 25, of 492 Pearl-street; Maggie Gillmore, aged 19, of 1 Batavia-street; Julia O'Brien of 1 Batavia-street, and Jennie Seegal of 60 Baxter-street, were coming through Baxter-street, at Bayard, last night, a dog jumped out at them, biting Mary Murphy on the right arm and the other three girls on the legs. The dog was shot by a policeman and the girls had their wounds cauterized.

Lawyer Frederick B. House, in defense of Samuel smith Brewster, in Part II., General Sessions, summed up the case for the prisoner yesterday. The case was given to the jury by Recorder Smyth at 6:30 P.M., which, after being out until 10:15 o'clock, returned with a verdict of murder in the second degree.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23.--Capt. Burns, a Deputy United States Marshal, who has returned from Arizona, where he went to hunt down the Stein Pass train robbers, reports that they were burned out and shot down by Sheriff Paul and some Mexican soldiers.
ALBANY, April 23.--Senator Erwin asked the Senate to-night to allow the High License bill to be read on Wednesday or Thursday of this week.
Thomas Yound, aged 45 years, of 122 Concord-street, went to Chambers-Street Hospital April 14 suffering, as he supposed, from the bite of an insect.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 23.--Central NewYork was this morning treated to another example of the dishonesty of a bank official. The Seneca Falls Savings Bank is closed and N.P. B. ORIENT, Long Island, April 23.--The schooner Nelson of Port Jefferson, in ballast, sunk in this harbor on Sunday. She sprung a leak in Plum (Gut. The Captain and crew reached the shore in a small boat. Wrockers will try to raise the vessel.
The Columbia, Yacht Club held its annual meeting last evening at Maling's Hall, on the Boulevard, between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth streets. About 100 members were present.
CHICAGO, April 23.--The Chicago Democracy dined in state to-night, when the fifth annual banquet of the Iroquois Club was held in the great hall of the Palmer House.

Cook, who was run over by a train and killed at that place this morning Mr. Cook was a man of liberal education and much ability.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 23.--Sheriff Clarkson will probably not have a chance to hand the Italian, Pallidona, who is at the Fairfield County Jail under sentence of death.
A meeting of delegates of the Harlem River Boating Association was held yesterday at the office of T.G. Barry, in the Equitable Building, to decide upon a date for the Spring regatta.
LONDON, April 23.--A scene occurred in the House of Commons this evening on a question being raised by Mr. Shaw-Lefevre regarding the increase of sentences in Ireland in appeal cases.

LOUISVILLE, April 23.--Col. Clark's decision to run the Kentucky Derby on some day other than the opening one was overruled by the Board of Directors to-day, and the Derby will be run on the opening day of the meeting as usual.

August Loos and Rudolph Schneider, composing the firm of Loos Schneider, dealers in brewers' supplies and manufacturers of varnishes at 26 and 28 Frankfort-street with a factory at Astoria, made an assignment yesterday to Louis C. Raegner, giving preferences for $13,350, the largest being to Conrad Stein, $8,500, and Rudolph Stoeckel, $4,508.

PARIS, April 23.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Floquet, the Prime Minister, agreed to an immediate debate on the interpellation of Count de Martinprey regarding the appointment of a civilian (M. de Freycinet) as Minister of War. Count de Martinprey declared that M. Floquet's action in making such an appointment was revolutionary and would have a deplorable effect upon the army.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., April 23.--Every once in a while some "old boatman" starts a new story afloat about when, where, and how certain vessels were built along the Hudson River in bygone days.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 23.--But few Summer homes were rented during the last week and only a small number of those looking for cottages made their appearance to gladden the hearts of the real estate agents.

Mrs. Scott-Siddons and her adopted son, Henry Waller, appeared in an entertainment of readings and piano playing at Steinway Hall last evening. Mr. Waller was known a dozen years ago as "Seraphael," a juvenile prodigy.

SIVERLYVILLE, Penn., April 23.--One week ago to-day James McLaughlin, a leading citizen of this place and an enthusiastle trout fisherman, left home to fish in Hemlock Creek, a noted trout stream in a wild region back of the village of President in this county.

BATAVIA, N.Y., April 23.--The Hon. R.A. Maxwell, Superintendent of the State Insurance Department; the Hon. Myron H. Peek, County Judge, and George A. Porter, merchant, were to-day elected delegates to the State Convention by the Genesee County Democratic Convention.

For 101 years the celebration by the Englishmen in New-York of St. George's Day has been more or less prosaic. The one hundred and second, which took place last night at Delmonico's in the form of a dinner was considerably less prosaic and was not a little ruffled.

The fight between the locked-out journeymen brewers and the Brewers' Association is settling into one of endurance. Besides the fact that wealth is on the side of the brewers, the men have to contend against the enmity of the leading spirits of District Assembly No. 49.
BERLIN, April 23.--The bulletin issued at 9 o'clock this morning says: "Although the Emperor was troubled by coughing last night, he otherwise passed a tolerably fair night. His fever is low."
Knickerbocker Council, No. 572, Royal Arcanum, made its first annual plunge into the pool of pleasures, literary and social, last evening at the Grand Opera House Hall.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 23.--The members of the new City Government, elected on Tuesday last, were sworn in and took charge of their offices to-day. At 12 o'clock the new City Council, consisting of twenty-nine Independents and one Regular Democrat, occupied their council hall.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 23.--Death in a remarkable form overtook the 4-year-old child of William Stringer of this city to-day. Mr. Stringer is something of a chicken fancier and kept a half dozen game cocks in his back yard.

The examination of Mme. Diss Debar will be continued to-day before Justice Kilbreth. Some interesting developments are expected, and the prosecuting attorneys promise to offer proof that will clinch the chain of evidence woven around the fat medium.

WASHINGTON, April 23.--Without the services of Ward the New-Yorks played their third championship game here to-day, the contest resulting in a draw because none of the players seemed able to hit the ball.

BALTIMORE, April 23.--Brooklyn, flushed with four victories over the Cleveland Club, came here, and were easily beaten in a game in which the visitors showed no ability either at the bat, in the field, or in running the bases, playing like the veriest amateurs.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24.--J.B. Haggin to-day stated that he was preparing to retire permanently from the turf. He proposes to offer for sale at NewYork in June 100 yearling colts, and this will be the first step in his plan of disposing of all of his splendid racing stock.

MONTREAL, April 24.--Detective Kellert arrested James Taylor on a charge of forgery this morning. A few days ago information was received that he was wanted and a reward was offered for his arrest.

OIL CITY, Penn., April 24.--Reliable information has been received by the trade here that the Eagle Refinery at Lima, Ohio, has not failed, but is running to its full capacity. The report of the failure originated in a New-York newspaper, which has since corrected it.

CHATTANOOGA Tenn., April 24.--An assignment for the benefit of creditors was to-day made by C.C. McCullough, wholesale dealer in paints and oils.

PALATKA, Fla., April 24.--At 7:10 o'clock this evening the hard-worked delegates of the Republican State Convention took a rest until 9 o'clock. They had had two sessions, and though talk had been plentiful yet the results were slight.
BANGOR, Me., April 24.--O.M. Shaw, proprietor of the West End Hotel, Bar Harbor, is just home from Florence, Italy, where he left the Hon. James G. Blaine four weeks ago.

ALBANY, April 24.--Superintendent of Public Instruction Draper went through the usual form to-day by sending a check amounting to $640,417 28 to Chamberlain Ivins, as New-York's small share of the public school, tax for which she has to contribute so liberally.
The League championship season will be opened with a game between the New-York and Philadelphia Clubs at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. Cappa's band will be in attendance to furnish music.

Mr. GOLDWIN SMITH'S suggestion that English residents in this country shall become citizens for the purpose of guarding the interests of their native land against the machinations of Irishmen was not particularly brilliant.

The Court of Special Sessions, at the Tombs, was crowded yesterday as it was never crowded before. It was the third day of the examination into the charges against Mme. Diss Debar and her companions for conspiring to defraud Luther R. Marsh.

Martinson, a committee of the dissatisfied security holders of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway, issued a formal reply yesterday to the recent letter in which Jay Gould cast imputations upon the proverty that the security holders are trying to protect.

TROY, N.Y., April 24.--The marriage of Edward Cortland Gate to Miss Marie Warren, daughter of John Thompson, took place this noon at St. Paul's Church. The Right Rev. William Coswell Doane, assisted by the Rev. Edgar A. Enos, Rector of the parish, officiated.
At 5 o'clock yesterday morning the Kings County Elevated Railroad, on Fulton-street, Brooklyn, was thrown open to the public and the first train was drawn out of the station at Nostrand-avenue.

Yesterday's labors of the Court of Appeals were witnessed by an assemblage of people who filled every part of the General Term court room. The spectacle of gowned Judges was enough of a novelty in this city to attract many, evidently from curiosity. Such of the spectators kept coming and going, a stay of a few minutes evidently being all that was sought or desired.
BOSTON, April 24.--The Republican State Convention will be held at Tremont Temple tomorrow, opening at 11 o'clock.

On Monday evening the Assembly of this State committed the amazing folly of passing the Yates Prison bill by a vote of 74 to 22. All the Democratic votes cast were for the bill, and added to these were 28 Republican votes.

Mrs. Mary White, a widow, was the plaintiff in Justice Massey's court, Brooklyn, yesterday, against Mrs. Mary Harrison, who resides with her husband on Hudson-avenue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 24.--The resumption of the work at the Edgar Thomson Steel Mill is progressing quietly. There were comparatively few men on the main street of Braddock to-day, but there was an increased number doing something at the big plant just outside the borough line.

PARIS, April 24.--"Germinal" is a failure The play will undoubtedly have a certain ran, owing to the prestige of the name of the author. PHILADELPHIA, April 24.--The Keystone Investment Company, after a brief history of a few weeks, has suspended payment. The liabilities are placed at $20,000. No figures on the assets are given.

ALBANY, April 24.--The Tammany Central Association of the City of New-York was incorporated to-day, the object being for social, political, and literary purposes.

PARIS, April 24.--The Senate to-day discussed the Military bill. M. de Freycinet defended the committee's proposal to establish a three-years' service as sufficient to provide enough soldiers for the defense of the country. Gen. Billot supported the proposal in its subtantial points, at the same time expressing confidence in the existing army.
BOSTON, Mass., April 24.--While the steamer Catalonia was still at quarantine John L. Sullivan, the pugilist, was taken aboard a tugboat by his friends and brought to the city.
The Rev. Dr. William F. Morgan, D.D., the aged Rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, has resigned the post which he has so actively and efficiently filed for over 30 years.

ELMIRA, April 25.--The Republican Congressional Convention to elect delegates to the National Convention was held at the Republican Headquarters this afternoon.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25.--Gov. Larrabee this afternoon appointed Mrs. Mary A. Miller, a teacher in the Grant Building, in West Des Moines, as State Librarian, to succeed Mrs. S.B. Maxwell, who has filled the position for 10 years past. Mrs. Miller is the widow of an Iowa soldier, and her appointment was strongly urged by the old soldiers of this city and Eddyville, where she formerly resided.

PARIS, April 25.--President Carnot, accompanied by M. Lockroy, Minister of Public Instruction, and M. Pelnus-Montaud, Minister of Public Works, left Paris to-day on a tour of France. President Carnot was cordially welcomed at the stations along the route.
BOSTON, April 25.--James G. Blaine for President, sick or well, with letters burned or unburned, with declination now written or yet to be penned, was the verdict of the Republican State Convention.
The Gas Commission yesterday rejected all the bids for lighting this city with electric lights and will advertise for new bids, to be opened on May 9.
LONDON, April 25.--At a little dinner given by ex-May or Grace last Saturday Mr. Parnell said a number of interesting things to me across the table which I asked his permission to print.
DETROIT, Mich., April 25.--The business troubles of the large dry goods house of Metcalf Brothers Co. have resulted, as many feared would be the case, in their making an assignment.

Thomas B. Kerr, ex-Treasurer of the Broadway Railroad, will be placed upon trial for bribery on Wednesday of next week. So decided Judge Patterson, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday morning.

ST. LOUIS, April 25.--An assignment was made to-day by the Smith, Beggs Ranken Machine Company to William H. Thompson for the benefit of creditors. Johnson Beggs, President of the company, states that the value of the interest of the company in property, machinery and stock, after deducting incumbrances amounting to $60,000, will be about $60,000.

WASHINGTON, April 25.--Boston, 1; Washington, 0, in 11 innings. Base hits--Boston, 8; Washington, 5. Errors--Boston, 6; Washington, 5. Stolen bases--Boston, 4. Struck out--By Clarkson, 11; by O'Day, 12.

The Republicans of Pennsylvania, in the platform adopted at Harrisburg yesterday, followed closely the lines laid down at Day ton last week, and in some of the resolutions used the same language employed by the Ohio Republicans.

BERLIN, April 25.--This morning's bulletin says: "The Emperor passed a good night. His fever is lower and his condition satisfactory. As the condition of the Emperor changes little during the day only one bulletin will be issued daily until further notice."

The Board of Aldermen has instructed Clerk Twomey not to send Mayor Hewitt any resolutions adopted by the board containing a petition to any State or United States officer or city department. This is done to prevent the Mayor from vetoing such resolutions as may be passed.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas Armitage, Pastor of the Fifth-Avenue Baptist Church, has tendered his resignation after a ministry of 40 years. He is to sail for England on Saturday, and last evening he was to bid farewell to his congregation for the Summer. Not only did he do this, but he tendered his resignation to take effect on Jan. 1.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25.--Drafts, sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 26 cents.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 25.--The Republican State Convention reassembled this morning at 9 o'clock. Webster Flanigan of Rusk was made permanent Chairman. The Committee on Platform and Resolutions made their report, which was adopted.
LONDON, April 26.--The Chronicle announces the approaching marriage of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain to Miss Endicott, whom he met in America.
The baseball season in this city was inaugurated at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a game between the New-York and Philadelphia Clubs. There were some 10,000 persons at the grounds to witness it.

The General Passenger Agent of the Trunk Line Association and the Commissioners of Emigration met yesterday and discussed the condition of things at the Castle Garden Closring House, brought about by the recent immigrant rate war. No settlement of the difficulty was reached.

MALONE, N.J., April 25.--Franklin County delegates to the Democratic State Convention are W.S. Lawrence and N.W. Porter, favorable to Cleveland, and Asaph Harwood unpledged. The convention adopted a resolution commending Cleveland's Administration, but did not mention Hill.

LONDON, April 25.--The Anchor Line steamship City of Rome, Capt. Young, from New-York April 18, for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown to-day. The steamship Caledonia, (Br.,) Capt. Hassenstein, from Mediterranean ports, for New-York, passed Gibraltar to-day.
In their new clubrooms, adorned with palms and roses, smilax and flags, the Federal Club gave a reception last evening, which was attended by a large assemblage of enthusiastic Republicans.

Some say the Governor will sign it, others that he will veto it, while a third class insists ...

A verdict for $147,759 71 was given yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Wallace, in favor of Henry J. Anderson, Receiver of the First National Bank of Albion, in his suit against Kissam, Whitney Co., the Broad-street brokers.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 26.--Adam S. Fry, Judge; C.E. Tilghman and S.T. Henry, Inspectors; and Isaac Kauffman and E.T. Kauffman, Clerks; the election officers in the Indiantown district, Manor township, convicted of committing frauds at the Republican primary elections of May last, were sentenced to-day by Judge Patterson to one year and two weeks' imprisonment, with fine and costs of prosecution.
DECATUR, Ill., April 26.--The Union Labor Party of Illinois held its first State Convention in Decatur to-day, with 100 delegates present, who had a stormy time.

The Mills bill provides that the duty on wood screws shall be 35 per cent. of their value. Under the present law the duty is measured by the weight of the goods, the rates ranging from 6 cents to 10 cents a pound.
CHESTER, Ill., April 26.--An exciting fire occurred in the penitentiary here this afternoon, which destroyed the plant of the Western Boot and Shoe Company valued at $100,000.

Mrs. Matilda Kerrigan of 211 Carlton-avenue, Brooklyn, and her daughter-in-law went out driving yesterday afternoon, and when near the Atlantic-avenue division of the Long Island Railroad, the horses became unmanageble and dashed across the track in front of an approaching train.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--The offers for the sale of bonds to the Government, opened by Acting Secretary Thompson to-day, aggregated $922,050, in lots as follows: Four per cent., coupon--$50,000 at 126 , $4,600 at 126, $50,000 at 126 ; total, $104,600.

Chauncey M. Depew's nomination for the Presidency by Elliott F. Shepard at the meeting of the Federal Club Wednesday evening set all the town talking yesterday, and, as a matter of course, Mr. Depew's office at the Grand Central Station was occupied from morning until night by a stream of callers anxious to learn his views on the latest turn of affairs.

BANGOR, April 26.--The statements of Mr. O.M. Shaw of the West End Hotel of Bar Harbor, regarding the health of the Hon. James G. Blaine, which appeared in THE TIMES on Wednesday, caused consternation and dismay here.

RONDOUT, N.Y., April 26.--Forest fires are reported to-night on the Fishkill and Shawangunk Mountain ranges. On the latter mountains deep snow is still to be found, and the glare of the red fire reflected upon the snow in the distance presents a brilliant appearance.

Gov. HILL'S method of meeting the damaging testimony of Chamberlain IVINS in regard to the former's relations with ROLLIN M. SQUIRE is a curt demand for his resignation of the position of Judge-Advocate-General on the Governor's staff.
ANTIGO, Wis., April 26.--The Bank of Antigo was robbed of $6,000 between 12 and 1 o'clock this afternoon by some unknown person who went in by the back door while the cashier was at dinner.
AMESBURY, Mass., April 26.--F.A. Babcock, carriage manufacturer, has made an assignment. His liabilities are not stated.
BELVIDERE, Kan., April 26.--The murder of Dr. W.E. Ashley and Eugene Grove of this place, in the Indian Territory, has been confirmed.

Gen. Abram Merritt of Nyack, N.Y., committed suicide in the Fifth-avenue Hotel on Wednesday night. He arrived there on Tuesday and registered as usual. He did not seem to be feeling well. A chambermaid made several unsuccessful attempts to enter his bedroom on Wednesday, and at nearly ...

BALTIMORE, Md., April 26.--The Staten Island ferry steamer, the Erastus Wiman, was successfully launched to-day from the works of the Columbian Iron Works in this city. She is built of steel, and is one of the largest craft of the kind ever constructed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26.--The Rev. A. N. Wever, appointed to Napeuoch, Ulster County, at the recent Methodist Episcopal Conference, and who preached his first sermon on Sunday last, was taken suddenly ill after dinner on that day and died in convulsions on Tuesday. The sickness of the Rev. Mr. Wever is attributed to eating canned vegetables.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 26.--John Shindle, aged 75 years, was struck by the Columbia accommodation train at 7:40 this evening and instantly killed. When the train approached Shindle was standing at the fence near the Walnut-street crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad in this city.
ROME, April 26.--Gen. San Marzano telegraphs from Massowah that King John has reopened negotiations for the conclusion of peace between Italy and Abyssinia.

Phillip Kranenberg, who lived at 1,331 Thirdavenue, went to work yesterday morning, after a night's illness caused by too much drink. He was a watchmaker and worked on One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 26.--The trial of Andrew S. Ford of Chatham, Columbia County, for the alleged murder of his wife by poisoning is attracting a great deal of attention here. Evidence so far is in the main circumstantial and against the prisoner. He says he will be able to prove his innocence.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 26.--The first yearling sale of thoroughbreds, the produce of the Kenesaw and Cliff Lawn breeding farms, was held at the former place, near Gallatin, Tenn., to-day, and was a decided failure, principally because the youngsters were not engaged in the rich Futurity Stakes.

BALTIMORE, April 26.--Baltimore, 5; Brooklyn, 3. Earned runs--Baltimore, 4; Brooklyn, 1. Base hits--Baltimore, 13; Brooklyn, 9. Stolen bases --Brooklyn, 6. Errors--Five each. Struck out--By Cunningham, 2; by Caruthers, 2.

Husbands who make their wives presents of all their property must be certain that they will never want it back again; otherwise, they will get into the trouble under which William S. Wyse now labors, and out of which he is very anxious to get. Mr. Wyse was for many years in the advertising department of Harper Brothers, receiving an income of $20,000 a year.
Dedication services were held last evening by the Trinity Congregational Church of Tremont in the new building at Washington-avenue and East One Hundred and Seventy-sixth-street, which cost $18,000.
PARIS, April 26.--A dispatch from Nancy says a riot broke out there this evening, a mob of Boulangists attacking the students' clubs with stones and other missiles.
The 18 cabin passengers of the Hamburg Line steamship Bohemia will no doubt be glad to leave her for shore when allowed. The Bohemia is known as a freight steamer.

At Reichard's Gallery Mr. Theodore Wores of San Francisco offers 45 oil paintings and pastels which would merit examination merely on the score of curiosity, were the workmanship indifferent. Fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the varnish room of Blanchard Brothers Lane's large patent leather factory, on McWhorter-street, Newark, and the roof of the Second Reformed Church building adjoining was ignited and destroyed.

Miss Jeannette Milnor, a daughter of Mrs. Susannah Milnor of 12 East Forty-seventhstreet, was to have been married on Wednesday to Henry D. Cooke, a son of R.K. Cooke. Superintendent of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, in St. George's Church.
Prof. Hartl of Vienna and his company of women fencers will give an exhibition of their skill at Chickering Hall to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock.

MILWAUKEE, April 26.--Five members of the Hebrew congregations Anse Jacob and Moses Montefiere were held for trial to-day by Judge Mallory in a preliminary hearing, for boycotting a Hebrew butcher named Jacob Weisfeld, and for conspiring to injure his business.
New-York's aggregation of ball players succeeded in defeating Philadelphia's representatives by a score of 11 to 5 at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Sixty graduates of Rochester University attended the first annual dinner Of the NewYork Alumni of that institution at the Buckingham Hotel last night. Rossiter Johnson presided.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--The Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club was begun at the Ivy City track to-day, and resulted in a series of surprises, favorites winning but two of the six races run. The great surprise of the day was the defeat of Favor by Boaz in the easiest possible fashion.

Theodore Grossman, about 50 years of age, committed suicide yesterday at 233 East Houstonstreet by shooting himself in the month. A letter from him to the Coroner states that poverty drove him to suicide.

The Rev. Dr. James McCosh, President of Princeton College, and the President-elect, the Rev. Dr. Francis L. Patton, were both present and each delivered an address at the last regular meeting of the Princeton Club for the present season, which was held last night at the Hotel Brunswick.
