CHICAGO, April 26.--There is a hot fight going on in the Fourth Congressional District for the Republican nomination between Congressman Adams and Hempstead Washburne.

The steamship Chateau Lafite, from Bordeaux, yesterday, had on board 109 secondclass passengers who tried hard to pass themselves off as Greek man-of-war's men on some mysterious mission to this country.

The second evening's sale of the Hermann Herzog paintings at the American Art Gallery was fairly well attended. Seventy-four paintings were sold for $5,527 50, making a total of $11,687 50 for the two nights.

CHICAGO, April 26.--The General Managers of the Northwestern lines met to-day to consider the proposition of the Chicago, Burlington and Northern to reduce rates on through business from New-York to St. Paul. All the roads interested in St. Paul business were represented, with the exception of the St. Paul and Duluth.
CHICAGO, April 26.--At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago Gas Trust Company to-day the following officers were elected:

Radcliffe Co., dry goods commission merchants at West Broadway and Leonardstreet, failed yesterday. The first intimation in the trade of any trouble was the closing of the store by Deputy Sheriff Kaufman early in the day on executions amounting to $174,500.

WOODBURY, N.J., April 26.--George McClellan Dunham was hanged in the jailyard at this place today. Dunham killed his mother-in-law, Mrs. Barbara Kandle, on her farm, near Uniontown, N.J., on Nov. 10 last.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 26.--An unknown war ship is ashore off the southern point of Scatary Island on the Cape Breton coast. She is anchored in the ice. There is no communication with the island.
CHICAGO, April 26.--The new rates on live stock and dressed meats adopted by the Chicago Committee on East-bound Lreight went into effect to-day on all the lines in the Central Traffic Association.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26.--Adam Mugler, a laborer, is in jail here to-night on his voluntary confession that he is the murderer of his wife.

The convention of milk dealers and producers which was called to meet yesterday morning and continue in session two days came to a sudden and untimely end. The call was signed by 25 persons, and the idea of the convention was fostered by Amzi Howell, the editor of the Milk Reporter.

VIENNA, April 7.--Civil war at the present moment is raging in Roumania, and the insurrection which at first was of an agrarian character is developing into a full-blown revolution that bids fair to drive King Charles and his poet Queen from their perilous throne to seek refuge in the German Fatherland.

Miss Rose Hutchinson and John J. Phelps were yesterday married at St. George's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, in the presence of the relatives of the bridal couple and a few intimate friends.

NORFOLK, Va., April 26.--A heavy frost in this section last night greatly damaged all kinds of truck crops. Estimates of the damage made to-day place the loss to the farmers in Norfolk, Princess Anne, and Nansemond Counties at not less than $1,000,000, and some make the estimate as high as $2,000,000, but this is probably an exaggeration, and the first-named ...

NEWTOWN, Penn., April 26.--This morning two empty coal trains collided on the Bound Brook branch of the Reading Railroad at Woodburne Station. Charles Wesherman, conductor, and George Warren, brakeman, of Philadelphia, were killed. Seventy-five cars were wrecked.

PARIS, April 26.--President Carnot arrived to-night at Agen, where he laid the foundation stone of a new lyceum. The President met with an enthusiastic reception. The day's ceremony was marred by a serious accident.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26.--An important alliance has just been entered into between the Philadelphia and Reading and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroads. President Spencer and Vice-President Smith of the Baltimore and Ohio and President Maxwell of the NewJersey Central, President Wilbur and ...

ALBANY, April 26.--State Entomologist J.A., Lintner thinks the bill providing a bounty of 2 cents a head for English sparrows, in order to exterminate them, is a dangerous one and would result in the destruction of the remaining native swamp, song, tree, chipping, and field sparrows by irresponsible parties.
Several of the well-known Irish revolutionists in this city prodict that England will soon again hear from the dynamiters.

INDIANAPOLIS Ind., April 26.--The Democrats of Indiana met in State Convention this morning in Tomlinson Hall. The convention was called to order at 10 o'clock by E.P. Richardson, who called for the polling of the delegates by counties.

BLACKVILLE, S.C., April 26.--The dwelling house of Louis Stroman, near Springfield, on the Barnwell and Alston Railroad, was burned at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and four of Stroman's children, two boys and two girls, who were sleeping up stairs, perished in the flames. Stroman's eldest son was frightfully burned while endeavoring to rescue his brothers and sisters and will probably die.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 26.--The Fifteenth Congressional District Republican Convention for the election of delegates to the National Republican Convention at Chicago will meet here on May 10, and an active canvass has already been begun by aspirants to the honor of taking part in the nomination of the Presidential candidate of the party.
LANCASTER, Penn., April 26.--To-day there is a great gathering of Republican clubs in this city, the object of the convention being to form a State branch of the National League of Republican clubs.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 26.--The thirdparty prohibitionists, in spite of last Winter's radical pharmacy law, called their convention to order at 2 P.M. to-day in the Young Men's Christian Association's rooms. The Rev. Dr. Nash of Des Moines was elected temporary Chairman, and the Rev. Mr. Nichols of Gladbrook temporary Secretary.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26.--H.K. Sadler, who has been employed in the counting room of the New-York Herald for upward of 20 years, has laid claim to the estate of Mrs. Sarah Riley, who died in January last, amounting to several thousand dollars, consisting of real estate in Walkerville, Canada, and in this city.

A German band of strolling players stood the other afternoon in front of a Bowery saloon, over the door of which hung a green banner decorated with a golden harp rampant. The players were filling the air with a discordant attempt at "St. Patrick's Day in the Morning."

The Special Sessions Court of the Tombs was crowded agian yesterday when the examination of Mme. Diss Debar and "Gen." Diss Debar on charges of conspiring to defraud Lawyer Luther R. Marsh was continued. Mr. Howe had promised that a picture should be produced in open court upon a blank piece of paper through natural means, and he kept his promise, much to the delight of the spectators.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--Second Lieut. Alfred M. Hunter, at his own request, has been transferred from the Fifth Cavalry to the Fourth Artillery. Major Richard S. Vickery, Surgeon, has been granted leave of absence for four months. Second Lieut. John C. Walshe, Signal Corps, has been granted leave of absence for four months.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26.--One of the most remarkable cases of suicide ever known in this city was discovered to-night, the victims being Ernest Eichfeld, aged 60, and his wife, aged 55. Eichfeld was a German by birth and a tailor by trade, living in a small house in the rear of 1,131 North Second-street.
The Ward Line steamer Santiago, bound for Nassau yesterday, sunk the pilot boat J.F. Loubat, No. 16. which was on station at Sandy Hook.
The Yale Glee Club will give a concert at Chickering Hall on May 8.

ALBANY, April 26.--The Assembly adjourned soon after the passage of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge bill to-day, and the fact that so many idiots and knaves were recorded in the affirmative on the measure was a general topic of conversation.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 26.--Eleanor Tudor Hart of Montreal will get her divorce from Fred Hart, a wealthy sporting man.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 26.--So far as appearances were concerned the situation at Braddock to-day was the same as it was yesterday. Nothing occurred to mar the calm exterior. Furnaces A and B were turning out pig metal, and large gangs of men were engaged in placing the machinery in working order preparatory to active resumption in a few days.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 26.--Temperance representatives from all parts of the county were present to-day at a convention held here to decide upon a proposition to apply at once for a special election under the new local option law.

BANGOR, Me., April 26.--It was a largelyattended convention. All Eastern Maine was here and Republicans from the remotest section of York County produced credentials. The Stalwarts were here in great numbers; that is, not only Blaine men, but men who care for nobody else but Blaine.
Dr. C.H. Tebault said yesterday: "I am indebted to a prominent gentleman of this city for the loan of a letter just received by him from Dr. George M. Sternberg, dated Baltimore, ...
Forty or fifty good judges of beer spent more than six hours yesterday in the Common Council Chamber at the City Hall. Some of them drink "pool" beer exclusively; the rest prefer "union" beer.

BOSTON, Mass., April 26.--The Atlantic Machine Works, corner of Border and Maverick streets, were burned this morning, causing an estimated loss of $150,000. The fire started in the pattern shop, and the supposition is that it caught from the wires of an arc electric light.

PATERSON, N.J., April 26.--Extra coal train No. 88 on the Delaware, Lackawanna, and Western Road, going east, about 11 o'clock this morning, ran into a passenger train bound west, on the NewYork and Greenwood Lake Road, near Mountainview, a few miles west of here, where the two roads cross.
ALBANY, April 26.--Superintendent of Public Instruction Draper has designated Aug. 20-24 for the examination of applicants for State Regents' certificates.
D. Lowber Smith, Deputy Commissioner of Public Works, was asked by a TIMES reporter yesterday if he could explain the failure of the water supply at the Delamater Iron Works fire the night before.

The enrolled Republicans of the Seventeenth Assembly District met last evening, and when the Committee on Nominations was called on to report upon the names of 128 men who had been nominated for membership it reported on some 13 names.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--Mr. Daniel W. Voorhees of Indiana has done that which a good many Republicans have wished no man could do. He has provoked Mr. John J. Ingalls of Kansas into a determination to make another political speech in the Senate.

There was much excitement in the fivestory apartment house at the southwest corner of Ninth-avenue and Fifty-eighth-street yesterday afternoon. A fire which started in the cellar spread rapidly through the dumb-waiter shaft to the roof, imperiling the lives of the occupants of the promises, but, although there were many narrow escapes, everybody got out unharmed.

ALBANY, April 26.--Gov. Hill was particular to announce to the public to-day that he had demanded the resignation of Mr. Ivins. He was also particular to create the impression that in appointing Mr. Ivins as Judge-Advocate and member of his staff he had conferred some favor upon the late Hubert O. Thompson and ex-Mayor William R. Grace.

PEARSALL, Texas, April 26.--An old quarrel was renewed in the "Red Front" saloon yesterday between Frank Nolan and William Jordan, well-known and wealthy cattle dealers. During the discussion Jordan secured a billiard cue and struck Nolan a murderous blow on the head.

QUEENSTOWN, April 27.--The White Star Line steamship Celtic, Capt. Irving, for Liverpool, arr. here at 1 A.M. today. The Guion Line steamship Nevada, Capt. Cushing, from New-York April 17 for Liverpool, arr. here at 2 A.M. to-day.

The Star Theatre never say so many children within its walls as have flocked each afternoon this week to witness the antics of Herr Brockmann's educated monkeys, dogs, and ponies. The hour for beginning the matinees has been fixed at 3 o'clock, so as to allow school children time to get to the theatre, and the ...
LONDON, April 26.--I get a cipher dispatch from Berlin to-night which says that doubt arises as to the value of the recent optimistic bulletins relative to the Kaiser's condition.

The arrangements for the celebration of Gen. Grant's birthday at Delmonico's this evening have been completed. Instead of the con ventional long tables that ordinarily form the arrangement of the banqueting hall Gen. Collis has ordered eight round tables, each accommodating ...

CHICAGO, April 26.--Elevated railroad companies are fashionable in Chicago, and the City Council will be asked very soon--perhaps next Monday night--to pass an ordinance for the consolidated rapid transit and elevated railroad.

BERLIN, April 26.--Queen Victoria visited the mausoleum this morning and spent some time in prayer at the tomb of Emperor William. The Empress and her daughters accompanied the Queen. Before leaving the mausoleum the Queen placed a wreath upon Emperor William's coffin.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--When the investigation into the subject of trusts was resumed by the House Committee on Manufactures thin morning, Mr. Dodd, counsel of the Standard Oil Company, introduced Mr. Joseph H. Choate of New-York as the representative of the Standard Company before the committee.

CHICAGO, April 26.--An explosion that pitched 70 people into the air, throwing one man 50 feet, wrecked 16 big plate-glass windows, ruined $35,000 worth of clothing, and caused a stampede of hundreds of people from the upper stories of tall buildings, occurred in a basement at State and ...

The initiation by Gen. SHERMAN, his most famous lieutenant and only successor in the grade of General, of the annual celebration of the 27th of April as the birthday of GRANT is a happy thought, whose establishment into a constantly-widening custom may safely be predicted.

ANTIGO, Wis., April 26.--A freight train ran into a work train between Bernamwood and Eland Junction on the Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western Road at 9 o'clock this morning and 10 persons were seriously injured.
HARRISBURG, Penn., April 26.--A curious discovery is reported as having been made by some workmen who were tearing down an old building in McKeesport a few days ago.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 26.--Mrs. J.C. Fuller was taken to the State Insane Asylum today. She had become demented in grieving over the death of her child, who ate some poison which the mother had carelessly placed on a shelf within the child's reach.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 26.--Mrs. Elnor E. Buck, wife of A.D. Buck, furniture dealer, committed suicide this morning by hanging herself with a skein of yarn. She made a noose which she fastened around her neck, then got upon a chair and threw the loop of the skein over a door and jumped from the chair. She was dead when found. She had been sick for some time and lately became despondent.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 26.--Miss Mollie Green is the heroine of a thrilling scene in Perry County, Tenn. Miss Mollie is an attractive young lady of 18, who teaches school on Cypress Creek.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., April 27.--A special from Washington to a paper in this city, the home of the Hon. A.E. Stevenson, First Assistant Postmaster-General, states exactly his position as to the Vice-Presidential nomination. Mr. Stevenson said last night that he was not seeking, asking, or expecting the nomination; that he had no desire for it.

Mrs. Ellen Terry, the widow of Senor Juan P. Terry, whose career has often been described, was summoned to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer a charge of assault made by Annie Maria Coogan, a servant ...
The performance of "Otello" at the Academy of Music last evening was for the benefit of the popular tenor and impresario, Signor Italo Campanini.

The two children of Mrs. Diss Debar again found a new abiding place yesterday. When Mr. Marsh last Tuesday conferred with Mr. Gerry, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, he thought, he said, ...

"Canalboat Hattie," as she used to be known when the police first heard of her--Mrs. Andrew Connelly as she now calls herself--is in the police toils in Jersey City for a series of swindling operations. She was passing as the wife of Andrew Connelly of Monmouth-street, when she became acquainted with Albert J. Pratt, a printer, of 96 Montgomery-street.

In reply to the message of sympathy sent to Berlin from the German singing societies and other organizations, on the occasion of the memorial meeting at Steinway Hall on March 21, after the death of the Emperor William, the following was received yesterday by Commissioner Charles Hauselt:
The cabin passengers of the steamship Bohemia, which arrived from Hamburg Thursday with a case of smallpox in the steerage, were brought up to the city yesterday.

TEMPLE, Texas, April 27.--T.C. Wright received a letter from his son-in-law, D.F. Murtell, this afternoon, which states that the latter was kidnapped by two Mexicans at Coleman Junction, 154 miles west of here, at 11:25 ...

SOFIA, April 27.--Prince Ferdinand, accompanied by M. Stambuloff, Minister of the Interior, and M. Natchovitch, Minister of Finance, has left Sofia on a northern tour. He was cheered enthusiastically by the troops and populace as he departed.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--The Speaker today laid before the House the reply of the Secretary of the Interior of the resolution calling upon him for information in his possession relating to the alleged frauds upon the Government by the California Redwood Company, and also for ...

The Metallic Decorating Company, at West and Bank streets, is in the hands of the Sheriff on an execution for $9,240 in favor of J.H. Lane Co. The company was organized in December, 1886, with a capital of $25,000. Deputy Sheriff Stevens, who is in charge, has fixed the sale for Tuesday.

BOSTON, April 27.--David Johnson, an employe of J.F. Folsom, candy manufacturer, struck Patrick Devlin, a fellow-workman, on the head with a piece of joist this noon, fracturing his skull. Devlin died this afternoon. Devlin delighted in "horse play," and it was while thus engaged that he met his death. Johnson is under arrest.

CHICAGO, April 27.--To-morrow the issue of the Alarm, the paper of which A.R. Parsons, the Anarchist, was editor, will be suspended indefinitely. Difficulties partaking somewhat of a financial character, it is supposed, have caused the stoppage. It is a queer coincidence that the day is ex actly the second anniversary of the last issue of the paper by Parsons himself, the number just preceding the Haymarket bomb throwing and containing the call "to arms."
The steamer Tallahassee of the Ocean Steamship Company, which arrived yesterday from Savannah, brought an interesting consignment of live freight.
It's a poor stock that doesn't pop up into conspicuous place just now while the whole market is kiting upward. And it's a poor man who doesn't get the chance to win a passing glory.
A peddler selling oranges enlisted the sympathies of Mrs. Henry C. Hertler of 250 Hudson-street, Hoboken, the other day, and she made up a bundle of clothing for his wife.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 27.--At the meeting of the Department of Tennessee, Georgia, and Alabama, Grand Army of the Republic, held at Athens, Tenn., William Rule of Knoxville was elected Department Commander. Gen. John P. Rea, Commander-in-General, was present.

CHICAGO, April 27.--The General Managers of the lines between Chicago and Missouri Riverpoints met to-day for the purpose of agreeing on a basis of division with the lines west of the Missouri River on through business on the new tariff.

CHICAGO, April 27.--C.W. Earnst of Boston talked of "Principles of Tariff Reform" before the bankers of Chicago at their annual dinner to-night. He said that the country had had enough of this tariff topic and that Congress would not have an attentive audience for ...

The Rev. Francis Stoddard Haines, Pastor of the Reformed Dutch Church of Canajoharie, N.Y., and Miss Mary Orr of Princeton, N.J., were married in the First Presbyterian Church, Princeton, on Wednesday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James McCosh, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Horace Hinsdale, Pastor of the church.

OMAHA, Neb., April 27.--The cannonball train from Kansas City on the Burlington and Missouri Railroad was wrecked near Alma to-day, caused by a bridge giving way. L.A. Town of Grand Rapids, Mich., was killed and Charles Eaton of Lincoln badly injured. The mail and express cars, with their contents, were consumed.

TAMPA, Fla., April 27.--Advices from Havana state that Captain-General Marin has declared martial law in the provinces of Havana, Matanzas, Santa Clara, and Pinar del Rio. The sugar-making season is nearly over.
WASHINGTON, April 27.--Green B. Morris's speedy 3-year-old colt, Sir Dixon, made his first appearance in a race this season on the Ivy City track this afternoon.

Holly C. Lyon, a veteran detective, who was retired last year as a sexagenarian, died early yesterday morning at 298 Sumner-avenue, Brooklyn, of heart trouble and pneumonia. He had a wonderful memory of important criminal events and methods, and his acquaintance with ...
The charge is made by Morris Brothers of 47 Walker-street that during the fire next door Thursday night, somebody stole 20 pairs of suspenders from a sample lot on the third floor.
Peculiar interest attaches to the launch of the gunboat Yorktown and the dynamite cruiser, announced to take place at the shipyard of CRAMP SONS to-day, from ...

PHILADELHIA, April 27.--The launch of the gunboat Yorktown and the dynamite cruiser from Cramp's shipyard to-morrow promises to be one of the most interesting events that has ever occurred along the shores of the Delaware.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 27.--Reinstra Power, stock brokers, who has a handsomely fitted up office on the first floor of the Girard House, suspended to-day. They were not members of the Stock Exchange.

PITTSBURG, April 27.--A private telegram received from New-York this afternoon states that a conference of the leaders of the American Flint Glass Workers' Association and manufacturers was held to-day and the strike settled. The fires have been started in all the factories and work will be resumed next Monday. The settlement will give employment to several thousand men who have been idle since last September.

O'FALLON, Mo., April 27.--A domestic tragedy that is horrible in all its features occurred at the house of Mrs. Ernest Kleeschulte at 7 o'clock this morning. Mrs. Kleeschulte has been married nine years, but two years ago a separation occurred and her husband has since lived in St. Louis.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27.--Woodard Harbison's horse sale closed to-day, 277 animals having been disposed of during the week for $82,675, an average of $298. This makes the report that Traynor Potts of Richmond, Ky., paid $1,100 for a yearling colt by Vatican out of Harry Wilkes's dam look like the usual Kentucky exaggeration about the prices breeders get for their stock.
There was a notable gathering at Grace Church yesterday morning at the funeral of exGov. John T. Hoffman. It filled the spacious edifice to the doors.

Greek "man-o'-war's men" will not find it as easy in the future to get into this country by coming second class on steamers of the Bordeaux Line as did those who came on the Chateau Lafitte on Thursday. It was a very flimsy excuse for getting the 109 laborers and fakirs into the country without their undergoing the close questioning of Castle Garden, but it worked.

ALBANY, April 27.--The Fassett AntiBribery bill has finally been reported by the Conference Committee. The Assembly Committee receded from the amendments tacked upon it by Crank Platt and Assemblyman Greene, ...

CHICAGO, April 27.--Congressman Adams to-day captured the Republican primaries in the Fourth Congressional District, and so secures a renomination. He has a small majority over Hemstead Washburne, who made a desperate fight against the machine.

The net earnings of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad company for March were $639,822 02, or an increase of $19,913 99 over the same month last year, notwithstanding the expenses and delay of blizzard week.

BOSTON, Mass., April 27.--The Committee on Election Laws reported to the Senate to-day a bill to provide for printing and distributing ballots at the public expense and to regulate the voteing at State and city elections. The bill is founded on the Australian system so-called.

LEWISTON, Me., April 27.--At the Second District Republican Convention to-day the Hon. Nelson Dingley, Jr., was nominated for Congress by acclamation, and T.R. Simonton of Camden, for Elector. The following were elected delegates to the National Convention: George A. Wilson of Paris and John H. Kimball of Bath. The resolutions adopted indorse the platform of the Republican State Convention at Bangor and favor J.G. Blaine as a candidate for President.
Judge Barrett yesterday, after listening to ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer in behalf of Miss Davenport, and to William F. Howe in behalf of Maurice Barrymore, decided that Miss Davenport ...

LEONARDTOWN, Md., April 27.--John B. Biscoe, colored, was executed here to-day for the murder of Capt. R.P. Dixon on the Potomac River, at the close of August, 1886. The execution was private, as under the law only 20 persons are permitted to be present.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 27.--A powerful sentiment against William H. Barnum is being developed among the Democrats of Central Connecticut. In Middlesex County the opposition to the Democratic boss is especially pronounced, and many of his former henchmen are deserting him.

The Rev. A.D. Smith, Pastor of the Willow-Place Chapel, Brooklyn, was the defendant in Justice Courtney's court yesterday in a suit brought by Gilmarten Doyle, New-York clothiers, to recover $55 on a note made by the minister.
ALBANY, April 27.--The report of the Sixth-Avenue Elevated Railroad Company for the quarter ended March 31 admits of these comparison.

By a scratch the New-Yorks won another game from the Philadelphia Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Buffinton pitched for Philadelphia, and had he been well supported his team would have "shut out" the New-Yorks.

The investigation undertaken by the State Board of Arbitration of the controversy which led to the lock-out by the brewers of their union workmen does not promise very cheerful results for the brewers' union or for unions generally.

Dr. Edward G. Loring's will was filed for probate yesterday. It was executed Nov. 20, 1887. He makes Edward S. Rapallo of this city, and R.H. Stevenson of Boston, his Executors. If his estate should not exceed $20,000, then it is all to go to his wife, Helen Sumner Loring; if ...

LONDON, April 27.--I hasten to put on the wire a sensational statement made to me tonight by one of the best informed men in London, without in the least vouching for more than that he has extraordinary facilities for knowing what is going on underneath the surface of diplomacy.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 27.--After a season of great prosperity the Wilkesbarre Axle Works, formerly situated at Auburn, N.Y., and the largest of the kind in the country, today notified their men that the market was glutted, and that they would have to reduce wages or suspend work for a time.
The so-called Barnes plan recently adopted by the Bridge Trustees is severely criticised in the Engineering News of this date, ...

CONCORD, N.H., April 27.--At the hearing to take testimony in the equity suit of the Boston, Concord and Montreal Railroad against the Boston and Maine Railroad, Frank A. Merrill of Concord, a civil engineer, testified that in his opinion the line is not safe for present traffic because of the worn condition of the rails, rotten ties and bad spiking, broken plates and culverts and poor ballasting.

ALBANY, April 27.--Gov. Hill goes to New-York to-morrow, ostensibly to review the Sixty-ninth Regiment, but there is a suspicion that he intends to appear in a dramatic way before the Senate investigating committee and try to explain his intimate relations with the disreputable Squire.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Apri1 27.--The Presbytery of Louisville has adopted the following concerning the union of the Northern and Southern Churches:

At the fire in the apartment house at Ninth-avenue and Fifty-seventh-street on Thursday afternoon there were 13 engines present, 3 of which attached their hose to hydrants that proved to be dry. These were at Fifty-seventh-street, 200 feet east of Ninth-avenue; at Sixtieth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, and at 315 West Fifty-eighth-street.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 27.--The Prohibition Convention of the Fitteenth Congressional District assembled in this town to-day and selected for delegates to the Prohibition National Convention, to be held in Indianapolis ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 27.--The second annual dinner of the Americus Club of this city in commemoration of the birthday of Gen. Grant was given this evening at the Monongahela House, covers for 200 being laid.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--The attendance in the House to-day, particularly during the afternoon, was small, and the members who spoke on the Tariff bill realized that their power to draw was slight as compared with that of the horse races at Ivy City.

BANGOR, Me., April 27.--Salmon have come with a rush much earlier than usual, and fly fishing for the beauties began yesterday. Six magnificent fellows were struck and three were landed, two of them weighing 17 pounds each. The grounds are in the city limits. There are no restrictions regarding the fishing. The water is very low.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 27.--The sale of the Belle Meade and Richland yearlings, held at Belle Meade to-day, was as complete a failure as was that of the Kenesaw and Cliff Lawn younsters, held yesterday.

Frank Nowlan, a nurse at the Long Island College Hospital, was found dead in his room in the hospital yesterday morning, and it was supposed that he had been poisoned. Nowlan had been given a day off Thursday, and had not returned to the hospital until midnight.

PARIS, April 27.--Gen. Boulanger gave his political banquet at the Cafe Riche this evening. There was a crowd of about 1,000 persons outside the cafe at 6 P.M. Gen. Boulanger and Count Dillon arrived at 7 o' clock.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday gave a hearing on the application of Louis Wendel, who was a member of the "boodle" Board of Aldermen of 1884, for a renewal of the concert license for Lion Park, at Ninth-avenue and One Hundred and Ninth-street.

ALBANY, April 27.--There are three ale and porter breweries here now that are working with non-union forces. The Arbitration Committee of District Assembly No. 147, Knights of Labor, waited on Granger Story to-day and demanded that they sign the Knights' agreement.

The cause of the failure of Clarke, Radcliffe Co., the hosiery commission house, is still a mystery. Frederick B. Bard, the Assignee, said yesterday that he had a force of experts engaged in an examination of the books, ...

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27.--Manager Bigelow of the Nevada Bank states as a reason for the reorganization of the stock and Directorate of the Nevada Bank on a new basis as proposed in a circular issued to-day that the three men owning nearly all the stock--J.C. Flood, ex-Senator Fair, and J.W. Mackay--cannot give that personal attention to the bank that it should receive, on account of Flood's ill health and Mackay and Fair's other business.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, April 27.--A dispatch from Fort Gibson announces that Sergt. James White, Company C, Eighteenth Infantry, met a horrible death there yesterday. He went to lariat Col. Coppinger's horse. While holding a stake with the point toward him the animal suddenly kicked at him, striking the stake and driving it clean through his body. The Sergeant died instantly.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 27.--What was seemingly a very innocent gathering of grapesugar men was held at Cleveland this week. It was given out to the papers there that it was simply for the discussion of certain tariff matters, but it is learned that the matter which was considered for two days was the formation of a trust.

The Harlem Republican Club observed the birthday of Gen. Grant with a reception that was attended by a large number of people who listened to speeches and the music of an orchestra and enjoyed a supper. Andrew B. Humphrey presided.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 27.--Calvin Turner, the 15-year-old boy who killed his brother by running a pitchfork into his brain in February, was sentenced to-day by Chief-Justice Beasley to the State Reform School until he arrives at age. In order to permit this it was necessary to have a special law passed by the recent Legislature, persons guilty of manslaughter not being allowed to enter this school.

PARIS, April 27.--The debate on the Panama Canal Lottery Loan bill was resumed in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. M. Leguay urged the Chamber not to abandon to ruin a work so essentially French and of such a magnitude.

Nothing quite so curious as the Blaine canvass, at present going on with such vigor, has ever been seen before in American politics. In the first place, the object of all this enthusiasm has apparently declined in advance to be a candidate for the nomination.
A great deal of interest is being taken by those interested in athletics in the second annual meeting of the Cross Country Association, which is to be held this afternoon at Fleetwood Park.

Whether or not Gov. HILL will approve the High License bill seems to be seriously regarded as an open question. We have not very much doubt on the subject, though it will be difficult for him to give any reasons for withholding his approval which will be satisfactory to anybody but the liquor dealers and those who are in close alliance with them.

Mrs. Grant visited the tomb of her husband at Riverside Park yesterday morning, and placed several wreaths or immortelles on the coffin, and a number of azaleas, Easter lilies, and othor flowers in vases upon and about the platform.

The Thompson and Taylor Spice Company of Chicago on April 20 sent from Chicago a registered letter to Hoffman, Lee Co., a coffee house of Baltimore, containing three promissory notes payable at the National Bank of Commerce in this city--one due on ...

ELIZABETHTOWN, April 27.--The Essex County Republicans to-day elected the following delegates to the District Convention: Chester B. McLaughlin of Port Henry, A.S. Viall of Crown Point, Byron Pond of Elizabethtown.

BERLIN, April 27.--A bulletin issued this morning says the Emperor had a good sleep last night and feels much stronger this morning. He was feverish last evening, but early this morning, the fever had disappeared. His general condition is slowly improving.

PRATT, Kan., April 27.--A cyclone struck the east edge of the city this afternoon, demolishing several houses and killing Mrs. William Fisher. Many other persons were seriously hurt by flying debris. This is the second cyclone Pratt has had this Spring.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 27.--All the correspondence relative to the seizure of sealing vessels in Behring Sea has been laid before the House of Commons. It shows that the British Government has been in constant correspondence with the United States authorities since ...
PITTSBURG, April 27.--The strike at the Carnegie Works at Braddock is to-night in a more serious phase than at any other time since its inception.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 27.--Negotiations looking to a lease of the Providence and Worcester Railroad to the New-York, Providence and Boston (Stonington) Railway have ...

LONDON, April 27.--Helene Crosmond, a prima donna, committed suicide in a cab in Piccadilly on Wednesday night. She had signed a contract with Mr. Harris of the Drury Lane Opera Company, but owing to a misunderstanding she tore up the contract in a fit of temper.
The College of the City of New-York, in full operation under the gaslight, was an attraction offered the public by the Alumni last evening that about 2,000 of their friends could not resist.

CHICAGO, April 27.--Chicago shippers are worrying over a discrimination made against them in favor of Eastern merchants, the discrimination being brought about in this way. The rates made by the New-York-Colorado Association on through business from the East ...

The Harlem Bridge, Morrisania and Fordham Railroad Company (the old Huckleberry road) obtained from Judge Barrett yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the Southern Boulevard (surface) Railroad Company from laying tracks on the boulevard in front of the premises of the former company.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--The offers for the sale of bonds to the Government received by Secretary Fairchild to-day amounted to $848,000 in lots as follows: Four percents, registered, $300,000 at 126.70; $3,000 at 125 ; 4 per cents, coupon, $5,000 at 127; ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 27.--A.M. Palmer's "Jim the Penman" company produced a new play, "A Comedy From Life," by Louis Ludovici, at the Arch-Street Theatre this afternoon in the presence of a large audience, including many members of the theatrical profession, to whom an invitation had been extended. The play made an emphatic success and author and actors were warmly applauded.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 27.--Katie Smith, the young lady who became insane in New-York last weak while on her way to a Long Island village, where she was to teach school, and who was brought to the Jefferson County Asylum, died there this morning after a violent recurrence of her insanity. She will be buried at her late home in Rodman, this county.

SALEM, Mass., April 27.--The Seventh District Republican Convention to-day chose as delegates to the National Convention Gen. William Cogswell of Salem and W.E. Blunt of Haverhill. The mention of Blaine as a possible candidate met with enthusiastic applause.
Mrs. Clemence Sophia Harned Lozier, M. D., Dean of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women, died suddenly on Thursday evening at her home, 103 West Forty-eighthstreet.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 27.--Twentyseven years ago Matthew Vassar by gifts and bequests founded Vassar College. He provided it with grounds and buildings worth over half a million of dollars and funds amounting to $275,000.
LONDON, April 27.--The statement that the Pope has issued a decree condemning the plan of campaign in Ireland is confirmed.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 27.--At a special meeting of the City Council to-night the Hon. Carleten Hunt was elected City Attorney in place of W.S. Parkerson, who declined. Mr. Hunt was a member of Congress from this city four years ago, and was recently Dean of the Law School of Tulane University. It is regarded as a superb appointment.
PARIS, April 10.--Gen. Boulanger is not nearly "the dead cock in the pit" that he has been described to be. It is not at all improbable that the General, having gone up rocket-like, ...

TROY, N.Y., April 27.--The Globe Knitting Company in Amsterdam, of which John Consalus and F.A. Fales of this city are the principal owners, and Edward McDonough, mill owner of Amsterdam, have assigned, the latter to Henry O'Brien.
Secretary McIntyre has arranged the following programme for the stake races to be run at the Brooklyn Spring meeting, the entries to which are given in the very neat book programme just issued:

Two beautiful flags--one the American Stars and Stripes, the other the Irish Sunburst-- were on exhibition yesterday at the rectory of the Mission of the Most Holy Rosary, 7 Statestreet, and were admired by all who saw them.

LONDON, April 27.--The Grosvenor Gallery opened its list of Spring oil exhibitions with the worst and weakest show I have ever seen in London. Doubtless the secession of Carr and Halle and Starling to the New Gallery accounts for something of the lamentable falling off in the Grosvenor.

ALBANY, April 27.--The Governor has signed the bills amending the New-York Consolidation act and enabling the New-York Board of Education to provide special schools and classes of instruction in that city.
BOSTON, Mass., April 27.--Nellie, the 19year-old daughter of Mrs. Shewell, a physician who has been living in New-York until recently, in which city she owns considerable property, ...

WASHINGTON, April 27.--Mr. Joseph D. Potts of Philadelphia, formerly President of the Empire Transportation Company, which was bought out by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in 1877, was the first witness in the trust investigation before the House Committee on Manufactures this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--Boston, 4; Washington, 2. Earned runs--Boston, 4. Base hits--Boston, 6; Washington, 5. Stolen bases--Boston, 1. Errors--Boston, 4; Washington, 9. Struck out--By Clarkson, 3; by O'Day, 7.

LONDON, April 27.--The steamship Schledam, (Dutch,) Capt. Monsonides, from New-York April 14 for Amsterdam, passed the Lizard to-day. The steamship Caledonia, (Br.,) Capt. Hassenstein, from Naples for New-York, hasarr, at Lisbon with her machinery out of order.

Henry D. Cooke, the young man who disappeared two days before the date of his wedding to Miss Jeannette Milnor, was found by his father between 12 and 1 o' clock yesterday morning in Sixth-avenue, near Forty-second-street.

Frederick Witt, a German, 23 years old, who was bookkeeper in the tailor's store of his uncle, L. Schlesinger, at 200 Bowery, was instantly killed last night by a shock from a wire of the United States Illuminating Company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 27.--Game Constable Matthew Kennedy made a tour of the Hudson River to-day, notifying all shad fishermen that the law passed a year ago prohibiting fishing from sunset of Saturday night till sunrise Monday morning will be strictly enforced. He says there are about 1,000 shad fishermen between the Narrows and Albany. As yet the catch is very light. The season is going to be short.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., April 27.--Messrs. Andrews Co., manufacturers of boneless fish and wholesale dealers in fish, failed this morning. Liabilities, $20,000; assets small.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 28.--The Alamo Ice and Brewing Company made an assignment yesterday. The property of the company is valued at about $75,000.
Gen. Joseph E. Johnston, the gallant exConfederate officer, has been elected a contributing member of Gen. E.D. Baker Post, No. 8, of this city.

Funeral services will be held to-day in the old Allen Street Church. They will begin with a love feast at 9 o'clock, followed by a sermon at 10:30 by Bishop Cyrus D. Foss; a reunion service at 3 o'clock, with addresses by former Pastors and members: prayer meeting at 6:30, and regular evening service at 7:30, when the Rev. M.D'C. Crawford will preach.

CHICAGO, April 28.--Congressman Adams was to-day renominated by the Republicans of the Fourth Congressional District. Hempstead Washburne, who made such a strong fight against Adams at the primaries, has been ...

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 28.--The Democrats of Broome County held their convention in this city to-day. Charles A. Hull, George E. Collins, and James A. Wheeler were elected delegates to the State Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28.--Among the documents which the executive department of the Pennsylvania State Government compiles for public information, and which, of course, few people take the trouble to read, to the report of the Auditor-General.

The dealers and importers in the Foreign Fruit Exchange are at odds over the manner in which fruit is put up for sale at auctions. The dealers claim that they have to buy they goods without a proper chance to inspect them.

NASHVILLE, April 28.--The Spring meeting opened here to-day with excellent sport, Jacobin running his mile in the best time of the year, 1:41, and Milton Young winning the Ivy Leaf Stakes for 2-year-olds, as he has every stake ...

WALLA WALLA, Washington Territory, April 28.--Three weeks ago there were published meagre accounts of a massacre of Chinamen on Snake River, just above the mouth of the Imnaha.
WINNSBORO, S.C., April 28.--William and Robert Charles, brothers were planting cotton yesterday in a field in this county.

Senator Wade Hampton, Gen. Hampton in his native State, has had some queer experiences during his eventful life--we speak of experiences with the animal of all others that he loves and can handle best--the horse.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--The sensational race here to-day was that for the Youthful Stakes, at a half mile--the first, 2-year-old race in the East. It was won, as had been expected, by R.W. Walden's Holiday, a chestnut filly by Plunger Walton's Hopeful, out of Minnie Mac.

There was a tremendous fall of rocks the other day upon the railway line between Vienna and Trieste, near Gratz, and there was just time to stop the express which was then due and in which the Archduke Otto was a passenger.

Capt. Thomas Sampson, who for over 25 years has been employed in the Sub-Treasury in this city, is in a fair way to receive Government recognition for the heroism displayed by him in rescuing five boys from drowning, in peril of his own life, over 30 years ago.

The tenants of THE TIMES Building have joined the grand army of movers this Spring, and will be missed from quarters that have known them long. They were not forced to enlist by any dispossess proceedings, and they were not given notice because they were in any manner objectionable; neither is it correct to suppose that they were dissatisfied.

BOSTON, Mass., April 28.--The reports in full of the majority and minority of the committee appointed by the overseers of Harvard College to consider the subject of athletics at the university are published to-day.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 28.--The steamer Main, from Bremen, which had been detained at Quarantine for two days on account of a case of smallpox having been discovered on board, reached Pier No. 8, Locust Point, today. Her 1,147 immigrants were discharged and started on their way West by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

The Volunteer Firemen's Association serenaded Gov. Hill at the Hoffman House last evening, in token of their appreciation of his action in regard to the tax on foreign insurance companies, whereby their widows and orphans' fund is benefited.
There have been endless squabbles and "tracasseries" about the tiara which was presented to the Princess of Wales by her "lady friends."

The following letter, recently received at the Lincoln Institution, confirms the story of the wedding of Chaska, the Cheyenne Indian, to Miss Cora Fellows, a white lady teacher on the reservation, concerning which there have been so many contradictory stories. Chaska's English name is Samuel Campbell:

During the late violent storms in the channel the washed through a high and hard sandbank near St. Malo, nearly four meters thick, laying bare a portion of an ancient forest, which was already passing into the condition of coal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 28.--There was considerable excitement at the session of the call board to-day owing to the steadily-rising prices.
PHILADELPHIA, Apri1 28.--This has been the biggest day ever known in Philadelphia's harbor. Half the vessels in port, from Southwark to Kensington, were decked with their national colors.

ALBANY, April 28.--Five lager beer brewing firms in this city, producing 100,000 barrels a year, four in Troy, and one each in West Troy and Schenectady, making an aggregate of 55,000 barrels per annum, have signed an agreement with the Central Labor Union, to which their employes belong, for one year from May 1.
It was hoped that Robert Forman, the eccentric young Englishman who has been bothering the Hoffman House people for a week by his vagaries, world sail yesterday on the Umbria.
NYACK, N.Y., April 28.--The largest Funeral ever held in this place was that of Gen. Abram Merritt, which occurred at the Reformed Church at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

The event which already in the anticipation overshadows every other theatrical incident of the year is the Wallack benefit. The tribute to Lester Wallack which the people of New-York are now contemplating will be substantial, and will fitly express the esteem in which that distinguished actor and manager is held.

A number of ministers of this city have been invited to hear Gen. George A. Sheridan deliver his reply to Col. Robert G. Ingersoll in the shape of a lecture entitled. "The Modern Pagan," to be given to-night at the Forty-thirdStreet Methodist Episcopal Church. This subject has never been discussed by Gen. Sheridan before in this city. The lecture will be given under the auspices of the lyceum of the church.

Madison-Square Garden was filled with a shouting multitude last night when Gov. Hill presented the Archbishop Croke American flag to the Sixty--ninth Regiment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 28.--A passenger train on the Western New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad was wrecked near Portville, Allegany County, shortly before noon to-day. The rails spread and the baggage and mail car and two passenger coaches were thrown from the track, rolling down an embankment 20 ...
HAVANA, April 28.--Manuel Santalla and Miguel Gonzalez, the convicted kidnappers, were executed at Matanzas yesterday.

PITTSBURG, April 28.--The feeling at Braddock to-day was intensified when the men read the published interview in which Mr. Carnegie not only repeated his views, but emphasized the statement that the men must go to work on the terms proposed.

Mrs. Carl Strakosch (Miss Clara Louise Kellogg) has been ill for about a month with whooping cough, which has caused her to abandon the concert tour she had planned for this Spring. The couth is severe and extremely troublesome.

ALBANY, April 28.--Under the opinion by Attorney-General Tabor that the appointments by the Board of Electrical Control came under the rules of the State Civil Service Commissioners, that board has scheduled the positions as follows: Under schedule A, the Chief Engineer and Assistant Secretary. Under schedule B, the electrical expert, the inspectors of electrical conductors, the inspectors of underground construction, the stenographer, and messenger.
GAINESVILLE, Texas, April 28.--The greatest flood that has ever swept Northern Texas is now passing over the country for 50 miles on each side of the Red River.

William B. Dinsmore's will was filed for probate yesterday. It was executed Jan. 20, 1878, and Dumont Clarke and his sons, William B. Dinsmore and Clarence G. Dinsmore, are named as Executors, with power to appoint ...

WASHINGTON, April 28.--Altogether the best day in the House since the tariff debate opened was that upon which fully two-thirds of the members were away at the launching of the Yorktown and the dynamite cruiser or off at the Ivy City races.

It has been a puzzle to some of Mr. BLAINE'S friends, and to nearly all Republicans who are not his friends, why he wrote his Florence letter declaring that his name would not be presented to the Republican National Convention.

LONDON, April 28.--Certain vague rumors concerning the fear of an impending FranceItalian trouble, of which I cabled last night, are circulating to-day among the people who are interested in Continental politics, but no hint of it as yet has appeared in the papers.
A confirmed old bachelor, named Gueit, a retired tradesman of considerable wealth, has just committed suicide under rather peculiar circumstances.

At Princeton yesterday afternoon wearers of the orange and black won a significant victory over nine men sporting the dark blue of Yale. It was the opening game of the College Association championship series, and the score of 6 to 5 in favor of the players against whom odds were offered indicates that it was a desperately contested game of baseball.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--Mr. Michael Dwyer of the firm of Dwyer Brothers to-day purchased of Mr. G.B. Morris his colt Sir Dixon and will send him to Brooklyn Sunday. The price paid was $20,000. This sale makes it certain that Sir Dixon will not start for the Kentucky Derby, for which he had been heavily backed.

FORT SMITH, Ark., April 28.--While the Cherokee authorities were attempting to arrest Jack Hawk and Bill Beaver, two outlaws, on Lees Creek on Monday, they resisted and were shot dead, after a long fight from behind a barricade of horses. They were two desperate characters, and had long been wanted for murders covering a series of years.

LONDON, April 14.--Some three months ago a special telegram from London in THE NEW-YORK TIMES announced that Major Templer, Instructor in Ballooning at Chatham, had been arrested charged with purvoying State secrets to foreign powers.

Carl Pfeiffer, the architect, died Friday at Washington, aged 50 years. His health had been precarious for several years, but he grew suddenly worse about a month ago and went to Asheville, N.C., in the hope that change of scene and entire rest might prove beneficial.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 28.--Several months ago Josephine Ammon went to jail and remained there for six weeks because she would not tell the whereabouts of Josie Blann, a simple-minded woman who is worth $70,000.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 28.--While work men yesterday were tearing down a house in McKeesport, which was built in 1833 by Orlando Grier, they found built in with the chimney a flask filled with whisky, a label on the bottle giving the date of distillation as 1828.

So far as the real estate market may be ganged by public sales, last week was the reverse of brilliant. During no other week of the present season was so much property bought in. It is surely within safe bounds to say that fully half the property offered did not change owner ship.

The Queen's private rooms at a Villa Palmieri, which are on the upper floor, have been almost entirely furnished from Windsor, her Majesty sending a bedstead, with its furniture, a bath, all the washing apparatus, a rocking-chair, two armchairs, a sofa, a writing-table, ...

There was a gallant struggle at Fleetwood Park yesterday, between the famous crosscountry runners E.C. Carter, who holds the English and American championships, and T.P. Conneff, the Irish champion. The former ran with the Suburban Harriers, the latter with the Manhattan Athletic Club's men.

BATH, Me., April 28.--The steam yacht Sapphire, designed by Edward Burgess, and built for John Stetson of the Globe Theatre, Boston, was launched at 2 o'clock this afternoon from the yard of the New-England Ship Building Company. She cost about $35,000, and will be used exclusively as a pleasure boat.

John Gilbert, the actor, was attacked with illness while on the stage on Thursday night, and since then the frequenters of Wallack's Theatre have missed the familiar features of the aged player of Sir Peter Teazle in " The School for Scandal." Mr. Gilbert's indisposition, however, is not of an alarming nature, and he will fill his accustomed part on Monday evening.
PARIS, April 28.--The Panama Lottery Loan bill passed the Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 312 to 132.

There is awful suggestiveness in the statement of the Rev. George H. Tilghman, who shot his wife yesterday, that he borrowed the pistol "as he intended to go out into the country to collect funds for his church."

There is consternation among the managers of the Fifth-Avenue Stage Company. "Col." Elliott F. Shepard, the traveled son-inlaw of the late William H. Vanderbilt, founder of the bank of banks, journalistic missionary, and maker of Presidents, is up to strange tricks.
In appealing for subscriptions to the Mount Sanai Hospital through a circular just issued figures are given to justify such an appeal.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 28.--The canal toll on gram is fixed at 2 cents a ton, which includes both the Welland and St. Lawrence Canals.

Last night another landmark disappeared, ivory ceasing play to make way for the architectural growth of the metropolis. The old billiard room in Park-row is historic. Existing for 30 years it was known to professionals and amateurs from Portland, Me., to Portland, Oregon.
A theatrical performance by amateurs and professionals for the benefit of the Babies' Shelter of the Church of the Holy Communion will be given at the Lyceum Theatre on Friday afternoon.

I heard two good stories to-day of Pettigrew of South Carolina, the great lawyer and Unionist. He was practicing at one time before a Judge who was a Presbyterian of the straitest sect and a very hard working officer.

The death of Roscoe Conkling recalls the Republican National Convention of 1880 at Chicago,in which he led the New-York delegation. He had not only supported Grant for the nomination, but made the nominating speech and east the vote of his delegation 36 times in that memorable contest, in which 306 delegates remained ...
In the investigation of the brewers' lockout by the State Board of Arbitration the workmen yesterday, as previously, suffered more from the testimony of their own witnesses than did the employers.
BOSTON, Mass., April 28.--The old war ship Ticonderoga, which was recently sold to be broken up, was towed to Apple Island this morning, where she will be burned for her ...

WASHINGTON, April 28.--In the course of his examination before the Manufacturers' Committee to-day Mr. Archibald of the Standard Oil Company, admitted that a number of small oil manufactories had been dismantled after their purchase by the Standard Oil Company.

The trout anglers who have been confined to Long Island for the gratification of their love of the sport will be enabled to change their scene and whip the brooks and rivers of the Forest Preserve this week.
ROME, April 28.--It is stated here that the action of the Congregation of the Holy See regarding the plan of campaign in Ireland was taken spontaneously and without previous suggestion from England.
CHICAGO, April 28.--Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde, home rule member of Parliament for South Dublin, reached this city today after a tour in the West and in Mexico.
LONDON, April 28.--The General Transatlantic Line steamship La Bourgogne, Capt. Franquel, from New-York April 21 for Havre, passed the Lizard at 8:25 P.M. to-day.

LANSING, Mich., April 28.--Two cases of scarlet fever have been reported at the State Agricultural College, and the authorities deemed it wise to suspend the term.

SOUTH BOSTON, Va., April 26.--Mr. Archibald Glenn, of this (Halifax) county, was in his day a very prominent man. He was a graduate of the University of Virginia, and among his college mates were men who afterward became illustrious in the annals of their State and country.

Company F. Eighth Regiment, elects a Second Lieutenant to-morrow evening. Non-commissioned officers are to be elected Tuesday evening by Company B, Seventyfirst Regiment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28.--Near Richmond, Ky., Saturday, Aaron Stoltz, a farmer, committed suicide by taking poison. His brother William, seeing the corpse, took the remainder of the poison, leaving a note saying he wished both to be buried in the same coffin.

The appropriations in the pending River and Harbor bill for Buttermilk Channel and Sabine Pass show to what extent the logrollers who make such bills are guided by the actual requirements of commerce.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 28.--Seeding in the Northwest has not been so late since the Spring of 1885. Not until last week was the ground in anything like favorable condition, and then only in a portion of this State and Dakota.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 28.--There is apparently no one in or about Newport who is not preparing in some way for the approaching fashionable season. The farmer has planted his early vegetables, for which he expects fancy prices; the local shop keeper is painting and improving his place of business, and he is laying ...

Seth Thomas, the head of the Seth Thomaas Clock and Watch Manufacturing Company, died yesterday at Thomaston, Conn., aged 71 years. He was born in Thomaston and was the son of Seth Thomas, the original founder of the firm.

The fifty-sixth annual convention of the Alpha Detta Phi Fraternity will be held in the Grand Commandery Hall of the Masonic Temple, Sixth-avenue and Twenty-third-street, on Thursday and Friday, May 3 and 4, under the auspices of the Executive Council of the fraternity.
The Hon. James D. Porter has withdrawn from the race for the Senatorship by the following letter addressed to Mr. John R. Rison, editor of the Paris (Tenn.) Post-Intelligencer:

MINNEAPOLIS, April 28.--Coroner Hill, who returned from Europe on Thursday, came in contact with Mr. Blaine while the latter was recuperating at Florence, Italy. The doctor had an opportunity to judge of Mr. Blaine's physical condition, and says that he was really in a critical state. He says that Mr. Blaine rode a great, deal, and the serious condition of his health was very generally impressed upon the public mind.
Medicine in the market is Riker's Compound Sarsaparilla, because it costs only 75 cents per large bottle. It contains nearly double quantity of any other.
BELLEFONTAINE, Ohio, April 28.--A terrible accident occurred at Rushsylvania, last night. A school exhibition was in progress in Brookman's Hall, situated in the second story of a brick building.
BERLIN, April 28.--Mr. Pendleton, the American Minister, will remain at Wiesbaden some time longer. His condition is improving, and he leaves his bed daily.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--First Lieut. Ogden Rafferty, Assistant Surgeon, has been ordered to report for duty at Fort Clark, Texas, relieving Capt. John Lauderdale, Assistant Surgeon, ordered to duty at Fort Davis, Texas.
The State Senate Committee on Taxation was to have given a hearing on the Brundage Tax bill yesterday, but as Senator Vedder was the only member or the committee who appeared he declined to go on.
VIENNA, April 10.--A magnificent entertainment took place last night in the palace of the reigning Prince of Lichtenetein for the benefit of one the city charities.
Since 9 o'clock on Saturday night snow has not ceased failling here. It rests upon our roofs and in the streets half a foot deep, seriously interfering with traffic of all kinds.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 28.--The Western steel company that has been operating the Vulcan Steel Mills in South St. Louis will close down in July, throwing several hundred man out of employment.

PARIS, April 28.--There was a renewal of the disorders at Nancy to-night. Ten arrests were made, but the crowd refused to disperse, and the hussars were ordered to charge with the gendarmes and clear the streets.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 28.--The friends of Wesleyan University are manifesting deep interest in the selection of a President of the institution to suceed Dr. J.W. Beach, who was removed from office by the Trustees last Summer.
COLUMBUS, April 28.--Owing to the mismanagement of its affairs by the Cashier, P.W. Corzelius, the South End Bank temporarily suspended payment this morning.

In Europe the popular idea of citizens of these United States still partakes of the prejudices derived from the romances of Sam Slick, the performances of the stage Yankee, and the " American Notes" of the late Mr. CHARLES DICKENS. We are thought nothing if not 'cute.

CANTON, Ohio, April 28.--Ray Falke, aged 17 years, son of William Falke, and employed in Newsteitei's printing office, last night called on Mamie Roof, daughter of Adam Roof, to whom rumor had Falke engaged.

CHICAGO, April 28.--The race for the Republican nomination for Governor is extremely hot between "Private" Joseph Fifer and Gen. John McNulta, Receiver of the Wabash Road, and one of the latest features was a report that Gen. McNulta was to withdraw in favor of ...

NEWPORT, R.I., April 28.--Miss Jane Stuart, daughter of Gilbert Stuart, the artist, died here this morning, aged nearly 80. Miss Stuart had been ill only about a week. She was a brilliant and accomplished woman and in the Summer season her pretty cottage was thronged with people prominent in literary circles. AUBURN, N.Y., April 30.--John Joseph McMahon was released from the prison here this morning, having been pardoned by President Cleveland. On March 18, 1886, McMahon pleaded guilty in the United States Court in the city of New-York to embezzling $20,000 from the Leather Manufacturers' Bank. His sentence was for five years, and he has actually served two years, one month, and eight days of this time.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30.--C.Y. King, Pastor of Miller-Avenue Methodist Church, committed suicide last night while delirions from fever. He arose from his bed, secured a razor, and before his landlady could reach him had dashed into another part of the house and cut three frightful gashes in his neck and almost severed his head from his body. He died instantly. King was 80 years old. He was a successful minister and well known.

LONDON, April 30.--There is a panic in the tin market. The French syndicate has ceased buying. The cash price has dropped from 166 to 105 per ton, and little has changed hands at the latter price.

Thanks to Capt. Ewing's very poor playing at third base yesterday, the Boston ball players won a game from the New-York team, though it took ten innings for them to do it. Eight thousand people saw New-York's highsalaried players lose a game that should have been won, as the New-York nine, with the exception of Ewing, played by far the better game.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 30.--Drafts--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

WIESBADEN, April 30.--Mr. Pendleton, the American Minister, went out driving to-day. The effects of his stroke of paralysis have nearly disappeared. He will remain at Wiesbaden for several weeks.

CHICAGO, April 30.--Chairman Midgley and the gentlemen acting with him on the committee having in charge the question of through rates to Colorado points have agreed to make the rates on commodities from Chicago 20 to 25 per cent. below the authorized rates from NewYork. This includes all articles which in the East come under the head of commodities.

He was to-day dominated by the President for Chief-Justice of the United States, and will probably be confirmed without delay. It was only within a day or two that the President has riveted his attention upon Mr. Fuller with a conviction that he ...
The Amateur Opera Association of Brooklyn closed its eleventh season last evening with a performance at the Academy of Music in that city of "The Beggar Student."

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 30.--Yesterday was another "dry Sunday" here. The saloons were all closed but one, the proprietor of which was arrested. This morning the Recorder fined him $30. Other business places besides the saloons were ordered closed yesterday.
Mary L. Chipperfield, a spinster, 53 years old, poor and threatened with total blindness, attempted to commit suicide by taking paris green at 8 Hester-street yesterday.

PARIS, April 30.--The affray Saturday night between Boulangists and a party of students who came out from the students' Club, in which several shots were fired, though few persons were injured, was not in this city, but at Toulouse. The conflict was resumed last night, but was suppressed by the police without any serious results.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 30.--The License Court Judges to-day announced their decisions in the cases of applicants for liquor license in the Seventeenth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth, Twentieth, and Twenty-first Wards. Licensee are granted to 187 applicants and refused to 389. In the district covered by these five wards there are at present 1,056 saloons, the licenses for which expire May 30.

NAVASOTA, Tex., April 30.--Reports reached the city to-day that a man named Jordan, together with his wife and two children, were drowned yesterday in the Brazos River. Jordan was a fisherman by occupation, and at one time was a prominent citizen of this city.

The thirtieth annual report of the Chamber of Commerce, presented yesterday by Secretary George Wilson, gives a comprehensive review of the proceedings of the Chamber for 1887, with reports of the loading trades, in the staples of export and import, collected from reports of the Nation, State, and city.

LONDON, April 30.--On the Stock Exchange to-day business was active and prices closed firm. Foreign securities were strong American railroad securities were largely bought on both English and New-York account. The advance ranges from 20 to 3/8.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 30.--A rupture bordering upon open revolt has occurred in St. Augustine's Church here, a large and wealthy society of which the Rep. Father Cremin is the Rector.

Bayonne's City Council organized last evening with nine Councilmen, the election contest in the Fourth Ward remaining unsettled. John Bull and William Kelley had each received 206 votes. Councilman John W. Goddard of the First Ward was re-elected President.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 30.--A romantic marriage occured at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Woman's Chbistian Home, 49 West Petersstreet.

HARTFORD, April 30.--The Connecticut delegates to the National Democratic Convention at St. Louis will be selected on Wednesday of this week, the State Convention being held here. The Democracy of the State will present an unbroken front in favor of the renomination of President Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30.--The body of Charles J. Ferguson, the Philadelphia Baseball Club's pitcher, who died here Sunday evening, was taken to his home at Charlottesville, Va., to-day. All the players and Directors of the Philadelphia Club attended that funeral services here to-day. The Princeton College ball nine, which he has trained for several years, will attend his funeral.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30.--Fire this afternoon destroyed the offices of the Leader and Homestead, on Court-avenue.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 30.--The Republican State Convention will meet in this city tomorrow at 11 A. M. in the State House.
Henry Belden, a stock broker who lives at 49 Fort Greene-place, Brooklyn, was awakened at 2 o'clock yesterday morning by his wife who thought she heard some one down stairs.

John Moody, a bootblack, 16 years old while playing at Maiden-lane and Water-street yesterday afternoon, was knocked down and run over by an Adams Express wagon, driven by Frank Sanders and was severely injured.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 30.--Superintendent of Public Works Shanahan directs that the State canals be officially opened on May 10. The repairs to the damaged schcharie aqueduct and the work on the lengthened locks will be finished by Saturday night.
The closing exercises of the art schools of the Metropolitan Museum, at Third-avenue and Forty-ninth-street, took place last night.
HAVANA, April 30.--Advices from Matanzas state that the bandit Marrero has been killed and the bandit Alfonso so severely wounded that he had to be taken to a hospital.

Mrs. Emma Phillips, the wife of John S. Phillips, who was formerly the Manager of the United Press Association, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by hanging herself in her bedroom.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 30.--In the Senate to-day the fisheries treaty was again up for discussion.

Four more railroads reported their earnings yesterday for the third week of April, all showing increases. The Memphis and Charleston gained $5,414; East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia increased $17,240; Ohio River gained $3,994; Flint and Pere Marquette gained $2,124.
BOSTON, April 30.--The Fourth District Democrats to-night elected Matthew Keaney and James A. McGeough as delegates to the National Convention, with P.J. Kennedy and Isaac Rosnosky as alternates.
Fire Marshal Lewis of Brooklyn is convinced that the disastrous fire which consumed stover's dry goods store on Sunday was the result of some incendiary's work.
CHICAGO, April 30.--The disturbance of passenger rates between Chicago and Boston led to a meeting of the General Passenger Agents of the interested lines here to-day.

BOSTON, Mass., April 30.--The expected change in the Boston Advertiser proprietorship has been consummated by the incorporation of the Advertiser Newspaper Company of Boston, with William C. Barrett, President, Henry Parkman, Treasurer, and Samuel W. McCall as Directors. The capital stock is $30,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30.--A meeting of the stockholders and Directors of the South End Bank was held to-day. A full statement of the actual financial condition of the bank showed that it was sound.

DETROIT, Mich., April 30.--The annual report of the Flint and Pere Marquette Railway for the year ending Dec. 31, 1887, is just out. It shows the number of miles of main track to be 363 , and of sidings 224. The earnings with comparison were as follows:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 30.--The strike of the employes of Weibeb Brewery in this city was settled by arbitration to-night. The strike has bean in progress for five weeks, and arose from the discharge of a workman for incompetency. Alderman Kleiner was chosen as arbitrator, and both sides find no fault with his decission. It is said that concessions were made on both sides.

DANBURY, Conn., April 30.--The Tweedy Manufacturing Company, the largest hat factory in America and the oldest in the State, shut down to-day for the first time in nearly 20 years, throwing 1,100 hatters out of work. The factory will be closed for an indefinite time until a reorganization of the company is effected.

The one thing that was talked about more than anything else in White Plains yesterday was the suicide of the Rev. Edgar Laing Heermance in his former pulpit on Sunday. At the house of the dead clergyman the blinds were drawn and the family saw only a few intimate friends.
Prof. Leed's labaratory in Stevens Institute, Hoboken, was destroyed by fire last night. Instruments worth $5,000 were consumed. The building way slightly damaged. The cause of the fire is unknown.

LONDON, May 1.--The dynamite outcry threatens again to arise. The police pretend to have been informed that a group of dynamiters, sent by the Clan-na-Gael, are on their way to this country. A special watch has been placed at all the ports.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 1.--The Finance Committee of the new City Council Monday night held a meeting to investigate alleged irregularities in the office of the Board of Tax Assessors.

Melton Prior, the famous war artist and correspondent of the London Illustrated News, lectured in Chickering Hall last night on the Soudan War and the Nile Expedition, including the defeat of Gen. Baker Pasha at Trinkitat.

About four weeks ago F.H. McDonald, who has a bucket shop at 69 New-street, took Chauncey Lewis into partnership. Since then the two have been doing business under the firm name of F.H. McDonald Co. Saturday ...

The sensation in financial and business circles yesterday, was the National Park Bank defalcation, announced exclusively in THE TIMES. It was the talk of the town and caused countless inquiries for further particulars at the bank building, in Broadway, between Fulton and Ann streets.

One of the officers of the Manhattan Railway News Company was asked yesterday by a TIMES reporter to give for publication his opinion of the bill to prevent the sale of newspapers on the elevated railroads.

WOODSVILLE, N.H., May 1.--The farm buildings of George O. Butler were struck by lightning last night and burned, together with 16 cows, 2 horses, 18 hogs, and 3 young cattle. Most of the farming implements and household furniture were saved. The loss is about $4,000; nearly covered by insurance.

CHICAGO, May. 1.--A secret conference was held at the Grand Pacific Hotel late to-day, which is reported to have resulted in a determination by the representatives of the Brotherhood of Engineers to declare the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy strike off.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--The Municipal Councils of the Irish National League held a meeting to-night, at which 31 branches of the league were represented.
CITY OF MEXICO, May 1, via Galveston.-- Following in the footsteps of Guanajuato and Michoacan, Guerrero has suppressed bull fighting.

CHICAGO, May 1.--Charles A. Howard of Milwaukee, a widely-known Masonic dignitary, but whose financial circumstances have heretofore been at bestonly moderately comfortable, was yesterday notified by his lawyer here of a bequest aggregating over $1,000,000.
TOWER CITY, Dakota, May 1.--Particulars of the burning of the residence of George Stillman, 18 miles northwest of here, are just received. The fire was discovered at 6 o'clock in the morning.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 1.--The story has already been published of the marriage of Dr. Atkinson of Chester, S.C., to Miss Florence Little of Gaffney City, and of her confession to him that she had been previously married to Augustus Mintz.

Saint Mary's Young Men's Catholic Association of Morristown, N.J., opened their new association rooms with appropriate exercises yesterday afternoon.

NYACK, N.Y., May 1.--An elopement from this place, which occurred yesterday afternoon, has proved an interesting theme for many persons here to-day. Lorenzo C. Comings is a gentleman well known in this place, where he resides and is much respected.
The fishing cranks in Bangor to-day are wild with delight and enthusiasm and men carrying rods and reels and with their feet stuck into rubber boots have been seen scurrying in all directions.

YOKOHAMA, May 1.--Count Hiroburni, the Prime Minister, has resigned. Count Kurado, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, succeeds him.

The question as to who shall have possession of the Diss Debar children was discussed before Justice Kilbreth in the Special Sessions Court yesterday. Elbridge T. Gerry appeared on behalf of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, in whose custody the children have been for several days.

One of the most brutal murders ever set on record in Italy was committed last week in Venice, a city little used to crimes of such a singularly revolting kind. Giovanni Rossi, a young artisan, had, it seems, fallen desperately in love with his wife's sister, Anna dalla Giustina.

CONCORD, N.H., May 1.--Democrats crowded old Phoenix Hall to-day until it was overflowed. It was the date of the State Convention, and such a large convention was never before held here. The floor of the hall was not large enough to hold all the delegates, and many were obliged to be content with seats in the gallery.

The term of Mr. Eugene Tompkins's management of the Fifth-Avenue Theatre began last evening in a promising manner. PITTSBURG, May 1.--The rail, blooming, and converting departments at the Edgar Thomson Steel Works have not yet been started up, but the machinery is in operation and everything points to a resumption in these departments at any hour.
A good story was recently in circulation at the Bangor Theological Seminary which would indicate that old sermons are at a premium.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 1.--A meeting of the stock and bond holders of the South Pennsyl vania Railroad Company has been called for May 9 at the office of F.L. Stetson, 45 William-street, New-York. The call is signed S.M. Stevenson, Secretary of the Reorganization Committee.

Albert Griffin, the Chairman of the antisaloon Republicans, was not as enthusiastic yesterday as he was some time since over the second National Convention of his party, which will be held in the Cooper Union, beginning at 11 A.M. to-day.
Judge C.F. Brown of the Supreme Court yesterday rendered his decision at Sing Sing on the constitutionality of the cattle law.
