WASHINGTON, May 1.--The House Committee on Manufactures resumed its investigation into the Standard Oil Trust this morning. Harlow Dow of Memphis, Tenn., was called. He said he was engaged in buying and selling oil from persons and companies in opposition to the Standard Oil Trust.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 1.--Judging from present appearances, the State Convention of Prohibitionists, which will meet in this city to-morrow, will be the largest in the history of the movement in Pennsylvania, and if the spirit which animates the leaders and delegates now here prevails during the sittings of the convention it will be the most enthusiastic also.
ADRIAN, Mich., May 1.--The first delegates to the Republican National Convention from Michigan were elected to-day by the Second District Congressional Convention.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 1.--The Illinois State Republican Convention which meets tomorrow promises to be one of the most exciting and most numerously attended that has been held for many years.
OMAHA, Neb., May 1.--The Democrats of Nebraska will meet in convention in this city to-morrow afternoon for the purpose of selecting ten delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 1.--Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde arrived here this morning from the West and was given a hearty reception. He was received in both houses of the Legislature, and in the afternoon was entertained by ex-Mayor John Boyd Thatcher. This evening a public meeting was held at which Sir Thomas made an address on home rule for Ireland. Afterward he was received by the Dongan Club.

MADISON, Ind., May 1.--In the election to-day the Republicans gained one Councilman and a Water Works Trustee, retaining control of city affairs. The Democrats re-elect the Mayor by a reduced majority.

JACKSON, Miss., May 1.--Ever since the killing of young Roderick Gambrell, the Prohibition editor, by Col. Jones S. Hamilton, the penitentiary lessee, for which Col. Hamilton was acquitted last week, there has been bitterness between the friends of the parties.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 1.--The Republican Club delegates have been arriving rapidly all day, and the prospect is that the gathering to-morrow will be large and rather enthusiastic.

Business was stagnant on the Iron and Metal Exchange yesterday. The unprecedented drop in the tin market was the cause.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 1.--It is mentioned as among the possibilities that the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway will this season be extended to the international boundary to make connection with the Red River Valley Railroad.
HUDSON, N.Y., May 1.--The trial of Andrew S. Ford, charged with causing the death of his wife by poison in September last, is nearly at an end.
It is a very interesting bill, this bill for the improvement of rivers and harbors which is now before the House. There is no page of it that is not rich in specimens of queer legislation.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 1.--The Connecticut River continues to rise, and has caused considerable damage. Long reaches of track on the Meriden and Cromwell Railroad are inundated, and traffic is seriously interrupted.

The Twenty-fifth General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began its sessions in the Metropolitan Opera House at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. For more than half an hour previous the big building was thronged with ministerial and lay delegates, local and visiting brethren, and persons who had come to look on.

RICHMOND, Va., May 1.--Mr. Maurice B. Flynn of New-York, whose name has been prominently mentioned in connection with the Aqueduct investigation now being conducted by the Fassett Senate Committee, was arrested here yesterday on an absconding debtor's warrant.
John Masterson was shot and fatally wounded last night in Jersey City by Daniel Tighe. Both men live at 438 First-street, and the shooting occurred at the door of their dwelling.

Senator INGALLS made a number of gentlemen very uncomfortable yesterday. Perhaps the most acute and immediate distress was among the Democratic Senators, to whom he recalled some passages in their records that they would wish to have the public forget.

An examination of the State Supreme Court records for the present term shows that 195 cases have been affirmed and 133 cases reversed. There seems to be serious difference between the lower and higher courts as to what is the law in Georgia.

The trouble which has existed between the Commissioners of Emigration and the railroad companies over the ticketing of immigrants in Castle Garden was settled at a special meeting of the board yesterday, when a contract as agreed upon by the passenger agents of the several railroads was accepted.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--Judging of the appropriateness of the President's candidate for Chief-Justice by the character of the comments made here upon the nomination of Mr. Melville W. Fuller, it must be regarded as one of the most fortunate selections made by him since he took office.

President Henry C. Johnson of the Long Island City Board of Police Commissioners resigned yesterday. Mayor Gleason appointed William H. Williams to fill the vacancy. Commissioner Johnson is a Republican and a church member. He desired to prohibit baseball playing on Sundays, and arranged a raid for Sunday last. Mayor Gleason interposed, hence the resignation. The new Commissioner is a brother of Police Inspector Williams of New-York. He held the same position under Mayor Debevoise.

Fire broke out just before 8 o'clock yesterday morning on the second floor of 56 West Thirtieth-street. This building is one of a row of two-story structures, with mansard roofs, the upper part of those numbered from 52 to 56 being occupied by Amelia Carl, who rented furnished rooms.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 1.--A charter was granted at the State Department to-day to the Baltimore and Harrisburg Railway Company, (western extension;) capital, $250,000. WILMINGTON, Del., May 1.--About 100 house carpenters and 75 hod carriers went on strike this morning in accordance with the notice given some weeks ago.
The Morris Tennis Club of Tremont, recently organized, will open for the season of 1888 on Decoration Day.

Two grand marriages took place to-day in Paris. In the first place, the daughter of the Baron and Baroness Legoux was married to the Vicomte de La Poeze. The mother of the bridegroom was formerly dame d'honneur to the Empress Eugenie, who was therefore represented at the ceremony by Prince Murat.

George H. Creed, confidential clerk of Deputy Collector Rockwell at the Custom House, has resigned. He was appointed in 1887, but has been elected Tax Collector of Jamaica, Long Island, and will confine his attention to his new duties.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 1.--The rear of frieght train 82, on the Erie Road, was run into to-day near this city by the extra train following. The caboose, locomotive, and six cars of merchandise were wrecked, blocking the road for 10 hours and causing a loss of $25,000. The conductor and engineer of the extra are held responsible. No one was seriously hurt.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 1.--A good many curious complications arise from the application of the marriage license law of Pennsylvania, but none have ever been reported of so curious and especially discouraging a nature to the parties concerned as are involved in a case which occurred in Beaver County.

Stirling, who claims to be an agent of the New-York Live Stock Mutual Benefit Association, was arrested at Birmingham to night charged with soliciting insurance without a license from the State Commissioner. He was held in $1,000 bonds to await the arrival of Commissioner Tyler.

ALBANY, May 1.--A Buffalo bill with some little politics in it occupied the attention of the Senate for an hour this morning. Assemblyman Sheehan introduced and passed it through the lower house, and Senator Laughlin had agreed to take charge of it in the upper.

Russell W.S. Blackwell, shoe manufacturer at 129 West Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Noah Tibbetts, giving preferences for $1,280. He formerly had a factory at East Stoughton, Mass., but gave it up about a year ago. He failed in De cember, 1884, and compromised at 50 cents on the dollar.

CHICAGO, May 1.--At Galesburg, Ill., today the Coroner's jury decided that Albert W. Hedberg, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy fireman who shot two strikers, Herbert B. Newell and George Cable, acted in self-defense.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18.--With less powerful, although more diffuse, influence than the lumbermen of California the wool people are noisier even than the latter in their opposition to anything in the shape of tariff reform.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 1.--The remains of Charles J. Ferguson reached here from Philadelphia this morning and were interred in Maplewood. Clubs of the National League all sent flowers. J. M. Ward, President of the Brotherhood of Baseball Players, of which the dead pitcher was a memberl also sent a handsome floral tribute.

PATERSON, N.J., May 1.--A meeting of about 100 Prohibitionists was held in the Congregational Church to-night to consider whether to petition for a local option election in Passaic County under the new law. A resolution to that effect was carried unanimously. It will require 1,350 signers to the petition to secure such electtion. The clergy of the city generally ignored the meeting, only three being present.

ST. LOUIS, May 1.--The stockholders of the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas Railway (Cotton Belt) held their annual meeting yesterday at the company's headquarters, in the Equitable Building. The stock was very nearly all representen--140,347 shares out of a total of 140,390 being voted.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 1.--Henry Pope, colored, was hanged by a mob at midnight last night from the Court House verandah in Sommerville, Chattooga County. CONCORD, N.H., May 2.--By the breaking of a journal on a car of a freight train on the Boston, Concord and Montreal Railroad this morning, five cars were piled up and wrecked at Sewall's Falls, some four miles above the city. TRIESTE, May 2.--News has reached here that 15 banking houses in Buenos Ayres have suspended within 10 days. The liabilities of one of the banks exceed 7,000,000 pesos. The Government bank refuses to discount bills. Italian seaport houses suffer heavily.

ST. LOUIS, May 3.--A north-bound passenger train on the Jacksonville and Southeast ern Railway was struck by a south-bound freight at Sorrento, Ill., this morning. The passenger engine was wrecked, the smoker and baggage car telescoped, and two passengers killed. Four others were seriously injured. The names of the dead and wounded cannot at this hour be learned.

BANGOR, Me., May 3.--From the point where the Province of Quebec, the State of New-Hampshire, and the State of Maine unite the boundary line between Maine and the Dominion of Canada runs nearly north, then east, and then south to a point west of Eastport, a distance of 380 miles or more.

The brokers on the Iron and Metal Exchange kept up their mourning over the condition of the tin market yesterday. The Exchange was open, of course, but there was no more business done in tin than there was on the two preceding days.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 3.--Arguments in the contempt case against Allen O. Myers were concluded last night, and this morning Judge Pugh rendered a decision which had a paralyzing effect on the defense, the sentence being a fine of $200 and 90 days in jail. The decision is quite long, and various cases in other States are cited.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 3.--The delegates to the Prohibition Convention, whose zeal survived the tedium of yesterday's session and the appeals for cash so peristently pressed at last night's meeting, assembled in the Opera House at 8:45 o'clock this morning, determined to promptly finish the remaining business.

Concerning the Emperor Frederick's disease this week's issue of the Medical Record will say: "It is quite difficult to reconcile the conflicting reports concerning the present condition of the Emperor of Germany. WASHINGTON, May 3.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Henry George of Kentucky to be Agent for the Indians of the Colorado River Agency in Arizona. Postmasters--Howard H. Edwards, Fayetteville, N.Y.; James B. Keeler, Ellenville, N.Y.; N.H. Bixby, Horseheads, N.Y.
It is understood that the Hon. P.A. Collins has been selected by the National Committee to preside at the meeting of the Democratic Convention at St. Louis.

An Executor's sale of modern paintings, belonging to the estate of R.S. Clark and others, was begun last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries, 366 Fifth-avenue. One-third of the pictures were withdrawn, but those that were put up brought good prices.

WATERTOWN, Dakota, May 3.--The Church wing of the Democratic Party of Dakota spent the whole of last night, from 7:30 until this morning at 2 o'clock, in electing delegates, passing resolutions, and in glorification of the Democratic Party.
PHILADELPHIA, May 3.--The upper floor and the roof of the handsome clubhouse of the Belmont Cricket Club, at Fiftieth-street and Chester avenue, was destroyed by fire early this morning.

JACKSON, Miss., May 3.--The tragedy of May 1, in which Gen. Wirt Adams, Postmaster of this city, and J.H. Martin, editor of the New Mississippian, were killed, is still the principal topic of conversation, and to say that the unfortunate affair is universally regretted and deeply deplored is putting it mildly.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 3.--There are as yet no indications of a cessation of the rainstorm which began a week ago, and the rivers continue to rise. The storm is retarding seeding in the Northwest, as in many sections the fields are reported as being completely under water.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 3.--From early last evening until noon to-day delegates from all sections of the State have been coming into the city for the purpose of participating in the Union Labor State Convention, which met at 10 o'clock this morning.

ALBANY, May 3.--Gov. Hill to-day gave a hearing to the representatives of the Citizens' Committee on High License of New-York City, who submitted to him an argument in behalf of the High License bill now in the Governor's hands, after having been passed by the Legislature. The bill also has the indorsement of the Church Temperance Society and the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

It has more than 100 incandescent lamps in its house at 147 Fifth-avenue, which are supplied by an arc light circuit of the United States Illuminating Company. The wire enters a switch box in the east window of the main dining room, on the second floor, and in the switch box it is divided into sections of seven lights.

The announced grand mass meeting of saloon keepers and liquor dealers of New-York was not much of a success. It was held at Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon, and was attended by about 50 east side beer saloon keepers and as many more of the striking brewers.

CHICAGO, May 3.--Deep sorrow, as well as great surprise, was created among the many friends and associates of Gen. Martin Beem in Chicago by the receipt of a dispatch from Stanton, Neb., stating that he had committed suicide there on Tuesday last by shooting himself, and saying that family troubles were the cause.

WASHINGTON, May 3.--Representative William L. Wilson of West Virginia, a Democrat and a member of the Ways and Means Committee, spoke in the House to-day on the Tariff bill, and the general verdict is, from both Democrats and Republicans, that he made rather the best speech that has been heard on either side. Mr. Wilson is a slight, spare man, with fair hair and mustache.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 3, via Galveston, Texas.--The Government has granted a concession to Louis Huller Co. to build a railroad from a point on the line of the Mexican Central Railroad through the States of Chihuahua and Sonora, crossing the Sierra Madre Mountains.

NYACK, N.Y., May 3.--The Republicans of Rockland County at New-City this afternoon held the largest convention that has been held in the county in a number of years, and the proceedings were marked by extraordinary interest. Clarence Lexow of Nyack, Chairman of the County Central Committee, presided, and made a ringing speech at the opening.
MADISON, Ind., May 3.--Gen. Rea, Commanderin-Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, received an ovation this evening and made a stirring speech. The city is decked with flags.

Justice Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday granted the motion of Nathaniel Smith to reopen the suit brought against him by his cousin, Mary Smith, and in which she took a verdict for $18,000 by default.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3.--Four running horses were galloping at break-neck speed on the track of the Gentlemen's Driving Park this afternoon when one of them leaped a high rail fence and plunged into a startled crowd of people, knocking two men senseless and injuring two other spectators.

The Baptist Social Union dined last night at Delmonico's, having for guests the Rev. Dr. Wayland Hoyt of Philadelphia, the Rev. Dr. O.P. Gifford of Boston, and the Rev. Carter Helm Jones of Elizabeth, N.J.

DETROIT, Mich., May 3.--The annual meeting of the Michigan Central Railroad Company was held in this city to-day, when the annual report was submitted. NEWPORT, R.I., May 4.--Fishermen who came in to-night report that the fishing sloop Soddgeorge, owned and sailed by George Delvalley of Tiverton, went ashore last night near Light Hill, Seaconnett River, with sails up. No one was found in her, and it is feared that Delvalley has been drowned.

Our esteemed contemporary, Mr. ELLIOTT F. SHEPARD, is not easily wearied in welldoing. COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4.--Frederick Siedel met with a horrible and instant death at the penitentiary yesterday. He was the engineer in the Patton foundry and is some way became entangled in the great flywheel.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 4.--Drafts--Sight, 12 cents; telegraphic, 17 cents.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 4.--Capt. Robert E. Smith, a well-known lawyer of this city, says he was in command of the soldiers who attacked Mr. Voorhees on the train between Terre Haute and Greencastle, an incident to which Mr. Ingalls referred in his speech.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 4.--Two cases of smallpox were discovered in this city to-day. The youngest child of John McNulty, an employe of the Boston and Albany Railroad, died this morning after being ill with the disease over a week. The mother is in a very critical condition with the same disease. Medical aid was not smmoned until last night and the whole neighborhood has been exposed.
An amusing story comes from St. Petersburg. A few days ago the Czar went, without previously announcing his visit, to a religious house where his Majesty was received but not recognized.

With regard to the Donnelly boom my own impression has always been that Bacon's works were written by Shakespeare. Ernest D. Kahn, dealer in cloaks at 56 West Twenty-third-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edward L. Lithauer, giving two preferences for $3.987.

CHICAGO, May 4.--Boston rates were cut again to-day, this time by the Niagara Falls Short Line. Early in the day the Chicago ticket agent of the company received instructions to sell first-class tickets from Chicago to Boston at $16.75.

MANGUM, Green County, Texas, May 4.-- Two weeks ago a citizen of this county discovered a boot protruding from a water hole in the Indian Territory.

BOSTON, May 4.--The Hon. H.B. Lovering today filed his bond in the United States District Court. His bondsmen are Messrs. J.H. French of Gloucester, A.A. Mower of Lynn, and William Taylor of Boston. The amount of the bond is $30,000. Mr. Lovering has received his commission as United States Marshal, and will take the oath of office on Tuesday next.

The stock market continues heavy and weak. Prices are raided easily. Yesterday's quotations fell off with some show of resistance, except in particularly soft spots, where recessions were sharp; yet all along the whole list closing prices were lower than on the day before, just as Thursday's were lower than Wednesday's, and as Wednesday's were under Tuesday's.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--Capt. James Halloran, Twelfth Infantry, has been directed to visit the encampment of the Illinois National Guard at Springfield, Ill., from June 2 to July 30 next and to inspect the troops. Capt. Carle A. Woodruff, Second Artillery, has been detailed to similar duty at the encampment of the militia of North Carolina at Wrightsville Sound.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--The body of a man who committed suicide by shooting in Logan-square early yesterday morning was identified to-day as that of Joseph Patrick Wilson of Chicago, Ill.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 4.--A dispatch reports a bad condition of affairs in Lowndes County, growing out of the recent lynching of a negro murderer by a white mob.
Judge Barrett has again rebuked a Sheriff's jury. In the case of Maria Lucretia Johnson, a lunatic, the-Sheriff's jury which found her insane sent in a bill of $75 for its services.
LONDON, May 4.--The people of a number of parishes in Ireland have warned the priests that if the Pope's rescript against the League is read in the chapels they will protest against it by leaving.

Josiah F. Day, who was held for trial on a charge of grand larceny April 23 last on the complaint of George H. Emery, who accused him of collecting money for the Concord Harness Company and depositing it to his own credit, was honorably discharged by Justice White in the Jefferson Market Police Court Wednesday.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 4.--John H. Atkins, ex-Chief of Police, was fatally shot in Bryant's saloon last night. Atkins and Joseph Sample, a liveryman, had engaged in two fist fights during the afternoon in the same saloon.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 4.--The investigation into past city methods made at the City Hall last night developed a state of facts of a most startling character regarding previously existing municipal methods.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 4.--A very remarkable case of somnambulism has occurred in the vicinity of Trure. About a year ago James Patterson committed suicide by jumping into a well.

BALTIMORE, May 4.--Thomas G. Woolford, chief clerk in the office of the Controller of the State, cut his throat this afternoon in his room at Barnum's Hotel and died shortly after.

Judge Barrett has denied the application of William S. Wyse for an order requiring his wife to restore to him the property which, in a moment of trusting confidence, he gave her. Wyse was formerly in the employ of Harper Brothers as an advertising agent, and received an income of $20,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--Mr. George Rice of Marietta, Ohio, was recalled at the beginning of the investigation by the House Committee on Manufactures to-day. Witness produced statements showing the difference in tariff rates on coal oil and cottonsed oil on the Missouri Pacific and the Queen and Crescent Railroads, coal oil going south and cottonseed oil going north.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--Horsemen in this city were very much down in the mouth to-day when they learned of the abandonment of the Spring trotting meetings at Belmont and Suffolk Parks in this city, at Merchantville, N.J., and Baltimore, which compose the Philadelpia Spring trotting circuit.

The Methodist General Conference devoted another session yesterday to the consideration of the woman question, and no friend of the female delegates-elect who heard the debate could candidly deny that the other side had the best of it and that when the session closed, with Dr. Buckley in possession of the floor, its speakers had greatly fortified its position.

"Hello, Blank," said a Boston man to one of his friends the other day, "I hear you are attending this memory school. What do you think of it, anyhow?" "Greatest discovery of the age!" says Blank, enthusiastically.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 4.--The heavy rains of the past few days have had the effect to swell the river almost to the danger line, and should the water come down in any great volume from the upper tributaries of the Mississippi it would easily cause an overflow of the upper and lower flats districts.
At the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon were presented the two-act drama "Ernestine" and the farce "The Dead Shot" by well-known amateurs and professionals.

BANGOR, Me., May 4.--A bitter fight is going on between game wardens and poachers who have been killing moose, caribou, and deer. Several arrests have been made, and in some cases five-hundred-dollar fines have been imposed.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--If a canvass of the House of Representatives which is now being made by the members of the River and Harbor Committee leads to a reasonable hope of success, the committee will try on Monday next to have its twenty-million-dollar River and Harbor bill again taken up.
C.F. Kleine, a jeweler in San Antonio, Texas, has a very great curiosity in the shape of the movement of a small round clock, such as is sold for $1.25 to $1.75, containing a hornet's nest.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4.--Several years ago Capt. Redfield of the whaling brig Susan Abagail reported that he had discovered, about 600 miles of Golden Gate, a danger reef. Voorhis has so vehemently protested.

Buffalo Bill and his entire exhibition will arrive in the city from Manchester, England, in about a fortnight, preparatory to the opening of the Sum mer season, Decoration Day, at the old place, Erastina, Staten Island.

Superintendent C.C. Martin submitted to President Howell of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees yesterday a revised estimate of the cost of adopting the proposed circulating system of Mr. Wellington, which estimate, although $36,400 less than the original one, Mr. Martin declares to be too small.

Several audacious robberies have recently been committed in the vicinity of the gardens of Monte Carle by a band of five or six Piedmontese. One case which happened yesterday afternoon is a good example.
One of the once-noted Fox sisters, Mrs. Kate Fox Jenekins, was arrested yesterday, charged with neglecting her two boys, Purdy and Henry, aged 13 and 12 years respectively.
Ramon Monteverde had an office at 35 and 37 Broadway, which was occupied yesterday by J.M. Dodd, Jr., the agent of the building.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 4.--A special meeting of the stockholders of the Connecticut River Railroad Company was held here to-day to see if they would agree to accept the provisions of the act of the Legislature allowing them to purchase the stocK of the Ashuelot Railroad ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 4.--Prof. Alfred L. Ripley, Professor of German in the Yale University Faculty, has resigned his position and will enter upon the banking business in Boston. It is expected that George Bendairi, Professor of Italian, will also retire in the near future.

Great as have been the strides of the anti-slavery movement in Brazil during the last three years, a step surpassing in importance any yet undertaken is now contemplated. The Government is thinking of introducing into the Legislature a bill absolutely to put an end to slavery throughout the empire at a fixed and early day.

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association yesterday, a committee of the Buffalo Merchants' Exchange appeared, to explain that it believed that Buffalo was discriminated against by the trunk lines.
The May-pole had a cold-wave flag on it--Pittsburg Chronicle Telegraph.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 4.--Five hundred coal miners and 200 coke drawers at the Pratt Mines, six miles from this city, are now idle. The contract for rates to be paid for mining, which was made two years ago, expired Tuesday.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4.--Charles J. Rutgers, a well-known lawyer, 52 years old, committed suicide to-day by hanging himself at his lodgings in East Hanover-street. He had been moody and depressed owing to the fact that he was made a co-respondent in the Williamson divorce case.
CHICAGO, May 4.--The reduced rates on the Chicago, Burlington and Northern have been in force four day's, and the "Soo" is the only line that has met them.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4.--The seventeenth annual sale of the yearlings bred at the famous Elmendorf Farm was held here this afternoon, and was the most successful of the sales held thus far this year. In all 47 animals were sold for a total of $40,525, an average of $862.

HARRISBURG, May 3.--A veteran engineer on the Pennsylvania Railroad was speaking the other day of singular sights and incidents he had met with in his long experience on the rail. "The queerest that I ever knew," said he, "was the vision that Bill Sandusky had a few years ago.
The Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity put an end to the labors of its fifty-sixth convention by assembling at Delmonico's last evening and partaking of a feast, followed by songs and speeches.
OMAHA, May 4.--Near Arlington, Neb., a barn belonging to Mrs. Freeze caught fire this morning, and while trying to save their horses seven members of the family were burned to death.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 4.--The final decree of foreclosure in the case of tho Farmers' Loan and Trust Company against the Houston and Texas Central Railway Company was entered to-day in the United States Circuit Court by Judge Don A. Pardee.

WARDNER, Idaho, May 3.--A shooting affray occurred this afternoon at Wardner June tion in which four men were wounded. The principals were Miles McNally of the Cricket Theatre of this place on one side and County Commissioner Pat McGowan and Jack Dillon on the other. Both McGowan and Dillon were badly wounded. A bystander named George Owens was fatally wounded.

CHICAGO, May. 4.--The big strike of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy enginemen and switchmen is over. It was practically ended weeks ago, but its managers have been quarreling lately over the time for issuing a formal circular declaring it off. It has been an extremely expensive piece of business for all concerned.

ALBANY, May 4.--The following is the report of the Ulster and Delaware Railroad for the quarter ended March 31: Gross earnings from operation, $50,275; operating expenses, (excluding all taxes.) $47,676; net earnings from operation, $2,599; gross income from all sources, $2,599.

Yesterday was an off day for the Eastern ball clubs, the New-Yorks and Bostons being on their way West and the Brooklyns resting. The Philadelphia Club went to Jersey City yesterday and were beaten by the Central League club there by a score of 10 to 2.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 4.--The Senate has adopted the report of the Schultz committee, appointed to gather information regarding the great Mackenzie River Basin, situatad east and northeast of Alaska. Fanny Davenport has begun a suit for divorce from Edward E. Price for adultery. Yesterday her counsel, ex-Judge Abram J. Dittenhoefer applied to Judge Barrett in the Supreme Court, Chambers, and had George Putnam Smith appointed Referee to take the testimony.

The people of this State were fully prepared to think evil of Gov. HILL before the testimony was given in the aqueduct investigation that convicted him of complicity in the lowest kind of political jobbery.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 4.--An arrangement will be completed to-morrow whereby the Georgia Central Railway and the Gulf Route will be operated as one line, and Savannah will be placed in direct communication with Kansas City. Officers of the two lines are here, and will go to Kansas City, where the arrangements will be completed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4.--The officials of the American Express Company are eagerly looking for a missing messenger named Fisher, running between Columbus, Ohio, and Indianapolis, Ind., on the Bee Line.

XENIA, Ohio, May 4.--Henry Farrell, grocer and liquor dealer, assigned this morning to John Little; bond, $20,000. Joseph McCormack, druggist, also failed for $2,000. There is nothing new in the big failure of yesterday except general indignation at false reports circulated about the standing of other Xenia banks, which have not in any way been affected by the trouble.

Three thousand Americans and two Irishmen assembled in the great hall of the Cooper Institute last evening. The Americans were there to do honor to Mayor Hewitt for his action in refusing to allow any but the American flag to float over the public buildings, and the Irishmen were there for purposes of their own.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--To-day's offerings of bonds aggregated $3,270,600 in lots, as follows: Four per cents., registered, $1,000 at 126 , $50,000 at 126 , $50,000 at 126 , $1,000,000 at 127, $100,000 at 126 , $100 at 126 , $10,000 at 126 , $400,000 at 126 .
Patrick Roxford and Isaac Hart, members of the notorious Red Tiger gang in Jersey City, stole two sheep on Thursday evening and Policeman Mann arrested Roxford.

CHICAGO, May 4.--The Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Company to-day offered a reward of $1,000 for the detection of the men who ditched their train near the stock yards last night and assaulted Conductor James A. Edwards.
I heard an anecdote last week of which Prince Bismarck is the hero, which would tend to show that he does not always gain his ends by the blunt, outspoken means he so often adopts.

The Directors of the New-York Arcade Railway Company make the following statement: "The New-York Arcade Railway Company has entered into a contract with a syndicate of wealthy American capitalists, with European associates, for the immediate construction of its underground railway.

NAPERVILLE, Ill., May 4.--A difficulty in the management of the Northwestern College, which is situated here, has proved quite serious. The institution is governed by a board of 15 Trustees, representing 11 Conferences of the Evangelical Church.
BOSTON, May 4.--Mrs. Mary A. Livermore, while on her way from Marlborough, N.H., to Westminster, Mass., to fill an engagement on Thursday evening, met with a serious accident.

BERLIN, May 4.--A bulleting issued this morning says: "The Emperor was free from fever this morning, and was able to rise. His strength is gradually increasing. No further bulletins will be issued unless the Emperor relapses."

CHICAGO, May 4.--The attack upon the Chicago cattle buyers and packers in the United States Senate has brought out a host of denials to-day of the truth of the charges made by Senators Vest and Plumb that a great trust exists among cattle handlers in this city.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May. 4.--The Los Angeles Cracker Company's block, with a large amount of valuable machinery and the residence of H. Weber, were burned last night. John Schuler, who slept in the factory, is supposed to have perished in the flames. The loss will be fully $65,000; insurance said to be not over $10,000. Cause of fire unknown.

In the trial of Thomas B. Kerr yesterday two more tentative jurors were got, making six in all. The new ones are George M. Huntington, a telegraph operator in the employ of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company, at its office, 329 Broadway, and John H. Welsh, Treasurer of the Hudson River Ice Company.

BOSTON, May 4.--Luther W. Holman of Worcester was arraigned in the Municipal Court to-day on a charge of soliciting to commit murder, and was held in $25,000 for the Grand Jury. The story of the crime, which Holman planned, and the circumstances attendant upon his detection and arrest, is a most remarkable one, resembling in many respects the notorious Coolidge-Mellen conspiracy case a few years ago.
TROY, N.Y., May 4.--Prof. Charles Gross, Ph. D., of this city, has accepted the Chair in History at Harvard College. Dr. Gross is now in London. He will return to this country shortly.

The down-town pool rooms were closed even to their regular and most persistent patrons yesterday afternoon, though a number of those up town in the immediate vicinity of Broadway were open and transacting business as usual.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May, 4.--John C. Degnan, lately Collector of the village of Middletown, was arrested last night charged with embezzlement.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 4.--Numbers of delegates to the Republican Congressional Convention which meets here to-morrow to elect delegates to the National Convention have arrived.
There was a railroad accident at Rye, yesterday morning by which George Sutton was killed instantly and Michael Curren was fatally injured.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 4.--The freight department of the Southern Pacific Road was tied up to-day owing to a strike of the switchmen.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 4.--At the meeting of the State Pharmaceutical Association yesterday a petition was agreed upon to be signed and forwarded to Congress asking that that portion of the revenue law classing druggists as liquor dealers be repealed and that Congress reduce the revenue tax on alcohol. WASHINGTON, May 4--The President has granted a pardon in the case of Frederick M. Ray. convicted of the murder of a negro in the Indian Territory and sentenced to be hanged April 17, 1885, but whose sentence was subsequently commuted by the President to imprisonment for life.
HUDSON, N.Y., May 4.--The jury in the Ford poisoning case, after being out 24 hours, failed to agree on a verdict and were discharged. They stood eight for acquittal and four for conviction.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 4.--The court-martial to try Col. William M. Bloomer of the Seventyfourth Regiment of Buffalo on charges unbecoming an officer and for making false parade returns, made by the Inspector-General's Department, began its session in the Adjutant-General's office at 10 o'clock this morning.
The Age published the news from Bessemer yesterday without comment, expecting tobe able to report this morning the exaggerated character of it.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., May 4.--The Republicans of the Second Congressional District renominated Congressman Funston by acclamation yesterday. Resolutions were passed congratulating Senator Ingalls on his speech of Tuesday.

The Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday, in the United States District Court, filed a cross libel in answer to the libel of the Inman and International Steamship Company, Limited, for damages to its steamship City of Richmond, incurred on Aug. 19, 1887, at the vessel's pier in Jersey City, by her screw getting caught in the telegraph company's submerged cables.

The officials of the Corporation Counsel's office and of the Department of Taxes and Assessments were greatly pleased yesterday over the culmination of an effort to compel certain religious institutions, whose property was not wholly used for religious purposes, to pay their share of the taxes annually levied by the city.

The news floated about the City Hall and other political resorts yesterday that Thomas C. Platt, Chauncey M. Depew, Whitelaw Reid, and Senator Frank Hiscock were to be the delegates at large from this State to the Republican National Convention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 4.--The Republican Convention for the First Assembly District, held at Mayville, Chautauqua County, elected the following delegates to the State Convention: Charles H. Wicks, H.J. Dean, Fred Brockway, Jerome Babcock, and Herman Sixby. The delegates favor either Blaine or Depew.

WASHINGTON, May 4.--The Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club was brought to a close here to-day, five overweight events being decided, the winners being Patrocles, Sam Brown, Sam Harper, Jr., Richmond, and Wellington.

According to an interesting communication from Lugano published here this evening great activity prevails just now amongst the Nihilists.

While the ferryboat Weehawken was making a trip from College Point, Long Island, to the foot of Ninety-ninth-street on Thursday, a rowboat in Hell Gate, containing three men fishing, was upset. Although the ferryboat went to the rescue, and every effort was made to save them, two of the men were drowned. The third man, it is thought, may have reached the shore, as he was last seen swimming very near to it.
In its notice of the sale of George Godwin's celebrated chairs the Times mentions Charles Mathews's favorite seat as "still redolent of excellent cigars," or words to that effect.
Judge O'Brien was recently applied to by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of this city to enjoin the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of Kansas from using the plaintiff's name in its business.

MOBILE, Ala., May 4.--The North Atlantic Squadron left the Lower Bay this morning bound for New-Orleans. During the stay of the fleet in this port there has been constant interchange of courtesies between the officers and the citizens, and there was an official welcome by the Mayor Tuesday afternoon, when the Yantic arrived at the city.

The investigation into the alleged corruption among the Kings County Board of Supervisors, which has been conducted by the Grand Jury for the past month, ended yesterday in the finding of a long presentment to the Sessions Court.

Not a single sale of tin was posted on the bulletin of the Iron and Metal Exchange yesterday. The market was as dull as if no such commodity as tin was in existence. The nominal quotations were on spot tin 24 and on May 21.
Without ceremony of any kind the hands of the city clock were pushed forward 32 minutes at noon yesterday, and Augusta was again placed abreast of the sun.

A fisherman, while on Plymouth beach last Friday, captured a large gray sea gull in a rather peculiar predicament. Firmly pinched upon the bird's bill was a sea clam about the size of the palm of a man's hand.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--An east-bound freight train on the Pennsylvania Railroad consisting of three oil tanks and 14 loaded freight cars was almost totally destroyed by fire at Wayne Station at noon to-day.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 4--A letter is published this afternoon from Prof. G.F. Stanley Hall, of Johns Hopkins University, formally accepting the office of President of Clark University, lately founded in this city by James G. Clark.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 4.--Bulldozing in Louisiana is getting to have its serious drawbacks. A party of white men visited the domicile of Manuel Bowers, a negro living in the Indian Village neighborhood, near Chaudmont.

The protest of an unknown workman who signed himself "Unlicensed Plumber," complaining that no unlicensed plumber was allowed to purchase supplies from local wholesale dealers, was called to the attention of the Brooklyn Board of Health yesterday.

Mercury is improving in his habits. He is up and also abed early. To-morrow morning he will rise at 4:35 o'clock, and on May 31 he will set at 9:04 P.M. Until May 10 he is morning star. At 7 P.M. of that day he will pass beyond the sun, reappearing on his eastern side as evening star. He is in the constellation Aries.

OTTAWA, May 4,--The Knights of Labor have been urging on the Canadian Government for some time past the necessity of taking steps to discontinue assisted immigration, with a view of putting a stop to the importation of paupers.

The Yale University Glee and Banjo Clubs gave a concert at Chickering Hall last evening for the benefit of the University Boat Club, which, judging from the size of the audience, must have netted that aquatic organization a cheering amount.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 4.--Robert Lansing, E.H. Meyers, and James A. Ward were chosen delegates to the State Convention by Democrats in the First Assembly Democratic Convention here to-day.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 4.--Major Rogers, a well known railroad engineer, left here this morning for the Pacific coast.

MOLINE, Ill., May 4.--Two masked men committed a bold robbery at Rapids City Wednesday night, the victim being Mrs. G. Mohr, an aged German widow. Mrs. Mohr had a goodsized bank account, and had made arrangements to loan $1,000 to parties who were to call for it yesterday.
BERLIN, May 4.--Mr. Carl Schurz dined this evening at the residence of Prince Bismarck. Among the invited guests were Count von Stolberg-Wernigerode and Count DoenhofFriedrichstein.

BALTIMORE, May 4.--Prof. Matthew Schmalz, a well-known music teacher of this city, hanged himself to his bedpost this morning and was dead when discovered. He was 63 year of age and in comfortable circumstances, having made considerable money in his profession. He had been drinking rather heavily of late, but is not known to have had any reason for taking his life.

The sale at the Fifth-Avenue Art Galleries of the collection of modern French and German paintings belonging to the estate of R.S. Clark and others, was concluded last evening. It seems now definitely settled that the famous little sloop yacht Fanita will hereafter hail from Boston. Horace Chittenden, Assignee of A.S. Hatch Co., among whose assets the Fanita was included, yesterday closed with an offer received through Edward Burgess, the well-known designer, to buy the Fanita. It is understood that the price is about $5,000, the yacht to be delivered in Boston.

George F. Slosson has this week been visiting friends in Albany and Troy. He and Jacob Schaefer gave up business in their respective cities, Chicago and St. Louis, as if by concurrence. Both set their faces Eastward, Schaefer pitching his tent in Chicago and Slosson at the close of last week reaching this city.

LONDON, May 4.--The race for the One Thousand Guinea Stakes for 3-year-old fillies, run at Newmarket to-day, was won by Mr. Douglas Baird's Briar-Root, a 12 to 1 chance, who beat the pronounced favorite, Seabreeze, by two lengths, in 1:44 , the run being over ...

LONDON, May 4.--The Stock Exchange was unsettled to day. Business was inactive. Foreign securities were rather firmer, in sympathy with the prices on other Bourses. American railroad securities were dispirited and irregular.

MEXICO, May 4.--The contract for the construction of the Tehuantepec Railway was signed Wednesday evening. Yesterday the translation of the contract was mailed to London to the syndicate of which Mr. McMurrock, well known in financial circles, is the head.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 4.--Judge Pugh to-day granted a peremptory writ of mandamus, requiring the Police Commissioners to comply with the law relative to closing the saloons on Sunday. The Commissioners held a meeting to-night and issued instructions to the Chief of Police to comply with the mandate of the Common Pleas Court. They also decided to carry the case to the Supreme Court.

So much that is wild has been circulated with regard to the future of Harrigan's Park Theatre that the public have grown curious, while professionals have had reason to be anxious. The curious phenomenon of "red snow" was observed the other day in the Gall Valley, Tyrol. Lombard, Ayres Co., the Constable Hook oil refineries, lost nearly $100,000 by fire on Shooter's Island last night. This island is located at the mouth of Staten Island Sound, and comprises about 10 acres of land.

The Bishops and conservatism prevailed yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Conference. After a galiant struggle the friends of the women delegates elect were overcome, though by so small a vote that the defeat was by no means devoid of glory.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 7.--Dr. William F. G. Young, a tall, thick-set, robust man of about 40 years of age, was sent to the penitentiary for 18 months to-day for bigamy. Young has a bad record all through the South.

LEXINGTON, May 7.--Sixty-four yearlings, the produce of Dixiana, McGrathiana, and the Lakeview breeding establishments, were sold at auction to-day by William Easton. Prices ruled low, as they have at all the sales this year, the 64 animals bringing $31,400, an average of $490.

The County Democracy of the Tenth District met last night and elected William P. Mitchell, George F. Langbein, and John H. Carll delegates to the Democratic State Convention. The alternates elected were Henry Von Minden, George Fox, and John Fennel. The Committee of Arrangements for the Democratic State Convention will meet to-night at the Hoffman House.

A fire was discovered in the basement of the Stelle Building at 12:30 this morning, and before it was put out the building and the four stores occupying it were damaged $5,000. Jacob B. Doblin and Samuel Abrahams, composing the firm of J.B. Doblin Co., tailors at 134 Bowery, made as assignment yesterday to Abraham Gruber. NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 8.--Thomas J. Cobb, Clerk of the Third District Court of Bristol County, disappeared at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. At the third meeting for the year 1887-8 of the Phi Beta Kappa Alumni at Clark's, West Twenty-third street, last evening Prof. Richmond M. Smith read a paper on "Restriction of Immigration." He denied that the individual had an inherent natural right of migration from one place to another or choice of residence. This claim was historical and of recent growth.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 10.--The establishment of a carrier pigeon messenger service in connection with the Signal Office at Key West is a foregone conclusion.
LOUISVILLE, May 10.--The interest in the coming meeting of the Jockey Club is increasing daily. The grounds are in perfect order, and fully 600 horses will take part in the sport.
An observant gentleman of our city says he thinks that he hears fewer of the South's greatest songsters, the mocking birds ...

The twentieth annnal Commencement of the Drew Theological Seminary was held yesterday in the Christ Methodist Episcopal Church at Madison, N.J. A large audience was present to listen to the addresses of the graduates, upon...

BOSTON, May 10.--Considerable surprise was expressed in the trade recently when the old crockery house of Nicholson, Frost Co., suspended, but the investigations of the committee appointed by the creditors show a cause. It appears that the firm had been systematically robbed for years by dishonest employes.
PHILADELPHIA, May 10.--The Coroner today held an inquest in the case of Annie Shulberg, who died at the Pennsylvania Hospital April 20 from injuries received April 12 by...
