SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--The firm of W. T. Coleman Co. of this city has issued a circular denying statements published in Eastern...

EATONTOWN, N.J., May 10.--Two horses belonging to Edward Ferry were struck by lightning yesterday afternoon and instantly killed. Ferry was plowing on his farm near here and was badly stunned by the shock. His condition is now critical. The bolt passed between the heads of the horses and made a black streak on each about the size of a silver dollar.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 10.--Mrs. J.Y. Scouller of Fair Haven, Ohio, conducted the devotional exercises to-day at the United Presbyterian Woman's Missionary Society meeting. A discussion on missions occupied nearly the whole of the morning session. The subject was divided into five parts, namely:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 10.--The Fifteenth Congressional District Republican Convention for the election of two delegates to the National Convention assembled at the Casino in this town at noon to-day. Every town in the district was represented.
The New-York Southern Society held is third meeting of the present year last evening at the Hotel Brunswick.
ALBANY, May 10.--Following is the report for the quarter ending March 31 of the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad:
LONDON, May 10.--The Lancet says that the Emperor of Germany is slowly gaining strength.

DETROIT, Mich., May 10.--There has grown up among the farmers of Lenawee County in this State a telegraph system which is quite unique in its character, and which might be profitably and generally extended throughout the rural districts everywhere.
MILAN, May 10.--The Emperor of Brazil, who has been suffering from pleurisy and other maladies, is now out of danger.
WASHINGTON, May 10.--The offers for the sale of bonds to the Government received at the Treasury Department to-day aggregated $4,457,500 in lots as follows: Four per cents, coupon, $750,000 at...

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 10.--The Democratic Second Assembly District Convention of Niagara County was held at Wilson this afternoon. The following delegates were elected to the State Convention to be held in New-York: Dr. George P. Eddy of Lewiston, the Hon. W. Caryl Ely of Niagara Falls, and John P. Townsend of Somerset.
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 10.--The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company after considerable negotiations have purchased the old roadbed, grounds, right of way, , of what...
The Actors' Fund Association, at a meeting yesterday, adopted an amendment to the constitution which will allow a more liberal use...

ALBANY, May 10.--Compared with the same quarter last year the operations of the Delaware and Hudson system of railroads for the quarter ended March 31 do not show very favorable results. These are the figures of both years:
"A Fair Bohemian," a society drama, by Mrs. Charles A. Doremus, was performed yesterday afternoon, at the Madison-Square Theatre, for the benefit of the Post-Graduate Hospital.

Hugo Mueller, a member of the New-York Produce Exchange, was found dead in his bed at his residence, 213 Havemeyer-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday morning. He had been feeling ill for some time, and to relieve his sufferings had contracted a habit of taking morphine.

CHICAGO, May 10.--The case of Gen. Martin Beem was given a new phase to-day when his will was filed in the Probate Court. It directs that his wife, Lucy Slayton Beem, shall have only what is permitted by law, the balance of the estate to go to the testator's sisters after all debts have been paid.

CHICAGO, May 10.--The first lost home game of the season was recorded against the Chicago to-day. A dropped fly by Ryan, a base on balls, a wild throw by Pfeffer, and a single by Richardson, gave the New-Yorks three unearned runs in the second inning, and really lost the game, as two runs were all the home team were able to score.
CHICAGO, May 10.--At Vandalia yesterday Henry Miller, a farmer, shot L.C. Kinsey in both arms and killed his horse.

LAWTON, Mich., May 10.--The dam at Hamlin went out with the flood yesterday and 2,000,000 feet of logs in Hamlin Lake went into Lake Michigan, carrying with them 17 houses along the stream. The logs belonged to Pardee, Cook Co. The life-saving station had a narrow escape. The houses were all deserted in anticipation of the flood.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 10.--An iron boiler used for heating water at the pork packing establishment of Hart Brother exploded...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 10.--The Democratic State Convention met in adjourned session at 9 o'clock this morning, and at once entered into the election of delegates from the State at large to the St. Louis Convention.
Matthew A. Potter, employed in the machine shop of the Mott Haven Wood Turning Company, One Hundred and Thirty-third-street...
PETERSBURG, Va., May 10.--Gov. Scales of North Carolina and Gov. Lee of Virginia occupied opposite boxes a the concert in the Academy of Music to-night.

Capt. Howard Patterson, Principal of the New-York Navigation School, has been unable to obtain, at a reasonable figure, a merchant vessel suitable for a training ship, as he had intended and as has already been described.
ANDERSON, Ind., May 10.--A fire occurred in Van Buren Township, near Summitville, last night, in which Enoch McMahon, one of the most prominent and substantial farmers of...
Mrs. Fanny B. Hutchinson, wife of the well-known singer, John W. Hutchinson, died recently after a lingering illness from consumption at Lynn.
Ascension Day was celebrated yesterday with an evening service and festival by the Knights Templar of Palestine Commandery, No. 18, in the Commandery Room, Masonic Hall.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 10.--A double tragedy was enacted shortly before 11 o'clock this morning at the house at the foot of the hill, on East Ohio-street, Allegheny.

WASHINGTON, May 10.--Major-Gen. Crook has been detailed as a member of the Military Prison Board in Gen. Terry's place. Capt. James Rockwell, Jr., Ordnance Department, has been ordered to temporary duty in connection with the repair of a battery erected by the State of Mississippi at...
We know from personal experience that the feeling of good will and friendship in the South toward the North is very general.
WASHINGTON, May 10.--The Senate has removed the injunction of secrecy from the reports of the Committee on Foreign Relations upon the fisheries treaty.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 10.--The State Democratic Convention of Alabama assembled in the Hall of Representatives at the Capitol at noon yesterday, and was called to order by Col....
ST. LOUIS, May 10.--The Supreme Court of Illinois rendered a decision yesterday that again calls public attention to the hopeless bankruptcy into which the people and Government...
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--The indictment found against Chris Buckley, Democratic boss of the city and State, for running an electric clock gambling game at Los Angeles, was no...

GLENCOE, Ontario, May 10.--The temporary bridge used in the construction of the new iron bridge over the Thames River gave way this morning, precipitating six men into the water. Alexander Watterworth and William Lamb were instantly killed. The others were seriously injured.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--Charles R. Bachman, steward of the English ship Brussels, who was convicted of setting fire to the vessel while the crew were on board, was sentenced...
PHILADELPHIA, May 10.--The game between the Athletics and Brooklyns was postponed on account of rain.

The New-York Alumni Association of the Ohio Wesleyan University gave a banquet at Clark's, in Twenty-third-street, last evening to members of the Alumni of the university in distant points who are now in this city attending the Methodist General Conference.

CINCINNATI, May 10.--Dr. L. Webster Fox of Philadelphia, who is here attending the American Medical Men's Association Convention, prepared a paper explaining a very difficult operation in ophthalmic surgery performed by him several days ago--that of transplanting the cornea of a rabbit's eye to a human eye.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--The Right Rev. John J. Keane, Bishop of Richmond and Rector of the Catholic University of America, has been in Philadelphia since Monday last soliciting contributions for the new university.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 11.--Charles Macgeachy, the representative of Gillette's "She" Company, has been indicted by the Grand Jury for libel.

Edison's new laboratory and perfected phonograph at Orange, N.J., were thrown open to representatives of the press yesterday. The plant is purely for experimental purposes, and is one of the largest in the world. An entire block of land is occupied, and there are five separate buildings of brick with hard-wood interiors.

BALTIMORE, May 11.--The fourth and last day of the spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was very much better attended than was anticipated. There was rain all night and up to noon to-day, but the people turned out well. The track was somewhat heavy, and the fields generally small. The meeting has not been one of profit to the Jockey Club.

All the seats for the Wallack testimonial performance of "Hamlet" have been sold for $19,000, but this sum, probably, will be increased to $21,000, as no admission tickets have yet been sold. The management is now debating as to the policy of selling admission tickets.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--First Lieut. George R. Burnett, Ninth Cavalry, has been granted leave of absence for four months for disability. Capt. Thaddeus S. Kirtland, Seventh Infantry, has been granted two months' additional leave of absence. A board of medical officers, to consist of Major Charles R. Greenleaf, Surgeon; Major Robert M. O'Reilly, ...
MADRID, May 11.--The Queen Regent has quite recovered from her indisposition. She presided to-day at a Ministerial Council.

In the employment of dilatory proceedings for the purpose of staving off the recovery of damages from it for injury to contiguous property the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company has about reached the end of its tether.

Mrs. Leroy, wife of Dr. Louis C. Leroy, dentist, of 226 Fifth-street, and her daughter, a girl of 14, started for down town on Thursday morning. Her husband had warned her not to board cars at the Bowery and Fifth-street, as the Third and Fourth avenue tracks cross each other there, so she walked down to Fourthstreet and hailed tha first Fourth-avenue car going down town that appeared.

LEXINGTON, May 11.--The tail-enders of the annual stock sales here are now in progress, Bruce and Kidd to-day disposing of a miscellaneous lot of 17 for $2,350, an average of $138. The animals offered were practically worthless, being broad mares, "roarers," and "crabs." No interest was taken in the sale.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 11.--The opinion of Yale men in this city concerning the removal of the college fence is considerably divided. The young graduates represented by Louis F. Robinson desire the fence to be saved. The men who have been out of college from 20 to 25 years look at the question from a business standpoint.

MOBILE, Ala., May 11.--Maude St. Pierre is in the backwoods of Conecuh County, Ala. Her history has been going the rounds of the press, but her whereabouts were unknown until to-day. Four years ago there was quite a sensation because of the disappearance of John W. Neal of Huntsville, Ala., private secretary to Miss St. Pierre, said to be a lady of wealth.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Skaters at the Hoffman House last night Stephen O'Brien, who last Winter won the amateur championship of America at 220 yards, was disqualified on the ground that he is a professional, and he was declared forever debarred from participating in the contests of the association.

There was a published report yesterday to the effect that the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company intended to extend its line to New-York and that, to carry out the project, the Santa Fe Company was using every endeavor to purchase the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad.

CHICAGO, May 11.--The five Cook County boodlers against whom the Supreme Court gave a decision two day ago were taken to Joliet today, each to serve a term of two years. In prison nomenclature Mike Layden will be No. 8,830, Adam Ochs No. 8,831, John E. Van Polt No. 8,882, Harry Varnell No. 8,833, and Michael Wasserman No. 8,834.

At the Yonkers primary election on Tuesday evening the Stahlnecker ticket, which named five delegate, carried the First Ward. The opposition ticket, which named only four delegates, was defeated by 36 votes.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--The last legal steps have been taken which assure to the heirs of Samuel Blodgett title to a tract of 250 acres in the city of Washington, which is roughly estimated to be worth over $8,000,000. Several of the heirs reside in this city, and among them is Lorin Blodgett, the well-known statistician and publisher.

GENEVA, Ill., May 11.--Mayor James Herrington's trial on the indictment brought against him by members of the City Council occurred yesterday before Judge Jamieson of Chicago. There were seven counts in the investment.

NOGALES, Arizona, May 11.--The Secretary of War of Mexico has notified the military officers stationed along the border that hereafter the rules regulating the demeanor of the military officials will be strictly enforced, and that the extreme penalty, including a heavy fine, will be meted out.
There has been a good deal of talk of late about the disappearance of the sinking fund of Jersey City. The story was that the city had borrowed the money and put its notes into the fund in its place.

Republican Conventions in the Sixth, Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, Tenth, Eleventh, Twelfth, and Thirteenth Congressional Districts were held last evening to nominate delegates and alternates for the Chicago Convention. The conventions in all but two or three of the districts went off smoothly.

The Ladies' Protection and Relief Society has just issued its report for 1887. The lady President was seen yesterday, and said that at present there are 200 boys and girls in the institution, while 362 children have been cared for during the past year.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--Acting Secretary Thompson to-day received offers for the sale of $7,266,250 bonds to the Government, as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$4,550 at 127, $500 at 126 with accrued interest; $200 at l26 , $3,000 at 126 7/8.
Conventions for the election of delegates to the Republican State Convention, which meets in Buffalo May 16, were held in the 12 Assembly districts of Kings County last night.

An electric light wire of the Brush Company killed one of its employes, Thomas H. Murray, on a cornice of the second floor of 616 and 618 Broadway, yesterday morning. There is always more or less trouble on the circuits in rainy weather, and ...

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 11.--With clear and warm weather, large attendance, the track in superb shape, and a better class of racers than had previously been offered, the fifth day of the Kentucky Association's Spring meeting was thoroughly enjoyable.

Several of the branch lines of the Erie converge at the west end of the Bergen Tunnel, and all the trains run through it to the Jersey City water front. A system of block signals has been arranged there for the movement of the trains, and a standing rule, rigidly enforced, is that two trains shall not move through the tunnel in the same direction at the same time.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 11.--The suit of Mayor T.J. Jarratt against Mr. R.P. Barham, editor of the Index-Appeal newspaper, for $10,000 damages for libel was ended to-day by a verdict against the defendant of $100 damages and costs.

PARIS, May 11.--Gen. Boulanger, Count Dillon, and Deputies Laguerre and Mayer have gone to Dunkirk. A crowd of 200 persons gathered at the station to witness their departure, and there were some cries of " Vive Boulanger."
Ten jurors in the Kerr trial remained in the box yesterday afternoon when Judge Patterson adjourned the Court of Oyer and Terminer until Monday.

PARIS, May 11.--A semi-official note is published which states that there has been no dispute between the French and United States Governments regarding the enrollment of naturalized citizens of the United States in the French Army.

The annual distribution of awards of merit was made last evening at the National Academy of Design. J.G. Brown, Chairman of the SChoo1 Committee, presided, and on behalf of the Council of the Academy, presented the prizes, which were awarded as follows:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 11.--The Coal Miners' Association of Alabama met here at noon to-day and fixed the rate for mining coal at 55 cents per ton in Winter, 50 cents in Summer, an advance of 5 cents per ton. It was resolved to order a general strike in case the mine owners refused to pay the advanced rates. The association meets again to-morrow to consider the question of demanding semi-monthly payments.

BANGOR, Me., May 11.--The venerable Hannibal Hamlin created a sensation here by re-entering the political field, and he will present the name of Gov. Marble at, the neat Republican Convention, although fully one-half the State is pledged to Burleigh.

It is predicted that another meeting of the trunk line pool's Executive Committee will have to be held within the next week. The fight precipitated by the Grand Trunk's cut in dressed beefs rates is of much more consequence than was first supposed, and the action taken by other roads in cutting live stock rates is ...

RICHMOND, Va., May 11.--The Southern Baptist Convention met in annual session here to-day in the First Baptist Church. On call of States it was found that 745 delegates were present. The convention then organized by the election of the following officers: President-- ...
LONDON, May 11.--On the Stock Exchange today a feeling of depression prevailed owing to news that prices were weaker on the Continent and in New-York. Foreigners were unsettled.

BLUE SPRINGS, Mo., May 11.--There was a quiet reunion here to-day of Quantrell's old guerrillas, and among those present was the mother of the noted outlaw. Nearly all the members of the band living in Missouri were present, and among the leaders absent are Frank James and Jim Cummings, who are in ...

COBLESKILL, N.Y., May 11.--The Twenty-fourth Congressional District Republican Convention convened in Opera Hall here to-day for the selection of delegates to the National Convention. J. Lee Tucker of Otsego called the convention to order and the roll call showed a full representation of 36 delegates.

WHEELING, West Va., May 11.--This afternoon, near Bloomington, Md., James Boughner, a well-known citizen of Garrett County, Md., was thrown over a cliff, 125 feet high, by Pat Farley, and was instantly killed.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 11.--Memorial Day, which was postponed from yesterday on account of the weather, was generally observed here this evening. Speeches were delivered and the graves of the Confederate and Union dead were decorated.

William Sexton and Albert M. Frey have made a match, but not at that game of ball with which their names are prominently associated. The younger having challenged the elder, they are to head baseball nines chosen from among the patrons of their respective rooms.
Herr Possart appeared at the Thalia Theatre last evening as Napoleon in Karl von Heigel's five act play of that name. "Napoleon" is a drama of the heroic type, but its heroism is of a cheap order.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 11.--The river is still rising, and is almost, if not quite, as high as any time in this season. Sergt. Lyons said the rise would doubtless continue for at least two days yet, his calculations being based on reports received from points up the river. The rise will be gradual, however, and there is no danger of a surprise by a sudden rise of the water.

Men who have witnessed every long-distance pedestrian contest held at Madison-Square Garden, and who have great difficulty in becoming enthusiastic, so far forgot themselves last night as to shout themselves into a condition of hoarseness. Five thousand or more people did little between 11 and 12 o'clock last night but stand on chairs, ...
The wife of ex-Officer Charles Rickerd, who was sent to Sing Sing within 24 hours after he had been detected robbing a store in Nassaustreet, has found friends in unexpected places.
The arrangements for the amateur billiard tournament at the Racquet Club have been completed and the contests will begin on Monday night.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 11.--More than a month ago Charles B. Beckwith was arrested in this city. He was married, and the charge brought against him was non-support of his wife. He was bailed out by his friends.
The Rev. Dr. Frank R. Morse, Pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Church, at Clintonstreet and Third-place, Brooklyn, has resigned, after being at the head of the church for nearly ten years.

P.B. Armstrong of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of New-York and his associates have made a proposition to the Board of Directors of the Fire Association of NewYork to purchase, at par, the whole or any portion ...

LONDON, May 11.--It is reported that at a recent parade of Russian troops a cavalry Lieutenant named Timofeief made an attempt upon the life of the Czar. The Lieutenant was about to fire at the Czar with a revolver when another officer seized him by the arm, and, the weapon being discharged, the bullet entered the ground. Timofeief, who was arrested, appeared to be insane.
The Alpha Bowling Club, headed by Dr. Warren, ex-Senator Trainer, and Judge Donohue of Yonkers, came to this city on Wednesday evening to complete the series of games with the Arlingtons.

BANGOR, Me., May 11.--A large school of seals have followed salmon into Penobscot Bay and are slaughtering them. In return owners of salmon weir have organized and they shoot seals as they come out upon the rocks for air. They have killed 10 this season. The skins are worthless.

Frederick Lowther, who was convicted in Part III., General Sessions, last week on a five-year-old indictment for picking a man's pocket of $10, was sentenced to 9 years and 10 months' imprisonment in State prison yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 11.--To-morrow morning at 7 o'clock the North Atlantic squadron will get under way and proceed down the river, the Richmond leading and the steel cruiser Atlanta bringing up the rear.
A large safe weighing upward of two tons was dropped from a third-story window at 79 Cedar-street yesterday afternoon about 3 o'olock, and two persons had narrow escapes from immediate death.

NOGALES, Arizona, May 11.--The Secretary of War at the city of Mexico has notified Mexican officers along the border that hereafter the penalty of death will be imposed for crossing over into the United States with troops and interfering with the affairs of citizens of a friendly nation. This action was taken after inquiry into the cases of Col. Arvizor and Lieut. Guitterez, who rescued a prisoner from the American authorities.

The war veterans of Company F. Eighth Regiment, met at the armory, Broadway and Thirty-sixth-street, last night, and took the preliminary steps toward forming a veteran organization of the Eighth Regiment. Col. George ...

The woes of the Democracy, should the Electoral Reform bill become a law, agitated the County Democracy at the meeting of their County Committee in the Cooper Union last evening. Thomas P. Walsh, ex-Warden, in particular, who occupied a front seat, was very indignant at the threatened outrage, and could hardly restrain himself.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 11.--The outlook for finishing wheat seeding in the Northwest is very discouraging. It has rained almost continually for nearly two weeks, and the ground is thoroughly soaked, and in some places water is standing from six inches to a foot deep in the fields that are already plowed and ready for seed.
It was a fine stroke for the managers of the May Festival not only to engage the leading English tenor of the age for the centennial festivity, but to bind him to sing nowhere else on this continent.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--The examination of Col. Knight, General Manager of the Superior Lumber Company, was resumed by the Senate Indian Tradership Committee this afternoon. The most interesting feature was one which will not appear in the record.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 11.--While workmen were engaged to-day in pulling down a large brick building on Old-street the walls fell in, burying three of them beneath the ruins. It was first thought they were killed, but it was soon found that their lives had been saved by protesting timbers. Two of the men, George Malry and Thomas McCrea, were painfully hurt.
The steamship Bohemia, which has been at Quarantine since April 26 on account of smallpox, was allowed to land her passengers yesterday. When she came into port she had 1,222 in the steerage.

The Arlington League, a social club which has been in existence for several years, recently took possession of the house 242 West Fourteenth-street, and last night the house was "warmed" and the club gave its reception to ladies.

Among the half dozen who are to be received into the Franciscan Sisterhood, Peekskill, N.Y., next Tuesday is the younger daughter of P.A. Fitzgerald, who for a number of years has been Superintendent of Keyser Garraty's billiard room, this city.

VICKSBURG, Miss., May 11.--Robert King shot and instantly killed Gus Cox in Justice Adams's office this evening. Both were negroes. The scene of the murder is about two miles north of this city, and in this county.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 11.--The Conestoga Valley near Churchtown is settled almost exclusively by the Amish, a plain, unpretentious seat of farmers who wear broad-brimmed hats and hooks and eyes on their clothes in place of buttons.
QUINCY, Mass., May 11.--John W. Powell, who claims to come from Philadelphia, was discovered in the house of tho Hon. Peter Butler at about 3 o'clock this morning.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 11.--One of the most remarkable cases ever known in this community is that of Mary Jane Weidler, an inmate of the Lancaster County Hospital, who has not tasted food for 50 days; in fact, Dr. Tanner has been far outdone. It has been almost two years since this woman began to fast. She first stopped eating meat of any kind, and soon afterward refused potatoes.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 11.--John Teemer, the oarsman, neither affirms nor denies the report that he has broken the three-mile record. He says he is not rowing trial hosts for the public, but only for his backer. He says it any one wants him to make the trial against the record he is willing to try providing a deposit is posted.

A strong, brave, truthful man--Simon Cameron made enemies as well as friends. An aggressive man, with convictions and the courage to maintain them, must and will make enemies as well as friends, and Mr. Cameron ...

WASHINGTON, May 11.--Mr. W.L. Scott of Pennsylvania never speaks in Congress unless he has something to say, and a member of the House who really has something to tell his associates is always sure of the attention of the body.

The trial of the two women Thierry and Coche, whose adventures were described in your columns a short time ago, has commenced. They styled themselves "Sister Adalbert" and "Sister Therese," and kept a so-called orphanage, which they had dubbed with the highsounding title of the "Convent of Our Lady of the Seven Sorrows."
The committee appointed at Springfield to report at the annual meeting of the American Board in Cleveland next October a revision of the by-laws are at work, and have made a surprising discovery.
WASHINGTON, May 11,--The following, in part, is the address of Representative W.L. Scott of Pennsylvania in the tariff debate in the House to-day:
The athletic meeting at Cedarhurst today, if the weather should happen to be fair, will be the greatest outdoor athletic meeting ever held in this country.

CHICAGO, May 11.--It was decided to-day by the agents of the roads interested in ChicagoBoston passenger business to restore rates Monday, pending a settlement of the difference between the Chicago and Grand Trunk and Niagara Falls Short Line. The latter insists upon a differential of $1 25, which the former is not willing to grant.

The new volume of the reports of the Historical Manuscript Commission calendars the family papers of the Earl of Dartmouth. Line most of its predecessers, it comprises many interesting historical anecdotes.

Two Brooklyn policemen, Patrolmen Dickerman and McCormick, of the Thirteenth Precinct, were before Commissioner Bell yesterday, charged by Capt. Druhan with refusing to be vaccinated, in violation of General Order No. 32, issued on March 26.

Michael Reilly, a watchman at the foot of West Twenty-fourth-street on the North River, reported to the police of the Sixteenth Precinct last night that he had shot a river pirate in a row boat in the vicinity of his beat.

A coroner's jury yesterday began an investigation of the circumstances under which Nathaniel W.T. Hatch met his death last Monday night at 64 West Twentieth-street. No decision has reached, as the large number of witnesses rendered an adjournment necessary.

DELHI, N.Y., May 11.--The Democratic Convention of Delaware County elected John C. Van Dyke, Robert Harby, and G.W. Youmans delegates to the State Convention, and instructed them to vote for Cleveland.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 11.--The National Bank of Portland, Conn., was entered last night by thieves, who forced open a window and made three unsuccessful attempts to break into the vault, the walls of solid masonry being bored through.

As it was intimated in our Washington dispatches yesterday morning, there is among the Democrats in the House of Representatives a certain number of men who are a little weak-kneed in regard to the reform of the tariff.

CHICAGO, May 11.--Chairman Cooley of the Inter-State Committee, who came to Chicago to-day, says that the board's investigation of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy strike will be held probably late next month. No date has yet been definitely settled upon.

Jessie Griswold, a pretty and intelligent young woman of 21 years, who has been engaged as a typewriter and copyist in a downtown business house, and who, up to last Sunday night, was a boarder with Mr. and Mrs. William H. McLoughlin at 127 West Sixteenth-street, ...

LONDON, May 11.--In the House of Lords to-day Viscount Hardinge asked what truth there was in the reports that England was in a defenseless condition; that she had the worst guns in the world, and that her ports and ships were unarmed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11.--Prosecuting Attorney Huling gave notice to-day that the case of the State against Allen O. Myers would be commenced on the 23d inst. Judge Pugh assigned the case at that time and stated that unless good and sufficient reasons for a continuance were shown the trial would at once proceed. Robert B. Montgomery's case is second on the list.

ST. Paul, Minn., May 11.--Interest in the suit of J.P. Farley against the Manitoba Railroad or rather against J.J. Hill and Commodore Kittson will be increased, both on account of the death of the latter and the rumor which has been dying around that Hill had made advances toward a settlement of the claim against him.

CHICAGO, May 11.--Judge Shepard to-day got a chance to express his opinion of professional divorce sharps when he sentenced one of them named Wade Abbott to 90 days in jail for contempt of court, after giving him a through raking over.

Frank Burkhardt, who has swindled many book publishers and book dealers, is in custody at Police Headquarters, and Inspector Byrnes tells the following story of him: Burkhardt, who has a good presence, speaks five languages and says that he is of gentle blood, was expelled from college in Germany for hazing in 1882.

ALBANY, May 11.--The Legislature adjourned at noon to-day after a morning session of three hours. The "aqueduct gang" made another unsuccessful effort to Ramper the Fassett investigating committee. So persistent were Contractor John O'Brien and Aqueduct Commissioner Ridgway in the attempt to pass through the Senate some resolution affecting the powers of that committee that arrangements ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11.--Miss Ellen B. Miner an inmate of the Columbus Insane Asylum from Harrison County, committed suicide to-day. She had been closely watched, having previously attempted destruction.

BERLIN, May 11.--A bulletin issued this morning says that the Emperor's condition during the last few days has been relatively good. His fever has been slight. His sleep, though occasionally broken, has been refreshing, and his strength has improved.

Another large audience was present yesterday at the Methodist General Conference, due to the mistaken impression that the Bishop Taylor matter, which is the special order for this morning, would be taken up. Those who attended and looked for a lively session were disappointed, as the proceedings were very tame.

LONDON, May 11.--In the absence for the moment of grave Continental matters or a domestic crisis, with the Kaiser maintaining his own, and the European signals set at fair weather, there is nothing here more interesting to talk about than the Senate's passage of the International Copyright bill. All the papers discuss it editorially and are naturally much pleased with even its limited provisions.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 11.--The American Printing Company has suspended operations for the present, and one-half of the machine printers have been discharged.

GREENSBOROUGH, Ga., May 11.--George McDuffie, the negro preacher who murdered William Chenoy, also colored, was hanged here to-day at 12:30 o'clock. He said he was fully prepared. The execution was in the jail.

Contributions for Decoration Day observance are coming in slowly. Grand Army men wish to raise $5,000. Ferdinand P. Earle, Treasurer of the Citizens' Auxillary Committee, acknowledges the following subscriptions to the memorial fund to date:

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11.--A.J. Bryant, ex-Mayor of San Francisco, committed suicide this morning by jumping from the ferry steamer Encinal just after the boat had started on the 9:15 trip to Oakland. Mr. Bryant was very nervous and trembling when he bought his ticket, and the gate-keeper appears to be the last man who talked with him.

LONDON, May 11.--The Kempton Park Spring meeting began to-day. The race for the Kempton Park Grand Prize of 1,000 sovereigns for 3-year olds was won by Mr. Vyner's ch. c. Crowberry by a length, with Mr. J.H. Houlesworth's b.c. Neaponlis second, four lengths ahead of Lord Bradford's b.c. Shillington, third. There were nine starters.

LOCKPORT, May 11.--The ice bridge in the Niagara River below the falls want out yesterday. This was one of the most compact and permanent bridges that has ever formed on the river. It has lasted over four months, and old residents say it has never before been equaled. The flow of the ice was grand as it swept down the river and through the rapids.

Before Judge Morgan J. O'Brien, in the Special Term of the Supreme Court yesterday, the trial of the suit of the United States of Colombia against Benjamin A. Gaetan took place. This suit grows out of one of the many revolutions with which Colombia has been afflicted.

The long session of the Legislature which has just closed has been singularly barren of important legislation. The best that can be said of it is that it has also been unusually free from corrupt jobbery.

The passenger agents of the Trunk Line Association decided yesterday to have a joint office for first and Second class tickets down town. It was practically decided that this office will be at 1 Broadway. All the roads in the association, with the exception of tho Lackawanna will be represented by a joint agent. The half dozen other offices in that part of the city will be closed.
MILAN, May 11.--The Emperor of Brazil has had a relapse. He shows symptoms of neuralgic cerebral congestion. Paris snd Gievanni of Padua have been summoned to attend his Majesty.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 11.--The TIMES'S correspondent took a run down to Webster today and finds that the sentiment there in regard to the various versions of the confession of Alice Hoyle is one of absolute incredulity so far as the charges against Tom McQuaid are concerned.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11.--Nathaniel W. T. Hatch, who met so tragic a death in New-York, besides being known in this city, was also well known at Glen Olden, about four miles outside the county line, on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad.

OTTAWA, May 11.--Prof. Wiggins, the weather prophet, says a mild earthquake is likely to occur on the Pacific coast, probably in California, between now and October. The seismic disturbance will move across from Asia, but he says it may never reach this side of the Pacific after all.

BUFFALO, N.Y. May 11.--John Cullen, who on Jan. 31 last killed his mother with an axe and who was found guilty of murder in the second degree, was this morning sentenced to imprisonment for life in Auburn Prison.

If Mayor HEWITT sees fit to persist in his refusal to again take his seat with the Board of Electrical Control, as he threatened on Thursday, he will be guilty of a neglect of a duty imposed on him by law, but the work of burying the wires need not necessarily be delayed on that account.
The passion for opium is reported to be rapidly destroying the native population on the Marquesas Islands, where the women even this fatal indulgence.
NYACK, N.Y., May 11.--The Rockland Oyer and Terminer Court this week, Judge Charles F. Brown of Newburg presiding, has disposed of several exceedingly interesting cases.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10.--The annual reports of the Southern Pacific Company for the year ending Dec. 11, 1887, were issued to-day. The total mileage of the company is 5,576 miles, inclusive of the Central Pacific, Southern Pacific, sundry leased lines in California, and roads owned or controlled by the company east of El Paso.
LONDON, May 11.--The steamship Montauk, (Br.,) Capt. Jenkins, from New-York April 24, are at Leith to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 11.--William Riley of Chicago, of the firm of Riley Co., bookmakers, deposited his cash box in the Phoenix Hotel safe last night. The box contained about $8,000--$3,300 in cash and $4,320 in certified checks and drafts. When Mr. Riley called for the box this morning it was gone. It is supposed to be the work of a sneak thief.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 11.--John Brant of Harrisburg, a brakeman on the Pennsylvania Railroad, was killed at 4 o'clock this morning at Lemon-place, by being thrown off a box car which was being, shifted to a side track. He was 35 years old and leaves a wife.

Carter Harrison has got far enough along on his trip around the world to be able to complete the circuit by cable, and last night he greeted Chicago direct for the first time since he sailed away from the west coast of America last August. COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 11--The May crop report by the State Board of Agriculture was issued to-day. Estimates are made on the reports from over 1,000 correspondents. In some of the counties more than one-half of the wheat land has been plowed up for oats and flax.
The set of questions to be asked immigrants by the landing clerks, which was recently adopted by the Emigration commissioners, was put in operation yesterday.

The Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church held a mass meeting last evening, under the auspices of the Methodist General Conference, at the Metropolitan Opera House. Bishop Foss of Minneapolis presided.
TORONTO, Ontario, May 12--Archbishop Lynch died at 1 o' clock to-night of congestion of the lungs.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 11.--The steamer Albatross, used by the United States Fish Commission in the prosecution of its work, and which was ordered to the Pacific coast last fall, arrived in port to-day, 172 days from Washington.
The new Board of Chosen Freeholders of Union County, N.J., that assumed control on Wednesday, has already brought down upon its head the wrath of all except two of the newspapers of the county.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--The anniversary of the birth of Mr. George W. Childs, on the recurrence of which day in each year all the union compositors east of the Mississippi River contribute to the Childs-Drexel fund the pay received for setting 1,000 ems of type, was further celebrated here this evening with a banquet at Dooner's Hotel.

The last meeting of the Browning Society for this season will be held at the Brunswick on Tuesday, May 22, at 3 o'clock, the special feature of interest being a paper by Mrs. Alice Kent Robertson, the accomplished Secretary, on "Browning's Treatment of Love."

"Summer Homes" is the title of a handsomely films rated book which has just been issued by the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad. The object of the publication is to direct people in search of a delightful and healthful spot in which to spend all or a portion of the Summer how and where to do so.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 12.--Gov. Hill to-day appointed Major Clifford A.H. Bartlett of NewYork as Judge-Advocate-General on his military staff, Gen. Bartlett is at present Major of the Ninth Regiment, National Guard, and was an aide on the staffs of Govs. Tilden and Robinson from 1875 to 1879.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 12.--C.M. Robbins, a traveling collector for Cassell Co., publishers, of New-York committed suicide at a hotel in this city to-day with morphine. He was despondent and tired of life.
Much excitement was caused in the neighborhood of Broadway and Howard-street yesterday by the antics of an electric light wire.

LONDON, April 28.--When her Majesty's Ministers go about and in their clubs and at the dinner parties of their friends say that war between France and Italy or an outbreak in Macedonia cannot be considered as anything but an affair of weeks, it is high time that England should look to her armory.

The famous "Flying Scotchman" goes to York (188 miles) in 3 hours 55 minutes, or at the rate of exactly 48 miles an hour. The Scotchman is timed to pass Doncaster (156 miles) 3 hours 15 minutes after leaving King's Cross; the 1:30 P.M. Leeds train draws up at the platform in 3 hours 4 minutes.

PARIS, May 12.--Gen. Boulanger met with anthusiastic receptions at Douai and Lille to-day. Speaking at a luncheon at Douai, Gen. Boulanger called the Constitution a "ridiculous compromise between a pseudo-monarchy and a false republic."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12.--The prospects for the twenty-seventh meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club, which begins Monday, are most flattering. String after string of thoroughbreds came in yesterday, and in the neighborhood of 200 arrived to-day. The probability is that there will be between 500 and 600 horses ...

OTTAWA, May 12.--A joint address of congratulation to the Governor-General upon his appointment as Viceroy of India, and at the same time regretting his early departure from Canada, will be presented to his Excellency next week by the senate and House of Commons. The address will go on to relate the great strides Canada has made since Lord Lansdowne arrived here, less than five years ago.

WASHINGTON, May 12.--After an informal consultation between the leading Democratic and Republican Representatives to-day, it was decided to extend until Saturday next the time for closing the general debate on the pending Tariff bill. The House will be asked on Monday to formally ratify this agreement, and the request will, of course, be promptly granted.

To American readers the name of Henry Taylor can scarcely be called a familiar one. Many who know the name hardly know more than that he is the author of "Philip van Artevelde," a noble dramatic poem, honestly admired and praised by readers highly competent to judge of it.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12.--J. Lusk's canning factory, Temescal, Alameda County, one of the largest of its kind in the world, yesterday made an assignment, owing to the failure of William T. Coleman Co.
LONDON, May 12.--The Sugar conference has concluded its work. To-day the delegates signed the final protocol, with the draft of a proposed convention.

JAMAICA, Long Island, May 12.--The Democrats of the Second Assembly District of Queens County held a convention this morning in the Town Hall and elected delegates to the State Convention at Albany. There was harmony and only one set of delegates from each town in the district except Long Island City.

BOSTON, Mass., May 12.--The indictment returned by the Grand Jury in the Superior Criminal Conrt in the case of Luther H. Holman, alias Luke W. Holman, charges the defendant with feloniously inciting one James J. Collins to burglariously enter the dwelling house of Emeline B. Holman at Worcester, to steal certain property, and to murder Emeline B. Holman, the prisoner's half sister. Holman will not be tried before Thursday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 12.--The Twentyfirst District Democrats to-day chose Rober Blee and Thomas Axworthy for delegates to the National Convention, with Thomas O'Rourke and B. Windecker alternates. August Zehring was nominated for Presidential Elector.

ISHPEMING, Mich., May 12.--By the carelessness of the "trammers" in the Cleveland mine this morning a tram car carrying a ton and a half of iron-ore was dumped into a shaft, fell 50 feet, and instantly killed August Turnquist and seriously injured E.J. Sifley, who were at the bottom of the shaft. Two others escaped with slight bruises.
WASHINGTON, May 12.--Col. Elmer Otis, Eighth Cavalry, has been granted leave of absence for six months, and Capt. James G. McAdam, Second Cavalry, for five months.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 12.--The Hon. Frank Hatton, ex-Postmaster-General, passed through the city this morning from New-York to Chicago. When asked what he thought of the Blaine revival he said: "I didn't know that there was a revival.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 12.--The Spring meeting of the Kentucky Association closed today. The attendance during the meeting has been the largest ever known in the history of the association.

DALLAS, Texas, May 12.--The St. Louis Wire Mill Company to-day filed a suit in the United States Circuit Court against the Washburn Moen Manufacturing Company and other companies, claiming $300,000 damages for alleged malicious conspiracy to injure plaintiff's business by circulating statements that the mill wire manufactured by the St. Louis Company infringed some patents held by rival companies.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 12.--After a long discussion in the House of Commons last night. PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 12.--Dr. William Grosvenor was arrested to-day by the state police for permitting a liquor nuisance to exist in the Grosvenor Block on Weybosset-street. When arraigned he pleaded not guilty, and was released in $300 bail.

ROME, May 12.--The Pope has charged Cardinal Monaco to have an inquiry instituted by the Congregation of the Propaganda to ascertain whether the methods employed by the Irish National League embrace principles or regulations that are contrary to religious or moral law.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 12.--Thomas Jordan, one of the leading merchants of the city, lives with his family at 32 Park-avenue, and has been here for some time, removing from Richmond, where Mrs. Jordan first showed signs of failing mental strength.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 12.--Advices from Texas say large numbers of cattle are dying in the northwest part of Cooke and eastern part of Montague County from a plague which broke out two weeks ago. The animal's throat swells, choking it to death a few hours after being attacked.

LONDON, May 12.--During the performance of Augustin Daly's company at the Gaiety Theatre this afternoon a scare was caused by the sudden extinction of the electric lights. Miss Ada Rehan reassured the audience and averted a panic, and the play proceeded.

TROY, N.Y., May 12.--Last night an overflow of the Champlain Canal caused a wash-out of the towpath north of Waterford. The break is 30 feet long and 2 feet-deep. Navigation will be suspended during the day, the water having been drawn from the level.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12.--William Killer, an Englishman, convicted a few days since of murder in the first degree for the killing of David Lewis, a colored hostler, was to-day sentenced by Judge Finletter to be hanged.

QUINCY, Ill., May 12.--The Mississippi River in this vicinity has passed the danger point and a repetition of the great flood of 1881 is seriously threatened. At that time the stage of water reached 19 feet above low-water mark, the highest ever known with one exception.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 12.--Three white and two black convicts were lashed at New-Castle this morning. Four of the number, for petty larcenies, took five lashes each. MILWAUKEE, May 13.--The iron propeller Clarion ran into the schooner Monguag on in the harbor to-day and sunk her in four minutes. The crew had barely time to escape with their lives. FAIRMONT, West Va., May 13.--William Burns, a well-known and popular citizen of this place and the proprietor of a large brewery, was murdered last evening by Peter T.R. Manley, a local hard case. The trouble leading up to the crime occurred at the brewery and but little is known about it, as Manley made his escape. Burns was shot with a revolver and was killed instantly. If Manley is caught he will be lynched.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 13,--Something of a sensation was produced here yesterday afternoon by the publication of the Grand Jury report. The foreman of the jury is William Keyser, one of the richest and most prominent men of the city and a leader among the Independents. The report makes grave charges of laxity against the State Attorney's office.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13.--Reports from the towns and cities in Western New-York and Northwestern Pennsylvania show that business is in a healthy, if not particularly active condition. In the opinion of conservative men the decreased movement of merchandise is an excellent thing.

BLUE SPRINGS, Mo., May 13.--The old Missouri guerrillas shook hands yesterday and parted. Mrs. Quantrell was bidden an affectionate farewell by each in turn, and left for her home in Ohio. There is a bit of history connected with Senators Voorhees and Ingalls which was not brought out in the recent heated debate between them. As the whole controversy impinged upon their respective attitudes as to soldiers and pensions, this history is of present interest.
Miss Pauline Hall is slowly recovering from a serious attack of gastric fever at her residence at Seventh-avenue and Thirty-ninth-street.

Fully that number of men and women, and probably more, have counted upon seeing the first meeting between Hanover, the greatest of the 3-year-olds of 1888, and The Bard, Mr. Cassatt's pride and pet, who is considered by many to be the greatest of the sons of Longfellow.

The Brooklyn Bridge Trustees held what some of them believed was their last meeting as an official board yesterday afternoon. The petition of the pilots to have the electric lights on the bridge screened was referred to the President and the chief engineer.
The postponed fourth annual field meeting of the Berkeley Athletic Association at the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds attracted quite a gathering despite the threatening weather.

LONDON, May 14.--The House of Lords this afternoon was crowded with people who desired to hear Lord Wolseley's defense. The galleries reserved for peers and peeresses were filed. Mr. Gladstone, Mr. Stanhope, Lord Randolph Churchill, Viscount Cranberne, and other members of the House of Commons crowded the steps of the throne.

PITTSBURG, May 14.--Cars have become so scarce on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad that several of the coal mines were shut down to-day. It is reported that there are between two and three miles of cars loaded with coal that are side tracked at Painesville waiting the arrival of ships to be unloaded. Last week there was unusual activity at the mines along the Youghiogheny River.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14,--The New-Yorkers are the first to occupy the ground. That eminent Methodist layman John Wesley Jacobus arrived this morning, accompanied by Dwight Lawrence and Assemblyman Jack Adams of Newburg.

The bark Rebecca Crowell, 92 days from Auckland, New-Zealand, reached this port yesterday morning about as badly shattered as a bark could be and float. She was run into at 2:30 o'clock Saturday morning when 100 miles off Barnegat by an unknown steamer.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will probably soon come into possession of a portrait of Washington painted for Daniel Carroll by Gilbert Stuart.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 14.--L.C. Houk was nominated by the Republicans of the Second Congressional District to-day for his sixth term in Congress. The delegates to Chicago were instructed for Blaine. They are W.W. Woodruff of Knoxville and George W. Hill of Dandridge.
It is under advisement to make billiards a feature of the Centennial Exposition in Cincinnati next August. An Offer of $1,000 in prizes, ...

ATLANTA, Ga., May 14.--Daniel Stanford accidentally shot and killed a young man named Felix Jones, who called upon his sister last night.

DENVER, Col., May 14.--A collision between four cars and a caboose of a freight train, and a passenger train on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Road at Fountain, 12 miles southeast of Colorado Springs, caused a teriffic explosion of a can of giant powder at 3:20 o'clock this morning.

Among the passengers that landed at Castle Garden yesterday from the steamship Suevia were Charles Friedick and three other German musicians who accompanied him. Ever since the advent of J.D. Campbell as Superintendent of the Sixth-avenue elevated railway the employes of that line say that discontent among them has been constantly on the increase.

The convention of Democrats that meets in this city to-day will have no trouble as to the Presidential candidate whom its delegates will support in the National Convention. All trace of definite opposition to the renomination of Mr. CLEVELAND has disappeared.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 14.--The deadlock in the Democratic State Convention, which for four days past has been endeavoring to nominate candidates for Governor, continues to-day. When the body was first called to order there were over 1,300 delegates in attendance, and it was thought the business could be disposed of within 24 hours.
The Brutus of Mr. Booth and the Cassius of Mr. Barrett attracted a large audience to the pretty little Amphion Academy in Williamsburg lat night.

BERLIN, May 14.--The Emperor had a good night. He arose at 10 o'clock this morning. The discharge of pus has lessened. The Emperor walked about his rooms during the day, and transacted official business by permission of the doctors.

The sudden death was announced yesterday from England of Dr. Howard Pinkney at this city. Dr. Pinkney left New-York on May 5, having been induced by his son, Dr. William H. Pinkney, to take a journey abroad for the sake of his health.

CINCINNATI, May 14.--Delegates to the two National Conventions--the Union Labor and the United Labor--are coming in rapidly. The Union Labor Party was organized here in February, 1887, taking in the greater portion of the Greenback Party.

The footsore pedestrians who were fortunate enough to cover 525 miles assembled in the office of the Sporting Times yesterday and received their share of the gate receipts. Littlewood, the winner, got 50 per cent., Guerrero 20, Herty 15, Noremac 10, and Golden 5.

The contest between the Horton and Nelson factions as to who should be the Town Committeeman from the town of Cortlandt, Westchester County, has not yet been settled. When the members of the Democratic County ...
WASHINGTON, May 14.--Sergt. Zacharias Post, Fifth Cavalry, has been placed on the retired list.

PARIS, May 14.--Gen. Boulanger was heartily received on his arrival at Bonain yesterday. At a banquet given in his honor in the evening he declared that only a criminal or a madman would dream of an aggressive war.

In spite of the declarations reported yesterday as having been made by the Irish leader, Michael Davitt, condemning the Papal rescript and resenting any interference with the political actions of the National League prominent Irish-Americans in this city are not united in their opinions of the rescript.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 14.--St. Mark's Colored Episcopal Church, Charleston, has determined to maintain an independent position. At a recent meeting of the congregation resolutions were adopted expressing gratification that after 13 years of patient efforts the constitution ...

The Trunk Line Association's Executive Committee has been obliged to make another big reduction in freight rates. Following so soon after the drop in the rates for the transportation of live stock; it is found to create much talk and comment. The latest cut has been made on railroad and lake rates from NewYork to Western points.

"Anderson," said President Cleveland to R.B. Anderson, our Minister to Denmark, when he went to Washington to get his credentials, "I want to say to you as I have said to all others who have been appointed to foreign posts, keep out of politics." Mr. Anderson tells this himself, and is quite sure that the President meant just what he said.
NORWALK, Conn., May 14.--The gang of burglars which has been operating throughout the towns in Fairfield County during the past few months still continues to ply its lawless vocation ...

MACHUCA RAPIDS, on the San Juan River, Nicaragua, April 14.--The Nicaragua Canal survey progresses satisfactorily, and the members of the expedition continue in good health. The location of the lower route from the dam at Ochoa to the San Juanillo River is complete, except ...
Several witnesses have recently testified before the House Committee on Manufactures concerning the attempts of the Standard Oil Trust to ruin them and drive them out of business.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 14.--A west-bound freight train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad jumped the track a few miles from Alden, about 4 o'clock this morning. Ten cars were derailed, blocking both tracks badly for seven hours.
WINNEMUCCA, Nev., May 14.--The Republican State Convention meets here to-morrow. There is a large attendance considering that the population of the State does not exceed 60,000.
"Well, have you unearthed any very great scandal yet?" That was the greeting given the new Commissioner of Accounts, James Daly, when he called yesterday afternoon upon Mayor Hewitt.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 14.--President Cleveland has written Col. R.H. Thomas, Secretary of the State Grange, Patrons of Husbandry, that he will visit the Inter-State Exposition at Williams Grove in August.

CHICAGO, May 14.--The Chicagos played a magnificent game all around to-day and won with ease. Krock's pitching was too much for the New-Yorks. Their one run was earned, however, through Connor's hit over the wall for a home run in the first inning.

If it had not been for the sudden and unexpected interjection by the Rev. Dr. W.H. Hunter of the Illinois Conference of an exceedingly lively topic into the midst of some very tame proceedings yesterday morning's session of the Methodist General Conference would have ...
The Rev. Dr. James Duncan Wilson died early Monday morning at his residence on West Fifty-seventh-street, in his 52d year. A wife and two sons and two daughters survive him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 14.--Kessler Co., New-York bankers, have brought suit against the Continental Construction and Improvement Company, which was organized under the joint stock laws of Connecticut in 1883 with a capital of $5,000,000, and which constructed the Hoosac Tunnel.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14.--The Judges of the Liquor License Court rendered their decision to-day in the cases of applicants in the Twenty-second, ...
A sub-committee of the Committee on Missions of the Methodist General Conference met last evening at the Washington-Square Methodist Episcopal Church.

The congregation of the South ThirdStreet Methodist Episcopal Church, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, gave, in their election of Trustees last evening, a silent disapproval of the petty scandal that has so exercised its members during the past week.

Col. J.G., better known throughout Missouri and the Southwest as Col. "Griff," Prather of St. Louis arrived in New-York yesterday in order to take part to-day in the meeting of the Democratic National Committee at the FifthAvenue Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 14.--The Supreme Court to-day denied the application for a rehearing of the telephone case. This application was made by the People's and Overland Telephone Companies, who claim that Drawbaugh and not Bell was the first inventor of the telephone.

Nicolas John Hassler, an immigrant child, 11 week old, was crushed to death yesterday at 1 Battery-place by his father, who sat on him by mistake. John Hassler, with his wife and three children, arrived here on the steamer Sorrento and landed at Castle Garden yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, May 14.--A Times special from Quincy, Ill., says that Congressman W.R. Morrison has sent a circular letter to friends of his in Adams County, in which he speaks of reports that he would like to be on the ticket with Mr. Cleveland, and says that ...

When Queen Victoria was at Berlin I retrained purposely from comparing her Majesty's reception by the population with that accorded to the Czar in November last. Any comparison was, indeed, utterly impossibly.
