Prof. Huxley, who is now staying at Bournemouth, has been seriously ill during the Spring, and he has been ordered to proceed to Switzerland for the benefit of his health as soon as the weather becomes fine and settled.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 14.--With the thermometer indicating a temperature of 50 or thereabout, a cold wind blowing, and the sun obsoured, the Democrats who have come early to the State Convention have devoted themselves to-day to objecting to the sudden change in the weather.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 14.--Mrs. Elizabeth Redmon, a lady 57 years of age, was instantly killed on an incoming train at Newport to-day. She was returning home from an errand in the town.

The Democratic State Convention meets in New-York City to-morrow to elect delegates to the National Convention. In the Assembly District Conventions to elect delegates to the State Convention, as in the conventions of other States already held, but one man has been named for the Democratic nomination for President--Grover Cleveland.

A romantic marriage--the union of a man of nearly 70 years of age with a girl scarcely out of her teens--consequent family dissen sions and, finally, the abduction of the venerable husband by his almost equally venerable sister comprise the features of a remarkable story that was made public yesterday.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 14.--Frank Alkire and Edward Foster, well-known farmers living in the northern part of this county, went fishing with dynamite cartridges Saturday night at the mouth of Tippecanoe River.

A grocery wagon and an ice wagon met in collision at the corner of Baxter and Bayard streets at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The collision was said to be due to the careless manner in which Joseph Levy was driving the horse attached to the grocer's wagon.
The entries for the Spring meeting of the Driving Club of New-York at Fleetwood Park were nominally closed last night. Ninety-seven entries were announced, with all the classes satisfactorily filled.

NYACK, May 15.--Nine of the lawyers of Rockland County have to-day issued a challenge to the physicians of the county to play them a game of baseball on the grounds of the Haverstraw Park Association either on Monday, May 21, ...
GALVESTON, Texas, May 15.--Several weeks ago the Galveston Ice and Cold Storage Company drilled an artesian well, striking a large flow of water at a depth of 856 feet.

The second game in the Racquet Club amateur billiard tournament was played last night between Messrs. Jennings and Bainbridge, and it proved to be one of the most remarkable contests ever witnessed in the club.

MAUCH CHUNK, Penn., May 15.--A Hungarian named Pokatzcky was arrested at Penn Haven Junction, near here, at noon to-day by the Chief of Police of this place, charged with having murdered the two Hungarian women ...
NASHVILLE, May 15.--The dead-lock in the Democratic State Convention was broken to-day by the renomination of Gov. Robert L. Taylor on the fortieth ballot.
PITTSBURG, May 15.--The Stove Founders' National Defense Association met at the Monongahela House this morning, thirty delegates being present from all parts of the country.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 15.--The Very Rev. William Gleeson, Vicar-General of the Catholic Diocese of Buffalo, was to-day invested with his robes of office as domestic prelate to Pope Lee XIII., with the title of Monsignor. The ceremony at the cathedral was an elaborate one. Bishop Ryan made the investiture.

PORTLAND, Me., May 15.--The event of the day at the Prohibition State Convention was the address of welcome from Gen. Neal Dow at 2 P.M. The General declared that he had cut away for good from the Republican Party: that ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 15.--A decided sensation was created to-day when it was learned that the South End Bank had been placed in the hands of a Receiver. The officers knew nothing of any move in this direction, and were amazed when they learned of the action taken by a stockholder named Joseph Erb.

T.P. Conneff writes to THE TIMES that he has given the New-York Athletic Club no authorization to state that he will meet Carter in the one-mile and the three-mile race at its Spring meeting Saturday, ...

The programme at the Brooklyn Club races to-day includes two stake races--the Myrtle Stakes for 3-year-olds and upward and the Carlton Stakes for 3-year-olds. The latter will bring together three of the best of a not particularly wonderful crop of 3-year-olds.

LOUISVILLE, May 15.--There was a large attendance at the races to-day, the weather being much warmer than yesterday. Only two favorites won, the other winners being long chances. The fields were all large, but Starter Caldwell got them off without annoying delays.

The Spanish Government has reopened negotiations with France for the creation of two new lines of railway across the Pyrenees, one passing through Canfranc, in Upper Aragon, and the other along the Noguera Valley, in the district of Lerida, Catalonia.

ELMIRA, May 15.--The death of Mrs. Phoebe Travis, frequently mentioned as the oldest person in the State, took place at the residence of her daughter, Hester Ann Hayes, on Travis Creek, Steuben County, to-day.
LITTLETON, West Va., May 15.--The Republican Convention for the First Congressional District to name two delegates to the Chicago Convention met here to-day at 1:30 o'clock.
BANGOR, Me., May 15.--The Hon. Hannibal Hamlin lives in a strong Republican ward in this city, and desires to go to the State Convention which nominates a Governor, but he was defeated to-night.

Miss Pauline Hall of "Erminie"-Casino fame is rapidly recovering from her severe illness of the past two weeks and is now able to be up and about her apartments. It is only a question of a few days now when she will be able to take outdoor exercise.

TRENTON, N.J., May 15.--Vice-Chancel lor Bird to-day decided the case of the Hutchins heirs against Henry George, the clause in the will leaving George a bequest for the purpose of aiding him in the circulation of his peculiar ideas and theories among the people was declared to be void.

LONDON, May 15.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. W.H. Smith, the Government leader, moved the adoption of a grant of 850,000 for the defense of the Australian colonies, the loan to be repaid in 12 years, with 3 per cent. interest.

LOUISIANA, Mo., May 15.--The gap in the Sny levee, through which the Mississippi is now roaring, has widened almost 300 yards. The break is just about the centre of the levee, so that the portion of the country north will es cape.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 15.--The Thirtythird Republican Congressional Convention was held at Niagara Falls this afternoon to elect two delegates to the National Republican Convention at Chicago. The headquarters were at the Spencer House, and delegates and politicians were arriving on all the morning trains from Erie and Niagara Counties.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 15.--The Democratic Convention of South Carolina will meet in the State House in this city on Thursday at noon to elect delegates to the National ...

TOPEKA, Kan., May 15.--William J. Bedger was yesterday arrested by a United states Marshal for a crime alleged to have been committed 30 years ago. In the year 1853 Badger was appointed by President Buchanan Indian Agent to the Kickapoo Tribe, then occupying ...

The Executive Committee of the Manhattan Railway Company held its regular meeting yesterday and, contrary to the expectation of some, no action was taken on the question of increasing the fares which has been attracting so much attention of late.

A notorious rastaquouere, or exotic blackleg, has just been condemned to a fortnight's imprisonment and to expulsion from the pleasant boulevards and the glittering cafes, where he had pursued his calling with such impunity for a considerable time.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 15.--The joint legislative committee continued its investigation to-day of the alleged irregularities in the management of the Morris Plains State Insane Asylum. The session was held in one of the reception rooms of the asylum, and all the members of the committee were present.

Henry MacMahon of 18 Laight-street, was convicted yesterday in the Court of General Sessions of having sent through the mails letters inviting persons to purchase counterfeit money of him. His letters were sent to him under the alais of J.D. Ramsden, at the cigar store of Louis Simon of 410 Canal-street.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--The President sent the following army nominations to the Senate to-day: Capt. Charles E.L.B. Davis, Engineer Corps, to be Major; First Lieut. George C. Derby, Engineer Corps. to be Captain; Second Lieut. William L. Sibert, Engineer Corps, to be First Lieutenant; Second Lieut. Eugene W. Van C. Lucas, First Artillery, to be Second Lieutenant, Corps of Engineers.

Gov. Hill and his adherents a few months ago made a contest in the Democratic State Committee and produced a dead-lock, for a brief period, in the matter of selecting a member of the National Committee of the party.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15.--All the railroads included in the Transcontinental Association, with the exception of the Missouri Pacific, were represented here to-day by representatives of their freight and passenger departments.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., May 15.--Workmen in this vicinity are exuberant ever the tidings that the Warren Foundries, owned by Cooper Hewitt, will be put in blast this week, employing several hundred hands.
Detectives Dugan and Cagney of the Twenty-seventh Precinct Monday night arrested William Reilly and John Pendergast of SouthBrooklyn on a charge of disorderly conduct.

The trout fishing season may now be said to be fairly open after a backward and tantalizing Spring to the lovers of angling for the beautiful fish. The law has allowed their capture since April 1 in most parts of the State, but outside of the preserve fishing on Long Island little has been accomplished by the fly caster or more modest trout plodders.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15.--To-day inaugurated another radical improvement in St. Paul-Chicago transportation facilities in the shape of a through vestibule train service.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--The first of the series of meetings to be held here during the present week by the five mission societies of the Baptist Church of America was held this morning at the Calvary Baptist Church in this city.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 15.--Capt. Simon Van Wickle of New-Brunswick died today, after a lingering illness.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15.--The American Refinery Company yesterday made a reduction on sugars of 1/8 cent all around, which was at once met by the California Company. Both refineries quot while sugars at 6 cents per pound.

Some years since, when on duty at recruiting stations in the North of England, I took observation on the great amount of disease and loss of the teeth existing among the class of men offering themselves. It became a cause of rejection of itself in great numbers.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 15.--Senator Voorhees has written a letter to State Geologist Thompson, in which he says, in response to a direct inquiry: "I shall go to the National Convention at St. Louis to carry out the expressed wishes of the Democrats of Indiana, not only without mental ...

BOSTON, Mass., May 15.--The American Bell Telephone Company issued circulars to-day offering stockholders the right to subscribe a par for $2,000,000 7 per cent. ten-year bonds, issued for the construction of the long-distance telephone system.

The breach between the members of the Stuyvesant-Avenue (Brooklyn) Congregational Church and the Pastor, Rev. J.W. Brooks, was not closed by the meeting held last evening to take action on his resignation, called for by the Trustees.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 15.--In a way that was at once unmethodical and enthusiastic the Illinois Prohibitionists began their two days' State Convention this morning in the Chamber of the House of Representatives. Nearly 1,000 delegates were present.
HANCOCK, Mich., May 15.--All the shafts of the Calumet and Hecla mine are now open, and the coming down of gas has been stopped President Agassiz, General Manager Whiting ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 15.--The Republican State Convention, called to elect delegates to the National Convention, held its preliminary session in the Hyperion Opera House this evening. One delegate will be chosen from each of Connecticut's eight counties and four delegates at large will be elected to represent the four Congressional districts.

Secretary Mellen of the Board of Quarantine Commissioners was a trifle surprised yesterday morning when Charles F. Allen and George W. Anderson walked into the office of the board and announced their intention of perfecting an organization.
William Fackner was arrested in Jersey City yesterday afternoon on suspicion of arson. When he married Mrs. Seifert he took possession of her saloon at 161 Warren-street.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 15.--Elevan persons have been killed and 30 injured by a collision on the Moscow and Kursk Railway.

JANESVILLE, Wis., May 15.--The jury in the case of Heddlas against the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company to-day rendered a verdict for the plaintiff, assigning damages at $30,000. The suit was brought to recover for injuries to a 7-year-old boy by a switch engine.

Henry W. Hewland, who has been reported as missing from his home, 1,495 Broadway, returned yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Mr. Howland had telegraphed his wife Monday night from New-Canaan, Conn., asking for funds to be sent there.

PARIS, May 15.--Gen. Boulanger has completed his tour and has returned to Paris. A crowd met him at the station and followed him to his hotel uttering mingled cries of "Vive Boulanger!" and "A bas Boulanger!" The General delivered a speech at Hirson last night.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 15.--The Republican State Convention will meet in the hall of the House of Representatives at noon to-morrow, and will be called to order by the Hon. A.M. Hughes, Chairman of the State Executive Committee.

The Pilot Commissioners recently received a letter from President L.J.N. Stark of the Dock Board, in relation to the bill, which has been passed by Congress and is now in the hands of the President, placing the regulation of anchorage in the Bay and harbor and in the ...
SEDALIA, Mo., May 15.--The Republican State Convention, which was called to order in Wood's Opera House at noon, required only 15 minutes to go on record for Blaine.

In the City Court yesterday, before Judge Ehrlich, the trial of the suit of Bernhardt Sandrowitz, a grocer, of 315 East Seventy-fourth-street, against John W. Connor, John B. Wendell, John V. Alexander, Isaac Cohn, and Caste von Guswinkle ...

JAMESTOWN, Dakota, May 15.--A convention of Republican clubs of the Territory met here to-day and organized a Territorial League to act with the national oranization, now in active operation, with A.B. Guptill of Fargo as President.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund sold at auction yesterday, at the Real Estate Exchange, on Liberty-street, the lot of ground known as Primary School No. 18, situated on Waverley-place, between West Eleventh and Bank streets.

The reorganization of the Fire Association of New-York under a new name and a new management was effected yesterday afternoon. P.B. Armstrong of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company had offered the old Board of Directors 100 cents on the dollar for all the stock of the company, or enough of it to control the organization.

The ninth annual special combination sale of Jersey cattle, consigned by prominent breeders throughout the country, was begun in the American Institute Building yesterday by Peter C. Kellogg Co. The sales will be continued to-morrow, Thursday, and Friday.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 15.--If ex-Representative John S. Wise, Senator Harrison H. Riddleberger, William E. Cameron, Gen. Groner, and the other leaders of the anti-Mahone Republicans have the nerve to stand by their colors to the last, the State Convention which meets here on Thursday will be split in two.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 15.--The State Republican Convention, which assembled in the Hall of Representatives at noon to-day, brought forth the biggest political wrangle since the stormy days of reconstruction.

PITTSBURG, May 15.--Mr. Andrew Carnegie, who arrived in the city from New-York last night, was in consultation with his partners all day. This is the last visit he expects to make to this city for a number of months, as he sails for Europe next Tuesday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 15.--It is not often that a State Convention assembles so free from the embarrassments of faction as that which is to meet in this city to-morrow. The coming State campaign is to cut no figure in this delegate body, which meets to express the opinion of the Republicans of the State upon the national situation, and to choose delegates to Chicago.
St. Agnes's Nursery, connected with Ascension Church, Fifth-avenue and Tenth-street, was formally opened and dedicated yesterday afternoon at 7l9 Greenwich-street.
The ordination and installation of the Rev. John Balcom Shaw as Pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church took place in the church at One Hundred and Fourth-street and the Boulevard, last evening.

CINCINNATI, May 15.--It was after 2 o'olock when the delegates of the United Labor Party were called to order in the Grand Opera House by John McMackin of the Executive Committee. The call for the convention was read, also the list of delegates. There were no contests.

William Gore, the young stonecutter who was bitten by a rattlesnake in the woods near Fort Lee, N.J., on Sunday, was in a precarious condition at the Manhattan Hospital last night. House Surgeon Dunning gives him from an ounce to an ounce and a half of whisky an hour, so that he is drunk all of the time.

The sub-committee of the Methodist Foreign Missions Committee met last evening at the Grand Central Hotel, on Broadway, to continue their investigations in regard to the methods pursued by Bishop Taylor of Africa in his foreign work, and the ecclesiastical position of his missionaries in the church.
HARRISONBURG, Va., May 15.--There was a heavy hailstorm in the eastern and western parts of this county yesterday and to-day. The damage is slight, but it is very cold here.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 15.--Lindeley T. Brown, an aged and prominent farmer, living near Gap Station, was gored to death by a bull on his farm last evening.
Frances Kenyon, wife of Frederick W. Kenyon of 155 West Fifty-eighth-street, seeks to gain possession of her daughter Gladys, by a writ of habeas corpus.

A surgical operation which attracted some attention in medical journals a few years ago was brought to the attention of the public yesterday by the institution of a suit in the City Court, Brooklyn, by Dr. Matthew Howard ...

"Lights and Shadows," Charles Gaylor's drama, which is to follow Neil Burgess at the Standard Theatre next Monday evening, was recently produced at the Arch-Street Theatre, Philadelphia, where it met with popular success. The scenes are laid in this city, covering ground from the Battery to Central Park, and 15 sets are used in the production.

A suit has been commenced in the Supreme Court by W.H. Peckham, Administrator of the estate of Mrs Eliza Jane Walker, against R.H. McDonald Co. for Mrs. Walker's interest in the patent medicine known as Vinegar Bitters.
DENVER, Col., May 15.--The Republican State Convention met at Pueblo to-day to nominate six delegates to the National Convention at Chicago.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 15.--The Democratic State Convention met at 1 o'clock to-day in Hazard's Pavillion with a full delegation, about 500 being present.

The Coroner's jury which has been investigating the death of Nathaniel W.T, Hatch finished its labors last evening and returned a verdict that Mr. Hatch was accidentally killed at 64 West Twentieth-street, whither he had been enticed by Mrs. Lillian E. Scofield and David C. Ferris.

The twenty-second annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island began at Garden City, Long Island, yesterday morning. There were very few persons in attendance except the clerical and lay delegates owing to the inclement weather.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 15.--All the trains coming into the city to-night were crowded with delegates from all parts of the State in attendance on the Democratic State Convention, which meets here to-morrow. The convention will be called to order by the Hon. S. G. Sharp, Chairman of the State Central ...

It is doubtful if there is any business that affords greater opportunities for testing the heights and depths and fibrous quality of human "gall" than the theatrical. To be the manager of a prosperous dramatic attraction is to come in touch with the genus "beat" in all his variety and glory of development.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 15.--The Ohio Democrats have about completed the preliminary work of their State Convention, and there is every prospect to-night that in one session they will to-morrow complete it.
The Methodist Conference refused yesterday to adopt the report of the General Conference Commission on Consolidation, Unification, and Reorganization of Church Benevolences.

LONDON, May 15.--There was little doing on the Stock Exhcnage to-day. Prices were firm except for American railroad securities, which were depressed. Any tendency to rise here is checked by the dullness in the New-York market.

Fire Marshal George H. Sheldon will, May 21, the fifteenth anniversary of his appointment to his office, cease to be a public official, as his resignation is in the hands of Col. Carl Jussen, Secretary to the Fire Commissioners. For several years Mr. Sheldon's health has not been rugged, and a bereavement unfitted him for a time for duty.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Maurice of Sing Sing yesterday afternoon and evening celebrated their golden wedding at their residence on Maurice-avenue, which Mr. Maurice laid out and which was named after him.
The State of New-York adds its column of delegates to the lengthening list of delegates from other States who will cast an undivided vote for President CLEVELAND at the St. Louis Convention.

It has been the usual custom to build cemetery vaults in much the same manner as other masonry is done--often the principal object being to obtain a showy front, while the balance of the work was, in fact, a mere shell.

The Committee of Seven of the National Democratic Committee, having in charge the preliminary arrangements for the Presidential Convention to be held at St. Louis June 5, 6, and 7, yesterday held an executive session at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

SYDNEY, New South Wales, May 15.--The steamer Guthrie arrived here to-day with 160 Chinese emigrants on board. They attempted to land, but were prevented from doing so by the police.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 15.--The estate of about 850 acres, with costly buildings and improvements, made famous as the Orange County Stock Farm by the erratic and extravagant operations of Latimer E. Jones, and situated in the town of Warwick, this county, was sold at Goshen on Saturday under foreclosure of mortgage by D.W. Esmond, Referee.

LONDON, April 21.--One has often heard of the mythical old man of the mountains, but it would seem there is a veritable old woman of the mountains more terrible than he. I met the other day Mr. H., her Majesty's Consul at Zanzibar, on the east coast of Africa, who told me the following tale of this redoubtable person, which well nigh outrivals Mr. Rider Haggard's "She."

It is a matter of some interest what sort of a platform will be adopted by the Republicans at their State Convention to-day. The leaders of both parties recognize NewYork as the battle ground of the Presidential campaign, no matter who may be the Republican candidate.

John P. Lockwood, the wayward son of a fashionable merchant tailor, who was arrested on Monday night at the Grand Central Station charged with swindling a number of persons with worthless and forged checks, was arraigned yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court before Judge Duffy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--The sale of the property at the foot of Reed-street to Claus Spreckels was finally consummated at noon to-day, Mr. Spreckels paying the balance of the purchase money, about $450,000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 15.--It seems to be settled that the "slate" will be ratified by the Republican Convention to-morrow. Chauncey M. Depew, Warner Miller, Frank Hiscock, Thomas C. Platt--these are the men who will be selected as delegates at large to Chicago.
Over 150 of the delegates of the Methodist Conference, both laymen and preachers, had the pleasure of meeting Mrs. Grant at her residence, 3 East Sixty-sixth-street, yesterday afternoon.

Elden B. Hayden, manufacturer of jewelry at 65 Nassau-street, New-York, who carried on two retail stores at 205 and 451 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, made an assignment yesterday to Edward E. Ford, giving preferences for $1,104.

Edward Hamilton Davis, A.M., M.D., widely known as a celebrated archaeologist, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 25 West One Hundred and Nineteenth-street Though Dr. Davis had made his mark in the medical profession before he reached his prime, ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 15.--Cleveland won to-day's game by hard batting at critical moments and by the inability of the Brooklyns to hit Bakely. Gilks made four clean hits out of five times at bat. McGlone's daring steal of third in the ninth inning and a phenomenal catch by Stricker in right field were the star features of the game.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--The explosion of a benzine tank in the cleaning house of F. Bonnot's dyeing establishment, Seventeenth and Fairmount avenues, this afternoon gutted the building, severely burned Francis Poullard, a dyer, and destroyed ...

In regard to the investigation which Chamberlain Ivins has demanded on account of the assertions made by Maurice B. Flynn, Commissioner of Accounts Shearman said yesterday that the private books of Mr. Ivins were now being examined and that the investigation was advancing.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 15.--The State Convention of the Prohibition Party will meet here to-morrow to nominate a candidate for Governor. Among those who are spoken of in connection with the nomination are the Hon. E. H. East of Nashville, the Hon. James J. Turner of Gallatin, Lewis Tillman of Knoxville, John R. Dean of Chattanooga, and J.R. Anderson of Bristol.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Offers for the sale of bonds to the Government were received at the Treasury Department to-day as follows: Four per cents. coupon: $32,000 at 127, $105,000 at 127 , $5,000 at 127 , $4,000 at 127, $1,700 at 127 1-16; total, $138,200.
WASHINGTON, May 15.--The United States Consul at Pernambuco has made a report to the Secretary of State in regard to the loss of the schooner Alice Montgomery of Boston, which sailed ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 15.--The NewYorks put Keefe in to beat the Pittsburgs, but it took 11 innings to satisfy the umpire that it was too dark to play further.
CHICAGO, May 15.--James Taylor, aged 45, a traveling salesman for James McNaughtin, a New-York drug dealer, to-day fell down the stairway shaft of the Palmer House from the sixth to the first floor.
The regular ticket in the New-York Stock Exchange election won the day. The reformers made a hard fight on the registered brokers' platform and came near electing some of the Board of Governors.
The Brooklyn Board of Education yesterday adopted the budget of expenses for the ensuing year, asking for $2,171,185 98, an increase over the appropriation of last year of $35,056 98.

Corporation Counsel Beekman is acting promptly on the letter of Mayor Hewitt's suggesting the beginning of a suit to compel the electric companies by mandamus to make use of the subways already prepared for them and to get rid of their poles and wires along the lines of such subways.
The Herald remarks that the Supreme Court's refusal to grant a new hearing in the telephone case "sanctions the continuance of the Bell monopoly until the expiration of the patent in 1893."

At her residence, 13 Washington-place, yesterday, the young wife of John Boyles Murray, the story of whose alleged abduction has already been told, received a number of sympathetic callers. Neither she nor her mother, who was with her, could add anything to what they had already stated regarding the case.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 15.--The election of the Hon. L.J. Foster of St. Mary as President of the Senate and the Hon. S.P. Henry of Cameron as Speaker of the House is regarded as significant of Gen. Gibson's re-election as his own successor in the Senate and the choice of Judge E.D. White as successor of Senator Eustis.

A large comforter that looked as though it contained some dutiable goods within its folds attracted the attention of Miss Belle Lawrence, a Custom inspectress, while looking over the baggage of Miss Hedwig Henle, a passenger on the steamship Suevia, from Havre, yesterday. Upon examination she found 3 yards of silk plush, 20 yards of silk, and 14 yards of lace, all of which was seized.

Lord WOLSELEY'S "explanation" in the House of Lords of his recent "banquet speech" was accepted by Lord SALISBURY as satisfactory, but the acceptance must have been dictated by an extreme desire not to quarrel with the explainer.

One of the most attractive musical entertainments in the city is that given at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, Tenth-avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-sixth and One Hundred and Thirty-eighth streets, every Saturday forenoon, between 11 and 12 o'clock. It is known as the "children's service."

CHICAGO, May 15.--The General Passenger Agents of the lines in the Western States Passenger Association held a joint meeting to-day with their Western and Eastern con nections and a representative of the Canadian Pacific Railway.
MACON, Ga., May 15.--From Fancy Bluffs, in Glynn County, this State, comes news of a tragedy in which a 9-year-old boy murdered his 6-year-old brother.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15.--The NewZealand Herald of April 10, which arrived here on the Alameda, contains an account of the murder of the American Consul at New-Britain.
The deadlock in Bayonne's City Council remained unbroken last evening, and no attempt was made to fill offices under the City Government.

The constitutional provision that the Governor of this State shall have thirty days after the end of the session of the Legislature in which to consider the bills that were passed during the closing days is a good one, but the power which it gives him is subject to abuse in the hands of an unscrupulous politician.

There was something of a break in wheat and corn yesterday at the Produce Exchange. The weather has been more favorable for the crops, and more satisfactory reports from the grain-producing districts were among the causes that helped to send the prices down.

The steam yacht Lancashire Witch reached this port yesterday from the West Indies by way of Charleston. The yacht is of wood, threemasted, barkentine-rigged, of 479 tons burden. She is owned by F.L. James, and belongs to the Royal Yacht squadron and several clubs.

The Bard yesterday proved himself to be the great race horse that THE TIMES told its readers he was. Hanover proved himself to be a trifle better than THE TIMES writer supposed him to be, while Oriflamme disappointed all his friends by failing to come up to expectations.
HAVANA, May 15.--A freight train on the Del Oeste Railroad was derailed today. The conductor was killed and the engineer, fireman, and one other person were injured.

BERLIN, May 15.--A bulletin issued this morning says the Emperor's condition is good. His appetite has improved, and the difficulty he experienced in swallowing has lessened. His strength has increased. He had but little fever last night.
At the Iron and Metal Exchange yesterday a syndicate buyer bought over 5,000 pounds of copper as 16.70.

The suit which has been brought against the Continental Construction and Improvement Company in New-Haven by New-York stockholders is a test case, and a hearing on the appointment of a Receiver will take place in that city June 4.
The Training School for Nurses at the Seney Hospital was the beneficiary of a musicale given at Historical Hall, Brooklyn, last evening, by the Florence Nightingale Society.

It was a pretty sight that the proud parents of the pupils of Grammar School No. 56 witnessed at the flag presentation exercises yesterday morning at the school, 351 West Eighteenth-street, the front of which was decorated with the national colors.

ALBANY, May 15.--The General Association of New-York Congregationalists convened in annual session in the First Congregational Church this afternoon, and were called to order by the retiring Moderator, the Rev. E.P. Ingersoll of Brooklyn.

"Plunger" F.T. Walton when he was a prominent figure on the turf was credited with having introduced the system of paying to jockeys a handsome gratuity to win a particular race with a particular horse he had backed heavily.

A mysterious lady in black, wearing a Leghorn hat, which shaded but did not conceal a pale and interesting face and a pair of large blue eyes, was the centre of attraction in the crowded Surrogate Court room yesterday during a part of the hearing in the Stewart will contest.

JOLIET, Ill., May 15.--Billy Hutchinson, one of the worst desperadoes that Chicago has yet turned out, made his escape from the Kankakee Asylum yesterday morning. Hutchinson has been a habitual criminal for 20 years past.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 15.--Otto Scheibel, Julius Waltzgott, and George Geist were arrested to-day on a warrant charging them with boycotting Brewer Joseph Weibel.

Corporation Counsel Beekman said yesterday that, as he had only just received the Mayor's letter regarding the bringing of suits to compel the electric light companies to make use of the subways and pull down the wires and poles, he had not yet decided how or when the suits would be brought, but that he would certainly act on the Mayor's suggestion and push the matter as far as the law would allow.
RICHMOND, Va., May 15.--Several petitions were filed in the Henrico Circuit Court here to-day in the suit of C.P. Huntington for the foreclosure of the mortgage of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad.

BALTIMORE, May 16.--The Princeton College lacrosse team was defeated to-day by the Druids of this city in the most scientific and hotly contested game ever seen in Baltimore. The score was: Druids, 2; Princeton, 0.
For the contemptible fraud of feigning misfortune, a young man named Frank Johnson, or Pickford, was justly sentenced yesterday at Westminster to six months' hard labor.

At the Manhattan Hospital last evening it was announced that William Gore, the young stonecutter who was bitten by a rattlesnake near Fort Lee, N.J., on Sunday, although his condition was best described by the word "stationary," had fair chances for recovery.
The number of changes in the organization of the army which Mr. LAIRD has been able to crowd into the twelve sections of his new bill for this purpose is surprising.
HAVANA, May 12.--Smallpox is rapidly declining in virulence. In April there were only 57 fatal cases, against 87 in March, 128 in February, and 270 in January.

Harper was on a visit to his uncle, Hoyd Armstrong, in an adjoining county, where he had gone to attend to important business matters over which he had had considerable trouble.

ALBANY, May 16.--At the second day's session of the General Association of Congregstionalists to-day the Rev. Dr. Frank Russell, State Sunday School Secretary, read a long report on the condition of the various Sunday schools in the State.

CHICAGO, May 16.--The suit of George M. Bogue, Receiver of the Chicago Life Insurance Company, against the stockholders of that bankrupt concern was compromised to-day by the payment into court by the stockholders of the sum of $25,000 for the benefit of the creditors. The company was put into a Receiver's hands several years ago.

BUFFALO, May 16.--A corps of Buffalo Express reporters to-day made a canvass of the delegates at the Republican State Convention. Delegates were asked to state their first and second choice for Presidential candidates, and out of a total of 693 delegates 494 answers were given.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The second of the series of Baptist Mission Conventions was held here to-day in the interest of the establishment of a general Baptist Educational Society.

The Rev. Edward Judson has launched the important undertaking of building a church on the border between the tenement district of Wooster, Thompson, and neighboring streets and the choice section that spreads northward from Washington-square.

Over three years ago Edison, the famous inventor, by his counsel, William M. Evarts, began 26 suits for infringement of patents against the United States Electric Light Company. Yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, Judge Wallace gave a decision in favor of the defendant. It was a test case, and one of the most important that has been before the courts for years.

WOODWARD, Indian Territory, May 16.-- Sergt. Porter Webster of Company A, Twenty-fourth Infantry, was shot and instantly killed by Private David Simons of the same company at Fort Reno yesterday. Simons had threatened the life of a woman with whom he had trouble, and while attempting to arrest him Webster was shot.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 16.--Mr. Harold Brown of Newport has just given $100,000 for, the missionary work in the Episcopal Churchit will be used for the endowment of the missionary episcopate of the church, and the only condition is one that is curiously interesting.

In Barrow-street, at No. 12, a few doors below Fourth-street, is a five-story modern brick building. It is new, ornamented on the outside, and has a fire escape that reaches from the top story to the broad stone coping over the front door.

The Long Island Diocesan Convention, at their session yesterday at the cathedral, Garden City, listened to some gratifying reports from the various churches, and contributions to the various enterprises of the church showed no falling off.

DAYTON, Ohio, May 16.--Cleveland, the Mills Tariff bill, the public lands for citizen settlers, liberal pensions, opposition to extravagant appropriations, sympathy with Ireland, and antagonism to trust monopolies are the key words in the declaration of principles adopted to-day by the Democrats of Ohio.

QUEBEC, May 16.--The--British bark Jessie Morris, Capt. Farland, from Greenock, which arrived at this port last night, picked up a fishing dory off the banks of Newfoundland on April 30 containing two men named Furlong, brothers, from St. John, New-Brunswick.

TORONTO, May 16.--The remains of the venerable Archbishop Lynch were laid away in the grave to-day, accompanied with the imposing and solemn ceremonial of the Roman Catholic Church.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16.--The steamship Abyasinia, from Hong-Kong via Vancouver, the second of the Canadian Pacific Company's line to arrive at this port, was allowed to dock yesterday by the Quarantine officers. No trace of smallpox was found on board. Her arrival here was followed by a cut in cabin rates to Yokohama, the new rate of $150 being made by the Canadian company.
PITTSBURG, May 16.--The local team took to-day's game from the New-Yorkers by their superior batting and base running. Welch was quite wild in the first two innings, giving four men bases on balls.

The efforts of the War Department to secure a field glass of greater power than the one now used has discovered the fact that the eyes of Americans are closer together than those of men in foreign countries.

Mr. Palmer announces that the arrangements for the Wallack testimonial performance of "Hamlet" in the Metropolitan Opera House next Monday night are practically completed.
PARIS, May 16.--The production at the Comedie Francaise of Richepin's simple and touching story in verse, blocked out in three acts and entitled "Le Flibustier," was a grand success.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 16.--The steamer Worcester, which sailed from Boston on Saturday afternoon, did not arrive here until to-day, being delayed by a heavy fog and stormy weather. She had a large number of passengers, and their friends were beginning to fear for their safety.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 16.--If any of the Republican "kickers" against the rule of Mahone in Virginia atre admitted to the Republican State Convention to-morrow, it will by kind permission of the great party boss. He has the making of the roll of the 683 delegates who will be entitled to seats in the convention.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 16.--During the second day of the State Democratic Convention little of importance was done. The convention was called to order at 10:30 o'clock this morning and a permanent organization and order of business was reported.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 16.--Thomas Gresham, a railroad employe, was shot and killed to-day by G. Eddleman, a real estate agent. Gresham had expressed himself as favorable to secret societies, when Eddleman, who was drunk, pulled out a pistol and shot him.

QUINCY, Ill., May 16.--Rail communication to the West is entirely cut off to-day by the great flood in the Mississippi River. Along the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad on the Missouri side, trains of flat cars loaded with railroad iron were sent out this morning to held down the trestle work and bridges and prevent their being swept away.

Stone announces that he has sold his entire interest in the paper to his long-time friend and business associate, Victor F. Lawson, who now becomes sole proprietor, editor, and publisher, Mr. Stone retiring from all participation in the management of the paper.

DANBURY, Conn., May 16.--Harriet F. Patch, wife of Edward Patch, died this morning from the effects of drinking wood alcohol which her husband used in softening paper. Mrs. Patch thought it was brandy.

BATH, N.Y., May 16.--Thomas Redding, formerly of Dover Plains, Dutchess County, an inmate of the State soldiers' Home here, shot Patrick Dowling, formerly of Troy, an inmate and Police Sergeant at the home Monday.

A meeting was held yesterday at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel by the Trustees of the fund given in 1882 by John F. Slater of Norwich, Conn., for the education of freedmen, and which is commonly known as the Slater fund.

JAMESTOWN, Dakotah, May 16.--The Republican Territorial Convention to select delegates to the National Convention at Chicago met this afternoon. Four hundred delegates are present, and the convention has the fullest representation of any yet held in the history of the Territory.

OTTAWA, May 16.--Citizens of Ottawa tendered Lord Lansdowne, Government-General, a farewell banquet last night preparatory to his departure to assume the post of Viceroy of India. He sails next Tuesday.

The British Ministry has introduced a resolution making a grant for military purposes, apparently in response to the criticisms of Lord WOLSELEY. In fact, however, the appropriation asked for will not be devoted to the objects which Lord WOLSELEY regards as most urgent.
BOSTON, May 16.--The tennis season at the Longwood Cricket Grounds was formally opened this afternoon. James Dwight, Tom Pettitt, Phil Sears, and Fred Mansfield participated in the games.
The predominant feature of yesterday's day session of the Methodist Conference was the memorial service in honor of those of the church's champions who have died during the last four years.

NORFOLK, Va., May 16.--At 12:45, when Chairman Barbour called the Democratic State Convention to order, the Academy of Music was filled with one of the largest and most representative delegations sent to a Virginia convention for years.
A breach of promise case, just reported, throws some light upon the etiquette of courtship in that class of life in which "walking out together" is the recognized mode of making acquaintance.
A terrible panic occurred in a menagerie at Prague last night. The structure is a wooden one and is capable of holding about 1,500 persons.

BOSTON, May 16.--Gen. Paine has decided to put the Volunteer into commission this year, and work will be commenced on her at once. Capt. Haff has been notified of this fact, and is expected here to-morrow to superintend the work of fitting her out.
NYACK, N.Y., May 16.--A temperance encampment of unusually large proportions is to be held at Monsey, Rockland County, the coming Summer, if a certain amount of encouragement is given in advance.

DETROIT, Mich., May 16.--The Assignee of Root, Strong Co., the recently failed wholesale dry goods house, was before Judge Hosmer, yesterday in answer to the petition of Frank A. Rockafellow of Carson City.

CINCINNATI, May 16.--Marshal Bowen of Carthage, a village 10 miles from Cincinnati, shot and killed C.D. Phillips last night.
NEWPORT, May 16.--The "oldest inhabitant" cannot account for the small run of scup so far. Scup are known as porgies in New-York and Philadelphia markets.
A most determined effort is being made to finish Melbourne Cathedral, which has been building since 1880.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 16.--Prof. F.M. Schneeweiss died to-day after a lingering illness. He was a well-known musician and composer and had passed a varied career.
A messenger from the Union Trust Company started for the National Park Bank yesterday morning with two checks for $16,000, drawn to the order of the latter institution.

The Ninth-Avenue Bank, at Fifty-ninthstreet and Ninth-avenue, has overcome the diffculties which Cashier H.J. Hubbard caused by his methods of financiering.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16.--The Prohibitionist State Convention worked hard this morning, but its progress was slow. After selecting a State Committee the delegates took up the platform, but in disposing of it were delayed by a number of rather unimportant resolutions and speeches.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--Capt. A.H. Russell, Ordnance Department, has been ordered to temporary duty at Wilmington, Del. First Lieut. Francis Woodbridge, Seventh Infantry, having been reported incapable for active service, has been ordered home.

Ellis, in a bill for divorce filed in the Circuit Court in this city to-day. The Ellises were married in 1870, and for 10 years managed to live together. They have one daughter.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 16.--The--Wesleyan Methodist Episcopal Church Conference is holding its annual session in the hamlet of Slab Hollow, in the town of Shandaken, in the Ulster Catskills.

The Society oF Ethical Culture held its twelfth annual meeting last evening at 109 West Fifty-fourth-street.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday, by a vote of six to one, awarded the contract fcr the construction of the pipe line from One Hundred and Thirty-fifth-street and Convent-avenue to the Central Park Reservoir to O'Brein Clark.

Rainy, disagreeable weather didn't keep some 5,000 people from the Brooklyn Jockey Club track at Gravesend yesterday. The Carlton Stakes, in which the crack 3-year-olds of the year were entered and were expected to run, brought two-thirds of the crowd there.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 16.--Oberlander's wildness, aided by some wretched fielding, lost the game to the Clevelands to-day. Had he been properly supported the score would have been different.

STAUNTON, Va., May 16.--The Diocesan Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Virginia met here to-day, Bishop Randolph presiding. Bishop Peterkin is present.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., May 16.--The raids by the State police go merrily on. A few day's ago they raided Burke Brothers' wholesale place on Fountain-street and secured a small quantity of liquor.

FORT FAIRFIELD, Me., May 16.--Five hundred thousand feet of lumber was washed out of H. Stevens Co.'s dam yesterday by the freshet. There are numerous wash-outs on the New-Brunswick Railroad and there have been no trains from Presque Isle since Monday and none from Woodstock since yesterday morning. The water is subsiding to-day.
The Ninth Regiment assembled in its armory in West Twenty-sixth-street last evening in force for an evening parade. A number of ladies and other friends of the regiment were present.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 16.--Thomas C. Platt has again demonstrated to the satisfaction of observing politicians that he is boss of the Republican Party of this State. The slate, which was made up under his eye, was indorsed by to-day's convention.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The Brazilian legation in this city has received information from Roderigo Silva, Minister of Foreign Affairs, that the Brazilian Parliament has approved the Government bill completely abolishing slavery, and that it had been sanctioned by the Regent on the 13th inst. The Minister stated also that this action met with extraordinary manifestations of joy.

NEW-HAVEN, May 16.--An unexpectedly strong sentiment for Depew was early manifested in the Republican State Convention today. Chairman John A. Tibbetts in the opening address spoke of the Republican Party as rich in Presidential material.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 16.--The schedule of the condition of the affairs of H.B. Beard, an extensive real estate dealer who recently assigned, shows assets, $1,523,526; direct liabilities, $549,384; contingent liabilities, $577,888. There are a number of heavy Eastern creditors.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 16.--Yale lost a game of ball unexpectedly to the Holy Cross nine at the Yale field to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16.--Articles of incorporation have been filed by the JohnsonLocke Mercantile Company, the incorporators being C.C. Kinzie, C.M. Johnson, B.A. Locke, H.M. Bissell, and W.L. Locke.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16.--The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church will begin its annual session to-morrow morning in the Franklin-Street Presbyterian Church. The last time it met here was in 1868.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 16.--In the construction of his palatial Summer home on his island in the St. Lawrence River, near Alexandria Bay, George M. Pullman of Chicago has provided for the perfect preservation of the room in rough structure of the early days in which Gen. Grant slept while Mr. Pullman's guest.

PITTSBURG, May 16.--Outside pig iron sellers always find Pittsburg the best market in the country, even in a dull season. The consumption now is rather more than 4,000 tons a day and the production about 2,600 from 17 furnaces. Nine of these belong to Carnegie Brothers Co.

COLUMBUS, Kan., May 16.--Three more of the notorious Blalock-Frye robber gang were sentenced last evening. Andrew Frye to 25 years; Fred Frye to 8 years, and Alexander Frye to 15 years in the penitentiary.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 16.--The State Republican Convention reassembled at 10 o'clock this morning. Albert Boyd (colored) of Birmingham, temporary President, and R.A. Mosely (white) of Decatur, temporary Secretary, were made the permanent officers of the convention.
The mysterious disappearance of Miss Augusta Abeles, a young and handsome woman, was reported to the police yesterday by her brother, Edward Abeles of 179 East One Hundred and Eighth-street.

MACON, Ga., May 16.--The 13-year-old son of H.M. Vaughan, a well-to-do farmer residing near Jackson, Ga., hanged himself in the barn last night with wagon lines. He was the family pet, and grief over a slight whipping with a switch administered by his mother is supposed to be the cause of the suicide.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 16.--This afternoon at 1:30 o'clock the Democratic Convention was called to order in the beautifully-decorated new opera house by the Chairman of the State Committee, Jndge S.G. Sharp, who made a stirring little speech in which he referred to President Cleveland as being the one man in the Union to lead the Democracy to another victory.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16.--The Republican Convention to day was exceedingly quiet compared to what is promised by the Minnesota Democracy in State Convention to-morrow. The Democrats themselves are not looking for a harmonious meeting; they do not expect it.

STAUNTON, Va., May 16.--The Republican Convention of the Seventh Virginia District at Charlottesville to-day elected Senator Riddleberger and ex-Senator Lewis delegates to the Chicago Convention. Stuart F. Lindsey was chosen Elector. All are uninstruced, but favor Blaine.
CHICAGO, May 16.--The Appellate Court this morning reversed and remanded the case of Eugene S. Pike against Levi Z. Leiter, which was appealed from Judge Garnett.

Richard Des Mones, a sailor belonging to the British bark Bristol, deserted his vessel at Valencia and managed to stow himself away on the steamship Scandinavia, bound for New-York. He was rather weak when discovered after the steamship sailed, but recovered in a few days and was put at work. He seemed despondent, however, and May 3 leaped overboard. Boats were lowered and every attempt made to save him, but in vain.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 17.--Gov. Hill has appointed hearings on Friday, May 25, at 2:30 P.M., on the bill relative to the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge; also, in relation to the use of sand on street railway tracks in cities of more than 500,000 population.

LOUISVILLE, May 17.--A light rain kept the track very heavy to-day and caused many scratches. The first race, for a purse of $400, at a mile and one-sixteenth, was won by Grisette from Persimmons, with Amelia P. third.

SALIDA, Col., May 17.--The Leadville express on the Denver and Rio Grande was derailed while rounding a long curve in Brown's Canon Tuesday night. The express and baggage cars were dashed to pieces on the rocks in the canon and the smoking car partially demolished.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 17.--The State Democratic Convention, to elect delegates to the National Convention, met here to-day in the Hall of Representatives. The State and Union flags floated over the building. There were 320 delegates present, the finest body of men ever assembled here.

CHICAGO, May 17.--At the closing meeting of the Western Unitarian Conference today it was received that the close relations between the Unitarian, Universalist, and Independent Churches be recognized by yearly State Conferences.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 17.--The schooner Schuyler Colfax, the only vessel engaged in mackerel fishing south this Spring, arrived to-day after a six weeks's cruise from Cape Hatteras to Block Island without seeing mackerel. It is believed the mackerel fishery is a failure this Spring.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 17.--The State police made their most extensive haul of liquor to-day in a raid upon Dodge Camfield's wholesale grocery establishment. CHICAGO, May. 17.--Erastus Gary, a native of Pomfret, Conn., died to-day at his home in Wheaton, Du Page County, aged 82. He was one of the oldest settlers in this part of the country, and was a soldier in the Black Hawk war. He afterward became the senior member of the banking firm of Gary Wheaton, at Wheaton, and accumulated a large estate. He was one of the founders of Wheaton College.

PARIS, May 17.--The bureau of the Senate have elected a committee to examine the Panama, Canal Lottery Loan bill. A majority of the committee favor the bill.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--The centennial meeting of the Presbyterian General Assembly, the supreme ecclesiastical court of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, began in this city this morning. There are over 500 delegates or Commissioners in attendance, representing every State and Territory in the Union.

Cox recognized when he gained the floor, and in his opening remarks alluded to his teacher in political economy, "the good Christian Baptist, Dr. Wayland."

A traveler recently from Corea complains of the difficulty of finding articles of beauty or interest in porcelain, pottery, bronze, c., even in the capital, Sofil. Much the same is reported of Manchinia by Mr. James of the Bombay civil service in his recent "Long White Mountain."

The Board of Officers of the Twelfth Regiment last evening gave a dinner at Pinard's, in West Fifteenth-street, to Col. James H. Jones, who has resigned and will sail for Europe on May 31. He will command the regiment for the last time on Decoration day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 18.--The lack of success of the New-York baseball team on its trip has caused the management and its friends much concern. Manager Mutrie is full of excuses, but hopeful of better luck from this time forward. The team is badly "broken up" at present.

Helena Modjeska shrugged her shoulders and shivered as she stood in the centre of the stage of Wallack's Theatre at noon yesterday and looked out into an auditorium made vast by its emptiness. The sale of admission tickets to the Wallack testimonial of Monday evening was held at the Metropolitan Opera Horse yesterday morning. The price of admission to the orchestra, dress circle, and balcony had been placed at $2 and to the family circle at $1, or an advance of 100 per cent. over the usual rates.

About five hundred people braved the cold and wet yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds while watching the tenth annual games of the New York Inter-Scholastic Athletic Association. Notwithstanding the heavy track, the boys succeeded in breaking three records--the running high jump, the twomile bicycle race, and the 100 yards' dash for boys of 15 and under.

The old Sixth Sub-Police Precinct in Brooklyn wag elevated to the dignity of a full precinct yesterday with the title of the Nineteenth. The station house is at 437 Graham-avenue, Williamsburg. In issuing the order Commissioner Bell accompanied it with one promoting Sergt. Stephen Martin of the Fourth Precinct to a Captaincy and assigning him to the command of the new precinct.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 18.--The trial of Detective Nagel and Constable Bureau was begun to-day. A startling discovery has been made in connection with the case.

LOUISVILLE, May 18.--The entries for the races to-day were large. Just after the first race a heavy rain began to fall and made the track bad. The first race, for a purse of $400 at six furlongs, was won by Orderly, Emma Johnson second, and Full Sail third. Time-- 1:17. The betting was 2 to 1 against Orderly to win. 4 to 5 for place; 5 to 1 againat Emma Johnson for place.

Lillian E. Scofield is a free woman again, her "brother-in-law," David C. Ferris, will probable soon be a free man, and the Hatch tragedy bids fair to pass out of sight. Soon after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, De Lancey Nicoll served Coroner Levy with a writ of habeas corpus, just granted by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court, for the production of Mrs. Scofield in Supreme Court, Chambers, at 3 o'clock.

OMAHA, Neb., May 18.--Considerable excitement still prevails at Plattsmouth over the wounding Wednesday night of Peter Rogers and John Dill, brotherhood firemen, and Special Officer Kane by a Pinkerton man named Goodwin, employed by the Burlington and Missouri River Company.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 18.--The Republican District Convention for the Twentysixth Congressional District was held in this city to-day. Delegates were present from the four counties comprising this district--namely, Broome, Chenango, Madison, and Tioga.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 18.--This morning, before the Attorney-General, evidence was taken in a case which may have in its results an important bearing on the validity of one of the bestknown and most important bills passed by the last Legislature.

WINCHESTER, Va., May 18.--Josiah B. Locke, tried in Berryville, Clarke County, for the murder of William Jenkins, an employe on his farm near Wadesville, last Fall, was to-day found guilty. The verdict was five years' imprisonment in the penitentiary. The jury was out all night. His son was an accessory and will be tried next week. They were tried jointly several months ago, but the jury disagreed.
The only new name, coupled last night with the scheme to organize Hill Clubs in the various Assembly Districts of this State, was that of Dr. Collins of 256 West Twenty-fifthstreet.

James Owen O'Connor, the actor, appeared in a new role yesterday at the Second District Civil Court, when he came up before Justice Claney in answer to the suit of Richard Griffin and others, members of O'Connor's company, for $250, two weeks' salary unpaid.

CHICAGO, May 18.--The last sessions of the Western Unitarian Annual Conference were held to-day. A number of papers were discussed and addresses made in the afternoon by Rabbi Hirsch and the Rev. Dr. Thomas.

SEATTLE, Wyoming, May 18.--The Seattle, Lake Shore and Eastern Railway Company entered into a contract last evening for the construction of 225 miles of standard gauge railroad through the Cascade Mountains toward Spokane Falls.

The Commissioners of Accounts failed to get Maurice B. Flynn before them yesterday to testify as to the charges he recently made respecting City Chamberlain Ivins. The Commissioners were unable to serve notice upon him to appear before them. A messenger was sent to Mr. Flynn's office in the morning, and was told that Mr. Flynn was up town on business.

Alabama heads the column and will first announce her vote in the Democratic National Convention. It will be 20 for Cleveland. Who can say how it will be for Vice-President? Up to a short time ago everything pointed to Gov. Gray's triumphant nomination. Now it is not so certain.

BOSTON, Mass., May 18.--The trial of Mrs. Abbie H. Corner, the West Medford Christian scientist, for manslaughter in neglecting to provide medical care for her daughter, Mrs. Lottie James, who died in childbirth, and whose infant also died, was begun to-day at Malden.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 18.--A jury to-day inquired into the mental condition of Harry McRae. McRae is worth considerable money, left him by his father. Some time ago he was sent to the Union Protestant Infirmary for treatment.

The Bedford Stakes and the Parkway Handicap should furnish excellent sport at the Gravesend track to-day, the former serving to introduce Montana Morrissey's crack 2-year-old French Park to the Eastern race goers.

The Woolen Goods Association is a representative organization of manufacturers and commission merchants in woolen goods. The leasing of the Amphion Academy in Brooklyn, Eastern District, to Knowles Morris for a term of 10 years has caused considerable indignant criticism from the friends of the present manager, C. Mortimer Wiske, who had a bid for the property before the Board of Trustees.

CHICAGO, May 18.--Judge Alweld has decided against the State officers in their case against the People's Insurance Exchange to recover $12,000 penalties for conducting "underground" insurance companies.

It was expected that Mrs. Rutherford B. Hayes would fireside last opening at the mass meeting of the Woman's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the Metropoli tan Opera House, but she sent a telegram announcing her inability to be present.

CHICAGO, May 18.--Only five innings were played, to-day when the game was given to Chicago. The cold and uncomfortabale weather and wet grounds rendered Morrill and Anson both willing that Lynch should call the game. Radbourne's delivery was hit very hard from the beginning.

BOSTON, Mass., May 18.--Bartlett Butman, manufacturers of trusses, , formerly of 329 Washington-street, have made an assignment to Halsey J. Boardman. Their liabilities are estimated at $17,000, and their assets are $4,000.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., May 18.--The Republican Congressional Convention of the Twenty-second District, composed of St. Law rence and Jefferson Counties, met here to-day. Each county is recognized as entitled to a delegate to the Chicago Convention.
BELVIDERE, N.J., May 18.--A meeting held in the Court House here last night to discuss the proposed lighting of the town by electricity broke up in a row.

The rooms of the New-York Flower Mission, 243 Fourth-avenue, rear, are open every Monday and Thursday for the receiption and distribution of flowers and fruit for the sick in hospitals and tenement houses. Money sent will be used to purchase delicacies for tenement house sick.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 18.--Four negroes assaulted two white women in the village of Washington. Rhea County, to-day. They were pursued and captured, and will in all probability be lynched.

NEW BEDFORD, March 18.--Thomas J. Cobb, the Clerk of the Third District Court of Bristol County, has returned after eight days' mysterious absence. The official examiner of county accounts has finished his revision of the books, and found that Mr. Cobb ought to have a bank account of $2,616 02. Mr. Cobb immediately increased his deposits to that amount, and had several hundred dollars left in his pockets. He has resumed his duties as Clerk.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 18.--The passenger department of the Manitoba Road has not as yet received instructions to reduce rates to the basis of 3 cents per mile on its lines in Minne sota to conform to those of the Northern Pacific.
Cernuschi of bimetalism fame has arranged to give a fancy ball in honor of a rosepeach beauty, incomparable in her way, Mile. Jeanne Hugo.

Our old friend H. Maltby, who resides at Briscoe, in this county, writes us that he measured a snowdrift on the morning of the 11th inst., extending from Mr. Judson's to Mr. Townsend's farm, and that it was 5 to 6 feet deep, 2 to 3 rods wide, with a continued length of 66 rods without a break.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18.--When United States Senator Quay arrived at the Continental Hotel this afternoon he was met by a big number of prominent politicians. The Senator had come to town to fix up the Pennsylvania delegation to the Chicago Convention, and he had long pow-wows with a number of the leading delegates. In speaking of his choice of a candidate for the Presidency he declared for Sherman.

At the meeting of the Trunk Line Association Freight Committee yesterday complaints that have been made relative to underbiling and underweighing in some localities were discussed. Commissioner Fink said at the conclusion of the meeting that he failed to find any great trouble in this regard, and that west-bound rates would be maintained.

In accordance with the expressed desire of the numerous friends of Signor Campanini he and his excellent operatic concert company will give a concert at Chickering Hall this afternoon. The programme is made up of some of the most delightful numbers from "Marta," "Simon Boccanerga," "Mefistofele," "Otello," "Faust," "Carmen," "La Giaconda," and other operas.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 18.--Only a few barrels of seut were caught yesterday or to-day, but sea bass are quite plentiful. Last night 116 barrels were shipped to New-York and 93 barrels to-night. Two hundred and forty-nine barrels were shipped to Philadelphia. Less than 30 barrels of scut were caught both days.

LONDON, May 18.--Business on the Stock Exchange was at a standstill to-day. American railroad securities were dull all day, but closed above the lowest quotations of the day under a renewal of New-York buying.

Algiers has been aroused from its provincial quietude by a visit of the King of Sweden, who has been marking a tour in the Mediterranean in a Swedish frigate. He came from Philippeville by a special train, and not being incognito was received with the honors due to his rank by M. Tirman, the Governor of Algeria. The King sleeps on board the frigate. He intends to make excursions into the interior.

Detectives James P. Reynolds of the Tenth Precinct, Brooklyn, was charged Yesterday with extorting $100 from H.J. Bridger, a jeweler doing business at 570 Fulton-street. W.C. Booth left his daughter's two-hundred-dollar diamond engagement ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 18.--Dr. Edward McGlynn, John McMackin, and other New-York labor politicians passed through this city to-day from the Cincinnati Convention. Dr. McGlynn was especially enthusiastic in regard to the prospects of the United Labor Party in the coming campaign.

DETROIT, Mich., May 18.--The Supreme Court to-day rendered a unanimous decision pronouncing the local option law enacted by the Legislature a little over a year ago unconstitutional. The decision rests upon one ground only.

CARTHAGE, Ill., May 18.--Mrs. Ida M. Wright, the bride of Silas M. Wright, was found hanging in the smokehouse near their home at Fountain Green last evening by her husband, who has been absent from home since Monday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 18.--The State Convention of Loan and Building Associations was called together this morning. The Committee on Permanent Organization recommended that the temporary organization of the convention be made permanent, and their report was adopted.

The latest invention in photography is the discovery of a process by which colors as well as objects may be photographed. By the use of several plates instead of one,three negatives are taken on plates specially prepared.

Among the passengers of the Guion Line steamship Arizona, landed at Castle Garden April 30, was Selma Hagland. She was quite attractive, 24 years old, well dressed, carried a gold watch and chain, were several gold rings, and had a large trunk and valise. Soon after landing she became violently insane, and was sent to Ward's Island.
LONDON, May 18.--The steamship Gallia, (Br.,) Capt. Murphy, from New-York May 9 for Liverpool, arr. at at Queenstown to-day.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 18.--The Cornell baseball nine left this afternoon for Philadelphia on their annual intercollegiate trip. To-morrow they run out to Princeton, N.J., playing the first game of the trip there.

TROY, N.Y., May 18.--There has been a fatal disease among sheep in Washington County this Spring, especially in White Creek. Loren Sweet has lost more than 100 out of his flock, Elon Sweet has lost from 30 to 40, and John James 15 to 20. Many others have lost large numbers. It seems to be a disease of the liver and kidneys.

In a decision handed down yesterday by the General Term in the case of Robert Goelet and others against the Metropolitan Transit Company the judgment of the Supreme Court sustaining the demurrer to the complaint was reversed, with costs, and the demurrer overruled, with leave to the defendant to answer on payment of the costs of the demurrer and the courts below.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 18.--J.H. Orr, dry goods, corset, and millinery merchant of this city, well known to the business public of New-York City by reason of his connection with several lawsuits in the courts there, is in trouble. Three suits of replevin ware issued to the Sheriff's office this morning.

The Faculty of the School of Arts, Columbia College, at its meeting yesterday afternoon elected the members of the Senior Class who will be awarded the Fellowships at the coming Commencement of the college, June 13, at the Academy of Music. To the Fellowships in Science were appointed Hampton D. Ewing and Percy F. Hall; in Letters.

Col. McCaull has notified his company that no new opera will be put in rehearsal for some time. He contemplates a long run for the "Lady, or the Tiger?" and the company are delighted at the prospect of vacation from rehearsals during the heated term.

CHICAGO, May 18.--Robert H. Cowdrey of this city regards the nomination he has had for President of the United States by the United Labor Party as a sacrifice. At all events, that is the way he expresses it.

ALBANY, May 18.--Ex-Policeman Charles Rickerts is now serving his sentence in Clinton Prison. He was transferred with 49 other prisoners, including two for life, from Sing Sing to Clinton Prison Wednesday. He will be placed at work making clothes.

John McGowan, 3-year old, of 180 East Seventy-eight-street, was knocked down yesterday by car 17 of the Third-avenue surface road at Third-avenue and Seventy-eighth-street, and was slightly injured. The driver of the car was arrested but not held, as the mother of the child refused to make a complaint against him.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 18.--Four burglars broke into the Post Office and railway office at Monticello last night, and blew open the safe in each. They got only $15, leaving behind a kit of tools worth much more. The gang then stole a hand car and worked it down to Rose's Point, 17 miles distant, where they lifted the car from the track, crossed the country to Guymard, and escaped.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, May 18.--The Rev. George Tompkins and wife, whose domestic troubles led to the minister discharging a revolver at Contractor Lundy a fortnight since, have agreed upon a settlement and separation. The property is equally divided between them and Mrs. Tompkins retains the custody of their child.

BERLIN, May 18.--A bulletin issued this morning says: "The Emperor is without fever. The difficulty he experienced in swallowing has nearly disappeared. His general condition is so satisfactory that he was allowed to spend the greater part of the day in the open air. His strength is increasing. There is less secretion of pus."

Harry Benson, the Patti swindler, who committed suicide in Ludlow-Street Jail, was buried yesterday afternoon in the Jewish burial ground at Union Fields, Long Island. One carriage followed the body, and in this were Peter Mitchell, Benson's counsel, and his clerks.

CHICAGO, May 18.--Joel Henry Wells, a well-known resident of this city, succeeded today in securing a decree restoring him to the status of a sane man. For several years Mr. Wells has been roaming around the country with a decree of insanity hanging over him.

The Society of the New-York Hospital has resolved upon a removal of the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum to White Plains, the demoli tion of all the buildings now composing the asylum except the Mrs. John C. Green memorial building, and the sale at auction by lots of the vast tract now occupied by the asylum for building purposes.

Warden McClaughry said in an interview a few days ago that there are now 200 less criminals in the penitentiary than there were a year or two ago; not because there has been a decrease of crime, but "the wave of punishment is just now receding in the State." The people would do well to raise a breeze which will send the wave back again.

NEGAUNEE, Mich., May 18.--By an explosion of dynamite at the Palmer Mine, near here, at 1:30 o'clock this moining, Fred Hanburg and Charles Sundberg were instantly killed. Sundberg's back was terribly torn and a staple from the door was found in it. Every bone in Hanburg's body was broken.

President Diaz, who has proved himself an able statesman as well as a distinguished soldier, was recently, the hero of the occasion in quieting what promised to be a dangerous panic in a crowded theatre in the city of Mexico.

BOSTON, May 18.--The will of Ada Augusta Draper of Boston, executed in Paris in January last, has been filed in the Suffolk County Probate Office.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 18.--The fifth day of the international and inter-State drill and celebration concluded the drill contests. A heavy rain cell during the forenoon, and the drill grounds were wet and in poor condition during the day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18.--Two suits in equity were to-day begun in Common Pleas Court against Mrs. Delia T.S. Parnell, and two foreign attachments were taken out by Lawyer Joseph Hopkins against her property on Tenth and Pryor streets. The amount of bail on each attachment is $8,500.

Mrs. Margaret J. Coxford has brought suit for absolute divorce against her husband, William F. Coxford, of the gun firm of Coxford MacIlvaine, 41 Centre-street. Through her counsel, Charles F. Lansing, application was made Thursday for alimony pendente lite and counsel fees before Judge Lawrence, who referred the application to Lawyer Edwin R. Mead.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Acting Secretary Thompson had written a letter in regard to the inspection of small pleasure steamers in which he says: "All pleasure yachts (steam) under 100 tons gross burden must carry a licensed pilot and a licensed engineer, but do not require a licensed master.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 18.--Yesterday an altercation took place at the Union Railway Station between a well-dressed and gentlemanly-looking traveler and the attendant at the parcel package check room. Passers-by were attracted by angry words and finally saw the traveler slap the attendant.

MASON CITY, Iowa, May 18.--Notices are now posted in all division round houses of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad that after May 20 all engineers unable to run engines without the aid of a pilot will be dismissed from the service. This will take off about 60 per cent. of the engineers.

MACON, Ga., May 18.--The people of Montgomery County are greatly excited over a tragedy which has just been brought to light. Near Perry's Mills, Grace Coleman ran a turpentine factory, and took into their employment a year ago a South Carolinian named David Davis. Davis subsequently won the affections of Grace's daughter, and the pair eloped and were married.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 18.--In the Democratic caucus last night United States Senator Gibson was renominated by unanimous vote. RIO JANEIRO, May 18, via Galveston.--A Government decree has been issued appointing three days for festivities in celebration of the abolition of slavery.
LONDON, May 18.--Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland, will introduce in Parliament three bills-dealing with the drainage of the rivers Bann, Barrow, and Shannon.

A cablegram received from Venice yesterday by the firm of Arnoux, Ritch Woodford brought the sad news of the death of the son of Mr. Arnoux, William Henry Arnoux, Jr., of typhoid fever. The young man was about twenty years old, and of great promise. It had been his intention to enter Columbia on the return of the family from abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 18.--Second Lieut. William H. Bean, Second Cavalry, has been granted two months' extension of leave of absence. Second Lieut. Eugene F. Ladd, Troop E, and Second Lieut. Harry H. Trout, Troop B, Ninth Cavalry, transferred.

John Jasper, City Superintendent of Schools, was in a placed and humorous frame of mind yesterday afternoon when the special committee of the Board of Education appointed to investigate charges against him was called together.
