ALBANY, May 18.--Adjt.-Gen. Porter to-day granted another examination to Russell Benedict, who has been nominated for Adjutant of the Thirteenth Regiment. Gen. Porter also granted a full discharge to David H. Teets as First Lieutenant of the Seventy-first Regiment, and commissioned Walton L. Miller as Captain of the Eleventh Regiment.

An old lady living at Ryde died recently, and in due course her furniture was advertised for sale. On the day before the sale one of the Executors carefully examined an ancient bureau, and discovered a secret drawer and a false bottom, in which were upward of 1,000 sovereigns, closely packed together.

ALBANY, May 18.--With the object of the regeneration of old English music and the improvement of song, in the English language, the English Ballad Concert Company (limited) was incorporated to-day with a capital of $250. The locality of its business is New-York City, and Jule A. DeRyther, Belle A. Fanton, Ferdinand Mayer, Charles T. Cunningham, and Frances Waters are Trustees.
"Daily Reader"--Aug. 6, 1876, fell on Sunday. Cappa's Band will play in Central Park this afternoon at 4 o'clock and to-morrow afternoon at the same hour.

ALBANY, N.Y., May. 18.--Gov. Hill to-day affixed his signature to the following bills: Assembly bill No. 836--Amending the act providing for recording and indexing conveyances and instruments in New-York City--Chapter 321.

ALBANY, May 18.--When Herman Anthony returned to his home in Medusa, this county, from work last night, he found his wife suspended by the neck in the barn, dead. She was about 30 years old and was flighty at times.
BURLINGTON, Vt., May 18.--The Vermont State Board of Trade to-day began operations under favorable auspices, with an attendance of more than a hundred buyers from New-York and Boston and producers.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 18.--M.W. Dennis, a well-to-do white farmer, was sitting by the fireside with his wife last evening conversing pleasantly when an angry dispute suddenly arose and Dennis attempted to chastise his wife. Mrs. Dennis defended herself with a piece of iron which she happened to be holding in her hand, and, striking her husband in the head, killed him almost instantly. The Coroner's jury acquitted her.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 18.--Samuel Morris, a well-known clothing dealer of South Main-street, left town rather suddenly last Wednesday without saying where he was going or when he would return.

The sub-committee of the Methodist General Foreign Missions Committee continued at the Grand Central Hotel last evening its consideration of the work of Bishop Taylor of Africa. Bishop Taylor further explained his system, and Missionary Davenport spoke strongly against Bishop Taylor's methods.

Patrolmen McCormack and Dickerman of the Thirteenth Police Precinct, Brooklyn, who refused to be vaccinated at the order of Commissioner Bell and who were given one week to make up their minds to obey orders, appeared before the Commissioner yesterday with swollen arms and a flag of truce.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 18.--The two leading fish dealers of this city were interviewed to-day relative to the failure of the soup or porgy season. One of the dealers said that from the 1st of the present month he had not received more than four barrels of soup, while a year ago he had within the same time received a hundred.

PARIS, May 18.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Delisse asked the Government to produce the official papers referring to the Sugar Bounties Conference. He said that the reported decisions of the conference had keenly moved the working classes interested in the sugar trade.

Chauncey M. Depew was not present at the fourth regular meeting of 1888 of the Yale Alumni Association at Delmonico's last night, but his name was very frequently mentioned. Allusions to him always provoked applause from the 75 or more Alumni of various ages present.
TROY, N.Y., May 18.--Farmers are suffering severely from the long-continued cold and wet weather. Plowing cannot be advanced, and oats in many places are rotting in the ground.
Advises from Constantinople state that the plans for completing the fortifications of Adrianopole and Tchataldja have been approved by the Porte, and will soon receive the sanction of the Sultan.

GLEN COVE, Long Island, May 19.--Archdeacon J.C. Middleton, Rector of St. Paul's Church, in this place, who has been very ill for a long time, was so much better that he sat up for a while. At about 3 o'clock Thursday afternoon he was suddenly stricken blind, and it is feared that the disease has gone to his brain.

MONTREAL, May 19.--Eight thoroughbred Clydesdale stallions, valued at $7,060, which were shipped from Scotland by Thomas McBey, have been seized here on the ground that McBey, who was adjudged a bankrupt after the ship had left Glasgow, exported them with the intention of defrauding his creditors.
Prof. Eugene A. Wierner, a well-known and very eccentric musician, was found dead in his bed at 661 Third-avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning.

The New-York Ladies' Health Protective Association, an organization which has been doing much good work, especially on the east side of the city, is going to hold a big meeting at Chickering Hall on Thursday evening, under the Presidency of ex-Judge Daly. He was known there for some years as "The Benefactor;" but now, I hear, that it is more the fashion to call him "The Malefactor."

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 19.--The details of the will of the late Norman A. Kittson were made known to-day. The only public bequest is $10,000 to the Masonic Building Association. His sons, Louis and James, are given the real and personal property at Erdenheim, near Philadelphia.

The New-York Athletic Club held possession of the Polo Grounds for three hours yesterday afternoon, conducting there its twentieth annual games. The weather was not lovely and the long wet spell had made the track heavy and dotted the field with mud puddles.
BOSTON, Mass., May 19.--The Harvard Union held a convention last evening "to nominate candidates for the Presidency of the United States."

ALBANY, May 19.--Following is the report for the quarter ending March 31 of the Ogdensburg and Lake Champlain Railroad (Vermont Central:) Gross earnings, $134,316; operating expenses $76,398; fixed charges, $64,040; deficit, $6,123.

I am sorry to learn that Canon Buckle, the father of the editor of the Times, is seriously ill. Canon Buckle, who was recently collated to a residentiary stall in Wells Cathedral, has intimated his intention of resigning the important vicarage of Weston-super-Mare, which is one of the best livings in the gift of the Bishop of Bath and Wells.

Clinton L. White, the attorney, wears upon his watch chain as a charm an English guinea coined in 1768. It is a well-preserved coin, having never been in circulation, and has quite a history. It is one of 15 guineas paid to a young man in Maryland by a British officer during the Revolutionary war in payment for a horse.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 19.--O.E. Frazer, Secretary of the New-York State Association of Glass Manufacturers, announces that the window glass manufacturers of the State will close their works for the season between June 1 and 15.

A daring burglary was perpetrated at the Long Island City Post Office early yesterday monring. An entrance was obtained by cutting out one of the panels of a rear door, which enabled the thieves to unlock it.

An interesting discovery of mastodon bones has been made in Liberty Township, Howard County, Ind., by Isaac Murphy, Trustee of the township, who measured the tusks, unearthed at a depth of three feet, and found them to be 9 feet long and 8 inches in diameter at the base.

DETROIT, Mich., May 19.--About 2,000 persons witnessed a comedy of errors to-day in which the honors were easy. The grounds were slippery and the temperature hovered close to the freezing point--conditions which were largely responsible for many of the errors made.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 19.--A carload of cotton goods consigned to Shanghai was started from this city to-day. The goods will go by rail to Vancouver, B.C., thence by steamer.

BERLIN, May 19.--For the first time since his critical relapse the Emperor has been seen to-day outside of the Schloss. Shortly after 5 o'clock the people assembled in front of the palace were gratified by the appearance of the Emperor and Empress in an open carriage.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 19.--A meeting of the incorporators of a new cotton manufacturing enterprise was held here to-day and a company was organized under the name of the Howland Mills Corporation.

President Engeman of the Brighton Beach Race Track intends to give a benefit day to the New-York Press Club building fund on the opening day, which will be about July 1. The feature of the day will be the race for the Mullins Cup, a free handicap for 3-year-olds and upward. The "cup" is the certified check for $500 of John Mullins, the Brooklyn furniture dealer, which was handed to Treasurer Battersby yesterday.

The McGlynn branch of the Anti-Poverty Society has now by the confession of its leader become a side show to the Blaine circus. He has been telling a reporter that the prospects of his "party" are very bright.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 19.--Yale, 7; Harvard, 1. That tells the story of the first championship game of the season played here to-day between the two old rivals. Fully 5,000 people were present to witness the contest.

The accused waived the reading of the complaint, pleaded guilty, and paid their fines.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 19.--The White Caps have broken out in Spencer County, of which Rockport is the capital. They came there recently from Crawford and Harrison Counties and have perpetrated numerous outrages during the past week.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 19.--Mrs. W.C. Duryea of Perry, whose husband has been missing since the night of May 10, to-day received the following dispatch from San Francisco: "Am coming back on next train." Duryea is an active business man, age about 35.

Wednesday will be an eventful day at West Brighton, Coney Island. The first annual parade of the Fire Department will be made in the afternoon, to be followed by a collation at the Casino and a ball in the evening.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., May 19.--Smith Hagan, a member of the Grand Army of the Republic and a pensioner, has abandoned his home in Spencer County in obedience to a command of the "White Caps." For alleged wife beating Hagan was taken by a "switch" committee to the woods a few nights ago, given 60 lashes on his bare back, and left gagged and tied to a tree.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 19.--Arrangements have been completed for the presentation of $10,000 to the Rev. Joseph H. Twichell, Pastor of the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in this city, on the occasion of his fiftieth birthday next week.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 4.--Next to the lumber and wool interests, the favorite hobby at present of the protective tariff maniacs in California is the raisinmaking industry. The duty on imported raisins is now 2 cents a pound. The Mills bill proposes to reduce that duty to 1 cents per pound.

The names of the principal singers engaged for next season at the Metropolitan Opera House have been made known to the public of this city. The announcements have created a sensation in musical circles, but not precisely the kind of sensation which was expected by lovers of great singing and grand opera.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 19.--In the Criminal Court to-day the Hon. Thomas E. Powell called up the case of Allen O. Myers for alleged complicity in the tally-sheet forgery, and asked a continuance of the case.

CHATTANOOGA, May 19.--J.M. Chandler shot Prof. Lawrence four times yesterday in the Congregational Church at Jellico, a remote East Tennessee village, wounding him fatally. Services were in progress in the church at the time. Chandler's children had been under Prof. Lawrence's tuition, and the trouble between the two men arose over the Professor's bill.

The Twelfth Regiment will attend service at St. Thomas's Church, Fifth-avenue and Fifty-thirdstreet, at 4 P.M. to-day. The annual sermon will be preached by the Regimental Chaplain, the Rev. William B. Frisby.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 19.--The past week has been a disastrous one for the canal boatmen. The freight rates are the lowest ever known in Buffalo. Instead of growing stronger, they are dull and near. Two and seven-eighths cents was the ruling quotation on wheat, 2 5/8 cents on corn, and 2 1/3 on oats to New-York. Some boats were able to secure a fraction better.

The thirteenth annual field meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association will be held next Saturday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at the Manhattan Athletic Grounds.

BOSTON, May 19.--Inspectors Dugan and Collins to-day arrested on indictment warrants Henry M. Cleaveland of Brooklyn, Conn., and Rufus H. Whitney of Boston, brokers, charged --the former in 25 counts, the latter in 15 counts--with embezzlement and larceny from Thomas H. Boardman of Newburyport.

CHICAGO, May 19.--A story was printed here this morning that Stuart Robson, the wellknown comedian, had taken advantage of a spare afternoon to go into court and take out naturalization papers. But Mr. Robson does not remember doing anything of the kind.

Staid, conservative medical journals of England are seriously discussing the evils of drinking tea, with particular reference to its effects upon the teeth of all who are addicted to this habit. It is charged that the excessive drinking of tea destroys the teeth and causes various diseases of the mouth.

PARIS, May 19.--The Chamber of Deputies is doing all it can to justify the accusations and maledictions of the Boulangists. The longer the members remain in permanent session the less work they seem to accomplish.
At Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon the members of the Campanini Operatic Concert Company sang for a large and enthusiastic audience. Signor Campanini himself was the star of the entertainment.

Joseph J. Little Co., the printers at 10 Astor-place, recovered a judgement of $2,382 10 against Charles L. Webster Co., the publishers of "The Personal Memoirs of U.S. Grant." The suit grew out of a contract which the defendants made with the plaintiffs to print the memoirs for them.

The Old Guard Veteran Battalion, under command of Major George W. McLean, will act as escort to President Cleveland during the observance of Memorial Day. On the non-commissioned staff Benjamin F. Moore, Jr., has been appointed Right General Guide and Morrison Hoyt Left General Guide.

Mr. Marsden's unhappy end was the main topic of conversation in theatrical circles yesterday, and hitherto concealed facts were made known which clearly proved that the playwright had determined on suicide at least a week ago.

BALTIMORE, May 20.--To-day and to-night the pulpits of all the Presbyterian churches in Baltimore were filled by members of the General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church, now in session here. They also preached in other churches, all of which were largely attended.

CHICAGO, May 20.--Thomas Barrett, a Pinkerton detective, 28 years old and a married man, died early this morning in his room at 188 Mather-street. A pistol bullet had entered his back, between the shoulders, causing a wound from which death quickly resulted.
The royal stand is not without its royal occupant. Her Majesty Natalie, Queen of Servia, who has been for some time in Florence, puts in an early appearance.

CHICAGO, May 20.--The Times last night received the second of its dispatches from the party which is trying to round up the last of the buffaloes on the great plains.
CHICAGO, May 20.--To the playgoers of this city the last week has been, perhaps, the most interesting of the whole season.

Harry Edwards, stage manager of Wallack's, is making preparations to visit with his wife his old home in England. Harry has not been "home" since he left it for Australia about 35 years ago, and he naturally expects to find many changes.
BERLIN, May 20.--During the first portion of last night the Emperor slept fairly well, but was afterward troubled with coughing.

Will Mr. BLAINE speak again before the assembling of the Chicago Convention? Probably not. Why should he? He is an experienced and astute politician. He knows how to let well enough alone. He knows and his friends know that he has the nomination within his grasp.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 20.--Mrs. Elizabeth Lewis, an aged woman, and her three grandchildren were smothered to death last night at the house of William Llewellyn, 38 Hoadly-street.

KEOKUK, Iowa, May 20.--The proportions which the mighty Mississippi has now assumed is a revelation to the oldest settler on its banks. For 100 miles south of this city the average width of the great stream is seven miles.

For three or four years the price paid for range cattle in the West has been falling without any corresponding reduction of the price of beef to consumers either in the East or in the Western cities where the cattle are slaughtered.
Before 10 o'clock Sunday morning Policeman Ward of the Twenty-seventh Precinct purchased 25 cents' worth of whisky in a grocery at 138 East Ninety-third-street.
BERLIN, May 20.--It is learned that the Emperor signed the decree ordering reprisals in return for obstacles put in the way of Germans entering France before Prince Bismarck started for Varzin.

At a crowded meeting of the Harvard Union last night a mock convention for the nomination of President of the United States was held. The first candidate presented was Robert T. Lincoln, who was enthusiastically applauded.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 20.--Five shots from a revolver yesterday morning aroused the people of Angelica. Allegany County, and when the cry of murder was raised the greatest excitement prevailed. The alarm was caused by Charles Gilbert killing his wife.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 20.--That a general disturbance of live stock rates will result from the recent action of the Burlington system in making its rates apply to all sized cars, regardless of length, is looked upon as a certainty.
ASHLAND, Wis., May 20.--At an early hour this morning "Billy" Andrews, proprietor of the Diamond Restaurant on Second-street, East, shot and instantly killed his wife in their apartments.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20.--Although surrounded by floods, to-day is the first real "dry" Sunday that St. Louis ever experienced.

LONDON, May 20.--Discount during the past week was quoted at 2 to 1 ; there was no demand. On the Stock Exchange business was inactive, but the tone was firm. Foreign securities were a fraction better, owing to the favorable reports regarding Emperor Frederick's condition.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--For a few days the fight in the House over the tariff will be suspended, and while the Republicans are endeavoring to reach a conclusion as to what they ought to do, or rather as to what they can do, the time of Congress will be devoted to some very necessary legislation.

SUMMIT, Miss., May 20.--A shooting affair occurred Wednesday night near this city, in which four men were wounded, one fatally. It grew out of bull-dozing negroes, which the best white people of the county are laboring to suppress.

PARIS, May 20.--After an exciting trial, the court rising at 5 A.M., Morand, the murderer, was sentenced to death. His victim was an old watchmaker named Vetard, of Joigny, who had been lured into a house by two women named Vacher and Martin. These women and another accomplice were sentenced to solitary confinement.

Mayor Grassman presided at a mass meeting last night in Odd Fellows' Hall, Hoboken, in favor of home rule for Ireland. The hall was packed and the platform was occupied by prominent citizens Mayor Orestes Cleveland of Jersey City made a speech and then he introduced Sir Thomas Esmonde, who made an eloquent appeal for home rule. Contributions amounting to $300 were raised.

BALTIMORE, May 20.--During a fight over a girl at Curtis Bay, a pleasure resort near this city, George Reilly, a carpenter, was shot and killed this afternoon. The parties concerned in the affair attempted to escape in a sailboat, but were captured by the harbor police. It is not known who fired the fatal shot.

With the return of fine weather work will now go forward rapidly on the new church building which Holy Trinity Church of Harlem is erecting at One Hundred and Twenty-secondstreet and Lenox (formerly Sixth) avenue.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 20.--Another case of smallpox was discovered to-day at 26 Everett-street by the Board of Health, the victim being the 6-year-old daughter of Timothy Driscoll, a railroad employe.

PARIS, May 20.--The race for the Prix de Diane for fillies was run to-day and was won by Solange, with Widgeon second, and Io third. There was a good start, Siberia, Nichette, Mandoline and Blue Silk leading, and Solange, Ara, Io, and La Grace following.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 20.--News reaches here from Junction City, the county seat of Kimble County, of the murder of J.T. Stroope, the chief freighter in that section. Stroope, with two of his teamsters, were followed six miles by two unknown persons.

The Rev. Dr. George R. Van De Water of St. Andrew's Church, Harlem, preached his farewell sermon as Chaplain of the Boooklyn Twenty-third Regiment yesterday afternoon in Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 20.--The canvass for State officers has closed. The Democratic State Convention meets here on May 31. The strength of the five candidates for Governer is pretty evenly divided, as indicated by the result of the primary elections and conventions which have so far been held.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 20.--The weather is cool and the skies have wept very often of late. The sun is rarely seen and many people begin to despair of ever seeing good weather again. Fogs also have been frequent. Of course this kind of weather has a depressing effect upon Newport's interests from a watering-place standpoint.

MARBLEHEAD NECK, Mass., May 20.--The report that the Nanepashemet Hotel at this resort was burned is incorrect. A small building belonging to the house was destroyed, but the hotel was not injured in the least.

Ten thousand people gathered along the northeastern shore of Staten Island yesterday and saw two things not to be seen every day. One was the landing of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show and the other the arrival there for the first time of an ocean passenger steamship.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 20.--One of the most memorable gatherings in this State for a long time was that of the Essex family at Hope, Bartholomew County, last week. Several hundred descendants took part in the affair.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 20.--Prior to the departure of the Canadian Pacific officials a tariff agreement with the Soo Company was completed, and has been forwarded to Montreal for approval.

CHICAGO, May 20.--Col. J.S. Clarkson of Iowa, Powell Clayton of Arkansas, and A. L. Conger of Ohio, a sub-committee of the National Republican Committee, are in Chicago to spend some time in arranging the details for the coming convention.

William O'Mara, 12 years old, of 287 Avenue A was run over at Avenue A and Eighteenth-street by a coach driven by Hugh Tumulty, aged 27 years, of 406 East Seventeenth-street, who is in the employ of Michael Smith of 243 East Twentieth-street.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 20.--A strike against the reduction in wages ordered at the National Tube Works, McKeesport, Penn., is probable. The workmen are required to give an answer to the company by Tuesday, and a large number seen to-night said they would not accept the reduction. A strike will affect nearly 4,000 men.

Bertha Kletzowski, a comely Jewess, was married April 17 by Alderman Martin to a man named Jacob Schaire. The couple took rooms in the tenement house 255 Broome-street, but Schaire left his wife the next week. She did not see her husband until last Friday, when he went to her with words of penitence.
BOSTON, May 20.--John L. Sullivan has purchased a one-third interest in John B. Doris's circus and will accompany the show on its Summer tour of the United States, starting about June 1.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 20.--J.R. Shye, Deputy Sheriff of Knox County, was shot and instantly killed this morning at Dunnevant's camp on the Powell Valley Railroad, 15 miles from this city, by Sam Hicks, a colored laborer, against whom he had two warrants, one forgrand larceny, the other for murder. A posse of 50 men are in pursuit of the murderer, and if he is caught a lynching will follow.

MARQUETTE, Mich., May 20.--The opinion generally obtains that a railroad deal of large proportions is imminent between the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic and the Canadian Pacific Railway, in which several foreign capitalists will be interested.

The will of Mary Holz, late of this city, was admitted to probate to-day by Surrogate Woods. It bequeaths to her husband, Herman, from whom she had not heard tidings for seven years, and who had deserted her many years previously, the sum of $5; all the rest and residue of her estate to her son William Roth, who is also named Executor. The will was made Sept. 22, 1884.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--John K. Miles, the manager of the Philadelphia office of the Shoe and Leather Reporter, at 404 Arch-street, is a fugitive from this city, and the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities is out $4,000 paid to him on a forged check.

BALTIMORE, May 20.--The Rev. Edward J. Sourin, Society of Jesus, one of the oldest and ablest priests of the Catholic Church, died this afternoon. He was born in Philadelphia Sept. 6, 1808, and was educated at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmettsburg, Md. Cardinal McCloskey was his schoolmate.

A large audience filled Cooper Union last evening at the meeting of the Anti-Poverty Society. Dr. McGlynn was on hand and with him were James Redpath and John McMackin. The latter attacked Henry George for backing out of the work which the United Labor Party expected of him.

Chang Yen Hoon, the Chinese Minister, with several secretaries, is here from Washington on several important official business matters. One of these is to meet his officers from the port of Havana, and the other is to visit Peru, South America, to which country the Minister is also accredited.

The Spring meeting of the Country Club Steeplechase Association of Pelham will occur on Monday, May 28, and Friday, June 1. Entries to all events on the first day, excepting the Pelham Handicap Steeplechase, will close at noon on Friday, May 25.

The Archduke Charles Louis, the brother of the Emperor of Austria, has been splendidly feted during his visit to Madrid. A banquet was given at the palace, followed by a reception, both being in every way worthy of the old reputation of the Court of Spain.

It had been frequently ridden by the deceased both on the Continent and in England. Mr. Sands hunted with it at Pau last season, and also had it with him in Paris for a month recently. Mrs. Sands is a niece of Mr. L. Morton, the American banker.

Mrs. Mary Walker, 48 years old, who lives in a tenement house at 27 Bridge-street, was found unconscious in the yard attached to the house late last evening and suffering from injuries which may prove fatal. It is believed that she was thrown out of a third-story window. Louis Barkman and a Mrs. Leo, who live in the same house, were arrested on suspicion.

The Wallack testimonial, to be given in the Metropolitan Opera House to-night, will bring together one of the most brilliant and distinguished audiences that ever gathered within the walls of a theatre in this or any other city. Mr. Booth's Hamlet has been witnessed by many notable assemblages, but never by ...

CHICAGO, Ill., May 20.--During the present week the attack of the Citizens' Association upon the Chicago Gas Trust will be begun in the Criminal Court, which has jurisdiction over quo warranto proceedings.
BERLIN, May 20.--It is rumored that the tariff on Russian goods imported into Germany is about to be raised 50 per cent.

In some quarters the truth of statements made regarding the prospective migration of Dr. Sketchley's ostrich flock from near Los Angeles to Tehama County has been questioned. Even the facts of the purchase of a large tract of land near Red Bluff did not bring conviction.

A company has been organized by philanthropic gentlemen for the purpose of carrying on in this city and Brooklyn pawnbroking establishments similar to those now conducted in France under Government auspices by the Mont de Piete.

The fine weather of yesterday tempted almost everybody out of doors. Central Park has rarely had a greater day. The trees of the Park never looked fairer, nor did its lawns ever appear greener. At 4 o'clock the Seventh Regiment Band began its concert with the "StarSpangled Banner."

Over 5,000 people witnessed the Brooklyn team whitewash the Kansas City Cowboys at Ridgewood Park yesterday afternoon. The fielding part of the contest was very sharp at times. Davis, the visitor's third baseman, played a very careless game.

William Shrady of 2,046 Madison-avenue had Edwin Clark of 266 West Fifty-thirdstreet arrested on a charge of larceny, and the accused was paroled in the Yorkville Court yesterday by Justice Murray for examination.
When an American undertook to make an extended criticism of the poets of Great Britain and Ireland there was some scoffing on the other side of the ocean.

The Whitsunday service yesterday morning at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, on Fifthavenue, was tinged with solemnity, and a deep regret for the loved Pastor of the church was clearly manifested by the entire congregation. Sombre drapings of black hung from the palpit and reading desk, and the choir stalls on ...

The old description of the Bourbons as men who never forget and never learn does not accurately apply to Republican leaders like Messrs. CHANDLER and HOAR, for the latter of these at least has managed to forget many generous impulses and broad views to which he gave recognition some years ago.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., May 20.--A monument has been erected by Major Bigelow and several other gentlemen on the spot where Gen. Hancock fell wounded during Pickett's charge. It is of granite, with a total height of 8 feet 6 inches, and bears on the front the inscription: "Major-Gen. Winfield Scott Hancock; Wounded July 3, 1863," and on the rear face, "Erected by Comrades and Friends."

Mayor Hewitt denied on Saturday afternoon that he had appointed anybody to succeed Charles H. Marshall as a Dock Commissioner. It was understood last evening, however, that he had appointed on Thursday or Friday last Capt. Edwin A. Post to that position. Mr. Post is 58 years of age and is a lawyer. He is not connected with either of the local Democratic organizations.

Yesterday being Pentecost, a feast which in the Catholic year ranks with Christmas and Easter, Archbishop Corrigan celebrated pontifical mass at the cathedral at 11 A.M., with the Rev. Michael J. Lavelle, the Rector, as assistant priest, the Revs. Thomas J. McCluskey and Joseph H. McMahon as ...
SOFIA, May 20.--The appeal of Major Popoff, who was convicted of complicity in frauds in the War Office, has been dismissed, but it is not expected that Prince Ferdinand will confirm his sentence.

Annual passes must be very convenient evidences and souvenirs of the public usefulness of railways. During the past session of Parliament some excellent jokes have been cracked on the subject by members who have been thus complimented.

It is said that a lively contest is on between Gen. William J. Sewell and Senator John W. Griggs for the Chairmanship of the New-Jersey delegation to the National Republican Convention. Gen. Sewell assumed, when the delegation was selected, that he would be the Chairman, and he was surprised to learn a few days ago that Mr. Griggs coveted the position.
CHICAGO, May 20.--There was a more confident feeling yesterday among the Chicago. Burlington and Quincy strikers than has existed for a month.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 20.--At Clinton last night Edward Ryder was fatally stabbed by Frederick Kittridge. Ryder was engaged to be married to Kittridge's sister, but the parents of the girl and her brother objected to the match. While visiting the girl on Saturday Ryder and the Kittridges got into a war of words, which resulted in the stabbing. Ryder is not expected ...

The Rev. J.W. Brooks the Pastor of the Stuyvesant-Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn, between whom and a portion of his congregation there has been some unpleasantness, culminating in a request that he should tender his resignation, conducted the services as usual yesterday to large congregations.

Ex-Mayor John Black was on 'Change to-day for the first time since his return from Europe, and was the centre of a group of a acquaintances most of the noon hour as he told of his travels in the Holy Land.

The Rev. Charles H. Parkhurst of the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church preached a rather remarkable sermon yesterday morning. The Nineteenth Century Club and the recent discussion there between Messrs. Coudert, Ingersoll, and Woodford came in for a pretty sharp rebuke, although the club was not alluded to by name.

Between 40 and 50 members of the Manhattan Fishing Club and invited guests assembled at the clubhouse at Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, yesterday afternoon to partake of the annual banquet with which the club always opens the fishing season. These annual dinners are always jolly affairs and they are always eaten by a crowd of jolly fellows.

A few years ago the Canadian shore of the Niagara River, along the greater part of that grand natural curve that affords the grandest view of the grandest scene on earth, had been almost robbed of its natural beauty by the settlers in the vicinity. Here was to be seen a grist mill, here a saw mill, here a most ...

There was somewhat of a row yesterday at the meeting of District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, and District Master Workman James E. Quinn, who is under suspension, summarily put an end to the meeting by walking off with the charter. His action was condemned by many as very hasty and foolish.

NEW-WINDSOR, Ill., May 19.--This village is the home of the Hon. A.J. Streeter, the nominee of the Cincinnati Union Labor Convention for the office of President of the United States. To-night has witnessed one of the most novel and interesting meetings ever seen in this country ...

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Monroe County, N.Y., has presented Mrs. Cleveland with an elegant Griffith Club microscope and accessories, in recognition of her temperance views.
The Methodist Episcopal General Conference held public service at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. At 3 o'clock, when the exercises began, the house was comfortably filled.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 20.--The many friends of Judge Gresham residing in Lafayette and surrounding country last night held a public reception in his honor at the Lahr House, which was largely attended and which was prolonged until a rather late hour.

The tournament now in progress at the Racquet Club is supplemental to that held there last May. The former was of unwonted interest because of its being the first serious attempt to define and determine the amateur billiard championship of this country. It had necessarily to fail of its full purpose.

There was a proud look on the face of Yan Phou Lee, a graduate of Yale, '87, who married Elizabeth Maud Jerome immediately after graduation last Summer, as he marched into the office of the New-Haven Register of ...
Racing will be continued at the Gravesend track to-day, and if the promise of fine weather holds those who visit the track will witness a good day's sport.

There stood before the bar in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday a good-looking West Indian. 20 years old, charged with abandoning his wife, Josephine, a pretty octoroon, two years his junior, and their infant child.

The schooner yacht Nirvana belonging to Gen. H.W. Perkins of this city recently returned from her annual cruise among the islands of the Bahama group in charge of her veteran Captain, Charles Kinner, of Port Jefferson, Long Island, who has for a number of years sailed the General's yachts at home and abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--Sunday baseball playing was began, or attempted to be, this afternoon at Gloucester. It was the first experiment of the kind in Philadelphia or vicinity and attracted not less than 40,000 people.

LONDON, May 20.--Six thousand persons assembled in Phoenix Park, Dublin, to-day, to take action on the resolutions adopted by the Irish Catholic members of Parliament with reference to the recent Papal rescript. There were no priests present. Lord Mayor Sexton presided, and Messrs. John Dillon, William O'Brien and other Parnellites made ...

I have been interviewing Boulanger; you would never guess about what. This morning I heard him violently attacked, not this time for riding the black horse, but for wearing a scalp and being a faux jeune homme. So I went to him to question. He said, "I give you leave to 'wig' me. Pull my hair." I did so. It was firm at the roots, and not even dyed.

CHICAGO, May 20.--The Western railroad muddle over live stock rates shows no signs of coming to an end. The action of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy in making its lowest tariff rate apply to all cars, irrespective of length or capacity, has already been met by some of the other roads, and the war may be said to have begun in earnest.

The congregation of the Third Order of St. Francis held a meeting last evening at 130 West Thirty-seventh-street, and elected under the society's old constitution a Board of Trustees. Sister Winifred Brophy presided, and the voting resulted in the election of Winifred Brophy, Margaret Kelley, Sarah Flanagan, Rose McDermott, Catherine Hernon, and Ann McDonnough. The congregation will meet again next Sunday to elect the same board under the new constitution.

HALLIDAYSBURG, Penn., May 20.--That animal instinct is lively in the bird was exemplified by the robin a few days ago. On one of the beautiful sugar maple trees which grow in the yard of a well-known citizen of this place a mother robin had built her nest, and as time went on she was rewarded by a brood of young robins.
On the 15th day of last November Mike Freismuth, the pigeon fancier of this city, sent to Charleston, this State, by Mr. Emsheimer, a pair of his famous carrier pigeons, an old one and a young one.
PHILADELPHIA, MAY 21.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly this morning the following telegram was received from the Presbyterian General Assembly at Baltimore:

Gov. Hill last Sauturday signed a bill creating the Sinking Fund Commissioners, the Register, the Surrogate, and the County Clerk a commission to secure a site for and erect a new municipal building for the accommodation of the departments of Register, Surrogate, and County Clerk.

CHICAGO, May 21.--Lillie Richmond, a woman 30 years old, dressed herself in male attire to-day, put on a fales mustache, took a pistol, and started out on a hunt for Thomas Bollander, a real estate agent.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 14.--The Department of Public Works has entered into a contract with Col. Edward MacMurdo, represented by Lord Archibald Gosford, for the rebuilding of 108 kilometers of the Tehuantepec National Railway, the construction of some 226 kilometers ...

With the exception of the building in which Angusta Sohlke opened a dancing school, to give it up a few weeks ago, there is nothing modern on the east side of Third-avenue, between Thirty-third and Thirty-fourth streets.
QUINCY, Ill., May 21.--While it has been generally believed that no loss of life was caused by the great flood in this locality, reports received to-day give particulars of several fatalities.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., MAY 21.--A rule to show cause was obtained to-day to show why a mandamus should not be issued to compel the Sewarage Commissioners to turn over their books to the Commissioners of Tax Adjustment.

PITTSBURG, May 21.--Peter J. Quinn, chief bookkeeper for Chris G. Dixon Co., large contractors and builders, has been missing for several days, and it is supposed that he has gone to Canada. An examination of his accounts shows a shortage of $15,000.

District Attorney Fellows notified John D. Townsend, counsel for Ann O'Delia Diss Debar, yesterday, afternoon that the indictment for grand larceny against the spock agent and Gen. Diss Debar would be shelved for the present.

Jose del Valle, aged 15, the only son of Jose Antonio del Valle, a well-known merchant of this city, residing in Orange, died yesterday morning from the effects of severe burns contracted last Saturday night.

The members of the Produce Exchange held a meeting in the call room of the Exchange at noon yesterday in response to a call signed by President A.E. Orr to take action in regard to the McEvoy bill regulating elevator charges.
E.A. Gardner, whose name came before the public of this country several months ago on account of his arrest as an opium smuggler at Ogdensburg, N.Y., has returned to his home in Seattle.
Pfingst Montag, Whit Monday, was generally celebrated by the Germans of this city and vicinity by picnics and outdoor amusements.
CITY OF MEXICO, May 14.--The Pabellon National newspaper has been exposing the illtreatment to which agricultural laborers on haciendas in remote parts of the country are subjected.
CHICAGO, May 21.--The vestibule train case occupied the attention of Judges Gresham and Blodgett in the United States Circuit Court to-day, on a motion to modify the injunction restraining ...

The project of uniting the Sea of Azov with the Blank Sea is about to receive a practical solution. It is understood that a company, working with a French capital to the extent of 85,000,000f., is only waiting for the sanction of the Russian Government to commence operations.
CHICAGO, May 21.--A large brick barn near the corner of Jefferson and Monroe streets, occupied by A.M. Forbes as a livery and boarding stable, was partially burned this morning at 2:30 o'clock.

Owing to a hitch in the manifest and clearance papers Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show was delayed in unloading the cargo from the Persian Monarch at Stapleton, Staten Island, until almost noon yesterday.

A fine portrait of Washington by Gilbert Stuart has been bought and presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is a most excellent specimen of Stuart's pencil, is in perfect condition, and has an interesting history.
In January, 1886, Annie W. Barnes began an action in the City Court against Lester Wallack and Charles Frohman to recover $310, claiming that she was wrongfully discharged by the two gentlemen named.

The following circulars, addressed to the stockholders of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company, were issued yesterday. It is the outcome of the movement which has been on foot for some time to make Henry Villard President of the company:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21.--To-night the Irishmen of the city tendered a reception to Sir Thomas Esmonde, at which he delivered a lecture. Gov. Green presided. Ex-Gov. Abbett, Senator McPherson, and Mayor Cleveland of Jersey City were among the other speakers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 21.--It is now definitely known that on June 1 all the roads centering here will meet the Burlington by accepting as their share of through rates 31, 22, 23, 17, 11, and 9 cents on the respective classes in the official classification, and that at the same time all these roads will unite in making local rates, Chicago to Minneapolis ...
WASHINGTON, May 21.--Acting Secretary Thompson to-day received offers for the sale of bonds to the Government as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$100 at 127.

BOSTON, May 21.--A strange discovery was made upon the locomotive Phaeton of the Lowell system, Boston and Maine Railroad, recently, by the engineer. A nest of rats was found under the footboard of the cab.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--Conferences and conversations between Domocratic and Republican leaders in the House of Representatives during the last 24 hours have served to weaken the hope of members who want to see a direct vote quickly reached on the Tariff bill.
Almost without exception the Republican members of the House who have made speeches during the recent tariff debate have said something about Trusts and other trade combinations.
The newly-elected Sachems of the Tammany Society met last evening and appointed committees to make preparations for the Fourth of July celebration in Tammany Hall.

ST. LOUIS, May 21.--The Missouri Supreme Court to-day received the mandate of the United States Supreme Court in the case of Hugh M. Brooks, alias Maxwell, the Englishman convicted of the sensational Southern Hotel murder. The State Supreme Court adjourned without fixing the date of execution.

The hearing in regard to the petition suit to dissolve the corporation of the Third Order of St. Francis was resumed again yesterday before Referee Burrill at the Mills Building. For some weeks the case has been hanging upon the decision of Referee Burrill as to whether he would allow the motion made by T.G. Barry, the counsel for the defense, to dismiss the petition or not.

The Commissioners of Accounts still further postponed their examination of Maurice B. Flynn yesterday, he having signified his willingness to appear and testify to his knowledge of Chamberlain W.M. Irvin's method of keeping the city's accounts to-day.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 21.--Additional indictments have been found against Wiltsie Pollock bankers, charged with grand larceny and they were arraigned at Goshen to-day and their trial was set down for September next.
Daniel E. Finn, whom the respectable voters in the First Assembly District are obliged to say is their Representative in the Assembly of this State, has been admitted to the Bar.

Porte V. Ransom, law assistant of the Surrogate, continued taking testimony in the Goodall will contest yesterday. The suit is brought by Mrs. Emma Goodall to revoke the probate of the will of her husband. Aldert G. Goodall, who died a year ago.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 21.--John Silver Co., wholesale and retail dry goods, have suspended. Liabilities, $65,000. English houses are the principal creditors.
Secretary Theodore Moss of the Board of Electrical Control has written a letter to the Mayor, Corporation Counsel Beekman, District Attorney Fellows, the Police Commissioners, and ...

FORT WORTH, Texas, May 21.--Every train that has arrived in this city during the last 48 hours has brought delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which meets here tomorrow to send delegates to the National Democratic Convention and to nominate Presidential Electors.

The petition of 100 property owners along the line of Deacon Richardson's AtlanticAvenue Railroad that his right to operate the road be declared forfeited on the ground that his charter had lapsed bore fruit yesterday in the presentation of an affirmative opinion by the Railroad Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen.

The Young Men's Democratic Club met last evening in parlor E of the Hoffman House. Lyttleton T. Garrettson presided. The widow of William Dorsheimer thanked the club for the resolutions passed on the character of the deceased.
There was quite a break in wheat yesterday and consequently considerable excitement on the Produce Exchange. The selling was very free, and the market closed with a decline of from 2 1/8 to 2 cents.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 21.--Sight drafts, 15 cents telegraphic, 20 cents.

LOUISVILLE, May 21.--The racing to-day was not very interesting. Orderly, in the last race, was the only decided favorite who won. Pat Donovan won the first race at one mile, Lepanto second, and Orange Girl third. Time-- 1:44 .

Mrs. Elizabeth Greenleaf, as Executrix of the late Charles H. Greenleaf, and James H. Butler began suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, to eject the Brighton Beach Hotel from its present location on the ground that a portion of the site of the hotel, a tract of land 66 feet wide and extending from the ocean back to the horse railroad belonged to them.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--Mrs. Henry D. Gregory, wife of the Vice-President of Girard College and a prominent leader in Presbyterian Church circles, died suddenly in the Calvary Presbyterian Church, at Fifteenth and Looust streets, to-day during the meeting of the Women's Foreign Missionary Society.

To-day's session of the Methodist General Conference will be more interesting than any since the opening. The great event of the entire session, notwithstanding all the important legislation that has been enacted, is the election of Bishops and other officers of the great religious organization.
It is now stated that Sir Charles Tupper has secured from Sir John Macdonald a promise that Mr. C.H. Tupper, member for Pictou and son of Sir Charles, will be appointed to the position ...

The second day's races of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association will be run this afternoon at Cedarhurst. They include the Galloway Race, for ponies, at about a mile on the flat, with 4 entries; an Open Handicap Race, at about ...
BALTIMORE, May 21.--Fielder Carr, aged 68, shot himself yesterday afternoon about four miles from Cockeysville, Baltimore County.
The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Leadville Consolidated Mining Company was held at the office of the company in the Washington Building yesterday.

A cable dispatch from London announcing that the Savage Club was indignant and surprised because of the refusal of the Lotos Club in this city to longer continue the exchange of courtesies that have heretofore been extended to members of each club visiting the two cities has raised a smile upon the countenances of the Lotos people and started a new discussion upon the matter.

The following is the official list of entries for the Decoration Day regatta, held under the auspices of the Harlem River Regatta Association, excepting those of college crews, who may enter any time this week:
PITTSBURG, May 21.--The iron manufacturers of the Mahoning Valley have formed a combination to advance their mutual interests.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--On Friday last, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Thompson accepted an offer of $5,000,000 of four and a half per cent. registered bonds at 108. The offer came from Philadelphia and purported to be from a prominent financial firm in that city whose name is not given out.

The natural vision of S.W. Burnham, the Chicagoan who is about to take charge of the great Lick telescope, is paid to be equal to that secured by an ordinary pair of human eyes aided by a 6-inch telescope.
James William Richardson, (23,) under sentence of death at Leeds for the willful murder of William Berridge, his foreman, at Barnsley, has addressed the following letter to his wife:

GLOUCESTER, May 21.--Vessels arriving at this port complain that it is difficult to make the harbor during foggy weather, owing to the whistling buoy off Eastern Point, which designates the entrance to the harbor, having its trumpet muffled with cloth so that no sound can be heard. It is not known whether the Government ordered it muffled or not.

Another chapter was added yesterday to the eventful career of Mrs. Lillian E. Scofield. Two lawyers, Nathaniel Ellis and Jacob Marks, representing a Union-square firm who had her for a customer in 1885, sat in Judge McAdam's City Court room yesterday morning awaiting the advent of Mrs. Scofield.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 21.--Scup are still growing scarce, while the supply of sea bass increases. Less than 40 barrels of scup were caught to-day. Church Brothers of Tiverton towed 200 barrels to pound, and out of this picked jsut two barrels of scup.

John W. Schutte, a driver in the employ of Beadleston Woerz, brewers, and Bernard Schmitz and William Kingott, drivers in the employ of the Continental Brewery, were delivering beer at lager beer saloons at different sides of Greenwich-avenue yesterday afternoon.

Senator Morrill of Vermont, to whom was due the appropriation for the new National Library Building, has in view another equally laudable enterprise. He now wants Congress to provide suitable quarters for the Supreme Court.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--Sir Charles Tupper, Minister of Finance, will sail from New-York Saturday next for England to resume his duties as High Commissioner for Canada. He will be absent until next session of Parliament.

PICTOU, Ontario, May 21.--The schooner William Elgin sprung a leak on Saturday afternoon 16 miles from Oswege and sank. She was loaded with 3,000 tons of coal from Oswego consigned to Belle ville. The crew were picked up by the schooner Ocean Wave and landed at Indian Point yesterday morning.
VIENNA, May 21.--The fire at Jenbach, in the forest of Innsbruck, has been subdued.
A court-martial will convene at the Brooklyn Navy Yard in a few days to try Capt. Thomas O. Selfridge, the former commander of the war ship Omaha.
WASHINGTON, Conn., May 21.--Sussman Rothchild, a Hebrew millionaire of San Francisco, came to this city to-day to give his brother Joseph a surprise in the shape of a visit.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 21.--The following candidates have successfully passed the examination for admission to the Naval Academy as cadets: J.G. Sawyer,...

BALTIMORE, May 21.--The largest and finest hospital in the world has been completed here after ten years of continuous work. It will be opened with formal ceremonies next Autumn. It bears the name of Johns Hopkins' which has been so widely familiarized in both hemispheres by the university which he founded and which is said to be better known in Europe for original works in science and education than any other American institution.

AUGUSTA, Me., May 21.--The Democratic State Convention meets in this city to-morrow at 11 o'clock. A large delegation of representative men of the party are already on the ground, and the hotels are all full to overflowing.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21.--After a wild race through the country Sam Peterson, a Swede, was captured near Monmouth Junction yesterday. On Saturday Peterson, walking with two crutches like a lame man, appeared at the farm of Freeholder Barelay and spoke to that man as he was plowing in the field.
The crowd which jammed itself into the passageways leading from the main floor of the auditorium was in the main a goodnatured one.

The cattle trust investigation provided for in Senator Vest's resolution adopted by the Senate Wednesday will clear up a matter that is involved in a good deal of mystery--the depression if prices of Western cattle in the last few years without any corresponding reduction in the price of beef in the retail markets.
The Summer excursion season is near at hand. In less than a month it will be in full swing, and the indications are that more business in this line will be done this season than ever before.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 14.--Gov. Canedo of Sinaloa, in a recent visit to the Socialistic colonists near Topolobambo Bay, found the fewremaining settlers industrious and well-behaved people who are perservering in their attempt to found permanent settlements.
For a few weeks past the Republicans who do not wish Mr. BLAINE as a candidate have been pointing out his weakness as a candidate and protesting that he could not be elected.
BERLIN, May 21.--The Emperor passed a satisfactory night. He appeared twice at a window of the castle this morning. He was dressed in uniform.

DETROIT, May 21.--By clever batting at opportune moments the New-Yorks managed to secure a victory here to-day. It was a hotlycontested game, however, the Giants winning by tha smallest possible margin--one run.
The Baptist Pastors met yesterday at their usual Monday morning conference, on Murraystreet, with somewhat diminished numbers, as many of them had gone off on the Washington excursion.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 21.--Montgomery's young Democracy, the Muscogee Club, has come to stay as an influence in politics, and at its last meeting, on Thursday night, the members decided on an attempt to widen their sphere of action.

"Snapper" Garrison and Fitzpatrick were reinstated at the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday, and the former won a splendid race upon his horse Cyclops, with 131 pounds up, in the opening dash of five furlongs.

The long-existing trouble between actor George Herbert Leonard and Abraham R. Erlanger, the dramatic agent, growing out of the disagreements between Leonard and his wife, Louise Balfe, an actresss, was brought to the surface again yesterday after it had lain dormant for several months.

LONDON, May 21.--In reply to an address by 1,200 Quakers in favor of home rule to-day Mr. Gladstone said it would have been difficult to persuade him that any large number of Friends could be so little in harmony with the noble social traditions of their body as to approve a coercive policy toward Ireland. He received the address with pleasure as definite evidence of the Friends' sentiments.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 21.--Mrs. William Boice, while driving with her husband yesterday afternoon near the city, was thrown out by a collision with another carriage driven by J. H. Batt and W.H. Johnson of this city, and received serious injuries.

Mr. Frederick Warde has closed his season and disbanded his company. His manager next Winter will be Mr. Joseph Brooks. An entirely new company will support Mr. Warde, and the new season will begin early in the Fall at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre, when Mr. Warde will try ...
ALBANY, May 21.--Gov. Hill added nine chapters to the session laws to-day by signing these bills:
The proposed retirement of the Hon. John D. Long from public life is viewed with regret by thousands of citizens regardless of political bias.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21.--A heavy sentence has been imposed on Simon Hamburg for swindling a man out of $10,000. Last November Hamburg and an accomplice sold to a man named Parker, an Oregon farmer, certain real estate in this city to which they had no title.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, May 21.--An important meeting of the stockholders of the Ohio Southern Railroad was held here this afternoon.

Detective Smith of the Elizabeth-street station was passing through Mulberry-street about 7:30 o'clock Sunday night, when a slip of paper was handed him by a short, stout man, who at once disappeared. On the paper was written:
The Sixty-ninth Regiment had a gala time last evening and 247 soldiers are now proudly wearing sharpshooters' badges on their breasts.
Thomas B. Kerr has placed in the custody of the Sheriff at the close of yesterday's proceedings in his trial for bribery and slept at his house last night in charge of Under Sheriff Sexton.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 21.--Friends of August Edson, a Swede, say he was killed by a "two-for" cigar. Saturday night he "set up" the cigars to a friend. Both smoked, and on the way home Edson was taken sick. His friend also felt squeamish. About midnight Edson was found dead in his bed.

CHICAGO, May 21.--The sub-committee of the Republican National Committee learned today from the auditorium managers some interesting facts about the seating capacity of the hall in which the convention will be held.

Lieut. Percy P. May of the Eleventh Regiment, National Guard, who had a narrow escape last December from being annihilated by an infernal machine alleged to have been sent him by some unknown enemy, yesterday claimed to have cleared away some of the mystery in which the affair has since been shrouded.
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--On the vote for the expenses of the Fisheries Commission in Parliament to-day Mr. Mitchell said that if, in the excitement of political turmoil, the United ...

When the Kings County Board of Supervisors on May 10 rejected all bids for making repairs to the county jail it was publicly charged that the action was caused by the fact that J.E. Greaney, a contractor who gets all the nice plums from the Supervisors, had been underbid by H.D. Southard, a man who never "divides" with committees.

According to a report from the British Minister at Washington, which has just been laid before Parliament, since the beginning of 1887 there have been 1,000 strikes in the United States, and of the 400,000 men engaged in them 25,000 to 50,000 are still out.
Considerable interest has been attached lately to the movements of the old schooner yacht Rambler. Some time ago the Rambler was sold. No one seemed to know who had bought her.
A very interesting conflict is in progress in Chicago, which promises to test with accuracy the comparative political strength of decency and indecency in that city.

BOSTON, May 21.--Boston burglars, evidently professionals, paid a flying visit to Waltham this morning and came away with $3,000 worth of booty. They visited the Summer residence of Augustus Flagg, on the corner of Forest and North streets.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21.--In the pretty village of Cazenovia, 18 miles from here, Mary Ann Smith, the wife of Jacob Vanderbilt, Jr., was born and brought up. She was born in a story and a half white cottage in the outskirts of the village, and on the banks of Chittenango Creek.
ALBANY, May 21.--Bishop Doane has decided to dedicate the new Cathedral of All Saints on All Saints' Day, in September. The plans call for a structure to cost $500,000.
The tribute to Lester Wallack has been paid. The distinguished actor and manager knows now, if he never knew before, that the people of New-York hold him high in their esteem.
COLLINGWOOD, Ontario, May 21.--The steamer Atlantic yesterday, near Killarney, picked up two men lashed to their boat, dead. They are supposed to be fishermen. The weather is cold and stormy.

About 10:30 o'clock last evening a little shower of sparks fell on the one-story building adjoining the Bijou Opera House from a chimney in the building on the northwest corner of Thirtieth-street and Broadway.

The earnings of the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railway Company for the second week in May were $33,570 48. Last year for the corresponding period they were $42,111 44, and the decrease is $8,540 96.

The Board of Officers of the Ninth Regiment held a meeting last evening for the purpose of making arrangements to entertain the Richmond Grays of Richmond, Va., during their visit to this city on Decoration Day.

Snakes seem to be getting very popular in Wall-street. At high noon yesterday one appeared right in front of the rostrum on the floor of the Stock Exchange.

RED BANK, N.J., May 21.--The people of Red Bank seem to have more trouble in the management of their municipal affairs than those of any other town in the State.
WHEELING, West Va., May 21.--A most peculiar and deplorable accident occurred at a point on Fishing Creek, eight miles back of New-Martinsville, Wetzell County, yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., May 21.--The Mayor this afternoon nominated E.G. Walker, the well-known colored lawyer, as a Principal Assessor to fill a vacancy. This is the first time a colored man has been nominated for such a position in this city.

At Mount Tabor a few days ago an effort was made to secure more spacious and suitable grounds for school purposes. A gentleman offered to give two acres of ground in a desirable location for the present school lot and $1,000.
BOSTON, May 21.--To-morrow the various Republican clubs recently formed throughout the State will meet at Tremont Temple and form a State League.
RED BANK, N.J., May 21.--For several years past William Applegate, one of the foremost Republicans in Monmouth County, has been the Postmaster of Red Bank.

Claus Spreckels and a number of friends on Saturday visited the site of the proposed sugar refinery. The sheds and other obstacles were being removed and the ground being made clear for operations to be commenced to-day.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 21.--It is evident that there is to be an unusually interesting contest in the Southern Assembly of the Presbyterian Church over the famous Woodrow case.

SKOWHEGAN, Me., May 21.--John P. Webster of Norridgewock, the oldest attorney in Somerset County, was killed by a fall from a railroad bridge in South Norridgewock Village this morning. He was crossing the bridge, not seeing an approaching train until it was close upon him. He got across the bridge, but being feeble, was either struck by the train or fell over an embankment, striking his head on a rock.
LONDON, May 21.--The National Line steamship Denmark, Capt. Rigby, from New-York May 5 for London, arr. off the Lizard at 6 P.M. yesterday.

At the former hearing on Wednesday last Herbert Anstey, Judge Hilton's private secretary for a dozen years, testified that last November Judge Hilton loaned him $5,000 on a promissory demand note.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., May 21.--This afternoon Charles Blauvel of this city and John Blauvel of Brooklyn, brothers, while fishing in Staten IsIand Sound were run down by a tug. Their boat was capsized and John was drowned.

The most interesting race at Gravesend to-day will be the Brooklyn Derby, for which five of the crack 3-year-olds are entered. If the track is in even as good condition as it was yesterday this ought to be the greatest race of the meeting.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 21.--The one hundred and forty-first Annual Convention of the Evangelical Lutheran Ministerium of Pennsylvania and adjacent States will be held in Trinity Church, this city, beginning on Thursday. This will be the twelfth meeting of this body here within the present century.

A 6-year-old boy named J. Howland Dalton of 50 Marion-street, was run over by engine No. 20, in front of the engine house yesterday afternoon, and was instantly killed. The front wheels of the engine passed over his chest, crushing in his ribs. The boy was playing in front of the engine house at the time.

ALBANY, May 21.--At the request of the Knights of Labor a committee of Typographical Union No. 4 have acted as mediators between the non-union ale and porter brewers and the Knights, looking to the adjustment of the existing difficulties.
DETROIT, Mich., May 21.--The plan of tunneling the Detroit River at this point, which has been talked of spasmodically for a long time past, is again in active agitation.

The Republican Club of the city of NewYork held last night the first meeting in its new clubhouse, 450 Fifth-avenue. Edward T. Bartlett, the President, congratulated the members upon the comfort and elegance of their new home.

VERA CRUZ, via Galveston, Texas, May 21.-- Congress to-day approved of the loan negotiated in Berlin after hearing the report of Senor Fuentes Munoz, Chairman of the Committee on Finances. The vote was unanimous.
BOSTON, May 21.--The reports concerning the health of Mr. William Seymour, who has just closed his engagement as stage manager at the Boston Museum, are somewhat exaggerated.

The inquest in the case of Thomas Murray, who was recently killed at 616 Broadway by an electric shock while in the discharge of his duties as a lineman of the Brush Illuminating Company, was continued yesterday before Coroner Levy.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, May 21.--Citizen Train took a last look at Canadian soil last night, when he took a train for Boston. He expects to be in Madison-square, New-York, on Tuesday, after a six-months expatriation.
The Trustees of Columbia College are contemplating improvements in the college premises that will entirely change its appearance and also remove several of the old landmarks of the institution.

CHICAGO, May 21.--The meeting of the American Tariff Reform League in Farwell Hall to-night was a success. The speakers were forcible, their arguments were well received, and the audience filled the hall. Franklin McVeagh, who opened with the President's address, said that in the coming campaign he was glad to say all would have an issue worthy of the politics of a dignified nation.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 14.--A contract has been entered into between the Board of Direction of the Drainage of the Valley of Mexico and Mr. J. Gladwyn Jebb, representing the London-Mexican Prospecting and Finance Company, Limited, for the execution of the work known as the Tequixquiac Tunnel.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 21.--"There will be no half-way business about the treatment of the tariff question by the Pennsylvania Democratic Convention," said Mr. W. L. Scott to-day. "The convention will indorse the President and his Administration, and it will also support the Mills Tariff bill in plain language."

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 21.--This morning there died at the Sherman Stock Farm in this city one of the best-bred sons of George Wilkes. Hector Wilkes, first dam Carrie Clinch, by Harold, second dam Pearlie Leonard, by American Clay. He was a beautiful bay, 5 years old, and although untried as a stallion, $15,000 had been refused for him.

The Board of Aldermen at its meeting today is expected to act upon the question of allowing the use of electricity as a motive power on the cars of the Fourth-Avenue Railroad, and it is said that a majority of the members are opposed to it.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The opening night of the second week of "The Black Hussar" by the McCaull Opera Company, at Albaugh's Grand Opera House, attracted a crowded house, such as always greets this opera, of which the Washington public never seems to tire.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--It is announced at the Navy Department that the detail of the courtmartial for the trial of Capt. Selfridge upon charges based upon the killing of several Japanese subjects by an unexploded shell from the Omaha will be made out within a few days.

CHICAGO, May 21.--The fight between the conservatives and radicals among the Turners cropped out again to-day when a resolution was introduced in the national convention of the order indorsing the course of the society's organ published at Milwaukee.

The New-York Retail Grocers' Union and a number of produce commission dealers met at the Mercantile Exchange yesterday to discuss the proposod market ordinance regulating the standard for the sale of farm produce, which goes into effect Sept. 1. Funeral services over the remains of Fred Marsden, the playwright, were held afternoon at the family residence, 318 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 22.--Carriages con taining a wedding party on their way to a preach er's house at Plymouth this evening ran over and killed a little girl. The whole party were arrested, and the wedding did not take place.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 22.--Both houses of the General Assembly at Baton Rouge to-day elected the Hon. Randall L. Gibson as United States Senator to succeed himself. NASHVILLE,Tenn., May 22.--The second day of the Inter-State Military Encampment was a great success. At 10:30 the soliders, headed by the Louisville Legion and followed by the differ ent infantry and artillery companies began their march through the densely-lined streets.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22.--The academic year at the United States Military Academy is approaching its termination, and the cadets are "brushing up" for the annual examinations. These will commence on Friday, June 1, and continue daily until finished, probably on the 10th.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The eighth session of the Jewish Ministers' Association began here to day. The association was called to order by the President, the Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil of New York.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22.--The licensed liquor dealers of this city have decided to contest the local option high license law, and they will carry the matter to the courts, issuing invitations to the saloon keepers of other cities to join in the movement. It is claimed that the law can be overthrown on the same plea that caused the defeat of the Michigan law.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 22.--The Prohibition State Convention assembled in Young Men's Christian Association Hall, this city, at 8:30 o'clock this evening. The gathering was composed of 40 voluntary or self-appointed delegates representing 13 counties of the 34 in the State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 22.--John Dunlap, a millionaire manufacturer, operating one of the most extensive tin concerns in the United States, and identified with many leading industrial institutions here, has prepared an open letter in which he indorses President Cleveland and the Mills bill.

LEXINGTON, May 22.--J.H. Sherman, proprietor of the Sherman stock farm of this city, has lost, by pneumonia, the 5-year-old bay stallion Hector Wilkes, by George Wilkes, dam Carrie Clinch, by Harold, second dam by American Clay.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 22.--The schooner Gladstone, from Halifax for Jamaica, is reported wrecked at Caicos Passage. The vessel is insured in a city office for $50,000, and the cargo in the Boston Marine for $6,600.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--An explosion occurred this morning in the basement of S.H. Hackett's chair and table manufactory, 232 South Second-street, and a few minutes later the interior of the basement and first floor was a mass of flames.

DETROIT, May 22.--The New-Yorks have at last struck a winning gait. The poor luck that has attended their efforts on the present Western trip has disappeared and they scored their second successive victory over the world's champions to-day.
BERLIN, May 22.--The Prince of Wales was met on his arrival here by the Crown Prince, Prince Henry, the Duke of SaxeMeinigen, Dr. Mackanzie, and the Governor of Berlin.

DETROIT, Mich., May 22.--At 10 o'clock this morning Assignee Thurber began opening the sealed bids for the stock, fixtures, lease accounts, , of Metcalf Brothers Co., the retail dry goods dealers of this city who recently failed.
The Police Commissioners yesterday considered a proposed increase in the election districts, chiefly is the upper Assembly districts, made necessary by the increased population.
LOWELL, Mass., May 22.--The Hamilton Com pany Directors have voted to suspend operations at the print works for four weeks, commencing June 1.
LONDON, May 23.--The White Star Line steamship Republic, Capt. Davison, from New-York May 13, arr. at Queenstown at 1 A.M. to-day, on her way to Liverpool.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22.--The Supreme Court to-day rendered a decision allowing Allen O. Myers to fi1e a petition in error to the decision of the Common Pleas Court for contempt and suspending the sentence imposed until the case had been argued.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 22.--The Grand Jury has found a fresh indictment against Dixon R. Cowie and Thomas B. McQuaid for the murder of Lilla Hoyle.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 22.--A notice has been posted at the Wayne Iron and Steel Works that a reduction in wages of 10 per cent. will be made when the mill resumes.

EASTPORT, Long Island, May 22.--The fire which started in the woods three miles east from here yesterday burned over several hundred acres of woodland. It was extinguished this afternoon. A schoolhouse and several farm buildings were saved by the farmers.

PARIS, May 22.--Inspection dues on the carcasses of cattle and sheep have been fixed at 1f. per 100 kilos.

TAUNTON, Mass., May 22.--The Post Office at Attleborough was entered by burglars this morning and about $1,200 in stamps was taken. Entrance was effected through a window by four men. The handle was knocked out of the safe and a hole was drilled aroung the lock. A man and his wife, who lived in an adjoining block, saw the burglars, but were so frightened that they dared not give the alarm.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22.--Eugene Chal fant, a laborer in the glass works at New Albany, died there this morning of hydrophobia. He was bitten some weeks ago by a small Spitz dog, but as the wound healed he paid no atten tion to it.

BOSTON, May 22.--As foreshadowed in these dispatches last night, the gathering of the various Republican clubs into a State League to-day did not come up in point of attendance of delegates or in enthusiasm displayed to the hopes of the leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--The Steamer Monmouth, built for the Central Railroad of NewJersey, was successfully launched at Cramp's ship yard this morning. The steamer is 250 feet long, with 35 feet breadth of beam, and a mean draught of 10 feet. She is provided with vertical, triple expansion, twin screw engines. The steamer will make 17 knots an hour.

DANBURY, Conn., May 22.--The Tweedy Manufacturing Company's hat shops, employing over 1,100 hands, which closed on April 28, are again running. The company has been reorganized, and a system of cut prices adopted. Other shops are reopening.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 22.--Two boys, Howard Gaskill, aged 12 years, and John Williams, aged 15 years, the former a son of a prominent attorney, and the latter of a policeman, were on a truant ex pedition down the canal. While attempting to jump from a raft to a passing canalboat on the canal, a mile below the city, they fell into the water and were drowned. The bodies were recovered and taken home.
