AUGUSTA, Me., May 22.--The Democratic State Convention, held here to-day, was a success that lacked no element of completeness. It was the largest and most enthnsiastic gathering of representative men of the party ever witnessed in Maine. Nearly every town was fully represented, the whole number of delegates being 1,007. Granite Hall, floor and galleries, was packed.
The suicide of Herr Stephen von Kegel, a well-known millionaire and man of fashion, and one of the handsomest men in the empire, has created an immense sensation at Vienna.

The Jersey City Board of Aldermen last night re-elected Joseph Warren a Finance Commissioner. His present term does not expire until April. It was said in explanation of his election at this this time that he was sick and wanted to make a trip through Europe. James C. Clarke, a dentist, was elected Inspector of Buildings.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 22.--Not a street car has movod in this city to-day. The drivers, 300 in all, remain firm and are evidently determined to hold out. The Board of Arbitration met at noon to-day and held an afternoon and evening session.

CHICAGO, May 22.--E.B. Bradley, Teller of the Union National Bank, was not at his post to-day, and the bank's officers were strongly of the opinion that he had gone to Canada. They had made up their minds that after 10 years' service in the institution he had fled to avoid the consequences of a defalcation.
DANBURY, Conn., May 22.--Diphtheria in a mulignant form prevails in the town of Brewster. A number of deaths occurred within a week, and new cases are appearing.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22.--The J. Lusk Can ning Company, which made an assignment recently, filed an inventory to-day, showing total liablities to be $254,000 and total assets $40,000.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 22.--The largest congregation so far of the General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church gathered today to hear the question of evolution discussed by the Rev. James Woodrow, D.D., and his prosecutors. They were not disappointed, for ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22.--The Des Moines River yesterday near its mouth was still booming. Selma, a hamlet on its banks, has a rope ferry, and one of the posts thereof pulled out while the ferryman was in the swift current.

Last November Mr. B.F. Colburn was in in tha vicinity of Chamberlain Lake, when he came across two bull moose engaged in a fierce struggle, the cause being a demure looking cow moose which stood hard by.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--It is now settled that the offer to sell the Government $5,265,000 bonds made in the name of a well-known Philadelphia firm was a straw bid solely intended to affect the stock market.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22. The athletic team which will represent Princeton in the inter-collegi ate games at Mott Haven is as follows: Hundred yards dash--King, '88. Two hundred and twenty yards--Dotin, '90; King, '88. Half mile--Roddy, '91; Hamilton, '88.
A once famous dweller on Mount Desert Island was Mme. Milliken, who lived to be 100 years of age. Her home was on the north side of Pretty Marsh Harbor.

CHICAGO, May 22.--The General Man agers of the Western and Northwestern lines to day decided in favor of rates per hundred pounds on live stock shipped over their lines. The present method is by carload charges. The change is to go into effect on June 10.

The newly-elected Board of Directors of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad held a meeting yesterday, and R. V. Martinsen was nominated as President. The meeting for reorganization will take place May 24.

CHICAGO, May 22.--William Starkey, a lawyer, was to-day indicted by the Grand Jury, charged with jury tampering. The true bill was found on the testimony of John S. Newton of 241 Hermitage-avenue, who served as a juror in the case of Rohmstorf against the Chicago City Railroad Company in April.

A woman echo is about to become a mother and is demented was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night by Lizzie Werner, a midwife, who had received her as a patient at her house, 338 East ...
MALDEN, Mass., May 22.--The continued case of Abby H. Corner, the West Medford Chris tian scientist, charged with manslaughter in causing the death of her daughter, Mrs.James, was resumed to-day.
George Francis Train returned to town yesterday and spent all the afternoon in Madison-square inhaling the pyschic forces that he claims are centred in that particular spot.

The attendance at the Cedarhurst races yesterday was not as large as could be desired by the Rockaway Steeplechase Association. There was a goodly number of ladies present with their escorts. There will be no races at Cedarhurst on Thursday, all the events set down for that day having been postponed till Friday.

An important report from the British Consul at Taganrog on the coal industry of Southern Russia has just been laid before Parliament. The five coal basins of Russia are the Donetz, sub-Moscow, Dombrova, (Poland,) Ural, and Caucasus; of these the first is the one described in the present report.
FALL RIVER, Mass., May 22.--A fire this afternoon caught in some cotton stored on the platform of the Old Colony freight sheds, at the steamboat docks, and spread rapidly.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 22.--Angelo Manaco, an Italian, who fatally stabbed a fellow-countryman named Dominico Pratto in February last, was to-day sentenced to Auburn State Prison for 12 years on his conviction of manslaughter in the first degree.

THE TIMES on Monday stated that it was the prevailing sentiment among persons who generally know of such things that Mayor Hewitt had appointed Edwin A. Post of this city as a Dock Commissioner in place of Charles H. Marshall, resigned.

The New-York and Chicago Limited of the Pennsylvania Railroad, composed exclusively of Pullman vestibule sleeping, dining, and smoking cars, duplicates on the rail the functions of a great hotel. It leaves New-York at 9 A.M. every day and lands its passengers in Cincinnati at 7:10 and Chicago at 9 A.M. next day.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday appeared before the Coroner's jury which is investigating the death of Lineman Thomas Murray, who was killed by an electric light current on the 11th inst. He had been summoned to testify, but that which his Honor the Mayor irascibly told Coroner Levy and the jury was not exactly in the nature of testimony.

MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass., May 22.--This morning Schubert Wilder, a wealthy retired iron merchant, formerly of New-Castle, Penn., was found dead in the street. It is thought he was thrown from a carriage and instantly killed.
BELVIDERE, N.J., May 22.--Nelson W. Teeter, the high constable, has three suits for false imprisonment on his hands for over-zeal ousness in trying to stop ball playing in town.

If Mr. Reed of Maine speaks with authority for the Republican minority in the House, the expected Republican substitute for the Mills Tariff bill is not to be forthcoming in that body. In that event it is to be hoped that the Republican majority in the Senate will be guided by wiser counsels and a juster view of the requirements (and opportunities) of the situation.

Signor Italo Campanini is resting comfortably at the Everett House after a season of great activity. The parade of the volunteer firemen of the four county towns of Kings County to-day, ending with a reception at the Casino, Coney Island, promises to end in a fight.

The Young America Cricket Club of Philadelphia finished its Eastern tour yesterday at Staten Island by administering a defeat to the local club. The visitors batted first, and made 146 runs. Young Martin bowled splendidly for the visitors throughout. The game resulted in a victory for the Young America Club by figures of 146 to 74. The visitors played one inning while the Staten Island men played two.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Two young men of this city who took part yesterday in a friendly boxing match near Gaithersburg, Md., were considerably astonished to-day to find themselves described in various newspapers as prize fighters who had been engaged in a terrible slugging match.

The French syndicate's contracts with the copper mining companies of the world have been signed, and now the syndicate is trying to sell its copper to manufacturers. Its price is 16 cents a pound in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The second day session of the American Baptist Missionary Union began with the Rev. Edward Judson, D. D., in the chair. At the Amphion Academy in the Eastern District of Brooklyn was given last evening the first performance of a new American comedy by Edwin Atwell, entitled "His Lordship." The audience was an exceedingly large one, and favorably disposed.
The creditors of Daniel J. Lavery, dealer in provisions at 150 Columbia-street, Brooklyn, charge that he has been endeavoring to cheat them.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--Home missions occupied the attention of the Presbyterian General Assembly this morning. Dr. Morris's report on the operations of the Board of Home Missions was a long and interesting document, showing a very encouraging year in home missionary work.
Three resignations were handed in and ac cepted at the meeting of the Niteenth Century Club, held last evening at Courtlandt Palmer's resi dence, in Gramercy Park.

UTICA, N.Y., May 22.--At the Republican Convention of the Twenty-third Congressional District, held at Boonville to-day, Samuel R.Campbell of New-York Mills and Henry A. Phillips of Lowville were elected delegates to Chicago; W.H. Bright and J. Edgar Jones were elected alternates. J.S. Koster of Lyonsdale was chosen as Presidential Elector.

JACKSON, Miss., May 22.--Many delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which meats here to-morrow, have already arrived, and owing to the several other conventions, the Stata Fair, laying of the cornerstone of the Confederate monument, , in progress during the week, the attendance promises to be the largest at a convention of this kind for years. UTICA, N.Y., May 22.--In alighting from a railroad train here to-day the Hon. Charles A. Chickering, Clerk of the Assembly, severely sprained his left wrist and received other painful bruises.

MADISON, Wis., May 16.--The decision of the United States Supreme Court for the defend ant in the case of the State of Wisconsin against the Pelican Insurance Company of New-Orleans means much more than appears on the surface.

BOSTON, May 22.--Mertie Hackett of Cambridge, who played with the Indianapolis Baseball Club last year, received a telegram from the manager of the New-Yorks yesterday, asking to be informed at once of his terms. Hackett will probably leave for New-York tomorrow.

Alexander c. Brown, 50 years old, a lodger at the Glenmore Hotel, at Park-row and Mott-street, was killed early yesterday morning by either jumping or falling out of a fourth-story window of the hotel. He had been stopping at the hotel for several weeks, but very little was known about him there.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--The Judges of the License Court to-day announced their decisions in the cases of applicants for liquor licenses in the Twenty-eighth, Twenty-ninth, and Thirty-first Wards.

FORT SMITH, Ark., May 22.--Owing to the absence of appropriations for the pay of witnesses the Federal court of this city has been obliged to close, and over 400 witnesses were discharged yes terday without pay.

PITTSBURG, May 22.--The thirty-fifth an nual conclave of Knights Templar of Pennsyl vania began here to-day and will continue sev eral days.
Some of the proprietors of the side shows that attended Forepaugh's Circus into Jersey City on Monday night make serious charges against the detectives connected with the local police force.

Col. Joseph R. Anderson, who was nominated as the Prohibition candidate for Governor by the Prohibition Convention in this city Wednesday, died at his home in Bristol yesterday. He was born Oct. 25, 1819.

There was talk among politicians last evening to the effect that immediately asfer the session of the Democratic National Convention, Gov. Hill would call an extra session of the Legislature to pass an appropriation for the support of the State prisons.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Senator Eugene Hale of Maine and 27 Democratic Senators are responsible for the formal defeat in secret session to-day of the Riddleberger resolution to discuss the fishery treaty with open doors.
F.D. Henderson, President of the Long Island Jockey Club; James L. Lovering, contractor, and A. Gibbons, an employe of the latter were arrested yesterday by Policeman Cosgrove for trespass.
BELVIDERE, N.J., May 22.--The Common Council, having refused to appropriate $1,500 per annum for electric lights for street purposes, the town is now in darkness and the citizens are very indignant.

We quite agree with Mr. PUTNAM, the Secretary of the American Publishers' Copyright League, that the petition against the bill for international copyright now pending in the House which has been put in circulation by a firm of lawyers in this city needs explanation.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21.--Judge Stewart to-day decided the Platt will case and sustained five of the thiry exceptions to the account of ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt as Executor of his sister's estate, one being the objection that he had forgotten to charge himself with $1,000 received from Wilson H. Todd of Metuchen.
LONDON, May 22.--Gen. Pearson's 4-yearold ch, c. Ruddigore won the Somersetshire Stakes to-day, beating Ceraline by four lengths.
HAVANA, May 22.--Advices from Yaguajay, in the province of Santa Clara, state that two bandits have surrendered themselves, with their arms and ammunition, to the authorities.

A Maltese cat came very near being the innocant cause of a tragedy on the track of the New-York Driving Club in Morrisania yesterday afternoon. As good luck would have it, however, the nondescript feline was primarily responsible for a wonderfully brave and clever emergency performance by a reputable trotting horse driver.

MILAN, May 22.--The Emperor of Brazil has had a serious relapse. He appears to be stricken with paralysis. He has lost the power of speech and his breathing is labored.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., May 22.--The Hon. E.H. Winchester of this city is being prominently mentioned in political circles in connection with the Republican Gubernatorial nomination this Fall. Mr. Winchester has never had the reputation of a politician, and the only office, elective or otherwise, that he has ever held was that of Elector on the Republican ticket in the Garfield-Hancock campaign.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 22.--It is understood that petitions asking for a commutation of the sentence passed on Grady and Racette, the murderers of McLeish, the half breed, have been considered by the Governor in Council, and that the law will be al lowed to take its course. The two men will there- fore be hanged at Regina next month.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 22.--The veterans of the Twenty-eighth Regiment of New-York volunteers held their twenty-seventh annual reunion at Medina to-day. There is a large attendance. No business was transacted before ...

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The Lighthouse Board has perfected arrangements for the illumination of Gedney's Channel, New-York Harbor, by means of electricity, and it is expected that contracts for the work wiil be made this week.
ALBANY, May 22.--Speaker Cole was at the Capitol a few minutes to-day. So also were Assemblyman Sheehan and Senator McNaugh ton.

ST. LOUIS, May 22.--The Episcopal Dio cese of Missouri began its annual session this morning, Bishop Tuttle presiding. Attention is given to the division of the Missouri Diocese. The Right Rev. Abiel Leonard, Bishop of Utah, is prominently mentioned for the new Bishop ric.

Yesterday afternoon there were filed in the Recorder's office of the articles of separation between Adolph Sutro and Leah, his wife. The document is dated July 30, 1880, and contains a long list of conditions.

The Rev. John Heyl Vincent, D.D., of Philadelphia and the Rev. James N. Fitzgerald, D.D., of the Newark Coonference, were yesterday elected Bishops and General Superintendents of the Methodist Episcopal Church, and as such swell the number of the Methodist episcopacy from 11 to 13. Three more remain to be elected before the work of the Conference will be complete on this order.

A female infant, about a week old, was found last night in the basement area of the residence of Mr. Erastus Titus, 10 East Seventieth-street, and was placed in charge of Matron Webb at Police Headquarters.

William A. Duer, the committee of John Travers's person and estate, made his report to Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court yesterday. Mr. Travers was adjudged to be a lunatic last December, and died Feb. 19, last.

Last week the inheritor of one of the most famous names of modern times died in London. Mr. Richard Brinsley Sheridan of Frampton Court, Dorset, was the grandson as well as the namesake of the dramatist, orator, statesman, and wit, who died leaving such a brilliant reputation for versatility of intellect in 1816.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 22.--Admiral Luce and the United States marines are having a fine time at Beaufort. A committee of citizens, headed by Intendant Collins, tendered them such a welcome that the North Atlantic squadron would be willing to fight it out on this line if it took all Summer.

PITTSBURG, May 22.--D.W. Carroll, a promi nent boiler manufacturer of this city, made an as signment to-day for the benefit of his creditors. The liabilities are about $75,000, and the assets estimat ed at $160,000. Inability to realize on investments was the cause of the suspension.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Although the Tariff bill has been laid aside in the House of Representatives since the close of the general debate on Saturday last, the majority members of the Ways and Means Committee have not been taking any rest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--The Yale Senior Society elections were given out upon the University campus this evening at 5 o'clock. A large crowd of students and their friends witnessed the elections. The following are the men elected:
SAN FRANCISCO, May, 24.--The Assignees of William T. Coleman made public to-day a statement of the assets and liabilities of the suspended firm.

All the arrangements for the Home Rule demonstration which takes place to-night at the Academy of Music under the Presidency of Eugene Kelly have been completed, and a very warm reception will be given to Sir Thomas Grattan Esmonde an the eve of his departure.
Travelers to St. Louis will find the Pennsylvania Railroad not only a very high-grade road in all respects, but its fast trains to the West equipped with the highest grade Pullman sleeping cars.

Mayor Hewitt yesterday sent two letters to Gov. Hill asking him to disapprove of the bills now before him permitting surface railroad companies to sand their tracks and repealing the prohibition against the Police and Fire Commissioners running for an elective office. Of the latter bill the Mayor says:

LONDON, May 24.--At a meeting of the Dublin Corporation to-day the Lord Mayor read a telegram from Archbishop Walsh, dated Rome, as follows: "Assure the municipal authorities of Dublin that all apprehension of interference by the Holy See in Irish political affairs is groundless.

PARIS, May 24.--The Paix and the Republique Francaise, commenting on the meeting of Republicans last night, which denounced Boulangerism, reproach M. Clemenceau for increasing the divisions in the Republican ranks. The Intransigeant describes the new society which the meeting decided to organize as a re-election league.

PITTSBURG, May 24.--Thomas Chidlow, a policeman, and Richard Ray, a collector, were struck by an accommodation train an the Pennsylvania Railroad near Roup's Station, four miles east of Union Station, this morning, and instantly killed.

There is no monopoly of discredit for either party as to its conduct on the question of open discussion for the fisheries treaty. For some time after the treaty was laid before the Senate the Republicans were strongly opposed to considering it in open session.

CHICAGO, May 24.--James Dobie went to Pullman to-day, bent on murder, and succeeded in fatally wounding his wife. They were married a year ago, when Dobie was a workman in the Pullman car shops, but they soon disagreed and the husband left the place.

Our energetic Mayor has again undergone his frequent misfortune of being misunderstood. When he was examined before the Coroner's jury he gave that body to understand that he was in a towering rage with its members in particular as well as with everybody in general.
BURLINGTON, Vt., May 24.--Minister Phelps, who arrived in this city last night, is the guest of Alderman Elias Lyman, his brother-inlaw.
DURANGO, Mexico, May 24.--Troops near San Miguel de Mequital executed seven bandits Wednesday for a murder and a robbery committed at a hacienda owned by an American named Muller.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 24.--The attempts that were made Saturday night to burn St. Vincent's Orphan Asylum at San Rafael, this State, were renewed Tuesday night and yesterday morning.
BOSTON, Mass., May 24.--The Senate unanimously rejected the bill to incorporate the Boston and Suburban Elevated Railway Company.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 24.--A free trade club was organized here to-night by men who have long been conspicuous in both political parties. W.S. Kerruish, long an active Republican, is the President. The membership is mainly composed of lawyers of prominence at the Bar whose reputation is a guarantee that the club will be aggressive.
THEY FEARED A LYNCHING. KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 24.--Hicks Carmichaels, the negro who killed Deputy Sheriff Shipe last Sunday, was arrested in a barn near Rankin's Station this morning.

Theodore Moss, Secretary of the Board of Electrical Control, yesterday received from Mayor Hewitt a long letter in which his Honor sets forth various excuses for his failure to comply with the board's request to him to use his power to secure the removal by the Commissioner of Public Works of the electrical wires and poles from the streets of the city.

EL PASO, Texas, May 24.--The surveys at present being made for the Kansas City, El Paso and Mexican Railroad, which will be built in a diagonal direction through NewMexico from northeast to southwest, promise to bring to the light of modern ...
PARIS, May 24.--A terrible explosion took place to-day in Merlot's cartridge and firework factory between Pantin and Pre St. Gervais, by which seven buildings were destroyed.

CHICAGO, May 24.--Charles H. Wacker of this city has declined the nomination for State Treasurer given him by the Democratic State Convention. The place on the ticket will be filled by the State Central Committee.
CHICAGO, May 24.--James Simmons, Consular Agent of the United States at San Jose, the Pacific port of entry for Guatemala, is in the city, bound for Washington.

Several witnesses in the Hatch case were examined yesterday before the Grand Jury, but neither Mrs. Scofield, her husband, nor Mr. Ferris was among them. No new evidence was given, and the case was dismissed.

CHICAGO, May 24.--Forty-five Sioux Indians, from the Pine Ridge Agency, arrived at the Northwestern station at 7 o'clock this morning. They are headed by Chief Rocky Bear and Interpreter Yellow Bird, and they all are picked from the Sioux tribe. The Indians left for New-York on the 11 o'clock train.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 24.--At a meeting of the Aldermen this evening Mayor Robinson tendered his resignation. He said that, according to his convictions, he could not sign liquor licenses. Alderman Shephard offered resolutions of regret for the Mayor's resignation, which were adopted by arising vote.
Entries for the first day's meeting of the Country Club Steeplechase Association at Pelham on Monday next will close with the Secretary, C.S. Pelham Clinton, at 13 Park-row, at noon to-day.
WASHINGTON, May 24.--Cardinal Gibbons has been informed of the appointment of Dr. John S. Foley of St. Martin's Church, Baltimore, to be Bishop of Detroit.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 24.--The Queen's Plate race at the Ontario Jockey Club's meeting to-day was won by Harry Cooper, with Evangeline second and Cast Off third. Distance, about one and a quarter miles.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 24.--Dr. William Grosvenor, the wealthy landlord of the Grosvenor Block, who was arrested by the State police under the landlord's liability section of the prohibitory ...
CHICAGO, May 24.--Annie Redmond, to little girl, was enticed away from her home, 2,608 Statestreet, yesterday by an unknown woman.

ROCHESTER, May 24.--The news of the election of Prof. Harrison R. Webster of Rochester University to the Presidency of Union College, at Schenectady, was not received in this city till late last night and Prof. Webster could not be seen until to-day.

When the Jasper investigation was resumed yesterday afternoon by the Board of Education Commissioner Sprague stated that he intended to take up the charge of incompentency and general incapacity of the Public School Superintendent. Mr. Jasper was called, and said that he was educated at the New-York Academy, ...

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Despite the downfall of rain, which has been incessant since last night, the programme for the ceremonies at the laying of the cornerstone of the new Catholic university at Brooks Station, just outside of Washington, was carried out this afternoon, with the omission of a few details made necessary ...
Mrs. Cordace Wheeler of 124 East Twenty-seventh-street and other New-York women are engaged in an effort to build an apartment house for the exclusive occupancy of members of their own sex.
CHARLESTON, S.C., May 24.--A verdict for $10,000 was rendered to-day in the United States court against the bondsmen of Charles E. Bartlett, defaulting Cashier of the Sumter National Bank.

Three women were injured during a fire which broke out at 10:30 yesterday morning in the rag warehouse of Hugh McGinness, at 59 Spring-street, and two of them died last evening at St. Vincent's Hospital.
SHELBY, Ontario, May 24.--A serious fire, resulting from the snooting off of firecrackers, occurred here to-day.
"La Belle Helene" becomes "Die Schone Helena" in German, and the effervescent sparkle of the Parisian text is somewhat diminished in the Teutonic version.
DENVER, Col., May 24.--The Democratic State Convention to select six delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis, met here today, but at 9 o'clock to-night only one delegate had been selected.
The average constable of Staten Island has his hands full when he is ordered to empanel a jury for the purpose of trying a case before a Justice of the Peace on that island.

GLENWOOD SPRINGS, Col., May 24.--Some weeks ago two residents of this place conceived the idea of making a novel and exciting excursion, which for boldness has seldom been equaled. They propose to start from this point and go by water to the Gulf of California.

BALTIMORE, May 24.--Democratic Congressional Conventions were held in this State to-day with the following results: First District--Convention at Easton. Charles H. Gibson, Easton, Talbot County, renominated on the one hundred and seventy-ninth ballot.

Acting Assistant District Attorney Gunning S. Bedford said yesterday that the District Attorney's office would take action if the law against dueling or sending a challenge has been violated, as, in his judgment, it had been by Mr. Blissert.

Good citizens who arose yesterday morning in blissful ignorance of the fire which had wrecked the "Thirty-ninth-street" exchange of the Metropolitan Telephone Company the previous night, were unduly exasperated when repeated ringings failed to arouse their central office.
DETROIT, Mich., May 24.--W.A. Crouch of East Saginaw, Great Senior Sagamore of the Improved Order of Red Men of Michigan, announced his withdrawal from the order.
MERIDEN, Conn., May 24.--The consolidation of the Meriden and Cromwell and the Meriden and Waterbury Railroad Companies was affected at a meeting of the stockholders of both companies here to-day.

ST. LOUIS, May 24.--Advices from the Indian Territory say: "Serious trouble is existing in Pickens County, Chickasaw Nation, between the non-residents and the Chickasaw officals, on account of the collecting of the one-dollar-per-head tax on all stock.

BERLIN, May 24.--The marriage ceremony of Prince Henry, second son of Emperor Frederick, and Princess Irene, third daughter of Grand Duke Ludwig of Hesse, was solemnized in the chapel of Charlottenburg Castle to-day.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 24.--This is the opening day of the one hundred and forty-first annual convention of the Lutheran Ministerium of Pennsylvania, at which between 300 and 400 delagates are expected, and a majority of them have arrived.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--To-day was given up by the butchers, who have been in convention in this city for the past three days, to pleasure, and although the weather was anything but pleasant the jolly meat men succeeded ...

Surrogate Ransom has decided to appoint a temporary Administrator of the property of Patrick Trenor, the old Vesey-street cordial merchant; over whose possession there was such a sharp contest during the last few months of his life.

The annual election of the Union Club Wednesday night was a great surprise to its members, especially three who had been among those whose names had been presented by the Nominating Committee for members of the Governing Committee.

The newly-elected Board of Directers of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad met yesterday and R.V. Martinsen was elected President. There will be another meeting today, and at this a VicePresident will be chosen. The Executive Committee appointed yesterday consisted of Simon Sterne, R. V. Martinsen, W. Mertens, H.K. Enos, W. Dowd, and W. Bond. The elections were all unanimous and the meeting was harmonious.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--Mrs. Cleveland devoted several hours to-day to sight seeing in the city. Shortly after 11 o'clock Mr. George W. Childs and Mrs. Cleveland, in company with the Rev. Charles Wood and Mrs. Wood of Germantown.
The Board of Finance and Taxation of Jersey City, whose members are appointed by the Board of Aldermen, is composed of three Democrats and two Republicans, Corporation Counsel and City Controller.

The Staten Island Rowing Club are overhauling their boats and getting ready for the boating season. The following officers were elected at their annual meeting: President--Albert Boardman; Vice President--Angus J. McDonald; Secretary and ...
WASHINGTON, May 24.--To-day's offerings of bonds aggregated $384,000, in lots, as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$40,000 at 128, $100 at 127.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--The Secretary of War has issued a general order as follows: "Enlisted men, confined in the guard house for offenses demanding trial by court martial, will not, while awaiting such trial, be sent out to work with the prisoners undergoing sentence.

State Railroad Commissioners Baker, Rogers, and Rickert at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday morning have a hearing to the street railroad companies of New-York and Brooklyn and the Suburban Rapid Transit ...

The annual reception of the Women's Art School of the Cooper Union was held last evening at the Cooper Union. A large number of the friends of the graduates and of Alumni of the Union went to see their art productions, congratulate the students, and listen to the music.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 24.--The Ohio Prohibition Convention convened this afternoon. About 200 accredited delegates were in attendance. More were expected on trains arriving to-night and to-morrow morning.

CHICAGO, May 24.--The General Managers of the Western and Northwestern roads met today to hear the report of the committee appointed to prepare a new form of agreement. The report was adopted practically as submitted.

Frank B. Patchen, Postmaster of Silver Creek, Chautauqua County, N.Y., is dead, aged 35 years. Isabel Louise Sarony, only daughter of Napoleon Sarony and the wife of Giusseppe Bonnono, died in this city Thursday, aged 24 years.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 24.--The Hon. W.D. Bynum, Representative from this district and member of the Ways and Means Committee, is at home for a brief visit.
About 500 people were present at Fleetwood Park yesterday. The track previous to the rain was in fine condition, but during the last few heats the mud was nearly fetlock deep.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 24.--The Faculty of Cornell University has announced a new departure and a decided innovation in the college curriculum in the shape of a carefully-considered step toward a school of journalism. A course of practical instruction in newspaper work will be offered next year.

The first Cleveland campaign club to be formed in New-York City was organized by the Democrats of the Eleventh Assembly District last night. In response to a call sent out by Abram Bernard about 30 leading Democratic ...

FARGO, Dakota, May 24.--The Farmers' Mass Convention to-day recommended the formation of Farmers' County Alliances and the building of farm storage elevators, which they claim will save the farmers from 16 to 20 cents per bushel on grain.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 24.--An anglers' tournament, the first affair of the kind west of NewYork, was held here today under the auspices of the Indianapolis Fly Fishermen's Club.

The American Electric Manufacturing Company at 3 East Fourteenth-street, whose factory is at 165 West Eighteenth-street, had 10 judgments aggregating $19,419 entered against it yesterday in favor of the American Electrical Works of Providence, and one for $543, and the Sheriff took possession.

The Newark Police Board have started a crusade against the dealers who sell cigarettes to minors. The Chief issued an order Wednesday night to patrolmen to investigate the matter and arrest all small boys seen smoking, and through them discover, if possible, those who sell to the children.

CHICAGO, May 24.--Charles Carey was to-day sentenced to 50 years' imprisonment in the Joliet Penitentiary. On April 3 he shot and killed Moy Ni Ding, a peaceable Chinaman. There was no excuse for the crime, and Carey pleaded guilty in hopes of getting a light sentence.

For a long time past the fruit importers and the fruit dealers have been at loggerheads over the manner in which fruit is sold in the auction rooms. The trade must buy from samples and take its chances on the bulk of the purchase.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--It is reported in railroad circles that the Schuylkill River East Side Railroad and the Philadelphia Division of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will be purchased by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company or by an independent company acting in the interest of the Pennsylvania.
The meeting of the Democratic State Committee, which was held last evening in the Hoffman House, was one of the most harmonious gatherings ever enjoyed by any similar body.

ALBANY, May 24.--On account of the failure of Clark, Radcliffe Co. of New-York, jobbers in woolen and knit goods, and the unsettled condition of the market, several of the Cohoes knit goods and woolen mills will be closed temporarily. The Harmony Mills, the largest of them, continues in full operation.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 24.--It was Lord Dufferin, who, when visiting the great Falls of Niagara the last time before his return to England, suggested the idea of a great free park at the Falls, the demolition of unsightly surroundings, ...
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 24.--Contrary to expectation, McFarland, who shot his wife and daughter and himself yesterday, will probably recover.

BANGOR, Me., May 24.--Just 21 salmon in the past 24 hours, weighing 390 pounds, is the record of the fly fishermen here, who caught nine yesterday and twelve to-day, all in a space not larger than Union-square.

A tall, fine-looking man, about 35 years old, with a clean-shaven face and dressed like a Catholic priest, stopped in James H. Hart's jewelry store, at Fulton and Johnson streets, Brooklyn, about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and asked to see a diamond cross worth $200.
There is no use in mincing matters with reference to the action of the Board of Aldermen in refusing its consent to the use of electric motors on the cars of the FourthAvenue Railroad.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May. 24.--Something unique in the way of a desertion recently occurred in the little village of Fredonia. Mrs. Frank Palmer was missing one day, and so was $1,500 in cash which Mr. Palmer had left within her reach.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 24.--The second annual meeting of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association, composed of Amherst, Brown, Dartmouth, Williams, Wesleyan, and Trinity Colleges and Worcester Polytechnic Institute, took place to-day on the fair grounds in this city.

Three hundred bright-eyed boys in holiday attire, each carrying a little flag and wearing a rosette on his coat, marched proudly into the upper classroom of Grammar School No. 11 in West Seventeenth-street yesterday morning.

The Ladies' Health and Protective Assocition of the city of New-York held its annual public meeting last evening at Chickering Hall. Ex-Judge Charles P. Daly, who presided, reviewed the good work which the ladies of the association had performed in the interests of the health of the city. The price of cleanliness, he said, was eternal vigilance.

ALBANY, May 24.--For three hours the Governor listened this afternoon to grain elevator men and boatmen in the hope of learning something about the profits of the one and the burdens imposed upon the other. CHICAGO, May 24.--The stock, lease, and fixtures of the jewelry firm of N. Matson Co. were sold by Judge Gresham to-day for $42,500 to W.R. Alling of 170 Broadway, New-York, ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--The failure of W.H. Stevenson, a member of the Stock Exchange, was announced late this afternoon, and 1,100 shares of Reading and 500 shares of Northern Pacific preferred were sold for his account under the rule.

STURGIS, Dakota, May 24.--George H. Cameron, Lieutenant of the Seventh Cavalry, and Miss Nina D. Telford were married last evening by the Rev. Father Metzger of Sturgis, at the bride's home, at Fort Meade. The affair was the social event of the season.

The twentieth annual catalogue of Wells College, the Alma Mater of Mrs. Grover Cleveand, has just been issued. The college, which was founded by the late Henry Wells of Aurora and liberally endowed by the late Hon. Edwin B. Morgan, has for its object to promote the education ...
RICHMOND, Va., May 24.--The municipal election here to-day passed off very quietly. The Democrats had it all their own way, there being no regularly organized opposition.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 24.--The third and fourth concerts of the Centennial May Festival were given to-day under satisfactory conditions, and have increased the festival spirit which pervades the music-loving portion of the city. The attendance at the matinee was about 4,000.

LEAVENWORTH, Ind., May 24.--This town is greatly excited again over the list of brutal outrages perpetrated by the "White Caps." Jacob Strice, who lives at Bogard's Fork, was the first victim of the despicable wretches who engage in this kind of villainous work.

JACKSON, Miss., May 24.--Miss Winnie Davis, daughter of Jefferson Davis, arrived here this afternoon on the regular express train, under the escort of the committee sent from here after her on Wednesday.
"C. flat."--Get a duplicate from the court that issued the paper. A.E. Costello wishes it known that he is not a second in any pending or impending duel.
At the Produce Exchange yesterday was exhibited a bronze imperial bushel measure cast in 1601 and used in England at that period as the Crown measurement.

CHICAGO, May 24.--The inquiry into the affairs relating to the organization of the Gas Trust brought out by the bill filed against its originators by Nicholas C. Miller, late President of the Town of Lake Gas Company, was continued this morning before Master in Chancery Bass.
One of the prettiest of suburban Spring weddings was celebrated last evening in the Bergen Point section of Bayonne City, N.J. The bride was Miss Adele S. Ward and William J. Morrison was the groom.

Plymouth Church and Society last evening unanimously elected the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott Pastor to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Mr. Beecher. Assistant Pastor Halliday led a very insignificant element of opposition, but after the test vote of 400 to 60 one of the opponents moved to make the election unanimous, and the historical church was again sailing on waveless waters.

CHICAGO, May 25.--The action of the Cincinnati Convention of Labor Men in nominating a national ticket was repudiated by a three-fourths vote at a meeting last night of the Land and Labor Club, No 1, though the President ...

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 25.--All the papers here, with one exception, indorse the appointment of the Hon. G.E. Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, as Minister of Finance and Fisheries, succeeding Sir Charles Tupper, who returns to England to resume the duties of High Commissioner to Canada.
BUCHAREST, May 25.--The village of Harlan was destroyed by fire to-day. Four hundred families are homeless.

ADRIAN, Mich., May 25.--A resolution was adopted by the Methodist Protestant Conference this morning, announcing unalterable opposition to any form of liquor license, high or low, and condemning any clergymen signing a petition for license to sell liquor. A resolution condemning the use of tobacco provoked animated discussion, as a large proportion of the clergymen use the weed. Westminster, Md., was selected as the place for holding the next Conference.
OTTAWA, May 25.--The Minister of Customs has sent a letter to the managing owner of the American ship Bridgewater, which was seized at Shelburne, Nova Scotia, in August ...
RALEIGH, N.C., May 25.--The Democratic Convention of the Eighth Congressional District at Lenoir yesterday renominated unanimously W.H.H. Cowles, the present Representative.

CONCORD, N.H., May 25.--William D. Burnham, an insane man, was instantly killed near the gas works this forenoon. He was being taken to an asylum in this city and jumped from the train, which was going at the rate of 20 miles an hour. Selectman Edgerly of Epping, who endeavored to capture Burnham, was dragged from the train and received severe scalp wounds.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 25.--The annual field day sports of the Intercollegiate Association were held at the Driving Park in this city this afternoon. The association includes Columbia, Hamilton, Hobart, Madison, Syracuse, Union, and Rochester. The Syracuse and Hobart boys took the greater share of the ...

A bold but fruitless attempt was made by three young men early yesterday morning to rob the safe in the Tompkinsville (Staten Island) Post Office. PORT ROYAL, S.C., May 25.--The seamen and marines of the squadron embarked in the boats yesterday morning and were towed up to Beaufort, where the naval brigade was formed under the latest approved system of organization drawn up by a board appointed for the purpose by Admiral Luce.
The first Spring tennis tournament under the auspices of the Flushing Athletic Club began at Flushing, Long Island, yesterday, with a small attendance. The matches played were as follows:

COLUMBUS, Neb., May 25.--Albert Kumpke, the old farmer who murdered his wife a few weeks ago by beating her brains out with a club, was found hanging dead in his cell yesterday. He had used his suspenders and a handkerchief for the noose. He left a letter saying that he wished to save the county further expense on his account and asking to be buried beside his wife.
Courtlandt Palmer delivered his lecture on "Human Mastership" last evening at the German Masonic Temple in East Fifteenth-street before an audience of about 300 persons.

The rainy weather which has so affected the attendance at the races this Spring did not deter 3,000 persons from going down to Cedarhurst yesterday to see the big event of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, the running of the Cedarhurst Grand National. VIROQUA, Wis., May 25.--Reuben Drake, his wife, and two grandchildren, children of James Dupee, were murdered last night in the town of Kickapoo. Drake and his wife were about 60 years old and lived on a well-cultivated farm, four and one half miles from the village of ...
WASHINGTON, May 25.--To-day's offerings of bonds to the Government amounted to $478,000.

ESTHERVILLE, Iowa, May 25.--George Daggle of Sioux Falls, Dakota, died from the effects of poison at Clarion yesterday. His wife, who is the principal actress of Ford's dramatic company, purchased morphine at a drug store and they spent the afternoon together. It is not known whether it is a case of accident, suicide, or murder.

There have been so many suicides from swallowing Rough on Rats lately, that the Kings County Board of Pharmacy made a careful analysis of the compound and discovered that 90 per cent of the stuff was arsenic. The board in consequence notified the 350 druggists in Brooklyn, yesterday, that the preparation must be properly labeled and registered as a poison before it is sold, and the name of every purchaser recorded.

The official announcement that the new Reading loan had been placed caused no surprise in Wall-street. For some time the news had been discounted, and of late the only question had been as to the day when the sale would be made and the price.

CHICAGO, May 25.--Lillie Richmond, the young woman who dressed herself in male attire and shot at Thomas J. Bollander, a real estate dealer, was discharged from custody by Judge Woodman to-day. There was no attempt to deny the pistol episode, but after the prisoner had testified that Bollander had deceived her by a bogus marriage, the Judge gave her her freedom, at the same time giving Bollander an unmerciful raking over.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, May 25.--In the fence case of the United States against the Douglass William Sartoris Horse Company Judge Sanfly of the Second Judicial District Court yesterday decided for the defendant. The company purchased railroad lands and in fencing the property inclosed Government sections, having obtained title only to each alternate section. The United States Attorney secured an injunction and suit followed. The decision is of the utmost importance to all ranchmen within ...

The investigation by the Senate committee of the administration of the Post Office and Custom House in Philadelphia, and thus far of the management of the Custom House in this city, is sufficiently justified by the disclosures already made.

ALBANY, May 25.--Gov. Hill showed considerable interest in the subject of ballot reform by asking numberless questions about its provisions and their probable effect at the hearing given by him to-day upon the Saxton bill. Tammany dispatched two of its lawyers--T.C.T. Crain and President George H. Forster of the Board of Aldermen--to argue against ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 25.--At Newport, Tenn., to-day, was captured William E. Jones wanted in Denver, Col., and for whose arrest a reward of $500 was offered by the Continental Oil Company of that city. He was disguised as a raw country lad, and was carrying a star route mail.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 25.--The Czar, in replying to a deputation inviting him to attend the celebration at Kiev in July of the ninth centenary of the conversion of Russia to Christianity, said: "I sincerely wish that this jubilee will not be disturbed by warlike events. All my efforts are directed to securing the peace of Russia."

The Standard Oil Trust is again threatened with the possibility of having to disclose its methods of doing business to one of its most persistent opponents. FARGO, Dakota, May 25.--The seeding of wheat in North Dakota is about completed under most favorable auspices.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25.--Mrs. Cleveland spent a comparatively quiet day to-day. She had a 9 o'clock breakfast at the residence of the Rev. Charles Woods, in Germantown, where she is being entertained, and at 10:30 o'clock she visited Mrs. Smith's West Walnut-lane school in an informal way. CHICAGO, May 25.--There is a hitch in the proposed settlement of the Western railroad trouble over live stock rates. The Western and Northwestern roads have agreed to put the weighing system in operation June 10, but the agreement was conditional on the approval of all the other lines interested in the live stock traffic between Chicago and the Missouri River.

BOSTON, Mass., May 25.--Mayor O'Brien has called a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen for to-day, at which a conference committee will probably be appointed to act with a similar committee of the Common Council to endeavor to break the dead-lock on the Appropriation bill, which has lasted since May 1.
WOOD'S HOLL, Mass., May 25.--The contract for laying the new Government submarine cable between Block Island and Point Judith has been awarded, and work will be begun next week.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 25.--At this morning's session of the Lutheran Ministerium the Rev. Dr. J.M. Anspach of Easton, Penn., was elected English Secretary. The Rev. Dr. J. J. Kuendig of Reading presented a petition from German congregations at Reading, Philadelphia, Trenton, and Pottsville asking for permission ...

Robert B. Roosevelt, who began a contest in the Surrogate's Court a few months ago over the will of Cornelius S.V. Roosevelt, and soon after withdrew it, has now begun another suit in the Supreme Court.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25.--Messrs. Baker Sloss, Assignees of W.T. Coleman Co., have been placed in an unpleasant position by the publication that the statement of assets and liabilities submitted yesterday was made by them instead of the assignor.
There will be a good time in the Academy of Music to-morrow (Sunday) evening, when Herrmann, the prestidigitateur, will lecture for the benefit of the New-York Press Club building fund.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25.--A meeting of the Women's Executive Committee of Home Missions was held in Calvary Presbyterian Church this morning. Delegates were in attendane from many States and Territories.

JAMESTOWN DEPOT, N.Y., May 25.--Tonight the jury in the suit of Miss Jennie Clark against Morris Cheney, a young farmer, for $5,000 for breach of promise of marriage brought in a verdict of $2,000.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 25.--Gov. Leslie of Montana has raised the quarantine against Texas cattle. The important part is a modification of the former proclamation establishing the quarantine, raising the embargo so far as the Pan Handle of Texas is concerned.

CINCINNATI, May 25.--The body of Henry Burland, a printer of this city, was found dead beside the railroad near Parkersburg, West Va., this morning. As he had about $500 with him when he left here a short time ago it is thought he was murdered. Nothing was found on his person. He was a prominent member of the Knights of Pythias.

CHICAGO, May 25.--G.E. Brown, an old man, hanged himself at his son's house, 73 Walnut-street, to-day. He had failed in an effort to get work and preferred death to dependence on his relatives. Mrs. Mary Searles, aged 35, shot herself this morning at the house of her brother, William Tompkins, at Irving Park. Three years ago her husband was killed in a railroad accident and she had been despondent ever since.

UTICA, N.Y., May 25.--George P. Bristol, Assistant Professor of Greek in Hamilton College, has accepted a call to a similar position in Cornell University, and will enter on his duties at the beginning of the next academic year.

DENVER, Col., May 25.--The Democratic State Convention did not adjourn until after midnight. The following are the delegates: T.M. Patterson, A.E. Ballard, Casimere Barella, W.S. Cockrell, J.N. Carlyle and T.B. Ryan. Resolutions were unanimously passed indorsing Cleveland's Administration. This portion of the platform is as follows:

CHICAGO, May 25.--G.O. Barrio, a Panama merchant, was at the Palmer House yesterday. He is on his way to Europe. "I am not a shareholder or a contractor," said he, "in the Panama Canal Company, but I am able to say that its success is assured since the concession by the French of $120,000,000 of lottery bonds.

Thomas C. Hoge of 56 Wall-street, President of the Silver Springs, Ocalla and Gulf Railroad Company, obtained an attachment from Judge Lawrence yesterday against the property of Henry A. Bate to recover the value of $15,000 in bonds of the company.
Politicians all over Jersey City yesterday discussed the turn in affairs by which City Controller Dickinson vanquished his enemies at Thursday evening's meeting of the Board of Finance.

PALMER, Mass., May 25.--Quite a sensation was caused to-day in the town of Wales by the arrest of Postmaster O.P. Royce, charged with opening letters in the mails. Post Office Inspector Knowiton of Boston made the arrest and took Royce to Boston. He will be arraigned before the United States Commissioner.

BALTIMORE, May 25.--The Baltimore and Ohio officials deny emphatically the statement from Philadelphia about the alleged sale of the Schuylkill and Eastside Railroad and the virtual transfer of the Philadelphia extension of the Pennsylvania.

The programme for the Decoration Day parade in Brooklyn was completed yesterday. The line of march will be from the Bedfordavenue fountain, starting at 10:15 A.M., through Bedford-avenue to Lafayette, thence ...

HAMPTON, Va., May 25.--This has been Commencement week at the Hampton Institute here and a most pleasant one for graduates, undergraduates, and the host of friends of this institution which has done so much toward educating the two "wards of the nation," the negro and Indian.

The rival race meetings at the St. Louis and Latonia tracks begin to-day, and as there are plenty of horses at each track there will probably be fair sport at each place. The rival Derbys will be the special features to-day.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 25.--The question of woman suffrage in Washington Territory came up to-day before Judge Nash at Spokane Falls on a test case. The Judge delivered a lengthy opinion, in which he decided that the act of Legislature extending the franchise to women is unconstitutional.

During the last day or two the report has been current that the police were exercising unusual energy in their suppression of pool selling. The following circular letter, sent to different Police Captains, may have some connection with these extraordinary efforts.

DETROIT, Mich., May 25.--To-day Charles H. Hackley, a wealthy lumberman of Muskegon, gave to the public schools of that city $100,000 in trust for the erection of a public library and reading room building and for the purchase of books and other material.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 25.--The Allan steamer Caspian, from Liverpool, which arrived here to-day, brought the new commander of the British forces here, Lieut.-Gen. Sir John Ross.

CINCINNATI, May 25.--Andrew Wetzel was tried in the Police Court to-day for keeping his saloon open on Sunday, contrary to law. Six or seven witnesses testified to the fact that his saloon was publicly open for the sale of intoxicants. No testimony was presented on his behalf. The jury in 10 minutes returned a verdict of not guilty.

It is common to hear young persons who aspire to certain social positions speak of their failure or success in what they call "making an impression." There need be no harm in making an impression, if the impression is worth making.

ALBANY, May 25.--The City Chamberlain sold 350 4 per cent. Albany City water bonds at auction to-day, and the entire lot was purchased by Blake Brothers Co. of New-York at a premium of $28,977. The last series of these bonds mature in 1908. This is the greatest premium ever paid here for 4 per cent, bonds.

The Rev. Dr. Marvin R. Vincent, former Pastor of the Church of the Covenant, sailed for Europe last night on the Fulda. He will return next September and take charge of his new position at the Union Theological Seminary.

LONDON, May 25.--Bishop O'Dwyer of Limerick has sent a letter to the Mayor of Limerick giving warning that Catholics who attend the League meeting announced to be held on Sunday will be guilty of a grievous sin, ...

The sub-committee of the United States Senate continued its investigation into the workings of the civil service law at the Custom House, in the Federal Building, yesterday. Senator Hale was still absent, owing to illness, and the examination was conducted by Senators Spooner and Blackburn.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 25.--De Witt C. West of Lowville, N.Y., a well-known and well-liked member of the Junior Class at Yale, attempted to board a moving train at the Consolidated station to-night, slipped, and was thrown violently against a post. He was taken to the New-Haven Hospital in an ambulance. His injuries are painful, but the physicians say not likely to be fatal. He is suffering from some sort of concussion.

The Methodist General Conference yesterday settled the question of Missionary Bishops for the time being by electing a new one-- Dr. J.M. Thoburn--for India and Malaisia. The agents for the Book Concerns, Sanford Hunt and J.M. Phillips for New-York and Earl Cranston and M.P. Howe for Cincinnati, were also reelected.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 25.--The Commencement exercises at Wesleyan University will begin Sunday, June 24, when the baccalaureate sermon will be delivered by the Rev. Albert S. Hunt, D.D., of New-York. Sunday evening the annual University sermon will be preached by the Rev. Theodore ...

YANKTON, Dakota, May 25.--Gen. Hugh J. Campbell's call for a convention of divisonists and Statehood supporters will be before the public in a few days. It is all prepared and will appear in the newspapers simultaneously.

Samuel W. Dineen, 18 years old, was tried before Judge Gildersleeve in General Sessions yesterday on a charge of having shot a policeman on August 24 last, and was found guilty of assault in the third degree.

ERIE, Penn., May 25.--The trial of Philip Stein, the shoemaker from Rochester, N.Y., for the brutal murder of William Jones, proprietor of the St. Cloud Hotel, closed to-day with a verdict of murder in the second degree.

Coronor Levy issued subpoenas yesterday to the Mayor, the Commissioner of Public Works and Subway Commissioner Gibbens ordering their attendance Monday next at the inquest in the case of Thomas Murray, who was killed by contact with an electric light wire. Officer Richard Cook was commissioned to serve the subpoena on the Mayor. He did not find Mr. Hewitt in.

LONDON, May 25.--On the Stock Exchange today business was meagre. American railroad securities were flat, and although prices rallied slightly in street dealings, still there was left a decline for the day.

BERLIN, May 25.--The Emperor had a satisfactory night. He still feels fatigued on account of the extra exertion caused by his attendance at the wedding of his son yesterday.

Policeman Connors of the Twenty-ninth Precinct found a boy, 12 years of age, sitting on the curbstone at One Hundred and Seventeenthstreet and Fifty-avenue at 8 o'clock Thursday morning. The boy seemed ill and said that his father had beaten him.
NEWBURG, N.Y., May 25.--A gentleman who came from Brown's Settlement, Sullivan County, on Wednesday of this week reports that the snow drifts were ten feet deep in that neighborhood on that day.

BUTTE, Montana, May 25.--Alexander Lavenberg, locally known as "old Walkerville," died today, aged 54. He came to Montana in 1867 and accumulated quite a fortune, which was swept away by fire. Several years ago he came to this city, where, it is said, he died possessed of $250,000, which is deposited with a Berlin banker. He leaves a wife and two stepsons, one of them samuel Alexander of Helena.

ODELL, Ill., May 25.--Fred M. Matthieson, son of J.H. Matthieson and nephew of the wealthy family of that name, bankers, refiners, and smelters in New-York, Chicago, and La Salle, committed suicide yesterday. He has for two or three years past been publishing the Odell Reporter and had been subject to fits of despondency owing to continued ill health.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 25.--Mrs. Carrie S. Carr, a lady living at New-Lisbon, Wis., had J.R. Schuyler, a Minneapolis real estate dealer, arrested on the charge of embezzlement.

WELSH, La., May 25.--Benoit Builledeau was waylaid and killed yesterday forenoon while passing through a thick wood three miles south of this town. He was evidently shot in the back first, and then the murderer, to make sure of his work, shot him through the head after he was down, as a bullet was dug out of the ground under the man's head.

There is a decided difference of opinion among the stockholders and Directors of the New-York Equitable Insurance Company as to the future of the company, and at the coming election of Directors it will practically be decided whether or no the company shall go into liquidation.

Forty men and boys employed in the foundry of the Cooke Locomotive Works at Paterson, N.J., went on strike yesterday without notice to the company.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 25.--The contract for dredging Crooked Lake and outlet under chapter 206 of the Laws of 1888, appropriating $15,000, was awarded to-day by Superintendent of Public Works Shanahan to A.R. Wright of Portland, Me., at 33 cents a square yard.
Mayor Hewitt will move from the Stewart Building to his old quarters in the City Hall on Monday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 25.--The Board of Engineers appointed by the Government to determine the height, span, and site of the bridge to be built over the Mississippi River at this point concluded its labors this afternoon and will make its report to-morrow.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25.--Reports from Seaconnet Point state that soup seem to be striking in much larger quantities than a week ago, when it was feared that no run would be obtained at all and that a heavy loss would thereby be incurred by the fishermen.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 25.--The shipments of truck from Charleston this season have been the largest ever known, and the crops are the heaviest ever planted. Last Sunday 88 carloads were forwarded to the Northern markets.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 25.--Gen. Beauregard has determined to withhold for the present his resignation of the Commissionership of Public Works, notwithstanding the slight put upon him by the City Council, and meantime lend all the resources within his reach to the proper cleaning of the city for the Summer.

Lord Bradford's 3-year-old colt Merry Andrew won the Manchester Cup race in England yesterday, with Selby second and Scottish King third. There were nine starters, with Scottish King the favorite, and the odds 7 to 1 against the winter.

LOUISVILLE, May 25.--A remarkable exhibition of nerve was made by Jockey Andy McCarthy in the Kentucky Handicap, run here yesterday, when, with a broken leg, he rode Gallifet the full mile and a quarter and finished with the others. The certificate holders of the Mexican National Railroad Company, who are entitled to a representation of three in the Board of Directors to be chosen at the annual meeting next week, nominated yesterday to serve them in that capacity William J. Palmer and George Foster Peabody as American Directors and James Sullivan as Director resident in Mexico.

Prof. Lewis Boss is not only an astronomer, but an ardent lover of books. The Bard of Avon is his especial admiration, and the Professor is brushing up his Shakespearean lore by reading a play a week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 25.--The hardware firm of Rockwell Kinnie assigned last night to Charles E. Benedict. The assets are scheduled at $38,803, including stock, open accounts, and bills receivable. The liabilities will amount to fully $50,000, with $18,508 preferred to home creditors. Both partners also assign and give up all their property. It is one of the worst failures here for some time.

SCRANTON, Miss., May 25.--A thunder squall and heavy rain visited this section at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The two-masted schooner Lizzie S. James of Philadelphia, hauled out on Blanchard's shipyard here, was struck by lightning. Capt. W. B. Johnson was killed and Christian Christiansen, Charles Robbins, John McKibben, Lawrence Aukenson, and Peter Blanchard were injured.

BALTIMORE, May 25.--The General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church reassembled this afternoon, the Rev. Dr. J. Henry Smith of North Carolina in the chair. The pending case, the complaint of the Rev. Dr. Woodrow against the Synod of Georgia, was resumed.

Quarantine Commissioners Anderson and Allen, State Engineer Bogart, Health Officer Smith of the Port of New-York, and Secretary Mellen yesterday inspected the Quarantine property in order to see how the recent appropriations could best be spent.

John Hamilton, an agent of the defunct American Exchange, who has a claim for $50,000 commissions against it, yesterday asked Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court to issue an order requiring W.C. Boone, the Receiver, to give him access to the books and also to enjoin the Receiver from carrying the books with him to Europe. Judge Lacombe issued the order, and also made an order permitting the Receiver to sail.
MONTREAL, May 25.--Detective Naegele was to-day sentenced to 10 years in the penitentiary for complicity in the robbery of the Grand Trunk Railway offices.

Patrons of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad who were passengers on the "Limited" Thursday report a peculiar accident. The train left the Grand Central Station at 4:30 and was running between Rye and Port Chester when the locomotive struck a cow on the track.

The famous Lake Shore deal of 1884, in which the Vanderbilts and several other prominent men figured, had an exciting sequel on the deck of a ferryboat yesterday morning. H.B. Hollins of the firm of H.B. Hollins Co., 18 Wall-street, and W.L. Breese of the firm of Smith Breese, had a fisticuff encounter of which Wall-street talked all day long.

Ann O'Delia Diss Debar has another suit on her hands. Catherine Kulp, who claims to have been her servant, has begun a suit against her to recover $872 which she claims has been due her since 1882.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 25.--The fifth concert of the centennial festival was given tonight to another great audience. The chairs, except in the upper gallery, were all filled, and there were many standing, ladies ac well as gentlemen. It was regarded as a notable night in the series.
CHICAGO, May 25.--The jury-bribing investigation promises to extend much further than the trial of Sumner C. Welch, who is now out on $5,000 bonds.

Secretary McIntyre has furnished a lively puzzle for speculators in his handicapping of the lot of horses to run in to-day's races over the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track. The entries promise to furnish as good a day's sport as has been had at the Gravesend track this season, and that is saying a great deal.
The Intercollegiate Athletic Association holds its thirteenth annual field meeting at 2:30 this afternoon, at the Manhattan Athletic Grounds.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 25.--A few weeks ago a man of mysterious manner and appearance located in Greene County. He called himself "Abbidigal," or "Holy One," claimed to possess a Divine nature, and said he had received instruction by Divine revelation to free the negroes of Georgia from the bondage of a false religion.

CHICAGO, May 25.--The Vanderbilt roads are said to be complaining vigorously of the demoralizing practices which obtain among some of the trunk lines, and Chairman Blanchard of the Central Traffic Association has been in New-York in consultation with Commissioner Fink about the matter.

BOSTON, Mass., May 25.--In the House to-day the Finance Committee reported that the estimated expenses for the current political year were $5,784,485 and the expenses authorized by the present Legislature are $6,242,380. The principal items of the excess are $259,500 for public buildings, $103,277 for special grants, and $28,691 for deficiencies. The committee therefore recommend the levying of a State tax of $2,250,000.

Ireland's cause never received a livelier indorsement than was given it last evening at the Academy of Music. A crowd which filled the seats to the topmost row of the topmost gallery, the platform, and nearly every aisle, shouted and cheered, groaned and hissed as only Irishmen can.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 25.--After the intercollegiate games the Yale Athletic Association will hold two meetings in New-Haven. One of these will be devoted to attempts to break intercollegiate records. Expert timekeepers will be present from New-York.

Bradstreet's reports only 139 failures in the United States during the week, as against 180 for the preceding week, and 107, 170, 184, and 183 for the corresponding weeks of 1887, 1886, 1885, and 1884 respectively. The Middle States had 30. NewEngland 22. Southern 32. Western 38. Pacific and Territories 17. Canada had 22, a decrease of 2 from the previous week.

At high noon yesterday the Board of Electrical Control met in its office in the Wallack Theatre Building, which commands a view of as fine a maze of electric light, telephone, and telegraph wires as can be found in the city. Mayor Hewitt, who is a member ex officio of the board, was not there.

DILLON, Neb., May 25.--In rehearsing for an amateur presentation of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" at a country schoolhouse near here last night J.W. Fouls, the school teacher, pointed a pistol at Samuel Stump, thinking it was not loaded. It exploded, the ball passing through Stump's head, killing him instantly.
NYACK, N.Y., May 25.--For months past a spirit of lawlessness has prevailed in a portion of Haverstraw and the peace of the Sabbath has been greatly disturbed.

CHICAGO, May 25.--The opening scenes of the contest between the magnates of the Chicago Gas Trust and their opponents have changed from the office of a Master in Chancery to the more dignified arena of a court of record. The investigation has been but the preliminary canter over the course the inquiry will take.

The Rev. Charles Parker, the celebrated blind preacher, died on Thursday at his home, 202 South Oxford-street, Brooklyn. He was attacked with pneumonia a week ago, and his feeble constitution could not withstand the disease.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--At yesterday's meeting of the Executive Committee of the Presbyterian Home Missions Mrs. Grover Cleveland was made a life member of the committee.

Preparations for the reorganization and concentration of the Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company's system have been quietly going on for some time. Probably within a year most of the various exchanges or "central offices" will have been merged into two monster stations.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 26.--The RailroadCommissioners are receiving many communications daily, inquiring as to what steps are being taken toward enforcing their order requiring the Northern Pacific and Manitoba Roads to reduce their passenger rates to 3 cents a mile.

A few miscellaneous items of intelligence recorded for the benefit of travelers in 1820 may not be without their interest for the more fortu nate travelers in 1887. At that time the passenger by diligence from Paris to Brussels had to sleep two nights on the road.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 28.--The Southern Presbyterians by a vote of 109 to 34 decided to-day that they did not believe in evolution or a reopening of Dr. Woodrow's case. The trial had been thorough each side had spoken four hours and Dr. Woodrow had closed.
It is said that a determined effort is to be made by the refiners of Russian petroleum to introduce their products into this country.

SALEM, Mass., May 26.--The jury in the case of Thomas Smith of Gloucester, on trial for the murder of Thomas A. Lomasney by drowning in Gloucester Harbor on April 15, brought in a verdict this morning of guilty of murder in the second degree, and Smith was sentenced to State prison for life.

BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., May 26.--A visit to the settlement or reservation of the Winnebage Indians, a few miles from here, reveals much of interest. Many have got little farms of 40 acres, with little frame houses on them, and log stables for their ponies.

PARIS, May 15.--In the gallery of the royal palace of Hampton Court is a picture of Elizabeth of England, signed Lucas von Heere. The Flemish painter represents the great Queen holding in her right hand a globe, draped in a robe of brocade, which shows to advantage her splendid figure.

It was learned yesterday that the woman who last Wednesday night jumped off the ferryboat Oswego of the West Shore Line on the return trip from Forty-second-street to Weehawken was Mrs. Mary Wills, the wife of Charles Wills of Polk-street, West New-York.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 28.--Constable Peirce was convicted to-night of attempting to extort bribes from the liquor sellers, and he was given until Thursday to prepare the appeal.

READING, Penn., May 26.--Ada Christman, a highly respected young woman, aged 20 years, of East Greenville, Montgomery County had a quarrel with her lover last night, and after his departure swallowed in the presence of her father, a quantity of Paris green, which caused her death after terrible suffering.
MILAN, May 26.--The Emperor of Brazil continues to improve and the danger of a relapse is now regarded as over. The doctors propose to remove him to Aix-les-Bains on Thursday next.
