NEWPORT, R.I., May 28.--Inauguration festivities began this evening and open houses were all the go. Newport's absent sons and daughters returned by trains and steamboats all day, and the city would be quite gay tonight but for the fact that the storm which began early in the day has continued.
The Hon. Theodore Moss, Secretary of the Boarad of Electrical Control, yesterday sent to Mayor Hewitt the answer of the board to his recent letter relative to the removal of poles and wires.

The School Trustees of the Sixteenth Ward yesterday morning presented the 500 boys of Grammar School No. 55, at 140 West Thirtieth-street, with a pair of silk flags. As has been the rule at previous pleasant occasions of this sort, the hall of the school was a mass of prettily-blended.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28.--Judge Thurman denies the report that he has consented to the use of his name for Vice-President. He has not been consulted, and is a candidate for no office.

Four beach inspectors were recently appointed by the Board of Health of Stapleton at a salary of $40 a month. The Board of Trustees of Edgewater also appointed two inspectors at a salary of $10 a month.

The Board of Aldermen will meet at 1 P. M. to-day, and the matter of permitting the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company to run electric motors on the Fourth-avenue horse car line below Fourteenth-street will probably be again brought up for action.

DARIEN, Conn., May 28.--A record of fires, unusual and appalling for a village of its size, has convinced most citizens of Darien that they have a firebug, and an extremely active and vicious one, among them.

Some time this week the Trustees of the James Lick estate will convey to the Board of Regents of the State University the Mount Hamilton Observatory. The buildings are all completed, the magnificent telescope in position, and everything ready for immediate occupancy.

INDINAPOLIS, May 28.--The Prohibitionists will have woos to wrestle with as well as the other political parties this year. Woman suffrage has already lifted its head, and it promises to be one of the liveliest subjects that will be discussed by the Prohibition Convention which meets in this city this week.

PARIS, May 28.--Reports are circulating in the lobbies of the Chamber of Deputies that the French Ambassador at Vienna has been instructed to ask Count Kalnoky, the Austro-Hungarian Foreign Minister, to explain the speech made by Herr Tisza, the Hungarian Prime Minister, in the lower house of the Hungarian Diet ...

Curiously enough, the matter that yesterday engaged the attention of the committee investigating Mr. JASPER, the Superintendent of the New-York public schools, is one in which his conduct is apparently quite inconsistent with the system he has so long and so strenuously advocated and maintained to the serious injury of the schools.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The Chicago shippers who have been complaining of the course taken by the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Road in the matter of through rates from the seaboard to St. Paul and Minneapolis met to-day to decide what action should be taken.

The Thornycrofts are a family of sculptors and artists, but Mr. Hamo Thornycroft is the only one who has achieved Academic rank. His father, who died two years and a half ago, was a sculptor of great merit, who is best known, perhaps, to the outside world by the group of "Commerce" on the Albert Memorial.

The Brooklyn Aldermen had a lively fight yesterday over a resolution of "Mike" Coffey requesting that the Legislative Committee go to Albany on Friday and urge Gov. Hill to veto the Edison Electric Light bill.

AUGUSTA, Me., May 28.--Journal reporters have investigated the published story of the robbery of Mr. James G. Blaine's house, and confirm the statement that in April, 1885, when Mr. Blaine was away, the house was entered ...

WASHINGTON, May 28.--For several days past a good deal of quiet talk has been heard in Washington about the availability of Allen G. Thurman of Ohio as a candidate for Vice-President on the ticket with Mr. Cleveland.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 28.--At this morning's session of the Lutheran Ministerium the Rev. F. Wischan of Philadelphia presented the report of the Publication Committee, which shows that the stock on hand is valued at $1,190 69, and that $534 84 has been paid to the Tresaurer of the English church.
John Fallon, a wealthy sash and blind manufacturer, of Manhattan-avenue, Greenpoint, was arrested yesterday charged with assaulting Edward Hayes, a boy of 11 years, who lives at 73 Manhattan-avenue.

There will be a large assemblage of athletes at the Manhattan Athletic Club's Spring games, to be held at 2 P.M. to-morrow at the club's grounds, Eighth-avenue, between Eightysixth and Eighty-seventh streets. Among the competitors will be representatives of Yale, ...

A great bunch of La France roses and lilies of the valley stood on the reading desk of the brilliantly-illuminated hall of the Young Women's Christian Association, in East Fifteenth-street, last night, while the President, Mrs. Clarence E. Beebe, presented diplomas to the graduating industrial and business classes.

ST. PARIS, Ohio, May 28.--E. V. Rhoads, Cashier of the First National Bank, was arrested this morning on a charge of embezzling, stealing, and taking away funds belonging to the bank. He gave bonds for his appearance before the United States Commissioner on May 31.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 28.--All the Cabinet changes will be made within a month. It is now settled beyond doubt that Mr. McLellan, Postmaster-General, will accept the LieutenantGovernorship of Nova Scotia, and that Sir John ...

DETROIT, May 28.--Thomas Crobert, his son John, ago 12, and Henry C. Neverman were out sailing on the river yesterday. A squall struck their frail craft, which capsized, and Crobert and his son were drowned. Neverman was picked up by a tug. Crobert leaves a widow and three small children.

The second number of "Goodwin's Official Turf Guide," which is the pocket-companion of every racegoer, was issued yesterday. From its compilation Covington leads the list of winning jockeys this year, with 63 wins out of 193 mounts to his credit.

The American Yacht Club house at Milton Point, Rye, was open yesterday for members, but the weather prevented the attendance of many. The improvements in the building are about completed, and it is now very evident that the steam yachtsmen will have quarters fully as elegant and commodious as those of ...

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The Democratic caucus reassembled at 8 o'clock this evening with a rather slim attendance. Mr. Randall was present, but Speaker Carlisle was not in the chamber nor was Mr. Cox, the Chairman of the caucus. The greatest secrecy was maintained as to the proceedings, ...

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The President today vetoed the bills granting pensions to Elisha Griswold, Anna Mertz, and David A. Servis on the general ground that the cases are entirely devoid of merit. He also returned without his approval the act for the relief of J.E. Pitcher, ...
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28.--James McLaughlin Son, woolen manufacturers, of Skaneateles Falls, have failed. Liabilities over $250,000; nominal assets about $200,000.

The principal feature of the meeting last night of the New-York County Medical Society was a paper on "The Water Supply from Croton Lake," by Dr. John C. Peters. The doctor stated that the sewage created by 25,000 people, the largest condensed milk factory in the world, 10,000 cows, 1,200 horses, l,500 hogs, and 40 ...

Now that the Elm-street-improvement is again before the municipal authorities, with a fair prospect of reaching a practical determination, the aspirants for the right to construct a rapid transit railroad through the new thoroughfare are exhibiting renewed activity.

ABINGDON, Va., May 28.--Engineers of the Tennessee Steel and Iron Company while surveying in Wise County on the 25th were attacked by a body of men in the bushes and two of the party killed. A company of guards in command of Capt. Dotson employed to protect the engineers were driven off and routed.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The bond offerings to-day aggregated $160,000, as follows: Registered fours--$10,000 at 128, $100,000 at 128; registered four and a halfs--$50,000 at 108 . None of the offers of bonds to-day were accepted.

ALBANY, May 28.--The Troy Press of tonight makes an attack on the personal integrity of D. Cady Herrick, Chairman of the local Demoocratic Committee. The Press is Chairman Murphy's paper, and it is said here that Gov. Hill inspired the article in question. Following are extracts from it:

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 28.--News has just been received from the north of a total loss of the American bark Julia Foard in Karluk Bay, Alaska. The vessel was wrecked April 25, but first intelligence was received yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The long fight of the ministers and church people against the saloons resulted to-night in what is practically a victory for the liquor element, when the Aldermen met and passed an ordinance which is nominally a compromise measure.

In Boston the editor of the Pilot is an amateur boxer of some renown. Since the encounters between Kilrain and Smith and between Sullivan and Mitchell in France boxing has taken a new lease of interest, but at the same time has suffered from the unsatisfactory character of those contests.
At the Baptist Pastor's Conference yesterday the Rev. J.C. Rankin of Orange, N.J., read a paper on "Woman as a Poet," taking in illustratration of his theme the work of Elizabeth Barrett Browning.

Seven hundred men in correct evening dress, whose coat lapels were studded with the odd badges and devices that secret society members delight in, met last evening at Scottish Rite Hall, Madison-avenue and Twenty-ninthstreet, and watched over 100 plain Master ...

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday received a communication from Excise Commissioners Andrews and Von Glahn asking for $163,100 with which to pay the expenses of the Excise Board during the year ending April 30, 1889.
The Tammany Hall Executive Committee met last evening and saw that all was in readiness for the trip of the "braves" to the Democratic National Convention which will convene in St. Louis on June 5.

The following weights for the Fort Hamilton Handicap, for 3-year-olds, at one mile and one-eighth, to be run at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track to-morrow, are announced by Secretary McIntyre. Declarations are due at 6 o'clock this evening:
The Standard Oil Trust complains that it is persecuted by one GEORGE RICE, a refiner of oil who has bought five shares of the Trust's stock and demands all the rights and privileges of a stockholder.

The body of Willie Gerlich, the 10-yearold son of J.H. Gerlich, a bookbinder residing at Flushing, Long Island, was found floating in Flushing Creek yesterday morning. From the statement of the boy's parents ther is no doubt ...
FLAGSTAFF, Arizona, May 28.--At 1 o'clock this morning a collision occurred near Walnut Station, 64 miles cast of here, between a light engine and an east-bound freight.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 28.--F.A. Wheeler, of the wholesale boot and shoe firm of Curtis Wheeler of Rochester, N.Y., was found dead yesterday in his berth in a sleeping car on the Cincinnati, Washington and Baltimore Railroad on its arrival at Cincinnati this morning. A small bottle centaining chloral was found beside the body. It is supposed he took an overdose of the drug. The body was taken to the Morgue.

The prosecution in the Kerr case rested last evening, having occupied over six days in presenting evidence to the jury. The defendant's counsel declined to commit themselves regarding the course they will pursue, but were undecided themselves when court was adjourned.

There is some probability that when the Stuyvesant-Avenue Congregational Church of Brooklyn accepted the resignation of its Pastor, the Rev. Jesse W. Brooks, after it had been asked for, because of inability to pay his salary, it reckoned without that always unknown quantity, the Congregational Council.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 28.--It is not impossible that Yale students may be forbidden by the Faculty to engage in any further athletic sports this year. The details of a Faculty meeting held last Thursday have just been made known.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 28.--The Florida State Democratic Convention meets here tomorrow. Over 400 delegates have arrived. Besides selecting delegates to the National Democratic Convention, a full State and judicial ticket will be nominated.

Notice was received at the Coroner's office yesterday that Edward Lee, a well-known character of the Fourth Ward, died Sunday night very suddenly at Bellevue Hospital of acute bronchitis. He was known to his friends asf "Big Ned Lee," and in his time served with the veteran firemen, running with old engine No. 18.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 28.--The Sunday quiet and peace of this city has been broken for two Sundays past by a party of Newarkers whom the workings of the new high license local option law has deprived of their beer gardens on Sunday.

BOSTON, May 28.--Dr. George W. Galvin of this city had a rather startling experience Saturday night. He was assisting Dr. Dixon of Boylston-street in a confinement case, during which it was found necessary to etherize the mother.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 28.--The people of Portage Laprairie, a flourishing town about 60 miles west of Winnipeg, are in a state of the wildest excitement. During the past few weeks fires have been of nightly occurrence, and many of the principal buildings have been destroyed.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 28.--Stanford Potter, one of the negroes who killed Robert Hamilton at Long Branch on Christmas Eve, was sentenced to-day to 15 years' imprisonment at hard labor for stealing Hamilton's watch.

CHADRON, Neb., May 28.--The waterspout which broke in the northwestern part of Dawes County. Saturday night submerged five miles of track on the Fremont, Elk Horn and Missouri Valley Railroad and washed away numerous bridges.

LONDON, May 28.--Mr. Chamberlain has been elected President of the Birmingham Liberal Unionist Society. In a speech he praised the late scheme for the solution of the Irish question published in the Daily Post, and said that he would go no further if he lived 20 years.

BOSTON, Mass., May 28.--Luther W. Holman, who was charged with conspiring to cause the death of his half sister, Emeline B. Holman of Worcester, was brought before Judge Staples, in the Superior Criminal Court, to-day for trial.

DETROIT, Mich., May 28.--Two rumors of impending railroad changes in this State are taking definite shape. It is reported at Adrian that the eastern half of the Michigan and Ohio Division of the Cincinnati, Jackson and ...

The regular Yearly Meeting of the Hicksite branch, Society of Friends, began yesterday morning in their meeting house on Rutherfurd-place and Fifteenth-street. Clerk Robert S. Haviland presided, and 300 delegates from Eastern New-York ...

William N. Cromwell, Assignee of the estate of Henry S. Ives Co., applied for an injunction in the Supreme Court, Kings County, yesterday, to prevent Christopher Meyer, the Pack Bank, the Ninth National Bank, J.O. Evans, J.C. Meyer and James Dessler from voting on 6,400 shares of Cincinnati, Hamilton ...

BOSTON, Mass., May 28.--In the Superior Civil Court to-day the jury awarded the plaintiff $4,200 in the case of Pelatiah Fletcher against the Fitchburg Railroad Company, an action to recover $15,000 damages for injuries to plaintiff, who while driving over a crossing in the town of Ayer was struck by an express train and injured.

BOSTON, Mass., May 28.--The annual meeting of the American Peace Society was held this afternoon. The Secretary's report showed that a large correspondence had been conducted with the peace societies of Europe.

Railroad earnings were reported in Wall-street yesterday as follows for the third week of May: Omaha, a decrease of $44,414; Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern, a decrease of $11,547; Louisville and Neshville, a decrease of $8,535; Atlantic and Pacific, a decrease of $4,837; Flint and Pere ...
Steamship Ydun, (Nor.,) Hagemann, Baracoa 6 da., with fruit and passengers to H. Dumcis. Steamship Augustine. (Br.,) Harwood, Manaos 20 ds., with mdse. to Booth Co.

LONDON, May 28.--The bark Sophie Wilhelmine, (Norw.) from Almeria for New-York, which put into Lisbon Ieaky, has been surveyed and the surveyors recommend that her cargo be discharged in order to make reports. Much of her cargo has already melted and pumped overboard.

ALBANY, May 28.--There is considerable ill feeling among the local admirers here of the Parnell land movement in Ireland over the methods adopted by overzealous politicians in extending the freedom of the city to Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde last Saturday.

FALL RIVER, Mass, May 28.--Catharine M. Fielding was arraigned in the District Court to-day on a charge of homicide and committed, without bail, till Wednesday, June 6. Meanwhile her case will be brought before the Grand Jury, which sits next Monday.

Patrick Walsh, a Tammany politician, of 332 West Forty-ninth-street, was sentenced yesterday to imprisonment for four years and eight months by Recorder Smyth in the Court of General Sessions. This was the extreme penalty for his offense, an assault.

The Special Committee of the Board of Education appointed to investigate charges of incompetency and general incapacity against Superintendent Jasper held an afternoon and an evening session yesterday.

Democratic Senators made a serious mistake when they shifted their ground and opposed an open consideration of the fisheries treaty. Their action is calculated to beget an impression that they are afraid of a discussion of the treaty and the negotiations which led to it on their merits.
TAUNTON, Mass., May 28.--John Daly, boss spinner at the Mount Hope Yarn Mill, in North Dighton, has been put under bonds to await the result of injuries inflicted by him on ...

PITTSBURG, May 28.--The numerous reductions in wages that have taken place at different iron and steel mills recently will probably be followed by another at one of the largest works in this section of the State.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 28.--The annual meeting of the Pilgrim Society was held in Pilgrim Hall to-day. In the absence of President John D. Long Daniel E. Lee occupied the chair.

BUFFALO, May 28.--In the Superior Court to-day an order of attachment was granted upon the property of Oliver Esmond of Cleveland, author of "Algiers," the play which proved such a disastrous failure at the Academy of Music last week.

The County Democrats of the Tenth Assembly District organized a Cleveland Campaign Club last night at 72 Second-avenue. There were over 100 present when W.P. Mitchell called the meeting to order. The officers elected were: President--Jonn Fennel; Vice-President-- Lorenz Zeller; Secretaries--W.E. Senyens and Charles E. Brehm; Treasurer--John Clark; Sergeant-at-Arms--John Saul.
WASHINGTON, May 28.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Postmasters--Gilman L. Sleeper, Haverhill, Mass.; George G. Mecklem, West Point, N.Y.; Waterman ...

The veterans who are to take part in the Memorial Day parade are greatly exercised over two things. One is the serious illness of Gen. Sheridan and the other the likelihood of a march through rain and mud.

Twelve hundred people traversed a desert of mud and fog yesterday afternoon in order to reach the steeplechase course of the Country Club Racing Association, at Pelham. During a portion of the afternoon a most persistently penetrating mist fell upon the spectators.

BONHAM, Texas, May 28.--This place was thrown into a state of intense excitement yesterday evening when a runner came from Red River with information that a band of desperadoes were surrounded in a log cabin 20 miles from here, in the Indian Territory, and that help was wanted at once.

Prof. Herrmann's performance at the Academy of Music, in aid of the Press Club's building fund, will net about $3,000. This amount was due, in part, to the many friends of the club who aided by purchasing boxes and seats at generous prices.

The pupils of the Grand Conservatory of Music entertained a large audience last night in Chickering Hall at the institution's fourteenth annual Commencement. The programme, consisting of selections of vocal and instrumental music, was admirally rendered by pupils of the conservatory.

It has already been explained that the Papal rescript condemning the plan of campaign and the practice of boycotting is not an utteranee ex cathedra. That is to say, it may be sound, but is not infallible doctrine.

MONTREAL, May 28.--The Rev. Mr. Morrill, an ex-Protestant minister of Providence, R.L., has been ordained to the Roman Catholic priesthood in the Grand Seminary here.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28.--Twenty-six English sovereigns, $20 in bills, and other small amounts in silver and pennies were found concealed on the person of Ellen O'Hara, who died in the Albany Almshouse to-day. She came to this country from Ireland about two years ago.

ALBANY, May 28.--By general orders issued today the Twenty-second Separate Company of Saratoga is relieved from duty at the State Camp of Instruction for the week beginning June 19, and the Nineteenth Separate Company of Poughkeepsie is substituted.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The news concerning Gen. Sheridan's condition is received with the greatest sorrow in Chicago, where the General was a resident from 1869 to 1883. Yesterday the services in many of the Chicago churches were given a character in harmony with the spirit of Memorial Day.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 28.--The stockholders of the Sagamore Manufacturing Company this noon voted to build a new mill of 40,000 spindles, to cost $500,000, and to increase the capital stock from $550,000 to $800,000.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--To the surprise of his physicians and all who were with him last night Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan is still alive, and since morning there has been some slight improvement in his condition. All though the night the sick man's death was looked for at any moment.
The Richmond Grays, which is the bestknown military company of Richmond and which last visited this city in 1859, arrived here late Sunday night on the Old Dominion steamship Wyanoke.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 28.--At an early hour this morning the body of Henry E. Whitehouse, aged 22, employed at the Electric Light Works, was found lying on Noble's Island shore, near Rice's blacksmith's shop.

POTTSVILLE., Penn., May 28.--Arbitrators to-day sat in a suit for breach of promise, brought by Violet Rach of Reynolds against A.P. Hatch of Port Clinton, and filed an award in favor of the fair plaintiff for $1,000. The parties had courted each other for four years, ...

BALTIMORE, Md., May 28.--A dispatch to the American from Elkton says that John B. Hogg, probably the oldest railroad man in this country, if not in the world, died at his home in this town this morning a few minutes before 7 o'olock from old age, in his eighty-fourth year.

BERLIN, May 28.--The Emperor passed a good night. Dr. Mackenzie has inserted another canula. A bulletin issued this morning says he is without fever, and that his appetite and strength are satisfactory.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 28.--The officers of the St. Croix and La Crosse District Land Office in Wisconsin, while looking over the old records and filings in the office at St. Croix, have discovered about 1,000 old land patents which have been missing for over 30 years.

Prices on the Stock Exchange all went downward yesterday. The Gould stocks led in the slumps, Missouri Pacific cutting a particularly sorry figure with a sudden drop of three points.

Although yesterday was another of the unpleasant days that the clerk of the weather seems to specially allot to the Brooklyn Jockey Club for its race days, several thousand people were at the track to see a very commonplace lot of races run.

The annual parade, presentation of medals, and review of the police force of this city will take place on Thursday afternoon. The procession will form at the Battery at 1 o'clock and march up Broadway to Union-square, to Fourth-avenue, to East Twenty-sixth-street, to Madison-avenue, to East Fortieth-street and Fifth-avenue.

The Methodist General Conference began upon its fifth week's session yesterday, with the intention of completing its labors if possible by Wednesday night. The unsettled question whether one or two Secretaries of the Freedmen's Aid Society should be elected was settled ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28.--The Democratic State Executive Committee met here this afternoon and elected the Hon. J.B. Townsend of Lima Chairman, George A. Batson Secretary, and John A. Sarba Treasurer. The special train chartered to transport the Ohio delegation to the St. Louis Convention will leave here on Saturday afternoon.

OSWEGO, N.Y., May 28.--Thomas Matthews, of the firm of Matthews, Macfarlane Co., returned to-day from Washington, where he had a hearing before the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in regard to charges of removing bonded barley from the Continental Elevator without payment of duty.

The four sons of the late Gen. Q.A. Gillmore have begun a contest of his will before Surrogate Lott in Brooklyn on the ground that at the time of his death, on April 7, he was subject to undue influence.

Stern Brothers, the Twenty-third street dry goods firm, are always anxious to do everything in their power to make their store and stock attractive to customers. For this reason they last evening added to the already very large list of useful and ornamental articles to be found in their establishment dropped eggs-- dropped 90 feet in less than two seconds.

George F. Leyh, Jr., a medical student, having an office at 202 Grand-street. Brooklyn, Eastern District, was arraigned before Justice Walsh yesterday charged with violating the health laws in having boiled the bones of a corpse.

ALBANY, May 28.--The following bills were signed by the Governor to-day: Relative to the grading of One Hundred and Thirty-eighth-street, New-York City.

The Commissioners of Accounts, William P. Shearman and James Daly, yesterday presented to Mayor Hewitt their report on the examination of the charges against City Chamberlain William M. Ivins, which Maurice B. Flynn failed to substantiate. The report is a complete exoneration of Mr. Ivins.

Mr. kinglake opens this, the last of his volumes, with the changed aspect of affairs, P lissier being at the head of the French forces. Very cleverly does the author describe the contest between the fiery Norman soldier and the wily French Emperor.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 28.--At Milneburg this afternoon, during a light shower, 10 persons took refuge under a tent. Lightning struck the tent pole, killing one men a mortally injuring another, while ten other persons were severely shocked.

The Board of Education of Muskegon have accepted Charles H. Hackley's magnificent gift of $100,000 for the establishment and maintenance in the town of a public library and reading room. Walter Brainerd, the young son of David W. Brainerd of Irvington-avenue, South Orange, was arrested yesterday for burglary. For some time past his parents have not lived together. The mother is in Florida with her relatives. The father is a well-known New-York business man.

BALTIMORE, May 28.--The General Assembly reassembled at 9:30 o'clock this morning. The Moderator announced the names of the commission appointed to try the complaint of the Presbytery of Mecklenburg against the Synod of North Carolina.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 28.--At a meeting of Street Superintendents to-day it was agreed that the date to begin the general street cleaning be fixed for Monday, June 4. Superintendent Pierce thinks that 1,000 carts will be needed, a great many more than have been volunteered.

Henry George, the quondam prophet and leader of the United Labor Party, is to-day a political outcast. Last November his followers would have made him President of the United States and to-day they would tear off his scalp.

In March last Michael Martin, John Fullerton, and James Byrnes, who were employed by the Fortysecond-Street and Boulevard Railroad Company, were arrested for sprinkling sand in the streets through which the cars passed.

CALAIS, Me., May 28.--The Britishschooner Venture, Capt. Watfield, from Windsor, Nova Scotia, with rock plaster for the Red Beach plaster Company of Red Beach, struck on a ledge in a Letitis Passage yesterday morning and sank in 20 fathoms of water. The crew was saved. The loss is $2,000; insurance on vessel, $1,000.

Work is advancing on the foundation for the statue of Garibaldi, which will occupy a prominent place east of the fountain in Washington Park.

De Lancey Nicoll, as attorney for Leonard Grover, got an injunction from Judge Lawrence yesterday restraining Minnie Palmer and her husband, John R. Rogers, from producing the play "My Brother's Sister."
BATON ROUGE, May 28.--Four ballots were taken in the Democratic legislative caucus to-night for junior United States Senator.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 28.--Correspondence is in to-day from every section of Minnesota, Dakota, and Northern Iowa, and from it it is learned that the average condition of wheat and other small grain is good.

The New-Yorks have at last struck a winning gait. At least they gave evidence of that fact yesterday, when they won a game from the Washington Club by the old Chicago score of 9 to 0. It could not be termed a brilliant game, for more than one reason.

The Washington season of the McCaull opera company will close on Saturday next. It has proved financially successful far in excess of Col. McCaull's expectations. B.D. Stevens, the lieutenant-colonel of the McCaull organization, has had charge of the Washington business, but next week he will be again established ...

ATLANTA, Ga., May 28.--More than usual interest is being taken here in the decoration of the graves of the Union dead in Marietta on the 30th. Mitchel Post, G.A.R., has called to its support the citizens generally, with the promise now of quite an imposing demonstration on that day. The address will be delivered by Col. William Rule of Knoxville.

A special meeting of the Brickmakers' Association of the States of New-York and NewJersey was held in the Cosmopolitan Hotel parlors yesterday afternoon to devise means of resisting the violence and attempts at violence on the part of the knights of Labor and other workmen in the numerous brickyards along ...
Public interest is piqued by the rumor that the Hudson County Grand Jurors may, at the session to be held to-day, reconsider the indictment ordered last week against the Jersey City Board of Works.

The body of an unknown man was found floating in the Bay yesterday by a deck hand of the tug boat William J. McCalden, and was taken to the foot or Van Brunt-street, Brooklyn. The man was apparently about 40 years old above the medium height, and stoutly built.

Surveyor Beattie was examined yesterday afternoon before the sub-committe of the United States Senate--Senators Spooner and Blackburn--which is investigating the workings of the Custom House. His direct examination was concluded by Senator Blackburn.

CHICAGO, May 28.--During the progress of the trial of Sumner C. Welch, charged with jury fixing, to-day, the prosecution gave notice that it desired to amend its bill for the commitment of Welch and C.B. Holmes, President of the Chicago City Railway Company, so as to include C.M. Hardy, one of Welch's attorneys engaged in trying the present case.
CHICAGO, May 28.--Kyrle Bellew, leading man in Mrs. James Brown Potter's company, reached this city to-day for a week's engagement at the Columbia Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--Major William F. Tucker, Paymaster, has been ordered to temporary duty at Fortress Monroe, Va. The Secretary of War has ordered a board of officers, consiting of Lieut. Col. George L. Gillespie, Corps of Engineers; Lieut.-Col. Richard Lodor, Fifth Artillery, and Capt. Rogers Birnie, Jr., Ordance Department, to meet ...

The Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, by Eugene Kelly, last evening at the Hoffman House intrusted Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde with a draft for $10,000 to be used by Mr. Parnell in the furtherance of the cause of home rule for Ireland.
"M.L.C."--Send to the Charity Organization Society, 21 University-place. Mayor Hewitt yesterday moved from the Stewart Building back to his old quarters in the City Hall.

MILWAUKEE, May 28.--L.B. Rock, the well-known railway man, who just retired from the Superintendency of the Northern Division of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, fell down a stairway at his home in this city this morning and was instantly killed. It is thought he was stricken with paralysis, as he suffered two strokes within the past two years. He was about 63 years of age.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28.--The attorneys for "Blinkey" Morgan, sentenced to be executed on June 1, appeared before the State Board of Pardons to-day and urged a stay in the execution of the sentence.

OMAHA, Neb., May 28.--For two days the Missouri River Valley from the Black Hill regions in Southwestern Dakota to Kansas City has been visited by a series of terrific cloudbursting rainstorms, doing many hundred thousand dollars damage.
Charles L. Davis appeared before a good house at the Windsor last night in the title role of his play, "Alvin Joslin."
LONDON, May 28.--The great Russian railway into the heart of Asia, is at last a fact, and you can now go from London almost to the boundary of the Chinese Empire in 12 days.

The Duke of Argyll has been very seriously ill at Inverary Castle during the last month, and for some days he was in danger. The Duke is now recovering, but has been much pulled down by his illness. He comes up to town with the Duchess the week after next, ...

CHATHAM, Mass., May. 28.--Harrison Hamilton, a prominent merchant, drove into the woods to-day, tied and blanketed his horse, and blew the top of his head off. He was opposed to the erection of a building by Capt. Howes's in close proximity to his own.

Annie Arnold, a servant in the employ of Dr. F. Marshall of 54 West Fourteenth-street, was complainant yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court against her once-intended husband, Adonis Legendre, a young man of ...

SCRANTON, Penn., May 28.--John Keegan of South Washington-avenue dashed into the grocery store kept by P.M. Barret this afternoon, revolver in hand, and, without saying a word, commenced firing at Mrs. Barrett.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The Iroquois Club, the big Democratic organization of this city, is going to St. Louis in style. A special meeting of the organization was held to-night to make arrangements for the trip.
Sheriff Grant is not yet languishing in Ludlow-street Jail by reason of the stern mandate of the City Court, nor is he likely to for some little while at least.
The parlors of the Rutgers Female College, at 54 West Fifty-fifth-street, were thrown open last night for an elocutionary and musical ...
The following resolution was adopted by a rising vote at yesterday's session of the Methodist General Conference:

GROVENHURST, Ontario, May 29.--Frederick N. Toye, Township Clerk, his wife, and three children, aged 5, 9, and 11 years, were burned to death in their house at Uffington, several miles from this place, last night.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 29.--The first business of the morning session of the Lutheran Ministerium was the consideration of the report of the delegates to the General Council.
The Hellenic Athletic Association of St. Austin's School, West New-Brighton, Staten Island, held their third annual games yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club.

A sailor, just arrived from Central American waters, brought a curiosity in the snake line to the Academy of Sciences. The acquisition is a veritable sea serpent, according to the statements of the local scientists.

Lineman Thomas Murray's name was only mentioned once or twice yesterday, in an incidental sort of way, at Coroner Levy's investigation of Murray's death. Mayor Hewitt's name was mentioned times innumerable, and altogether its owner was the subject of a good deal more investigation than was anything else.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29.--W.R. Bonsal of Baltimore, Class '89, has been elected Captain of the lacrosse team for the ensuing year. As Princeton now holds the college championship at lacrosse this will be an important office, and it is expected that next year's team will even be better than that of this year.

CHICAGO, May 29.--Elias R. Bowen, Receiver of the Great Western Telegraph Company, received a verdict for $875 in Judge Clifford's court to-day against A.J. Hoagland, a Board of Trade man who was a stockholder in the company.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 29.--As Mr. I. N. McMullen was enjoying his vesper smoke last evening in his house yard on Seelye-avenue his attention was arrested by a blazing object in the sky shooting his way.
SYDNEY, New South Wales, May 29.-- The Supreme court has granted writs of habeas corpus in the case of 43 more of the Chinamen detained in the harbor.

The body of Dr. Howard Pinkney, who died in England on May 14, while traveling from Southampton to London, and of whom an obituary sketch appeared in THE TIMES on the following day, has been brought home in the Elbe for burial.
WINNIPEG, May 29.--Prof. Goldwin Smith writes the following letter to a city paper:

RICHMOND, VA., May 29.--Quite an array of New-York counsel was present in the Henrice Circuit Court to-day as the representatives of the various interests involved in the motion in foreclosure proceedings of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad heard before that court.

The consecration of six new Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church filled the Met ropolitan Opera House to overflowing yesterday noon. There were only individual attempts at decoration of the house.

Thirty six years ago, when Franklin Pierce was elected President, the happy end of the anti-slavery agitation was announced. But ten years after the election of Pierce Abraham Lincoln issued the proclamation of emancipation. The course of American history does not depend upon Presidents, but upon the people.
WASHINGTON, May 29.--Lient.-Gen. Sheriden has shown an amount of recuperative energy that is as astonishing as it is gratifying to his physicians and family.
BALTIMORE, Md., May 29.--The Southern Presbyterian General Assembly spent all of today wrangling. Organio union roused the members to a fever heat, and Dr. Smoot of Texas made a red-hot speech.
A great lady of the Russian Court has just died in the person of the Countess Catherine Feodorovna Tiesenhausen, whose decease occurred in the Winter Palace on the 8th inst.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 29.--The city is already full to its utmost capacity with delegates to the State Democratic Convention, which convenes at noon to-morrow. The Gubernatorial contest promises to be a memorable one.
A spirit of the utmost liberality pervaded the meeting of the Board of Stewards of the Grand Central Trotting Circuit at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.

A reporter of THE TIMES yesterday showed Shipping Commissioner Reed a newspaper article in which it was stated that six sailors of the ship Fannie Tucker, who were arrested for mutiny in Puget Sound, had been discharged by United States Commissioner Smith at Seattle for the reason that, as the ship was bound coastwise, there was no law under which he could hold them.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 29.--David J. Baker, a retired farmer of the town of Dryden, in the ninety-fifth year of his age, makes plausible claim to the distinction of being the oldest Freemason in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--If the Senators who fought against public consideration of the fishery treaty supposed that opening the doors would bring out a crowd of interested representatives of foreign Governments to hear them talk they were mistaken.
LONDON, May 29.--Ada Rehan made a great triumph to-night. It was the first performance of "The Taming of the Shrew" at the Gaiety Theatre.

DANBURY, Conn., May 29.--One of the largest and most disastrous fires known here for many years occurred early this morning, when Henry Perry's Block, consisting of several fourstory brick dwellings and stores, and the Griffin Block of six three-story and basement frame buildings, owned by Dr. M. Griffin, on Elm-street, were totally destroyed.
The steamer Sea Gull is a vessel of 250 tons burden, 160 feet in length, and draws 14 feet of water. She is the property of John Reid Co. of Bay City, Mich., and is said to be worth about $20,000.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 29.--President Cleveland's expressed preference for Thurman as Vice-President created talk in Georgia, the support of whose delegation he will never get.
The work of decorating the Washington, Lafayette, and Lincoln Monuments on Unionsquare was begun last night and will be completed early this morning by the addition of fresh flowers.
DUBLIN, May 29.--It is stated in Catholic circles that the Irish Bishops have been summoned to meet immediately for the consideration of their attitude toward the Papal rescript.
RAHWAY, N.J., May 29.--The members of the Young Men's Republican Club have been actively at work for a week past preparing for the opening of their new rooms in Union Hall to-morrow night.
HURON, Dakota, May 29.--A great deal of rain has fallen this week, and the ground is well soaked. The river, lakes, and ponds are all full.

The annual meeting of the members of the New-York Produce Exchange was held yesterday, and A.E. Orr, the President, delivered his annual address, and it was of an especially interesting character inasmuch as many timely topics were referred to.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 29.--Nine bills were signed by the Governor to-day, making in all 140 out of the 414 left him by the Legislature that he has signed since that body adjourned.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 29.--From P.J. Hall, a member of the Coroner's jury and a leading merchant of Osceola, Ark., a town 90 miles above Memphis on the Mississippi River, THE TIMES'S correspondent learned to-night the particulars of one of the most sickening tragedies which has ever shocked this section.

PARIS, May 29.--We are feeling very sore over the Tisza incident, which was very unnecessary, to say the least. As I have before stated, every one his well aware that owing to the date of the exhibition and a great many other reasons the show must depend for success upon private enterprise rather than official recognition.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 29.--The Svet publishes an article on the opening of the Transcaspian Railway, which says that no sensible Russian regards this railway as a means for the conquest of India.

Some of the bills to which Gov. Hill was reported yesterday to have attached his signature possess more than ordinary interest. This is particularly the case with the bill amending sections 970 and 974 of the Consolidation act relative to the laying out of streets.

The entertainments given nightly at Terrace Garden are enjoyable and commendable as well. Thus far the weather has not been as propitious as it might be, and the attendance has in consequence not been all that was desired. There are two distinct parts in each performance. One is that within the theatre proper and the other in the adjoining garden.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--The President to-day returned to the House without his approval the act appropriating $100,000 for a public building at Columbus, Ga., on the ground that there is at present no necessity for a building that would require such an expenditure.

Before the Grand Jury for May were discharged by Judge Gildersleeve yesterday, Fore man William M. Fleiss addressed the court, stat ing the Grand Jury had had a good deal of difficulty in regard to excise cases, which has caused much difference of opinion among its members.

It is so seldom that we are able to commend any official act of the Governor of New-York, that it is a pleasure as well as a duty to observe that the remarks he made yesterday to a deputation of marble manufacturers were just and sensible.
HURON, Dakota, May 29.--In some of the larger cities there is a great deal of grumbling about the failure of the local option law. Its friends are quite well satisfied.
President Cleveland, Secretaries Fairchild and Whitney, and Col. Lamont arrived in the city last evening, after an uneventful trip from Washington.

BERGEN POINT, N.J., May 29.--Bayonne City Council to-night re-elected Charles L. Ford City Treasurer unanimously. The Council has been organized a month and had only elected a City Clerk before. To-night's meeting was a special one to grant licenses. There was a large decrease from last year.
Mayor Hewitt sent a long communication to the Board of Aldermen yesterday in relation to the obstruction of the streets at night with trucks and vehicles.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., May 29.--Democrats of the Second Congressional District are having a hard time to select a candidate for Congress.

GLOUCESTER, May 29.--The City Council in joint convention this evening elected W.W. French Mayor to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of David J. Robinson. Mr. French is special Police Justice and Chairman of the Republican City Committee.

CHICAGO, May 29.--A meeting of the General Managers of the Central Traffic Association was held to-day, the object of which was to act on a proposition to reduce dressed beef rates between Chicago and the seaboard.
"Bellite," the new explosive which has been invented by M. Lamm of Stockholm, seems destined to knock dynamite, and perhaps meli nite, out of the field.

MONTREAL, May 29.--Considerable astonishment was expressed to-day when it was whispered that Honer E. Cotte, accountant of the Delisle estate, had left the city and is now supposed to be in New-York or Boston.
VIENNA, May 29.--Count Kalnoky to-day received M. Decrais, the French Ambassador, and gave him an explanation of Herr Tisza's speech, which, it is hoped, will end the incident.

The notoriety obtained by the Board of Aldermen in consequence of the unaccountable action of a majority in the matter of an application by the New-York and Harlem Railroad Company for the right to introduce electric motors on its city line had the effect of arousing great public interest in its regular meeting yesterday.

Cooper Conkling used to eat, drink, and sleep on the Rivington-street dock. He had no occupation, but when anybody desired to fish from the clock he was met by Conkling with the remark that the charge for the privilege of fishing was the price of a pint of beer.
The Rev. Andrew Beattie was ordained and installed as Pastor last evening at the Presbyterian Church of the Sea and Land, Henry and Market streets.
The news comes from Odessa that a caravan including several wealthy Russian tourists was lately captured by brigands about 200 kilometers from Aleppo.

The one hundred or more candidates who are progressing through the mysterious path ways of the Scottish Rite Masonry at the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison-avenue, corner of Twenty-ninth-street, made a further advance last evening.

LONDON, May 29.--A French gunboat has hoisted the tricolor on Maitre Ile, the largest of the Minquieres group, between the Island of Jersey and Brittany. Maitre Ile has hitherto been recognized as a part of the Channel Islands, and Lord Salisbury will maintain England's claims to its possession.
Charles Gehring, the son of a wealthy brewer of Cleveland, Ohio, committed suicide yesterday by stabbing himself in the breast at the International Hotel.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 29.--Closely following the appearance of the hand of flame in the heavens above Ohio comes a story from Darlington County, in this State, of a flying serpent.
Yesterday, the second day of the Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends, the meeting house at Rutherfurd-place and Fifteenth-street was crowded with delegates and ministers.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29.--The Prohibition National Convention will assemble in Tomlinson Hall at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning. The hall is a rectangular chamber, thoroughly lighted, and capable of seating at least 2,500 persons, ...

BOSTON, May 29.--The Governor has signed the bill passed by the Legislature providing for a State Naval Reserve, which it is expected will result in the organization of a trained force of volunteer seamen and gunners of at least 10,000 men.
WASHINGTON, May 29.--The bond offerings today aggregated $237,000, as follows: Four per cents, coupon--$40,000 at 127 7/8; $40,000 at 128.

In an opinion just delivered by the Supreme Court, deciding the suit of John McNulty against the Pittston Coal Company, Judge Clark of that court addressed himself to the task of vindicating the reputation of a mule owned by the company from the unwarranted aspersions thrown upon it by McNulty.
BOSTON, Mass., May 29.--The annual meeting of the American Unitarian Association was held here to-day and was largely attended.
LONDON, May 29.--The steamship Buffalo, (Br.,) Capt. Malet, from New-York May 17, arr. at London to-day.
ST. LOUIS, May 29.--The St. Louis Fair Oaks was won to-day by the Chicago Stable's filly. Huntress, who beat out Silver Bell, a big favorite in the books and pools.
A very cordial reception was tendered the Richmond Grays last night by the Ninth Regiment in its armory in Twenty-sixth-street.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 29.--The onehundreth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church came to an end to-day and its closing hours were marked by a stormy scene.
The more hopeful reports from Gen. Sheridan's bedside and the assurance of fine weather for to-day's parade made the vetarans very hopeful yesterday.
ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, May 29.-- some startling facts relative to the Maritime Bank have leaked out in court here.

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 29.--Civil and military residents of West Point are discussing the removal of Miss Blanche Berard from the Post Office there and the appointment in her place of George Mecklem of Newburg.

CHICAGO, May 29.--A Deputy Sheriff closed up the furniture and bracket manufactory of Edward A. Eastman Co., 67 West Washingtonstreet, to-day to satisfy judgments by confession in favor of Caroline Koelling for $1,017 50 and Henry Kruse for $337,50.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 29.--A system of automatically taking and recording votes at elections has been invented and patented by John W. Rhines of St. Paul. Printed tickets are done away with altogether, each voter recording his vote by means of a machine.
SEDALIA, Mo., May 29.--J.C. Thompson, one of the Directors of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad, returned from New-York by way of Hannibal this morning.

LEWES, Del., May 29.--By an accidental explosion of dynamite O. Martin and Kendall Palmer, workmen engaged in destroying the old railroad pier at this place, which was wrecked during the severe blizzard, were blown to atoms. W.H. Virden, the contractor, and Burton West, a workman, were severely injured.

Carl Kaltenborn, a saloon keeper of 344 East Thirty-ninth-street, last evening informed Sergt. McDonald of the Thirty-fifth-street police station that two man were going around in a cab and stopping at saloons to change five, ten, and twenty dollar bills.

The 150 members of the Kings County Democratic Club who are to escort Mayor Chapin, the delegate at large, and his eight associate delegates to the St. Louis Convention, made their final arrangements last night.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 29.--Something more than a year ago the Perry Stove Works removed from Albany, N.Y., to South Pittsburg, 35 miles below Chattanooga, on the Tennessee River.

If the request for $540,804 57 made by the Brooklyn Park Commissioners yesterday for the expenses of 1889 are granted by the Board of Estimate, Prospect Park stands a chance of being greatly improved before the money is expended, or the people will see a large amount of money diverted into wrong channels.

Those who may wonder at the sale of a three-story building on Broadway a little south of Ninth-street, for $3,600, which is reported among the transactions at the Real Estate Exchange yesterday, will see from the following facts that the price may not after all have been very low.

OSWEGO, N.Y., May 29.--No trace has yet been found of Charles Robinson, the telegraph operator at New-Haven, N.Y., a station 10 miles cast of here on the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Road, who so mysteriously disappeared on Friday night last. Young Robinson left the house of a friend that night for home.
LONDON, May 29.--The probable starters and their jockeys in the race for the Derby Stakes at Epsom to-morrow are as follows:
Dr. John C. Peters, speaking yesterday of his remarks before the County Medical Society in regard to the Croton water, said that he spoke not especially about Croton Lake itself, ...
The defense of Thomas B. Kerr, so far as testimony is concerned, occupied just 25 minutes. The line of the defense was exactly as it was stated in yesterday's TIMES.
CINCINNATI, May 29.--The races at Latonia to-day were run with the following results:
There was a lively time last night at the special meeting of the Harlem Republican Club, at its clubhouse, 24 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 29.--The trial of Abel John Allen for the murder of the aged widow, Ursula Ulrich, near Jeffersonville, in this county, Oct. 8 last began in the Sullivan County Over and Terminer Court to-day, Judge Alton B. Parker presiding.

Additional testimony was taken yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court for the defense in the complaint of libel by Register James J. Slevin against Lawyers Lewis Sanders, John Webber, E.W. Coggeshall, and John T. Lookman.
Lightning killed James O'Brien, a pile driver, last night, in Jersey City. O'Brien was hurrying to his home, in Seventeenth-street, near Erie-street, when he was overtaken by a sudden shower.

BROCKTON, Mass., May 29.--Herman Rydquest, aged 14, son of Andrew J. Rydquest, and Eddie Paine, aged 12, son of Augustus Paine, were drowned this afternoon in Ford's Pond through the capsizing of their canoe. Both bodies were recovered.

Racing will begin at 1:30 at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track this afternoon, and there will undoubtedly be a great crowd present to see them run, for the contests are of unquestionable merit throughout.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 29.--Sergeant-at-Arms Richard Bright will arrive in the city to-morrow to make arrangements for handling the Democratic National Convention.
By the decision, of the General Term of the Supreme Court, delivered yesterday, the North American Relief Society for Indigent Jews in Jerusalem, Palestine, received $50,000, ...

The death is announced at her son's, Mr. Richard Brinsley Knowles's, residence, near Regent's Park, London, in the eighty-first year of her age, of Mrs. Emma Knowles, widow of the celebrated dramatist, James, Sheridan Knowles.

A large number of visitors assembled yesterday morning in the hall of Grammar School No. 68, One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street, near Sixth-avenue, to witness the presentation of two silk flags to the female department of the school by Congressman A.B. Fitch.

BELVIDERE, N.J., May 29.--Chief-Justice Beasley to-day signed an order to hold a special election in Warren County on Sept. 4, under the new Local Option bill, when the vote will be license or no license.
CHICAGO, May 29.--Mrs. T. B. Carse has been appointed a member of the County Board of Education. She is the first woman who ever held a place on the board.

Special extra matinees will be given at all the theatres except the Madison-Square this afternoon. "The Lady or the Tiger?" can be seen at Wallack's, "Nadjy" at the Casino, "The Queen's Mate" at the Broadway, "Natural Gas" at the Fifth-Avenue. "The Wife" at the Lyceum, "The Still Alarm" at the Fourteenth-Street, ...
SAN FRANCISCO, May 29.--Drafts--Sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 25 cents.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 29.--Robert Dobbins, the 15-year-old son of Wesley H. Dobbins of 516 North Fourth-street, while at the Fish House, on the line of the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad, yesterday, was accidentally shot in the abdomen by the discharge of a revolver in the hands of Jesse Allen, an intimate companion.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 29.--The JonesGreene feud still rages in Hancock County. Another battle was fought yesterday, during which Joel Greene was seriously wounded. Both sides go heavily armed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29.--Railway officials in this city ridicule the story that the Pennsylvania Railroad management was negotiating for the purchase of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company.

Sir Thomas Henry Grattan Esmonde, the Irish member of Parliament who has been speaking in this country in the interest of home rule, sailed for Liverpool early yesterday morning in the Guion steamship Alaska.
Herman and Carl Martens, composing the firm of Martens Brothers, importers and publishers of music at 1,164 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday, giving 30 preferences aggregating $29,407.
Assistant District Attorney Gunning S. Bedford presented to the Grand Jury on Monday his views in reference to arrests under the excise law.

ST. PAUL, May 29.--Some 200 delegates arrived during the day to attend the twentyeighth annual convention of the United States Brewers' Association, which opened here to-night. There are 700 brewers in the association, out of about 2,200.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29.--The total amount of all kinds of iron and steel made in the five months about ended is not as large as was the volume of the same period last year, which reached over 50,000 tons, allowing only 20 working days for every month.
There is no lack of activity by lawyer William Strauss and his clients, who own Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad securities, and are opposed to the reorganization ...

A lighted candle dropped into a pot of paint by a painter who was working in the hallway on the second floor of the five-story building at 123 Norfolk-street at 8 o'clock yesterday morning caused a fire which left only its walls standing.
The programme at Jerome Park to-day promises no special features outside of the Decoration Day Steeplechase, which will probably have a large and good list of contestants.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 29.--The Phi Beta Kappa Society of Cornell University held its annual election here to-day and chose the following as members: Of the Senior Class--Kate May Edwards ...

SCRANTON, Penn., May 29.--Mrs. P.M. Barrett, the woman who was shot by John C. Keegan yesterday, died of her injuries this morning at 3 o'clock. The tragic story of the killing was told to-day bofore Coroner Burnett by Mrs. Walsh, the sister of the dead woman.

The enormous profits to be made in the manufacture and sale of patented articles was shown yesterday by the testimony of J.C. Hoagland in the suit brought against the Royal Baking Powder Company by William Ziegler, ...

SALEM, N.J., May 29.--At to-day's session of the Convocation of Burlington in St. John's Episcopal Church Bishop Scarborough ordained the following persons: The Revs. H. Sloper of South Amboy, R. Ringwalt of Mantua, and A.S. Phelps of Washington, D.C. Over 30 clergymen are in attendance.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--Gov. Proctor, the Chairman of the Vermont delegation to Chicago, is is town. It is learned that the newspaper reports that he and the Vermont delegation are pledged to Mr. Blaine are without foundation.

The Dexter Gazette has discovered an anomaly. Benny Holt, the young man who lately confessed to breaking into the cottages at Waldhim is, according to the Gazette, "honest in everything except the matter of stealing."
Mr. BLAINE has tried his hand a second time at withholding his name from tha Republican National Convention. This time he has been more successful than the first.
The Prince of Naples is now expected to visit England during the last week in next month, and will be the guest of the Queen at Buckingham Palace.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29.--Mrs. Cleveland and a party of friends took a trip to the "Switzerland of America," Mauch Chunk, and the Switchback neighborhood to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29.--The Allegheny County Republican Convention to-day renominated the Hon. John Dalzell for Congress, Twen ty-second District, and the Hon. Thomas M. Bayne for the Twenty-third District.
BERGEN POINT, N.J., May 29.--Commencement exercises were held to-night in the ladies' seminary at Bergen Point and many prominent people were present.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 29.--The Port Jervis and Monticello Railway, from this place to Monticello, is 24 miles in length, and connects with the Erie Road.
BERLIN, May 29.--The Emperor had a good night. At 11 o'clock this morning he reviewed the Crown Prince's brigade. His Majesty was in an open carriage and was accompanied by the Empress.

By clever batting, base running, and fielding the New-Yorks won a game in the easiest possible manner from the Washingtons yesterday. Gilmore, who pitched, was hit hard, and the Giants made the game as lively as possible by running around the bases with the speed of sprinters.
To-day the Cincinnati and Brooklyn Clubs will play two games in Brooklyn.

CADIZ JUNCTION, Ohio, May 29.--A terrible wind storm swept over Cadiz early last evening. It was heralded by a roaring sound like heavy artillery, and black clouds, capped by rolling white ones, leaped high in the air and whirled with terrible velocity.
TRENTON, N.J., May 29.--There are no funds in the State Treasury, and the authorities in consequence find themselves greatly embarrassed in several ways.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 29.--It is learned this evening that the Grand Jury will to-morrow present true bills against 69 persons for participating in or attending the Dillon-Hoar prize fight at Lee Park on Monday morning last. Among them are some of the leading citizens, merchants, newspaper men, and an Associated Press reporter.

WASHINGTON, May 29.--Lieut.-Col. Daniel W. Flagler, Ordnance Department, has been ordered from Frankford Arsenal, Penn., to Columbia, Tenn., on temporary duty. First Lieut. James Brennan, Seventeenth Infantry, has been granted leave of absence until July 18.

ALBANY, May 29.--State Controller Edward Wemple, who recently rejected Chamberlain Ivins's warrant for State taxes because it contained the words "and in full," to-day declared the charges for criminal prosecutions in New-York County as returned to him illegal and exorbitant.
Jerome Park never looked more attractive than it did yesterday; never looked anything like as attractive, in fact.

It may be that Gov. HILL will not give serious attention to the necessity of providing money for carrying on the industries of our State prisons until he has finished the consideration of bills left in his hands at the close of the session of the Legislature.

The sub-committee of the special committee of the United States Senate appointed to investigate the manner in which the civil service law has been observed in the Custom House of this city finished its labors for the time being in the Federal Building yesterday.

About a dozen of the survivors of the One Hundred and Nineteenth New-York Volunteer Regiment met in the office of Col. John T. Lockman, 88 Nassau-street, yesterday, and decided to leave this city on June 30 for the battlefield of Gettysburg and dedicate their monument on July 1.
BOSTON, May 29.--The National Woman Saffrage Association was to-night addressed by Baroness Grepenherg of Finland, Susan B. Anthony, and Mrs. Laura Ormiston Chant.
E.S. and H.D. Auchincloss's racing sloop Katrina, which has been building at City Island, in the Piepgras Yard, during the past few months, was successfully launched yesterday afternoon.
A man who is said to have been absent from his family 19 years returned to Newburg and called upon his wife and daughter the other day.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 29.--The following reports have been filed at the Secretary of State's office: The New-York and New-England Railroad Company for the quarter ended March 31, in comparison with the same quarter last year, shows:

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 29.--Thomson, 40 miles from Augusta, is ablaze with excitement to-night. Inquiries by telegraph remain unanswered, and it is thought here that a promised lynching has been accomplished.
Commissioner and Mrs. Thaddeus Moriarty sailed for Europe by the Alaska. "Subscriber."--Election comes one day too soon for you; you cannot vote.

Many poor people who had become members of the Providential Medical Benefit Association, organized to furnish subscribers with medicines and medical advice at a nominal cost, visited the rooms of the association at 177 and 179 Montague-street, Brooklyn, yesterday only to find them in the hands of the Sheriff.

BOSTON, May 29.--The finding of a box of arsenic concealed in the cellar of the house in Somerville formerly occupied by Mrs. Sarah J. Robinson, who is now in jail convicted of poisoning her child, caused somewhat of a sensation to-day.
The National Civil Service Reform League cannot be discouraged by the address to which it listened last evening from the eloquent orator who is its distinguished and efficient President.
A scheme for building a bridge over the Straits of Dover has been brought out by the Creusot Company and M. Hersent, the wellknown contractor.

Reckless driving in the city received some consideration from the Aldermen yesterday. The city ordinance was amended so as to prohibit the driving of any cart, carriage, horse car, or other vehicle at a greater speed than at the rate of five miles an hour.
The bandit Alessandri, who for more than six years had been the terror of the village populations in Corsica, has been killed by the gendarmes after a desperate resistance.
RAPID CITY, Dakota, May 29.--There is no truth in the report of an Indian uprising at Pine Ridge or at the agency on the Sioux Reservation.
CHICAGO, May 29.--No Vice-Presidential candidate can claim all the Chicago delegates to the St. Louis Convention.

At the colored people's Whitsuntide frolic, Monday night, a white man from Henry County named Frank Sams, a blockade liquor trader, who married some years ago near this place, thrust his presence into the dancing hall and made himself obnoxious.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 29.--E.A. White in the caucus at Baton Rouge received 70 votes, Eustis 43, and there were 5 blanks. This is a victory for Senator Gibson and Gov. Nicholls as well.

Agents Gardner and Finn of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children created a great deal of excitement at Poole's Theatre in Eighth-street on Monday night by their efforts to arrest two young girls who they supposed were in the theatre without the protecting care of their parents or guardians.

ANNAPOLIS, May 29.--Annapolis has a band of thieves, and United States property here had been made the field of their operations. The United States Government owns a beautiful piece of property opposite here called the Government Farm. It contains 114 acres of wooded hills and rivulet-threaded dales.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 29.--Prof. Hulst was selected to-day by the Trustees of Rutgers College to fill the Chair of Entomology, a new Professorship established in the college. He is a graduate of Rutgers in the Class of '66, has become a noted specialist, and is the editor of the American, Entomologist.

Owners of sealskin and plush sacques, wraps, furs, carriage and sleighing robes, and all kinds of heavy woolen clothing will be delighted to learn that a cheap and trustworthy means of preserving such articles in their homes during the summer has been discovered.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 29.--"Election day" turned out rather pleasant. At 10 o'clock the procession formed, made up of the Newport artillery and light infantry, and escorted Gov. Davis, his staff, and members of the General Assembly from their headquarters to the State House, where the two bodies repaired to their respective chambers for organization.
CONCORD, N.H., May 29.--The fortyeighth annual meeting of the Concord Railroad corporation was held here to-day with a small attendance. The report of the Directors was accepted and placed on file.

Active preparations are being made for increasing the work of St. John's Guild among the sick children in all departments, and the Trustees appeal to the public for contributions, which may be sent to Charles Schwacofer, Treasurer, 21 University place.

CHICAGO, May 29.--The stir created by the Chicago shippers in taking a hand in the dispute between the Burlington and Northern and Northwestern lines is likely to lead to some interesting developments.

A.H. Hummel, as counsel for Manager J. M. Hill, applied to Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday to have the temporary injunction restraining Margaret Mather from playing under any other management except Mr. Hill made permanent. Ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, counsel for Miss Mather, not being ready to proceed, the arguments were postponed until Monday.

LONDON, May 29.--On the Stock Exchange today there was altogether a stronger tone, with increased dealings at higher prices. Foreign securities, in response to the Bourses' buying, closed firm. Russian, Hungarian, and Turkish securities rose . American railroad securities were bought more freely, especially on the street.

ST. LOUIS, May 29.--Senator George Hearst is here attending the races, having just returned from a tripe to Mexico. During his stay in the city of Mexico he succeeded in consummating some very large financial transactions.
There were no vacant seats in Chickering Hall last night when George William Curtis, President of the National Civil Service Reform League, delivered his annual address.
Dullness ruled on the Stock Exchange yesterday, the anticipation of to-day's suspension of business deterring most of the room traders, who are now in control, from activity.

One of the last links which connect this country with what M. Thiers calls the "Napoleonic legend" is about to be snapped. In August, 1815, the great Napoleon was transferred from the Bellerophon, on board which ship he had remained since his surrender to Capt. Maitland at Rochefort on July 14, to the Northumberland of 74 guns, which conveyed him to St. Helena.

The largest dry goods auction sale that has ever been held in this country came off yes terday at the salesrooms of Wilmerding, Hoguet Co. in White-street. It was held for the account of Faulkner, Page Co., and consisted of 10,000 packages of plain and twilled flannels.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 29.--Judge Cooley, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, passed through the city this morning on the way from his home in Michigan to Washington, where the commission will consider and try to dispose of accumulating old business.

The first consignment of 25 men to serve as special detectives on the brick yards along the Hudson was organized yesterday and will leave on Thursday for Verplanck, where they will be stationed on Samuel Henry's yard, where work will commence that day with a crew of new men from this city.

CHICAGO, May 29.--John Novak, a German, 33 years old, who was at the county hospital recovering from a dose of rat poison, taken with suicidal intent, was killed while trying escape from the institution last night. He made a rope of two sheets and tried to slide down from an upper window to the ground, but he lost his hold and his head was crushed in by the fall upon the stone pavement.
CONCORD, N.H., May 29.--At a meeting of the Democratic State Committee to-night it was decided to hold the State Convention in this city on Thursday, Sept. 6.

CHICAGO, May 29.--Mrs. Georges W. Scovill, an elderly woman, to-day began a suit for $10,000 damages against Siegel, Cooper Co., dry goods dealers, which will be of interest to the shopping public generally.

The Brooklyn Civil Service Commissioners held a meeting last night to hear the protests of interested parties in regard to the proposed revocation of the eligible list of firemen, made up on Oct. 22, 1887.
The clerk of the weather was good-natured enough yesterday to give the Brooklyn Jockey Club a clear sky and a pleasant temperature, and fully 5,000 people went down to the Gravesend track.

After the performance of "Nadjy" at the Casino last evening, the roof-garden lighted with hundreds ut colored lamps was thrown open, the band took its place on the pavilion far above the stage, and enough of the large crowd in the auditorium went skyward for the sake of refreshments and sentiment, to occupy all the chairs and tables and leave a numerous promenading contingent.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 29.--Senator Sawyer of Wisconsin is being "roasted," so to speak, by the Minnesota press and business men for his opposition, in the Senate, to the improvement of the Northwest waterways.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 30.--Elizabeth Thompson is a 14-year-old girl employed as a servant at Metuchen. Yeaterday her mistress, "Mrs. Charles Watson, gave her a scolding for neglecting some of her duties, and the girl sulked all day.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 30, via Galveston.--Louis Huller, the great concessionaire of Lower California, yesterday concluded a cash purchase of 5,000,000 acres of land for colonization purposes in the States of Chiapas and Chihuahua. Mr. Huller's agents in Europe have forwarded a number of German families during the last month to Chiapas.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 30.--The Democratic Convention met at noon yesterday; 369 delegates present. Considerable time was spent in perfecting an organization, and balloting for Governor was begun this morning.

SALEM, Mass., May 30.--Harry Brown, the son of ex-Alderman Edward F. Brown, and 19 years of age, was struck by a bat which slipped from the hands of a fellow-player during a game of ball this afternoon in North Salem, and was so badly injured that he died within an hour.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 30.--The Allan steamer Sardinian, from Liverpool May 17, was towed into port this afternoon by the Warren steamer Norseman. WASHINGTON, May 30.--The President and party returned to the city to-night in a special car attached to the regular New-York train, which was about an hour late, and did not arrive until 10:15. They are some what fatigued, but say they had a pleasant as well as a busy time. Mrs. Cleveland joined the President at Germantown Junction and returned with him.

WASHINGTON, May 30.--Gen. Sheridan's condition is less favorable to-night than it has been since Monday noon, and there is renewed anxiety for his safety. During last night and the greater part of the day the General continued slightly to gain strength, and more and more encouraging reports were sent out from the sick room.

A marriage among the Zulus is as binding as any nuptial ceremony in England, and a man cannot put away his wife without valid cause approved by the councilors of the tribe. Infidelity is punishable by death both to wife and patner in guilt.

In the Spring games of the Manhattan Athletic Club yesterday afternoon T. P. Conneff distinguished himself, in the one-mile handicap run. There were 12 starters at long odds, and the game little fellow mowed them down as handily as if the race had been prearranged.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 30.--The Wednesday session of the Lutheran Ministerium was opened with devotional exercises by the Rev. J. L. Sibole of Philadelphia.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 30.--While Mr. Blaine was the first choice of the Republican State Covention in New-Haven two weeks ago for the Presidency, it was evident that Chauncey M. Depew of New-York was the most popular of the candidates in the field for the nomination next to Mr. Blaine.

Central Park and Prospect Park were the centres of attraction for cricketers yesterday. In the former the New-York Cricket Club was beaten by the Manhattan Club of Brooklyn in a one-inning game by a score of 176 to 37.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 30.--The Kentucky Union Land Company yesterday made a deed of trust to the Louisville Safety Vault and Trust Company covering the issue of $800,000 first mortgage bonds. The money thus secured will be used to extend the Kentucky Union Railroad to Beattyville.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 31.--The receipts of flour by the lake at Buffalo for the month of May aggregate 570,000 barrels, which is the largest May movement on record. HOLDREGE, Neb., May 31.--A.J. Winquest, a farmer, went into a saloon last evening in an intoxicated condition, and on being refused liquor drew a revolver. Winquest then shot himself twice in the head, inflicting fatal injuries.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 1.--The NewsPress of this city published a day or two ago an editorial strongly urging Don M. Dickinson for Vice-President. The Graphic of New-York immediately followed suit. ST. PAUL, Minn., June 1.--A few days ago a meeting of the Directors of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway was held, at which its President submitted a report covering the operations of the road from Jan. 1 to date, which explains why interest was to-day defaulted on certain bonds.

LONDON, June 1.--In the House of Commons to-night Baron Henry de Worms, replying to a question, said that there was no treaty with China giving Chinamen the right to emigrate to British colonies, nor had England engaged to admit Chinese immigrants.

PANAMA, June 1, via Galveston.--The Central and South American Telegraph Company's surveying staff is now engaged in locating its proposed telegraph line across the Isthmus of Panama, the company having secured from the United States of Colombia the necessary concessions for operating a line.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--Gen. Sheridan's hold upon life is a constant surprise to all about him. Not one of his physicians or attendants believed last night that he could live 24 hours longer, yet to-night he is still alive, and it will not surprise the doctors if he lives to see another day.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 1.--A celebrated English philanthropist was buried here yesterday, having died yesterday at the residence of his daughter, Mrs. Booth. John Glazebrook was his name, and he was a citizen of Manchester, England.

BERLIN, June 1.--Emperor Frederick had a good night. He left for Potsdam at 11 o'clock this morning on the steam yacht Alexandra. The weather was showery, and his Majesty retired to the cabin as soon as he got on board and remained there.

HARRISONBURG, Va., June 1.--James P. Cooper, agent for the foreign bondholders, today tendered to the Sheriff of this county Virginia coupons amounting to $3,500 in payment of executions on judgment against coupon taxpayers.

BOSTON, June 2.--The Edison Electric Light Company's station in Head-place, off Boylston-street, was gutted by fire this morning, and the contents, including 10 dynamos, are thought to be practically ruined. The loss cannot yet be definitely stated.

BALTIMORE, June 1.--In the convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church to-day an effort was made to revive the recommenation of Bisop Paret in regard to the church convocations. There was no disposition to deal longer with the matter and it was laid on the table by a decisive vote. Only routine business was transacted.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., June 1.--Forty freight cars were wrecked this morning on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad near here by an axle of one of the cars breaking. Harrison Wolfe, brakeman, was killed and James Everts, conductor, severely injured. Travel on the road was blocked for five hours.

The will of Edward B. Underhill of Yorktown Station, Westchester County, has been offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court at White Plains. By it he appoints James Wood of Bedford, Robert Underhill of Yorktown, and Abram S. Underhill of Sing Sing his Executors, to each of whom he leaves $500.

ST. LOUIS, June 1.--The delegates from California and Nevada to the Democratic National Convention held exclusive possession of the field here until this afternoon, when they were joined by the delegation from Oregon.
WYANDOTTE, Mich., June 1.--At 6:45 this morning the boiler in the plate mill of the Eureka Iron and Steel Works exploded with frightful force, wrecking the entire building.
